PREFACE
         This County Code of White Pine County, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including Ordinance 548, passed May 28, 2025. Ordinances
of the County adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this
code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult
the County office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the
code has been amended, superseded or repealed.

                     Cincinnati, Ohio

Ordinance 549
Bill No 06.11.2025
 
CHAPTER 10.03 OFFENSES RELATED TO VAPING
 
10.03.01: Definitions
10.03.02: Offenses Related To Vapor Products
10.03.03: Penalties
10.03.01: DEFINITIONS:
 
 
 
            Means any noncombustible product containing nicotine or any other substance that employs
            a heating element, power source, electronic circuit or other electronic, chemical or
            mechanical means, regardless of the shape or size thereof, that can be used to produce
            vapor from nicotine or any other substance in a solution or other form, for the use of
            inhalation of which simulates smoking.
            Vapor product includes, without limitation:
            An electronic cigarette, cigar, cigarillo, pipe, hookah, vape pen, or a similar product,
            item, or device; and,
VAPOR    The components of such a product, item, or device, whether or not sold
PRODUCT:    separately, including, without limitation, vapor cartridges or other container of
            nicotine, or any other substance in a solution or other form that is intended to be used
            with or in such product, item, or device, atomizers, cartomizers, digital displays,
            cartomizers, tank systems, flavors, programmable software, or other similar or related
            product(s), item(s), or device(s).
            As used in this Chapter, "component" means a product, item, or device,
            intended primarily or exclusively for use with or in an electronic
            cigarette, cigar, cigarillo, pipe, hookah, or vape pen, or a similar product,
            item, or device.
MINOR:      Means any person under the age of eighteen (18).
 
10.03.01   : OFFENSES RELATED TO VAPOR PRODUCTS:
It shall be unlawful for a minor to engage in any of the following acts:
(A)   Purchase or attempt to purchase a vapor product.
(B)   Possess or attempt to possess a vapor product; or,
(C)   Use or attempt to use a vapor product.
 
10.03.02   : PENALTIES:
(A)   A minor who violates any provision of this Chapter may be subject to the following
penalties:
1.   For the First or Second Offense:
(a)   The minor shall be deemed a child in need of supervision and is not a
delinquent child, and the child must be placed under informal supervision
pursuant to NRS 62C.200;
(b)   The child shall perform not more than 24 hours of Community Service; and,
(c)   Mandatory attendance and successful completion of a tobacco awareness and
cessation program.
2.   For the Third or Any Subsequent Offense:
(a)   A District Attorney may file a petition alleging delinquency.
(B) If the Juvenile Court imposes a fine pursuant to this Section and the minor willfully
fails to pay said fine, the Court may order the suspension or delay of the
minor's driver's license as follows:
1.   Suspension of the minor's driver's license for a minimum of thirty (30)
days and a maximum of ninety (90) days. If the minor does not possess
a driver's license, the issuance of a license
shall be delayed for the same duration:
(a)   If the minor is eligible to receive a driver's license on the date of the court
order, the suspension or delay shall begin immediately; or,
(b)   If the minor is not eligible on the date of the order, the suspension or delay
shall commence when the minor becomes eligible for a driver's license.
2.   If a prior court order has already suspended or delayed issuance of the
minor's driver's license, the new order shall run consecutively
to the prior order.
(C)   The Juvenile Court may authorize the Department of Motor Vehicles to issue a
restricted driver's license pursuant to NRS 483.490 to a minor whose license
has been suspended or delayed under this Chapter. Such a restricted license may
permit driving:
1.   To and from employment or during the course of employment;
2.   To and from educational institutions; or,
3.   For necessary medical or nutritional purposes, including obtaining
medicine, food, or attending scheduled
medical care for the minor or a member of the minor's immediate family.
(D)   A peace officer shall not take a minor into physical custody solely for a violation of
this Chapter. (Ord. 549, 2025)
EFFECTIVE DATE. This Ordinance shall take full force and effect from and after
passage, approval, and publication as required by law, to wit, from and after
the 28th day July 2025.
PROPOSED on the 11th day of June 2025.
PROPOSED by: Sheriff Scott Henriod.
PASSED on the 9th day of July 2025.

1.01.010: ADOPTION OF WHITE PINE COUNTY CODE:
As authorized by sections 244.116 through 244.119 of the Nevada Revised
Statutes, there is adopted the White Pine County code as compiled, edited and
published by Book Publishing Company, Seattle, Washington. (Ord. 60 §1, 1972)
1.01.020: TITLE; CITATION; REFERENCE:
This code shall be known as the White Pine County code and it shall be
sufficient to refer to said code as the White Pine County code in any
prosecution for the violation of any provision thereof or in any proceeding at
law or equity. It shall also be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding
to, amending, correcting or repealing all or any part or portion thereof as an
addition to, amendment to, correction or repeal of the White Pine County code.
Further, reference may be had to the titles, chapters, sections, and
subsections of the White Pine County code and such reference shall apply to
that numbered title, chapter, section or subsection as it appears in this code.
(Ord. 60 §2, 1972)
1.01.030: REFERENCE APPLIES TO AMENDMENTS:
Whenever a reference is made to this code as the White Pine County code or to
any portion thereof, or to any ordinance of White Pine County, Nevada, the
reference shall apply to all amendments, corrections and additions heretofore,
now or hereafter made. (Ord. 60 §3, 1972)
1.01.040: CODIFICATION AUTHORITY:
This code consists of all of the regulatory and penal ordinances and certain of
the administrative ordinances of White Pine County, Nevada, codified pursuant
to sections 244.116 through 244.119 of the Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 60
§4, 1972)
1.01.050: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases whenever used in this code shall be construed
as defined in this section unless from the context a different meaning is
intended, or unless a different meaning is specifically defined and more
particularly directed to the use of such words or phrases:
CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT: A public improvement of a permanent nature, and may
include land and equipment necessary for the functioning of a building or other
capital improvement.
COUNTY: The county of White Pine, Nevada.
LAW: Denotes applicable federal law, the constitution, and statutes of the
state of Nevada, the ordinances of White Pine County, Nevada, and when
appropriate, any and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated
thereunder.
LOCAL IMPROVEMENT: Public improvement specifically beneficial to the property
affected, and also includes the abatement of such unsafe, unhealthful, or
unsanitary conditions as the commissioners shall determine to be a public
nuisance.
MAY: Is permissive.
OATH: Includes affirmation.
OFFICE: The use of the title of any officer, employee, or any office, or
ordinance shall mean such officer, employee, office and ordinance of White Pine
County, Nevada, unless otherwise specifically designated.
ORDINANCE: A law of the county, provided that a temporary or special law,
administrative action, order or directive, may be in the form of a resolution.
PERSON: Extends and applies to association, firm, corporation, government
agency and unit of government as well as to an individual.
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT: Improvements to or in connection with streets, sidewalks,
parks, playgrounds, buildings, sewer systems, water systems, power systems, and
any other real property or appurtenances thereof of the county used by the
public.
PUBLIC UTILITY: Includes all common carriers in the public streets, water,
sewage disposal, electric light, central heating, gas, electric power,
telephone and telegraph lines and systems, and such other and different
enterprises as the law or the commissioners may determine.
SHALL AND MUST: Each is mandatory.
STATE: The state of Nevada.
WRITTEN: Includes printed, typewritten, mimeographed or multigraphed. (Ord. 60
§5, 1972)
1.01.060: GRAMMATICAL INTERPRETATION:
   A.   The following grammatical rules shall apply in this code:
      1.   Gender: Any gender includes the other genders;
      2.   Singular And Plural: The singular number includes the plural and the
plural includes the singular;
      3.   Tenses: Words used in the present tense include the past and the
future tenses and vice versa;
      4.   Use Of Words And Phrases: Words and phrases used in this code and
not specifically defined shall be construed according to the context and
approved usage of the language. (Ord. 60 §6, 1972)
1.01.070: CONSTRUCTION:
The provisions of this code and all proceedings under it are to be construed
with a view to effect its objects and to promote justice. (Ord. 60 §7, 1972)
1.01.080: TITLE, CHAPTER AND SECTION HEADINGS:
Title, chapter and section headings contained herein shall not be deemed to
govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of
the provisions of any title, chapter or section hereof. (Ord. 60 §8, 1972)
1.01.090: REFERENCE TO SPECIFIC ORDINANCES:
The provisions of this code shall not in any manner affect deposits or other
matters of record which refer to, or are otherwise connected with ordinates
which are therein specifically designated by number or otherwise and which are
included within this code, but such reference shall be construed to apply to
the corresponding provisions contained within this code. (Ord. 60 §9, 1972)
1.01.100: EFFECT OF CODE ON PAST ACTIONS AND OBLIGATIONS:
Neither the adoption of this code nor the repeal of amendments hereby of any
ordinance or part or portion of any ordinance of the county shall in any manner
affect the prosecution for violations of ordinances, which violations were
committed prior to the effective date hereof, nor be construed as a waiver of
any license, fee, or penalty at said effective date due and unpaid under such
ordinances, nor be construed as affecting any of the provisions of such
ordinances relating to the collection of any such license, fee, or penalty, on
the penal provisions applicable to any violation thereof, nor to affect the
validity of any bond or cash deposit in lieu thereof required to be posted,
filed, or deposited pursuant to any ordinance, and all rights and obligations
thereunder appertaining shall continue in full force and effect. (Ord. 60 §10,
1972)
1.01.110: REPEAL SHALL NOT REVIVE ANY ORDINANCE:
The repeal of an ordinance shall not repeal the repealing clause of such
ordinance or revive any ordinance which has been repealed thereby. (Ord. 60
§11, 1972)
1.01.120: REPEAL:
All general ordinances of White Pine County not included in this code or
excluded from the operation and effect of this section are hereby repealed.
(Ord. 60 §12, 1972)
1.01.130: EXCLUSIONS:
Every special ordinance of this county governing the following subject matter,
whether contained in whole or in part within this code, is excluded from the
operation and effect of section
1.01.120 of this chapter and is not affected by the repeal provisions hereof.
Annexations; franchises; naming roads, streets and public places; acquisition
or disposal of public property; vacation of streets, alleys, or public ways;
acceptance of any gift, devise, license or other benefit; provided that the
foregoing enumeration of exceptions or exclusions shall not be deemed to be
exclusive or exhaustive, it being the intent and purpose to exclude from repeal
any and all ordinates not of a general nature. (Ord. 60 §13, 1972)
1.01.140: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
It is unlawful for any person to violate any provision or to fail to comply
with any of the requirements of this code. Any person violating any of the
provisions of this code, unless provision is otherwise herein made, shall upon
conviction thereof, be punished by imprisonment in the county jail for not more
than six (6) months, or by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00), or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each such person is guilty
of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any
violation of any provision of this code is committed, continued, or permitted
by such person and shall be punished accordingly. (Ord. 119 §1, 1981: Ord. 60
§14, 1972)
1.01.150: PROHIBITED ACTS INCLUDE CAUSING, PERMITTING, ETC.:
Whenever in this code any act or omission is made unlawful, it includes
causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting, suffering, or concealing the
fact of such act or omission. (Ord. 60 §15, 1972)
1.01.160: CONSTITUTIONALITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this code is for any
reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect
the validity of the remaining portions of this code. The council hereby
declares that it would have passed this code, and each section, subsection,
sentence, clause and phrase thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or
more sections, subsections, sentences, clauses or phrases had been declared
invalid or unconstitutional, and if for any reason this code should be declared
invalid or unconstitutional, then the original ordinance or ordinances shall be
in full force and effect. (Ord. 60 §16, 1972)
1.01.170: EFFECTIVE DATE:
The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be in full force and effect from
and after its passage and approval. (Ord. 60 §17, 1972)
CHAPTER 1.04
OPEN SPACE USE ASSESSMENTS
SECTION:
1.04.010: Applications; Generally
1.04.020: Applications; Criteria
1.04.030: Applications; Denial By Board Of County Commissioners
1.04.010: APPLICATIONS; GENERALLY:
All applications pursuant to this chapter shall be received by the county
assessor from owners of real property and shall be in conformance with state
law. (Ord. 2/10/76 §1, 1976)
1.04.020: APPLICATIONS; CRITERIA:
   A.   Before any application for open space use assessment shall be granted,
the following criteria must be met:
      1.   All applications for open space use assessment shall state that the
land for which the assessment is requested is presently devoted to productive
agricultural use.
      2.   All applications for open space use assessment shall require the
land for which the assessment is requested to be open to the general public and
to have minimum public access, said public access to be conspicuously
designated on the property.
      3.   All applications for open space use assessment shall require that
the land for which the assessment is requested allow general public access for
hiking and walking, but the land need not be open for camping, cooking,
campfires, whether artificial or natural, or overnight use unless the applicant
consents thereto.
      4.   All applications for open space use assessment for any proposed
historical site shall require the site to be open to the general public for at
least thirty (30) days out of the calendar year. (Ord. 2/10/76 §2, 1976)
1.04.030: APPLICATIONS; DENIAL BY BOARD OF COUNTY COMMISSIONERS:
The board of county commissioners shall have the power to deny any application
for open space use assessment which has met all of the criteria set forth in
section
1.04.020 of this chapter if the board determines that the potential loss of
revenues which would result from approving the application outweighs the
benefits to be derived from preserving the current use of the property. (Ord.
2/10/76 §3, 1976)
CHAPTER 1.08
TAKING OF PROPERTY
SECTION:
1.08.010: Findings
1.08.020: Purposes
1.08.030: Definitions
1.08.040: Compensation For Taken Property
1.08.050: Jurisdiction And Judicial Review
1.08.060: Statute Of Limitations
1.08.070: Attorney Fees And Costs
1.08.010: FINDINGS:
The board of White Pine County commissioners finds that:
   A.   The several and various estates in property situated within White Pine
County, Nevada, have value;
   B.   All affected segments of the American public, whether acting through
federal, state or local governments, have an obligation and a legal right to
acquire and pay compensation, through eminent domain, for all or portions of
estates in property situated in White Pine County, Nevada, which are
necessarily taken for public purposes;
   C.   Government taking of property without compensation unjustly infringes
constitutionally protected property rights, restricts the reasonable use of
property, and causes a few property owners to bear a burden rightfully and
legally the responsibility of all;
   D.   Property rights in White Pine County, Nevada, are being subtly
diminished through gradual application of laws, regulations and other legal
actions of government at all levels which, in the aggregate, adversely affect
their value and their owners' ability to make legal and reasonable use of
private property and substantially diminishes the county's tax and economic
bases;
   E.   Protection of wilderness, natural, riparian, pristine, and wetlands
areas, as well as of endangered species, clean air corridors, clean water
sources, view sheds, and other like values, are noble actions, but result in
many property rights being taken from their owners and from the county's
economic and tax bases for the benefit of the American public at large;
   F.   Owners or trustees of property situated in White Pine County, Nevada,
should be able to fully recover compensation for government taking of their
property;
   G.   Governments' administrative appeal processes provide means for
contesting government administrative actions, but do not provide a means for
just resolution of taking claims; and
   H.   Owners of property situated in White Pine County, Nevada, should be
able to commence court action immediately following actual and concrete injury,
to recover just compensation for government taking of their property. (Ord. 339
§1, 1999)
1.08.020: PURPOSES:
The purposes of this chapter are to:
   A.   Declare that takings of private property within White Pine County,
Nevada, for public uses are legal government actions that serve interests of
the public at large;
   B.   Establish a clear and uniform process whereby owners of taken property
in White Pine County, Nevada, can obtain vindication of all property rights
guaranteed by this chapter, the Nevada state constitution, and the fifth and
fourteenth amendments to the United States constitution; and
   C.   Require federal, state and local governments to compensate owners of
property in White Pine County, Nevada, for deprivation of their property rights
due to enforcement of federal, state or locally mandated programs. (Ord. 339
§2, 1999)
1.08.030: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms are defined in this section:
AGENCY: Executive branch, department, agency, independent agency, or
instrumentality of the governments of the United States, state of Nevada,
county of White Pine, Nevada, or of any other units of government having
jurisdiction within the boundaries of White Pine County, Nevada.
AGENCY ACTION: Any action, inaction or decision taken by an agency that at the
time of such action, inaction, or decision affects property rights in White
Pine County, Nevada.
JUST COMPENSATION: A. Compensation equal to the full extent of a property
owner's loss, including the fair market value of the taken property situated in
White Pine County, Nevada, whether the taking is or has been by physical
occupation or through regulation, exaction, condition or other means; and
   B.   Shall include compounded interest, calculated from the date of the
taking until the date payment is tendered.
OWNER: The owner or possessor of property or rights in White Pine County,
Nevada, at the time the taking occurs, including when:
   A.   The statute, ordinance, regulation, rule, order, guideline, policy or
action is passed or promulgated; or
   B.   The permit, license, authorization or governmental permission is denied
or suspended.
PRIVATE PROPERTY OR PROPERTY: All interests constituting property in White Pine
County, Nevada, protected under the fifth and fourteenth amendments to the
United States constitution, and includes, but is not limited to, the following:
   A.   Real property, whether vested or unvested, including:
      1.   Estates in fee, life estates, estates for years, or otherwise,
      2.   Inchoate interests in real property such as remainders and future
interests,
      3.   Personalty that is affixed to or appurtenant to real property,
      4.   Easements,
      5.   Leaseholds,
      6.   Recorded liens,
      7.   Contracts or other security interests in, or related to, real
property, and
      8.   Any other rights enumerated in Nevada state law or decreed by Nevada
courts as constituting real property;
   B.   The vested, certificated or permitted right to make beneficial use of
or to receive water, including any recorded liens on such water right; or
   C.   Access to or rents, issues, products, profits, or customary or cultural
uses of land or of split estates in land, including metals, minerals, dust,
dirt, timber, wood, wood products, fodder, forage, crops, natural waste, oil,
gas, coal, geothermal energy, sustenance, and recreation.
   D.   "Property" does not mean any imagined, inferred, or implied interest in
property which has been or may in the future be repudiated as such by Nevada
state law or by Nevada courts.
TAKING OF PRIVATE PROPERTY, TAKING, TAKEN, OR TAKE: Any agency action whereby
restricting the ownership, alienability, possession, use or lawful enjoyment of
private property is an object of that action and is taken so as to require
compensation under the fifth amendment to the United States constitution,
including by physical invasion, regulation, exaction, condition or other means.
(Ord. 339 §3, 1999)
1.08.040: COMPENSATION FOR TAKEN PROPERTY:
   A.   In General: No agency shall take private property within White Pine
County, Nevada, except for public use and with just compensation to the
property owner. A property owner shall receive just compensation:
      1.   If, as a consequence of an agency action, property, whether all or
in part, has been physically invaded or otherwise taken without the consent of
the owner; and
         a.   Such action results in the property owner being deprived, either
temporarily or permanently, by twenty percent (20%) or more, in the aggregate
over time, of the economically beneficial or productive use of the property or
of that part of the property, affected by the action, without a showing that
such deprivation inheres in the title itself; or
         b.   Such action results in the property owner being deprived, either
temporarily or permanently, by less than twenty percent (20%), in the aggregate
over time, of the economically beneficial or productive use of the property or
that part of the property affected by the action.
      2.   Under any circumstances other than as described in subsection A1 of
this section which results in or has resulted in a taking within the meaning of
the fifth amendment of the United States constitution.
   B.   No Claim Against Agency Which Is Not Responsible For Action: No action
may be filed under this title against an agency for carrying out the functions
mandated by another agency's law, regulation, policy or order. Claims arising
from the action, inaction or decision of an agency shall be properly filed
against the agency which mandates and administers the relevant program.
   C.   Burden Of Proof:
      1.   Government shall bear the burden of proof in any action described
under subsection A1a of this section, with regard to showing that such
deprivation of value inheres in the title to the property.
      2.   The property owner shall bear the burden of proof in any action
described under subsection A1b of this section, with regard to establishing the
diminution in value of property by any amount less than twenty percent (20%).
   D.   Compensation And Nuisance Exception To Payment Of Compensation:
      1.   No compensation shall be required by this chapter for taking the
owner's use, or proposed use, and only such use, of property which constitutes
a nuisance as commonly understood and defined by the state of Nevada's
principles of nuisance and property law. To bar an award of damages under this
chapter, government shall bear the burden of proof to establish that all the
taken use or proposed use of the property is a nuisance.
   E.   Adjudication:
      1.   Ripeness:
         a.   A party seeking redress shall exhaust all administrative remedies
prior to filing an action under this title unless:
            (1)   No appeal process is available;
            (2)   An appeal cannot provide the relief requested; or
            (3)   The prospects for success are reasonably unlikely and
intervention by the Nevada state 7th judicial district court or the United
States court of federal claims under this title is thus warranted to decide the
merits.
               (A)   For the purpose of determining whether prospects for an
appeal's success are likely as provided in subsection E1a(3) of this section,
the agency's attitude, policy and philosophy, as expressed in correspondence
and other agency documents, shall be the basis for conclusion.
         b.   A civil action filed under this title is ripe for adjudication,
without further administrative appeal, at any time an agency action causes
actual and concrete injury to the party seeking redress. (Ord. 339 §4, 1999)
1.08.050: JURISDICTION AND JUDICIAL REVIEW:
   A.   Venue: A property owner may file a civil action ripe for adjudication
under this chapter seeking just compensation for government taking of that
owner's property situated in White Pine County, Nevada:
      1.   In Nevada's 7th judicial district court, if the action is against
the state of Nevada or a local agency, or
      2.   In the United States court of federal claims if the action is
against a federal agency.
   B.   Standing: Any party seeking redress of an action ripe for adjudication
under the provisions of this chapter shall have standing to file an action.
(Ord. 339 §5, 1999)
1.08.060: STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS:
The statute of limitations for actions brought under this chapter shall be six
(6) years from the date the property owner becomes aware or should have
reasonably become aware of the taking of private property. (Ord. 339 §6, 1999)
1.08.070: ATTORNEY FEES AND COSTS:
The court, in issuing a final order in any action brought under this chapter,
shall award costs of litigation reasonable attorney and expert witness fees to
any prevailing plaintiff. (Ord. 339 §7, 1999)
TITLE 2
ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL
CHAPTER 2.02
COUNTY ADVISORY BOARDS AND AD HOC COMMITTEES
SECTION:
2.02.010: Statutory Authority
2.02.020: Creation Of County Advisory Boards
2.02.030: Procedure For Establishment Of County Advisory Boards
2.02.040: Appointment To White Pine County Advisory Boards
2.02.050: Standards Of Operation
2.02.060: Recommendations And Actions Of County Advisory Boards Are Advisory In
Nature
2.02.070: Appointment Of Ad Hoc Committees
2.02.010: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
   A.   Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 244.1945, the White Pine County
commission establishes county advisory boards for the purpose of advising the
county commission on an on going basis on policy, development, and operation of
county facilities and programs; planning; and community and economic
development. (Ord. 432, 2009)
2.02.020: CREATION OF COUNTY ADVISORY BOARDS:
   A.   The county advisory boards created by this chapter are: Airport
Advisory Board, Baker Area Advisory Board, Board of Adjustments, County
Planning Commission, Economic Diversification Council, Fairgrounds Advisory
Board, Industrial Park Review Board, Local Emergency Planning Committee,
Preston Area Advisory Board, Revolving Loan Fund Advisory Board, and Natural
Resources Advisory Committee (combining the Public Land Users Advisory
Committee with the Water Advisory Committee).
   B.   The White Pine County commission may add or delete county advisory
boards by amendment to this chapter. (Ord. 526, 2021: Ord. 434, 2009: Ord. 432,
2009)
2.02.030: PROCEDURE FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF COUNTY ADVISORY BOARDS:
   A.   Each county advisory board is established by a resolution that
identifies the specific purpose, duties of the board, membership, desired
representation, and term of its members.
   B.   The county commission may amend the resolutions establishing county
advisory boards to modify the duties and membership.
   C.   If requested, a public hearing may be conducted prior to amending the
county advisory board resolution. (Ord. 432, 2009)
2.02.040: APPOINTMENT TO WHITE PINE COUNTY ADVISORY BOARDS:
   A.   All members of county advisory boards shall be appointed by the White
Pine County commission unless otherwise stipulated in Nevada Revised Statutes
or the provisions of an interlocal agreement. (Ord. 432, 2009)
2.02.050: STANDARDS OF OPERATION:
   A.   Unless otherwise stipulated by provisions in statute or an interlocal
agreement, all county advisory boards shall adhere to the general requirements
outlined in the standards of operation for county advisory boards.
   B.   The standards of operation for county advisory boards are adopted by
resolution and may be amended by the county commission by resolution following
a public hearing. (Ord. 432, 2009)
2.02.060: RECOMMENDATIONS AND ACTIONS OF COUNTY ADVISORY BOARDS ARE ADVISORY IN
NATURE:
   A.   No actions of county advisory boards are binding on the county
commission. (Ord. 432, 2009)
2.02.070: APPOINTMENT OF AD HOC COMMITTEES:
   A.   The county commission may appoint ad hoc committees to study specific
questions and provide recommendations to the commission.
   B.   County ad hoc advisory committees shall be formed by resolution.
   C.   The resolution shall specify the purpose of the committee, the
membership of the committee, and the expiration date of the committee
assignment.
   D.   The committee assignment may be extended through a vote of the county
commission. (Ord. 432, 2009)
CHAPTER 2.04

2.04.010: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT DEFINED:
"Emergency management" means the preparation for and the carrying out of all
emergency functions, other than functions for which military forces are
primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage
resulting from disasters caused by enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile
action, or by fire, flood, earthquake or other natural causes. These functions
include firefighting, police services, medical and health services, searches,
rescues, engineering, air raid warning services, communications, radiological,
chemical and other special weapons defense, evacuation of persons from stricken
areas, emergency welfare services (civilian war aid), emergency transportation,
existing or properly assigned functions of plant protection, temporary
restoration of public utility services and other functions related to civilian
protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to the
preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions. (Ord. 186 §1,
1985: Ord. 50 §1, 1970)
2.04.020: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL; MEMBERSHIP 1 :
(Rep. by Ord. 432, 2009)

(Rep. by Ord. 432, 2009)

1 1. See chapter 2.02 of this title.
2.04.050: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT CORPS; PURPOSE:
Officers and employees of White Pine County, with volunteer forces enrolled to
them during an emergency, and all groups, organizations and persons interested
and responsible for the operation of law are charged with the responsibility
for the protection of life and property in the county during such an emergency
and shall constitute the emergency management corps. (Ord. 186 §1, 1985: Ord.
50 §5, 1970)
2.04.060: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT CORPS; DIVISIONS:
   A.   The functions and duties of the county emergency management council
shall be distributed among the divisions as listed below. Each division shall
be under the direction of a chief and deputy chief appointed by the emergency
management council. The respective chiefs of each division may include public
officials as well as private businessmen, who through their profession,
knowledge or experience are particularly qualified to head divisions requiring
specialized knowledge and experience. The divisions are established as follows:
      1.   Law enforcement division;
      2.   Fire services division;
      3.   Medical and health division;
      4.   Engineering and utilities division;
      5.   Transportation division;
      6.   Communications division;
      7.   Welfare division;
      8.   Information and education division. (Ord. 186 §1, 1985: Ord. 50 §6,
1970)
2.04.070: VOLUNTEERS:
All persons, other than officers and employees of the county, volunteering in
service pursuant to the needs of this chapter shall serve without compensation.
While engaged in such service they shall have the same immunities as persons
and employees of the county performing similar duties. (Ord. 186 §1, 1985: Ord.
50 §5, 1970)
2.04.080: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
   A.   It shall be a misdemeanor punishable as provided in title 1, chapter
1.01 of this code, during an emergency:
      1.   To wilfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the emergency
management corps in the enforcement of any lawful rule or regulation issued
pursuant to this chapter, or in the performance of any duty imposed upon him by
virtue of this chapter;
      2.   To do any act forbidden by any lawful rule or regulation issued
pursuant to this chapter if such act is of such a nature as to give assistance
to the enemy or to imperil the life or property of any inhabitant of this
county or to prevent, hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof;
      3.   To wear or carry or display without authority any mark or
identification specified by the emergency management council. (Ord. 186 §1,
1985: Ord. 50 §8, 1970)
CHAPTER 2.08
POSITION CLASSIFICATION AND PAY PLAN 1

2.08.020: Purpose
2.08.030: Terminology

2.08.120: Longevity Pay
2.08.130: Overtime Pay
 
Notes
1 1. NRS ch. 245, 245.045.
2.08.010: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and referred to as the POSITION CLASSIFICATION AND
PAY PLAN. (Ord. 7/12/77 §1, 1977: Ord. 12/10/74 §1, 1974)
2.08.020: PURPOSE:
In order to provide systematic recruitment, uniform terminology, a
clarification of duties and responsibilities, and to secure good employee
morale, according to experience, aptitude and merit, there is adopted and
established this position classification and pay plan for the employees of
White Pine County, Nevada, who are not a part of a recognized collective
bargaining unit pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 2.88.160. (Ord. 152 §1
(part), 1983: Ord. 7/12/77 §2, 1977: Ord. 12/10/74 §2, 1974)
2.08.030: TERMINOLOGY:
When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include
the future; words in the singular include the plural; words in the plural
include the singular; all of which shall be applicable only to county
employees. (Ord. 12/10/74 §3, 1974)
2.08.040: DEFINITIONS:
The words and terms used in this chapter shall be defined as follows:
CLASSIFICATION: An employee's job title or position with respect to duties and
responsibilities.
GRADE: Each grade which brings together positions of equivalent duties and
responsibilities, i.e., classifications, for pay purposes.
SALARY STEPS: The steps on the salary schedule which are the means of rewarding
employees for continued good service and merit, recognizing the value of
experience and aptitude.
TYPES OF COUNTY EMPLOYMENT:
Full Time: An employee who occupies a full time regular position shall work
five (5) days, either forty (40) hours per week, eight (8) hours per day, or
thirty five (35) hours per week, seven (7) hours per day, exclusive of meal
breaks, but including rest breaks, unless otherwise directed by the department
head or elected official, or when any other work schedule is approved by the
board of commissioners and the employees affected.
Part Time: An employee who occupies a position and works twenty (20) or more
hours per week.
Permanent: An employee who has completed the probationary period.
Probationary: An employee shall be considered to be on probation and shall not
be entitled to any seniority until after he or she has worked six (6)
consecutive months after the date of last hire. If such employee is continued
in the employ of the county after the expiration of the probation period, the
employee's length of service shall be computed from such employee's date of
last hire.
The county retains the right to discharge new employees during or at the end of
the probationary period with or without cause.
Temporary: An employee who is hired for a period not to exceed six (6) months.
If a temporary employee's status is changed to probationary, his or her
probationary period shall be retroactive to the date of employment. (Ord. 152
§1(part), 1983: Ord. 7/12/77 §4, 1977: Ord. 12/10/74 §4, 1974)
2.08.050: RATE OF COMPENSATION:
   A.   Employees shall be compensated according to the classification schedule
and salary schedule set forth as appendices 1 and 2 respectively, copies of
which are attached to the ordinance codified herein, and incorporated herein,
and on file in the county clerk's office. The rates specified in the
classification schedule and salary schedule attached as appendices 1 and 2
respectively, shall be effective on July 1, 1982.
   B.   Amendments to the classification schedule and salary schedule shall be
by ordinance. (Ord. 152 §1(part), 1983: Ord. 7/12/77 §5, 1977: Ord. 12/10/74
§5, 1974)
2.08.060: SALARY STEP ADVANCEMENTS:
   A.   Subject to the financial ability of the county, salary step
advancements shall be made on the basis of the following:
      1.   Step Beginning To Step One: Each employee must successfully complete
a six (6) month trial period at the minimum hiring wage for the grade for which
the employee was originally hired.
      2.   After Step One: Step advancements after step one for county
employees shall be made on the basis of merit and length of service with the
county.
      3.   Merit: Merit shall be measured according to the following
considerations:
         a.   Has the physical qualifications to do the work;
         b.   Has experience related to the job;
         c.   Performs the work in the manner required by the county;
         d.   Cooperates with supervisors and observes county rules and
regulations;
         e.   Protects the property and interest of the county;
         f.   Reports for work promptly and regularly;
         g.   Maintains harmonious relations with coworkers;
         h.   Has a positive attitude toward the county and the job.
      4.   Length Of Service: The length of service required for salary step
advancements after step one shall be one year for each salary step. Effective
January 1, 1983, seasonal employees shall be required to have a minimum of nine
(9) months paid employment before qualifying for a salary step advancement in
length of service.
      5.   Procedure: Employees shall be advanced to a higher step only upon
written recommendation of the department head/elected official and approval by
the board of county commissioners during the first month of each fiscal year.
(Ord. 255 §1, 1990: Ord. 152 §1(part), 1983: Ord. 7/12/77 §6, 1977: Ord. 12/10/
74 §6, 1974)
2.08.070: EMPLOYEE PAYDAYS:
Employees shall be compensated for services rendered on a biweekly basis, with
the first payday on July 2, 1982, and every alternate Friday thereafter. (Ord.
152 §1(part), 1983: Ord. 7/12/77 §6, 1977: Ord. 12/10/74 §6, 1974)
2.08.090: JOB CLASSIFIER:
The board of county commissioners may, at its discretion, delegate the
supervision and operation of this position classification and pay plan to an
elected official of White Pine County who shall be titled job classifier and
who may be compensated for such services, in addition to his statutory salary.
(Ord. 7/12/77 §9, 1977: Ord. 12/10/74 §9, 1974)
2.08.100: APPLICATION TO EMPLOYEES:
The board of county commissioners shall, by resolution, apply the
classification schedule and salary schedule as established in section
2.08.050 of this chapter, to the employees of White Pine County, Nevada. (Ord.
152 §1(part), 1983: Ord. 7/12/77 §10, 1977: Ord. 12/10/74 §10, 1974)
2.08.120: LONGEVITY PAY:
   A.   Each full time employee who has completed ten (10) years of continuous
paid employment with the county shall be entitled to longevity pay pursuant to
this section. Additional compensation shall be provided to employees after the
completion of twenty (20) years and twenty five (25) years of continuous paid
employment with the county.
      1.   Compensation:
         a.   Employees who have completed ten (10) years, but less than twenty
(20) years of service for the county, shall receive a payment of fifty dollars
($50.00) per month in addition to the employee's base salary.
         b.   Employees who have completed twenty (20) years, but less than
twenty five (25) years of service for the county, shall receive a payment of
one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month in addition to the employee's base
salary.
         c.   Employees who have completed twenty five (25) years of service
for the county shall receive a payment of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00)
per month in addition to the employee's base salary.
      2.   Payment: All accrued longevity pay may be paid in a lump sum on the
first payday in December to all eligible employees, or on a monthly basis.
      3.   Breaks In Longevity: The following shall be considered as breaks in
qualifying service for longevity:
         a.   Authorized absence from work because of injury or disease arising
out of and in the course of the employee's employment after three (3) calendar
months, unless excused in the county commissioners' discretion;
         b.   Authorized leaves of absence, unless excused in the county
commissioners' discretion;
         c.   Authorized maternity leave, unless covered by accrued sick and/or
annual leave.
      4.   Absences Without Break In Longevity: The following shall not be
considered as breaks in qualifying service for longevity:
         a.   Authorized reserve military duty for a period of not more than
fifteen (15) working days in any one calendar year, pursuant to Nevada Revised
Statutes 281.145;
         b.   Authorized military service, provided the employee is reinstated
pursuant to United States Code title 38 section 2021 et seq., "veteran's re-
employment rights";
         c.   Authorized absence from work because of injury or disease arising
out of and in the course of his or her employment for three (3) calendar months
or less.
      5.   Forfeiture Of Longevity: The following shall be considered as
circumstances causing a forfeiture of all accrued longevity:
         a.   Absence from work for any reason stated above in excess of twelve
(12) consecutive months, unless excused, in the county commissioners'
discretion;
         b.   Discharge for cause, unless reinstated through the grievance
procedure herein, and/or any other agency or court of competent jurisdiction;
         c.   Voluntary resignation;
         d.   Failure to return to work within five (5) days when recalled
after layoff or reduction in force, unless excused for illness or other reason
in the county commissioners' discretion;
         e.   Absence from work for four (4) consecutive working days without
notifying the county of the reasons for such absence or without an excuse
acceptable to the county. (Ord. 213 §1, 1988: Ord. 152 §1(part), 1983: Ord. 94
§1, 1980)
2.08.130: OVERTIME PAY:
   A.   Overtime: Employees shall be paid for all hours worked in excess of
forty (40) hours per week at the rate of one and one-half (11/2) hours, which
may be paid in cash or as compensatory time at the discretion of the employee,
with the approval of the department head/elected official.
   B.   Compensatory Time: Employees electing compensatory time for overtime
worked shall not accumulate in excess of twenty four (24) hours at any one
time. Accrued compensatory time not used within ninety (90) days shall be paid
in cash. (Ord. 152 §3, 1983)

2.12.005: PURPOSE:
In order to provide improved recruitment and to secure good employee morale,
there is adopted and established leave provisions for the employees of White
Pine County, Nevada, who are not part of a recognized collective bargaining
unit pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 288.160. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.010: ANNUAL LEAVE; ACCRUAL:
   A.   All elected and appointed officers and employees shall accrue annual
leave with pay at the rates designated in the following schedule:
      1.   Up to two (2) years: Five-sixths (5/6) of a day per month of
service;
      2.   After two (2) years: One and one-fourth (11/4) days per month of
service;
      3.   After eighteen (18) years: One and two-thirds (12/3) days per month
of service. (Ord. 153 §1(part), 1983)
2.12.015: ANNUAL LEAVE; ACCUMULATION:
All elected and appointed officers and employees of White Pine County shall be
entitled to accumulate annual leave from year to year, but in no event more
than twenty five (25) days at any one time. Unused annual leave which exceeds
twenty five (25) days shall be lost and the officer or employee shall not be
compensated therefor. (Ord. 1/3/80 §1(part), 1980)
2.12.020: ANNUAL LEAVE; ADDITIONAL OR PRORATED:
The board of county commissioners may, by order, provide for additional annual
leave for elected officials and for long term appointed officers and employees
and for prorated annual leave for part time employees. (Ord. 48 §2, 1968)
2.12.025: ANNUAL LEAVE; LEAVE YEAR:
Annual leave and the eligibility to take said annual leave will be based upon
the employee's anniversary date. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.030: ANNUAL LEAVE; DECEASED EMPLOYEE:
If an appointed officer or employee dies and was entitled to accumulated annual
leave under the provisions of this chapter, the heirs of such deceased officer
or employee who are given priority to succeed to the decedent's assets under
the law of intestate succession and distribution of the state of Nevada, or the
executor or administrator of decedent's estate, upon submitting satisfactory
proof to the board of county commissioners of their entitlement shall be paid
an amount of money equal to the number of days of earned and accrued annual
leave multiplied by the daily salary or wages of the deceased officer or
employee. (Ord. 48 §3, 1968)
2.12.035: ANNUAL LEAVE; LIMITATION:
Annual leave shall not be granted in excess of the annual leave time earned.
(Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.040: ANNUAL LEAVE; TERMINATION OF ELECTED OFFICERS:
Elected county officers shall not be paid for accumulated annual leave upon
termination of service. (Ord. 48 §4, 1968)
2.12.050: ANNUAL LEAVE; FIRST SIX MONTHS' EMPLOYMENT:
During the first six (6) months of employment of any appointed officer or
employee, annual leave shall accrue, however, no annual leave shall be taken
during that six (6) month period. (Ord. 48 §5, 1968)
2.12.060: ANNUAL LEAVE; TERMINATION OF APPOINTED EMPLOYEE:
No appointed officer or employee shall be paid for accumulated annual leave
upon termination of employment unless he has been employed for six (6) months
or more. (Ord. 48 §6, 1968)
2.12.070: LEAVE OF ABSENCE:
   A.   An appointed officer or employee may, upon the written recommendation
of his superior and with the prior approval of the board of county
commissioners, be granted a leave of absence, without pay, for a period not
exceeding one year.
   B.   In no case will more than one leave of absence be granted to any
employee within a twelve (12) month period. (Ord. 153 §1(part), 1983: Ord. 48
§7, 1968)
2.12.072: LEAVE OF ABSENCE; REINSTATEMENT:
When an employee returns to duty in compliance with an authorized leave of
absence, such employee shall be reinstated in the same position in which the
employee was employed before his or her absence if qualified and if the
position is available. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.074: LEAVE OF ABSENCE; TERMINATION DURING LEAVE OF ABSENCE:
   A.   An employee who has been granted a leave of absence shall be considered
as having quit without notice if:
      1.   While on leave the employee engages in or applies for other
employment without the consent of the county;
      2.   The employee fails to report to work at the end of such leave, or
fails to obtain an extension;
      3.   The employee makes application for unemployment benefits while on
such leave;
      4.   The employee obtained a leave of absence through fraud or
misrepresentation. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.080: SICK LEAVE; ACCRUAL:
All elected officials, appointed officers and employees shall be entitled to
sick and disability leave with pay of one and one-fourth (11/4) working days
for each month of service, which may be cumulative from year to year, not to
exceed ninety (90) working days. (Ord. 153 §1(part), 1983: Ord. 8/10/73 §1
(part), 1973: Ord. 48 §8, 1968)
2.12.082: SICK LEAVE; USES:
Sick leave is authorized for either the illness of an employee, for the illness
of a member of the employee's immediate family, or for a member of the
employee's household, or for the transportation of such person for medical
treatment. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.084: SICK LEAVE; LIMITATIONS ON USE:
   A.   Under no circumstances shall sick leave benefits be made available:
      1.   For days of absence other than regularly scheduled workdays;
      2.   During any period of layoff;
      3.   During a leave of absence;
      4.   During periods of annual leave. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.090: SICK AND DISABILITY LEAVE; ADDITIONAL OR PRORATED:
The board of county commissioners may by minute order, provide for additional
sick and disability leave for long time employees, that is, employees who have
been regularly employed by the county for at least seven (7) full years and for
prorated sick and disability leave for part time employees. (Ord. 8/10/73 §1
(part), 1973: Ord. 48 §9, 1968)
2.12.092: SICK LEAVE; COMPENSATION ON TERMINATION:
Upon the termination of employment, retirement, or natural death, a full time
employee shall be entitled to compensation for fifty percent (50%) of all
accrued unused sick leave to a maximum to be paid of fifteen (15) days. (Ord.
153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.094: SICK LEAVE; SURVIVOR'S RIGHTS:
In the event an employee is killed in the line of duty, the employee's
beneficiary or estate will be compensated for one hundred percent (100%) of all
accrued sick leave. Payment will be paid to the beneficiary named in a written
designation filed with the county; or if such payment is prevented by law,
payment will be made to the employee's estate. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.096: SICK LEAVE; ABUSES:
An employee who abuses sick leave benefits by falsification of reasons for such
leave shall be subject to immediate disciplinary action, including discharge,
and shall be required to make restitution of any compensation the employee
received during the period of absence. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.100: JOB RELATED INJURIES:
   A.   An employee who is unable to work due to an injury arising out of and
in the course of employment with the county, shall receive full pay during the
period for which the employee receives Nevada industrial commission wage
compensation, specifically until the Nevada industrial commission determines
the employee is ineligible to return to work or that he is permanently, totally
or partially disabled, provided the employee in turn endorses the Nevada
industrial commission wage compensation checks to the county.
   B.   The first thirty (30) working days for which the absent employee
receives and endorses over Nevada industrial commission compensation as
provided above shall not be charged against such employee's sick leave.
Thereafter, each day of absence shall be a charge at the same rate against the
employee's sick leave. (Ord. 153 §1(part), 1983: Ord. 48 §10, 1968)
2.12.110: LEGAL HOLIDAYS DURING ANNUAL OR SICK LEAVE:
Legal holidays occurring during a period of annual or sick leave shall not be
counted as either annual or sick leave. (Ord. 48 §11, 1968)
2.12.120: FUNERAL LEAVE; PAY FOR FUNERAL LEAVE:
Paid leave to attend the funeral of a member of an employee's immediate family
may be granted at the discretion of the department head, elected official or
board of county commissioners, as applicable, for a period not to exceed three
(3) working days. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.130: FUNERAL LEAVE; EXTENDED FUNERAL LEAVE:
Additional leave to attend a funeral in excess of three (3) days may be granted
at the discretion of the department head, elected official or board of county
commissioners, as applicable. Such leave shall, however, be charged to the
accrued sick or annual leave of the employee, at the discretion of the
employee. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.140: FUNERAL LEAVE; IMMEDIATE FAMILY DEFINED:
"Immediate family" means the employee's father, mother, husband, wife, sister,
brother, son, daughter, son-in-law, daughter-in- law, father-in-law, mother-in-
law, grandparents, grandchildren, and foster, and step relatives in the same
degree. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.150: FUNERAL LEAVE; OTHER FUNERALS:
Paid leave to attend the funeral of any person not named in section
2.12.140 of this chapter may be granted at the discretion of the department
head, elected official or board of county commissioners, as applicable, for a
reasonable period of time. Such leave shall, however, be charged to the accrued
annual leave of the employee. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.160: MILITARY LEAVE:
Any employee who is an active member of the Nevada national guard, or any
reserve component of the United States armed forces, shall be relieved from the
employee's duties, upon request, to serve under orders without loss of regular
compensation for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) working days in any one
calendar year. Any such absence shall not be deducted from the employee's
accrued vacation. This is pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 281.145. (Ord.
153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.170: MATERNITY LEAVE:
   A.   An employee is entitled to use accumulated sick leave and annual leave
as maternity leave, regardless of the type of delivery or results of pregnancy,
if the provisions below are complied with fully:
      1.   Unless as otherwise provided herein, the decision as to when such
leave begins or ends shall be made by the employee with the approval of the
county accompanied by the approval of the employee's personal physician. The
county may require the employee to have a medical examination by a doctor of
its choice and at its expense for the purposes of determining if the employee
should take leave or continue on leave.
      2.   All maternity leave requests shall contain a signed statement by the
employee of her intention to return to her job at the earliest possible time in
accordance with her physician's decision. A failure to report for assignment at
the expiration of the maternity leave shall be considered as a resignation.
      3.   In every case, an employee shall submit a written report from her
physician to the county as to the anticipated dates of absence and the second
report stating that she is physically able to return to work as of a given
date.
      4.   If additional time is required, after exhausting sick and annual
leave, the board of county commissioners may grant leave without pay when
deemed for the good of the public service. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.180: MATERNITY LEAVE; NOTICE OF PREGNANCY:
Pregnancy shall not jeopardize an employee's job or seniority, except she shall
be responsible for reporting the pregnancy as soon as it is an established fact
so that steps may be taken to protect the employee's health or modify her
working conditions and in order that any necessary staffing adjustments may be
planned. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.190: MATERNITY LEAVE; REINSTATEMENT:
When an employee returns to duty in compliance with an authorized leave of
absence, such employee shall be reinstated in the same classification,
position, shift, unit and scheduled hours in which such employee was employed
before her absence, but if conditions in the county have so changed that it
would not be feasible to reinstate the employee in such manner, then the county
will reinstate the employee to as nearly comparable a position and shift as is
reasonable under the circumstances. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.200: JURY DUTY:
Any employee who is called for jury duty and serves as a juror on regularly
scheduled workdays shall be paid the employee's regular compensation as though
the employee were actually on the job during that time, not to exceed forty
(40) hours per week. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.210: COURT APPEARANCES:
   A.   Any employee who is called to testify or participate in a court case or
administrative hearing, except when the employee is a party to such action,
shall be paid the employee's regular compensation as though the employee were
actually on the job during that time, not to exceed forty (40) hours per week.
   B.   Anytime an employee is on county business, which shall mean any case in
which the county is suing a party or being sued, and an employee is called to
testify either on behalf or at the request of the county and actual court time
requires the employee to work overtime hours, the employee shall be entitled to
overtime pay. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.220: JURY DUTY/COURT APPEARANCES; LIMITATION ON COMPENSATION:
   A.   In no event will payment be made for jury duty or other court
appearances performed during any time other than regularly scheduled work
hours, including, but not limited to, holidays, Saturday, Sunday, maternity
leave, leave of absence, or overtime.
   B.   Any employee who is called for jury duty and serves as a juror or who
is called as a witness or participates on other than regularly scheduled
workdays shall be entitled to retain any compensation authorized by the court
or administrative agency for that appearance. Otherwise, compensation
authorized by the court or administrative agency shall be refused or assigned
to the county by the employee. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.230: JURY DUTY/COURT APPEARANCES; RETURN TO WORK:
If excused by the court within a reasonable time after reporting for jury duty
or as a witness, the employee shall return to work. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.240: HOLIDAYS; DESIGNATED HOLIDAYS:
   A.   All holidays designated by Nevada Revised Statutes 236.015, shall be
considered holidays for purposes of this agreement. The following days are the
legal holidays:
      1.   January 1 (New Year's Day);
      2.   Third Monday in February (Washington's Birthday);
      3.   Last Monday in May (Memorial Day);
      4.   July 4 (Independence Day);
      5.   First Monday in September (Labor Day);
      6.   October 31 (Nevada Day);
      7.   November 11 (Veterans Day);
      8.   Fourth Thursday in November (Thanksgiving Day);
      9.   December 25 (Christmas Day);
      10.   Any day that may be appointed by the president of the United States
or by the governor for public fast, thanksgiving or as a legal holiday except
for any presidential appointment of the fourth Monday in October as Veterans
Day;
      11.   If January 1, July 4, October 31, November 11 or December 25 falls
upon a:
         a.   Sunday, the Monday following shall be observed as a legal
holiday,
         b.   Saturday, the Friday preceding shall be observed as a legal
holiday. (Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
2.12.250: HOLIDAYS; PAY FOR HOLIDAYS:
   A.   An employee who works a holiday, as designated in section
2.12.240 of this chapter, shall be entitled to their regular authorized salary,
plus a full day's pay at the employee's regular rate for the holiday.
   B.   An employee who is scheduled off on a holiday and is not required to
work shall be paid an additional day's pay at the employee's regular rate.
(Ord. 153 §2(part), 1983)
CHAPTER 2.13
PERSONNEL POLICY MANUAL
SECTION:
2.13.010: Acceptance
2.13.020: Terms Defined
2.13.030: Creation
2.13.040: Title
2.13.050: Conflicting Policies
2.13.060: Future Revisions
2.13.070: Duty To Maintain Current Policy Manual
2.13.080: Intent Of Chapter
2.13.010: ACCEPTANCE:
The board of county commissioners accepts and adopts the White Pine County
personnel policy manual dated November 4, 1999. (Ord. 347 (part), 1999)
2.13.020: TERMS DEFINED:
As used in this chapter:
BOARD: Shall be construed as the board of county commissioners for White Pine
County, Nevada.
CODE: Shall have reference to the White Pine County code.
POLICY MANUAL: Shall be construed as that certain "White Pine County Personnel
Policy Manual" dated November 4, 1999. (Ord. 347 (part), 1999)
2.13.030: CREATION:
There is added to this code a new chapter, designated as chapter 2.13. (Ord.
347 (part), 1999)
2.13.040: TITLE:
This chapter is here made a part of this code and shall be entitled "County
Personnel Policy Manual". The policy manual shall be adopted by reference
herein. Any such reference to the manual shall include any of its latest
revisions or modifications as made pursuant to section
2.13.060 of this chapter. Adoption of the manual, by reference herein, shall
not create any duty to publish the manual in connection with any other
amendments, modifications, or printings of this code. (Ord. 347 (part), 1999)
2.13.050: CONFLICTING POLICIES:
All existing personnel policies, heretofore adopted by the board, in conflict
with the terms and provisions of the policy manual are hereby rescinded and
repealed. Any existing personnel policy not governed by the express provisions
of the policy manual may be adopted and made a part thereof as provided for by
section
2.13.060 of this chapter. (Ord. 347 (part), 1999)
2.13.060: FUTURE REVISIONS:
Any revision, modification or correction to the terms of the policy manual
shall be made upon resolution of the board. Any such resolution shall be
approved only at an open public meeting as provided for in Nevada Revised
Statutes 241.020 and as may be from time to time, changed, or modified,
periodically by amendment thereto by the Nevada state legislature. (Ord. 442,
2011)
2.13.070: DUTY TO MAINTAIN CURRENT POLICY MANUAL:
A copy of the manual, including all of its latest revisions and modifications
shall be maintained for inspection by any employee of the county at the office
of the White Pine County commission, the White Pine County clerk's office, the
office of the White Pine County recorder's office, and at such other place or
places as the board shall from time to time direct. (Ord. 347, 1999)
2.13.080: INTENT OF CHAPTER:
This chapter is not intended to provide for any additional rights or
obligations not specifically enumerated by the policy manual or any collective
bargaining agreement to which the county of White Pine, through the board, and
the employees thereof, are subject to, other than those rights and obligations
expressly set forth herein. (Ord. 347, 1999)
CHAPTER 2.16
MARRIAGE LICENSE FEE 1

2.16.010: EXTRA FEE:
The county clerk shall collect an extra fee of five dollars ($5.00) over and
above the statutory fee for each and every marriage license issued after
regular office hours. (Ord. 35 §1, 1963: Ord. 10 §1, 1957)
2.16.020: REGULAR OFFICE HOURS DEFINED:
"Regular office hours" as herein referred to means those hours from nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. to five o'clock (5:00) P.M. of Monday through Friday, and
excluding any and all legal holidays. However, any county office may open prior
to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and remain open past five o'clock (5:00) P.M. in
the discretion of the department head. (Ord. 307 §1, 1996: Ord. 35 §2, 1963:
Ord. 10 §1, 1957)
2.16.030: EXTRA COMPENSATION OF CLERK:
The county clerk shall retain the extra fee as his compensation for his
services in connection herewith. (Ord. 35 §3, 1963: Ord. 10 §1, 1957)
2.16.040: ADDITIONAL MARRIAGE LICENSE FILING FEE:
Pursuant to NRS 246.180(2), the county clerk shall charge and collect an extra
fee of three dollars ($3.00) for the filing of each and every marriage license.
(Ord. 520, 2021)

§1, 1980)

The board of county commissioners shall hold two (2) public meetings each
month. These meetings shall be held the second and fourth Wednesday of each
month and each meeting shall commence at nine o'clock (9:00) A.M., or at such
other time as the chairman, or in his absence, the vice chairman or acting
chairman, shall designate on the posting of the agenda. In the event any of the
above meeting dates occurs on a legal holiday, the board shall meet on the next
succeeding judicial day. (Ord. 430, 2009: Ord. 331 §1, 1998: Ord. 182 §1, 1985:
Ord. 158 §1, 1983: Ord. 136 §1, 1982: Ord. 113 §1, 1981: Ord. 88 §1, 1980: Ord.
3/15/77 §1, 1977: Ord. 62 §1, 1972)
2.20.020: FIRST MEETING IN ODD NUMBERED YEARS:

first Monday in January. (Ord. 62 §2, 1972)
2.20.030: CHANGE OF MEETING DAYS, SPECIAL MEETINGS, EMERGENCY MEETINGS:

proposed change is provided in accordance with Nevada Revised Statutes 241.020
and 244.090. Notice of special meetings and emergency meetings shall also
comply with the provisions of Nevada Revised Statutes 241.020 and 244.090.
(Ord. 87 §1, 1980: Ord. 3/15/77 §2, 1977: Ord. 62 §3, 1972)
