CHAPTER 2.32
REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION 1
2.32.010: Planning District
2.32.020: Establishment And Authority
2.32.030: Membership
2.32.040: Term Of Members, Removal, and Vacancies
2.32.050: Compensation And Expenses
2.32.060: Budget, Appropriations, And Expenditures
2.32.070: Chairperson, Officers, And Employees
2.32.080: Meetings, Rules, And Records
2.32.090: Duties
2.32.100: Authority, Appeal To Governing Bodies
2.32.110: Reformation Or Repeal Of Conflicting Ordinances
2.32.120: Adoption Of Ordinances
2.32.130: Severability
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2.02 of this title and subsection
  17.08.010A of this code.
2.32.010: PLANNING DISTRICT:
White Pine County, Nevada and the incorporated City of Ely, Nevada are hereby
declared to be part of a Regional Planning District, the boundaries of which
district shall be the boundaries of White Pine County, Nevada, including the
incorporated City of Ely, Nevada. (Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.020: ESTABLISHMENT AND AUTHORITY:
Effective January 1, 2020, there is hereby established and created a Regional
Planning Commission. White Pine County and the City of Ely shall be represented
on the Regional Planning Commission. The Regional Planning Commission is hereby
authorized to act for and on behalf of White Pine County and the City of Ely as
a Planning Commission which shall fulfill all of the duties and functions of a
Planning Commission as set forth in Chapter 278 of the Nevada Revised Statutes
and all applicable sections of the White Pine County Code and the City Code of
the City of Ely. (Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.030: MEMBERSHIP:
The Regional Planning Commission shall consist of six (6) members, three (3) of
whom shall be appointed by the Mayor of the City of Ely, with the approval of
the Ely City Council and three (3) of whom shall be appointed with the approval
of the White Pine County Board of County Commissioners. (Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.040: TERM OF MEMBERS, REMOVAL, AND VACANCIES:
   A.   The term of office for members shall be four (4) years and shall expire
on December 31 of their respective years.
   B.   The terms of the members shall be overlapping and the membership of the
Regional Planning Commission first appointed to represent White Pine County and
the City of Ely shall include two (2) members, one (1) from the County and one
(1) from the City, who will serve three (3) years, and one (1) member, selected
by the County, who will serve a term of two (2) years, and one (1) member,
selected by the City, who will serve a term of one (1) year.
   C.   Members appointed by the White Pine County Board of County
Commissioners may be removed, after public hearing if requested, by a majority
vote of the White Pine County Board of County Commissioners, for inefficiency,
neglect of duty, malfeasance of office, or conduct detrimental to the Regional
Planning Commission or any of its governing bodies.
   D.   Members appointed by the Ely City Council may be removed, after public
hearing if requested, by a majority vote of the Ely City Council, for
inefficiency, neglect of duty, malfeasance of office or conduct detrimental to
the Regional Planning Commission or any of its governing bodies.
   E.   Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of term of
office shall be filled for the unexpired term.
   F.   No more than one third (1/3) of the members of the Regional Planning
Commission may hold any other public office. Accordingly, only one (1) member
appointed by the County and only one (1) member appointed by the City may hold
any other public office.
   G.   Because Regional Planning Commission members are appointed by the
respective governing bodies and not elected, the twelve (12)-year term limit
imposed by Article 15, Section 3 of the Nevada Constitution is inapplicable.
(Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.050: COMPENSATION AND EXPENSES:
Members of the Regional Planning Commission shall serve without compensation,
except for reasonable travel expenses made necessary in the fulfillment of
their official duties. (Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.060: BUDGET, APPROPRIATIONS, AND EXPENDITURES:
   A.   The Regional Planning Commission shall prepare an annual budget
containing a detailed estimate of expenditures, and transmit copies thereof to
the budget officers of White Pine County and the City of Ely for their use in
complying with the provisions of the local government budget act.
   B.   White Pine County is hereby authorized independently or in
collaboration with the City of Ely, to appropriate from the funds received by
the County from general taxation or other sources, money for the expenses of
the Regional Planning Commission.
   C.   The City of Ely is hereby authorized independently or in collaboration
with White Pine County, to appropriate from the funds received by the City from
general taxation or other sources, money for the expenses of the Regional
Planning Commission.
   D.   The Regional Planning Commission shall have no authority to expend any
funds of White Pine County or the City of Ely in excess of those budgeted and
appropriated. The Regional Planning Commission may negotiate and receive gifts,
Federal or state grants, or other funds and may expend the same only within the
total amounts as acquired, budgeted and authorized.
   E.   White Pine County and the City of Ely shall not be chargeable with any
expense incurred by the Regional Planning Commission except pursuant to such
authorized appropriations and the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.070: CHAIRPERSON, OFFICERS, AND EMPLOYEES:
   A.   The Regional Planning Commission shall elect a Chairperson from its own
members, and the term of such elected Chairperson shall be one (1) year, with
eligibility for reelection to successive terms.
   B.   The Regional Planning Commission shall create and fill such other
offices as it may deem necessary.
   C.   The Regional Planning Commission shall have the power to employ
experts, clerks and a secretary, and to pay for their services and such other
expenses as may be necessary and proper, not exceeding, in all, the annual
appropriation that may be made by White Pine County and the City of Ely for the
Regional Planning Commission, together with such other funds as may be
available through grant, gift or other means.
   D.   The Building Department of White Pine County and the City of Ely is ex
officio the clerk and secretary of the Regional Planning Commission.
   E.   White Pine County and the City of Ely are authorized to provide
professional planning services for the Regional Planning Commission by mutual
agreement.
   F.   Legal counsel for White Pine County and the City of Ely is not ex
officio legal counsel for the Regional Planning Commission. (Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.080: MEETINGS, RULES, AND RECORDS:
   A.   The Regional Planning Commission shall hold at least one regular
meeting in each month.
   B.   The first meeting of the Regional Planning Commission shall take place
during the first week of January, 2020, at a time and place arranged by the
members first appointed by the White Pine County Board of County Commissioners
and the Ely City Council. The frequency, time, and place of the Regional
Planning Commission's regular meetings shall be fixed by resolution at this
first meeting.
   C.   Additional meetings may be held as circumstances may require or render
desirable for the performance of its functions and the proper discharge of its
duties and responsibilities.
   D.   A majority of the membership shall constitute a quorum for the purpose
of transacting business.
   E.   Action by the Regional Planning Commission shall be by majority vote.
   F.   The Regional Planning Commission shall adopt rules and regulations for
the conduct of its business, not inconsistent with applicable State laws, the
White Pine County Code, or the City Code of the City of Ely.
   G.   The Regional Planning Commission shall keep a record of its
Resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be a
public record. (Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.090: DUTIES:
The Regional Planning Commission shall prepare and adopt a Master Plan setting
forth a comprehensive, long-term general plan for the physical development of
the White Pine County, including the City of Ely, pursuant to the Master Plan
provisions set forth in Chapter 278 of the Nevada Revised Statutes, and shall
perform such other duties, functions and powers as provided by State law, the
White Pine County Code, and the City Code of the City of Ely. (Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.100: AUTHORITY, APPEAL TO GOVERNING BODIES:
   A.   Authority of Regional Planning Commission:
      1.   The following terms shall apply to this chapter as written unless
context indicates or requires a different meaning:
 
APPROPRIATE GOVERNING BODY The governing body wherein the property at issue
                           sits within its jurisdiction.
GOVERNING BODY             The Ely City Council or the White Pine County Board
                           of County Commissioners.
 
      2.   Except for the limitations provided in this Section, the Regional
Planning Commission shall be vested with the authority to make determinations
on all matters governed by Chapter 278 of the Nevada Revised Statutes vested in
the White Pine County Board of County Commissioners absent this provision.
      3.   Except for the limitations provided in this Section, the Regional
Planning Commission shall be vested with the authority to make determinations
on all matters governed by Chapter 278 of the Nevada Revised Statutes vested in
the Ely City Council absent this provision.
      4.   The Regional Planning Commission is not vested with the authority to
vacate or abandon a street or easement owned by the City of Ely or White Pine
County pursuant to Chapter 278 of the Nevada Revised Statutes. The Regional
Planning Commission is likewise not vested with the authority to vacate,
abandon, sell, lease, convey, or otherwise dispose of or authorize the
encroachment upon any property owned, leased, or otherwise controlled by the
City of Ely or White Pine County.
   B.   Appeal:
      1.   Any person or entity who is aggrieved by a decision of the Regional
Planning Commission may appeal the decision to the appropriate governing body.
      2.   A person or entity shall be deemed to be aggrieved Section if the
person or entity appeared, either in person, through an authorized
representative or in writing, before the Regional Planning Commission on the
matter which is the subject of the decision.
      3.   Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to divest a governing
body of the appeal authority granted to it, nor alter the appeal procedures
provided in Chapter 278 of the Nevada Revised Statutes.
   C.   Appeal Procedure:
      1.   A person or entity seeking to appeal a decision of the Regional
Planning Commission must file their appeal in writing with the clerk of the
appropriate governing body within thirty (30) days of the decision of the
Regional Planning Commission.
      2.   Thereafter, the governing body will place the appeal hearing on the
agenda of its next regular meeting.
      3.   The governing body must render a decision on the appeal with sixty
(60) days of the filing of the appeal.
      4.   If the governing body's regular meeting schedule is such that a
decision of the governing body cannot be rendered within sixty (60) days, the
governing body shall convene a special meeting to hear the appeal.
      5.   In reviewing a decision, the governing body will be guided by the
statement of purpose underlying the regulation of the improvement of land
expressed in NRS 278.020.
      6.   The governing body may affirm, modify or reverse a decision. The
decision of the governing body is a final decision for the purpose of judicial
review.
      7.   The governing body may charge the appellant a fee for the filing of
an appeal. The fee shall be set by resolution of the Regional Planning
Commission. (Ord. 509, 2020; Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.110: REFORMATION OR REPEAL OF CONFLICTING ORDINANCES:
   A.   Any and all ordinances or parts of ordinances heretofore adopted by the
White Pine County Board of County Commissioners or the Ely City Council which
are inconsistent with this chapter are hereby reformed to be read consistently
with this chapter. For example, any ordinance conferring a benefit or burden
that would normally fall upon the Regional Planning Commission pursuant to this
chapter or state law shall so fall upon the Regional Planning Commission
despite the fact that the Regional Planning Commission is not duly named in
said ordinance.
   B.   Any and all ordinances or parts of ordinances heretofore adopted by the
White Pine County Board of County Commissioners or the Ely City Council which
are in conflict with this chapter and cannot be reformed to be read
consistently with this chapter are hereby repealed. (Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.120: ADOPTION OF ORDINANCES:
   A.   Both the White Pine County Board of County Commissioners and the Ely
City Council shall adopt identical versions of this chapter in order to
effectuate the creation of the Regional Planning Commission.
   B.   Any modification of the terms of this chapter must be done through each
political subdivision's ordinance process. Any such modifying ordinance must be
identical in language to that of the other governing body.
   C.   Repeal of this chapter by either governing body shall dissolve the
Regional Planning Commission.
   D.   Upon repeal, a third party mutually selected by the White Pine County
Board of County Commissioners and the Ely City Council shall be charged with
the winding down of the Regional Planning Commission's affairs and the
distribution of its property or assets, if necessary. Both White Pine County
and the City of Ely agree that the cost of this shall be paid equally by the
parties that this subsection shall survive any repeal of this chapter.
   E.   This chapter is effective contingent upon the City of Ely's dissolution
of its City Planning Commission prior to the first meeting of the Regional
Planning Commission. (Ord. 502, 2019)
2.32.130: SEVERABILITY:
If any provisions of this chapter are held invalid, such invalidity shall not
affect other provisions and each provision is hereby declared to be severable.
(Ord. 502, 2019)

CHAPTER 2.44
REGIONAL TRANSPORTATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.44.010: Establishment
2.44.020: Membership
2.44.030: Terms Of Office, Removal And Vacancies
2.44.040: Compensation And Expenses
2.44.050: Chairman And Officers
2.44.060: Meetings, Rules And Records
2.44.070: Powers And Duties
2.44.010: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is established and created a White Pine County regional transportation
commission pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 373. (Ord. 138 §1, 1982)
2.44.020: MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   The county regional transportation commission shall consist of three
(3) members who shall be selected as follows:
      1.   Two (2) members who shall be appointed by the board of county
commissioners of White Pine County;
      2.   One member who shall be appointed by the governing body of the
largest incorporated city in the county. (Ord. 138 §1, 1982)
2.44.030: TERMS OF OFFICE, REMOVAL AND VACANCIES:
The term of office for the members of the regional transportation commission
shall be two (2) years and shall expire on December 31 of their respective
years. The first representatives shall be selected within thirty (30) days
after passage of the ordinance creating the commission, and shall serve until
the next ensuing December 31 of an even numbered year. (Ord. 138 §1, 1982)
2.44.040: COMPENSATION AND EXPENSES:
Members of the regional transportation commission shall serve without
compensation, except for reasonable travel expenses made necessary in the
fulfillment of their official duties. (Ord. 138 §1, 1982)
2.44.050: CHAIRMAN AND OFFICERS:
The regional transportation commission shall elect its chairman from among the
appointed members, and the term of such elected chairman shall be one year,
with eligibility for reelection to successive terms.
The commission shall create and fill such other offices as it may deem
necessary. (Ord. 138 §1, 1982)
2.44.060: MEETINGS, RULES AND RECORDS:
The regional transportation commission shall hold meetings as circumstances may
require or render desirable for the performance of its functions and the proper
discharge of its duties and responsibilities. A majority of the membership
shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of transacting business. Action by
the commission shall be by majority vote.
The regional transportation commission shall adopt rules and regulations for
the conduct of its business, subject to Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 373,
this chapter, or any other law of the state for the organization of the
commission and the conduct of its business.
The commission shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings
and determinations, which record shall be a public record. (Ord. 138 §1, 1982)
2.44.070: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The regional transportation commission shall exercise and perform only
those powers and duties specifically granted to it and enumerated in Nevada
Revised Statutes chapter 373 and shall exercise or perform the powers and
duties in the mode and manner set forth in Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 373.
The powers and duties shall include, but not be limited to:
      1.   Receive and disburse federal funds for transit or other highway and
transportation purposes;
      2.   Submit project applications and programs of projects to the urban
mass transportation administration of the United States department of
transportation or to other federal agencies;
      3.   Enter into formal project agreements with the urban mass
transportation administration of the United States department of
transportation;
      4.   Conduct public hearings on transit and other highway and
transportation matters and certify that such hearings were conducted;
      5.   Match federal funds and make appropriate disbursements pursuant to
Nevada Revised Statutes 373.115;
      6.   Review all street and highway construction, surfacing or resurfacing
projects which are proposed to be financed from the county motor vehicle fuel
tax pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 373.140;
      7.   Make annual reports to the department of transportation in
accordance with and pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 373.143;
      8.   Submit specifications and plans of any project to the director of
the department of transportation for review pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes
373.145. (Ord. 138 §1, 1982)
CHAPTER 2.50
BAKER AREA CITIZENS ADVISORY BOARD 1
(Rep. by Ord. 432, 2009)
 
Notes

CHAPTER 2.52
HOSPITAL DISTRICT BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
2.52.010: Establishment
2.52.020: Membership
2.52.030: Term Of Office
2.52.040: Time And Manner Of Election
2.52.050: Office Of Hospital Trustee Nonpartisan
2.52.060: Vacancies
2.52.010: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is established and created a White Pine County hospital district board of
trustees pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 450.620. (Ord. 165 §1, 1983)
2.52.020: MEMBERSHIP:
The White Pine County hospital district board of trustees shall consist of five
(5) trustees who shall govern the hospital. (Ord. 298, 1995: Ord. 275 §1, 1992:
Ord. 165 §1, 1983)
2.52.030: TERM OF OFFICE:
Three (3) trustees shall be elected to initial four (4) year terms and the
other two (2) trustees shall be elected to initial two (2) year terms. (Ord.
298, 1995: Ord. 275 §1, 1992: Ord. 165 §1, 1983)
2.52.040: TIME AND MANNER OF ELECTION:
Trustees shall be elected at the general election in the same manner as other
county officers are elected. (Ord. 165 §1, 1983)
2.52.050: OFFICE OF HOSPITAL TRUSTEE NONPARTISAN:
   A.   The office of hospital trustees are declared to be nonpartisan, and the
names of candidates for such offices shall appear alike upon the ballots of all
parties at the primary elections.
   B.   At the general election only the names of those candidates not to
exceed twice the number of hospital district trustees to be elected, who
receive the highest numbers of vote at the primary election shall appear on the
ballot. (Ord. 165 §1, 1983)
2.52.060: VACANCIES:
Vacancies in the hospital district board of trustees occasioned by
resignations, removals or otherwise including vacancies prior to the first
general election following enactment of this chapter shall be reported to the
board of county commissioners and shall be filled by appointment by the board
of county commissioners. Appointees shall hold office until the next following
general election in the usual manner. (Ord. 165 §1, 1983)
CHAPTER 2.54
COUNTY DEPARTMENT OF EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES
SECTION:
2.54.010: Establishment Of Department
2.54.020: Definitions
2.54.030: Duties Of The Director
2.54.040: Adoption And Regulation
2.54.050: Reimbursement
2.54.060: Ambulance Runs To The Prison
2.54.070: EMT Expense Reimbursement
2.54.080: Delegation Of Duties/Vesting Of Authority
2.54.010: ESTABLISHMENT OF DEPARTMENT:
   A.   There is hereby created a County Department of Emergency Medical
Services which shall consist of a Director/Coordinator of Emergency Medical
Services and such other persons as are hereinafter authorized.
   B.   The Department of Emergency Medical Services shall coordinate and
provide emergency medical care and ambulance services as is reasonably possible
to persons requiring and requesting such services within White Pine County,
surrounding counties, and Utah as per agreement, subject to and consistent with
the provisions of chapter 450B of the Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 423, 2008)
2.54.020: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
COMMISSIONERS: The Board of County Commissioners of White Pine County, Nevada.
DIRECTOR: The designee of the White Pine County Commission who shall serve as
the Administrator of the Department of Emergency Medical Services.
EMERGENCY MEDICAL CARE: That care which is necessary to stabilize a patient for
transport to a medical facility.
EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES: The White Pine County Department of Emergency
Medical Services.
EMERGENCY MEDICAL SITUATION: A situation which requires a decision to be made
by the senior EMT on site as to what emergency medical care shall be
administered to a patient.
PATIENT: That person receiving emergency medical care from emergency medical
services.
PRISON: The Ely State Prison, the Ely Honor Camp and the White Pine County
Jail.
RESPONSIBLE PARTY: One who is of sufficient financial ability and who is a
spouse, parent, or legal guardian of the recipient of emergency medical care.
(Ord. 423, 2008)
2.54.030: DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR:
   A.   The Director shall be the designee appointed by majority vote of the
White Pine County Commission in a regularly held meeting of the County
Commission.
   B.   The Director shall work under the direct supervision of the
Commissioners, shall discharge all those duties and administer all such
programs as the Commissioners may from time to time delegate to the Director.
Such duties and administrative responsibilities shall be restricted to those
which under the various State laws of Nevada, pertaining to emergency medical
service matters are made the responsibility of the counties and which can be
lawfully delegated by the boards of county commissioners to appointed or
elected officials of such counties. The Director shall serve at the will of the
Commissioners.
   C.   The Director shall have the authority to make decisions regarding
expenditure of funds budgeted for emergency medical services as approved by the
County Commission during the budget process.
   D.   The Director shall be responsible for scheduling maintenance on all
vehicles. Each local organization shall be responsible for emergency repairs on
all vehicles used and operated by that organization. (Ord. 423, 2008)
2.54.040: ADOPTION AND REGULATION:
The definitions and minimum guidelines, rules and regulations governing the
provisions of emergency medical services contained in the Nevada Revised
Statutes, in particular Nevada Revised Statutes 428 and 450B, and any
amendments to these chapters are herewith adopted and incorporated into this
chapter by this reference as they come into effect; and further any pertinent
Federal laws regulating emergency medical services are also adopted. (Ord. 423,
2008)
2.54.050: REIMBURSEMENT:
   A.   All persons who receive emergency medical care from Emergency Medical
Services shall reimburse the County of White Pine in accordance with the
following rules:
      1.   Indigents: No patient in White Pine County shall be denied emergency
medical care on the basis that the patient is indigent and without other means
to pay for said services.
      2.   Reimbursement Required: The patient or responsible party will be
required to reimburse Emergency Medical Services for all services and supplies
expended in the emergency medical care of the patient, in accordance with a
reasonable fee schedule to be established by the Director and approved by
resolution of the Commissioners.
      3.   Interest: Interest and/or a carrying charge shall be assessed
against any amount incurred for emergency medical care rendered by Emergency
Medical Services due and owing for more than one hundred twenty (120) days.
      4.   Action For Small Claims: Designated Emergency Services Billing
Department shall have the power and authority in the collection of or in
soliciting or obtaining in any lawful manner the payment of a claim owed or due
or asserted to be owed or due to the County of White Pine, including, but not
limited to, instituting and maintaining an action for small claims in the
Justice Court.
      5.   Liability: The liability for any bad debts shall be borne by
Emergency Medical Services.
      6.   Liens:
         a.   If it is determined by the Commissioners to be in the best
interest of the County, a lien against the property of the patient or
responsible party may be required.
         b.   All proceedings regarding the acquisition and foreclosure of
liens shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Nevada Revised
Statutes.
         c.   Sale or foreclosure of such lien shall not be enforced against
the home of the patient or responsible party:
            (1)   During his or her lifetime or that of his or her spouse;
            (2)   During the minority of his or her children if they reside in
the home;
            (3)   During the lifetime of any dependent adult child who resides
in the home and who is incapable of self-support because of a mental or
physical disability.
         d.   Any lien taken by the County for emergency medical services shall
be released when the debt owed the County is paid.
      7.   Responsible Party:
         a.   The cost of emergency medical care rendered to a patient is a
charge against the responsible party of the patient, except that the cost of
such care shall not be charged against a responsible party who is not of
sufficient financial responsibility as determined by the County.
      8.   Installment Payments: If the Director of the designated Emergency
Services Billing Department deems it appropriate, a person against whom the
cost of care is assessed may pay in installments in such amounts and at such
intervals as approved by the Director of the designated Emergency Services
Billing Department. (Ord. 423, 2008)
2.54.060: AMBULANCE RUNS TO THE PRISON:
Patients at Ely State Prison will be brought to the loading dock of Building
10. In the event that the patient is a prisoner, at least one correctional
officer will be on the ambulance with said prisoner, and there shall be a chase
vehicle to follow the ambulance. A correctional officer will not be required if
the patient is a prison employee. In the event of multiple patients at the
prison (a mass casualty incident), the Incident Commander, with unified
command, after consultation with triage, and inmate security, may authorize
more than one patient in each ambulance for transport to hospital. (Ord. 483,
2018)
2.54.070: EMT EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENT:
In the event an EMT is required to attend court under subpoena as a witness, as
a result of his or her response to a call, said EMT shall be reimbursed by the
County for any wage loss, which may result.
White Pine County EMS shall provide or pay for any required immunizations for
EMTs.
White Pine County EMS shall pay the cost of general safety programs, which
shall include providing specialized clothing for identification and protection
of EMTs.
White Pine County shall also pay the cost of EMT certification, specialized
training programs, and attendance at approved conferences. (Ord. 423, 2008)
2.54.080: DELEGATION OF DUTIES/VESTING OF AUTHORITY:
Upon White Pine County entering into an interlocal agreement with the White
Pine County Fire District for the provision of emergency medical services
contemplated by this chapter, the Fire District shall discharge all the
Emergency Medical Services duties vested by law in the White Pine County
Department of Emergency Medical Services, including, but not limited to,
implementation, supervision, and management. Upon any future termination or
nonexistence of an interlocal agreement between the County and the Fire
District for the provision of emergency medical services; dissolution of the
Fire District; reorganization of the Fire District into an elected district or;
by majority vote of the County Commission at any regular or special meeting
lawfully convened to withdraw delegation of the duties described herein, the
duties delegated upon the Fire District by this chapter shall thereupon
automatically vest in and be discharged by the White Pine County Department of
Emergency Medical Services. (Ord. 485, 2018)
CHAPTER 2.55
AMBULANCE SERVICE FRANCHISE
SECTION:
2.55.010: Definitions
2.55.020: Geographic Area Served
2.55.030: State Permits And County Franchise Required
2.55.040: Exemptions From Franchise Requirements
2.55.050: Exclusive Nature Of Franchise
2.55.060: Application For Franchise
2.55.070: Public Hearing Required Prior To Grant Of Exclusive Franchise
2.55.080: Franchise Duration
2.55.090: Franchisee Responsibilities
2.55.100: Ambulance Fees
2.55.110: Termination Of Franchise
2.55.120: General Provisions
2.55.130: Legal Compliance
2.55.140: Special Events
2.55.150: Severability
2.55.010: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall apply to this chapter as written unless context
indicates or requires a different meaning:
AMBULANCE SERVICE Any person, governmental unit, corporation, partnership, sole
proprietorship or other entity that operates ambulances, including Rotary Wing
Air ambulances, and that holds itself out as providing prehospital care or
medical transportation to persons who are ill, injured, have disabilities, or
otherwise require or request prehospital care or medical transportation.
EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE CALL Any sudden or serious illness or injury
requiring immediate medical attention, where delay in providing such services
may aggravate the medical condition or cause the loss of life.
ENTITY Any person, governmental unit, corporation, partnership, sole
proprietorship or other similar organization.
NON-EMERGENCY MEDICAL CALL The transportation of a patient by ambulance or
Rotary Wing Air Ambulance that would not constitute an emergency medical
service call.
ROTARY WING AIR AMBULANCE Any rotary wing aircraft specially constructed,
modified, or equipped, and used for the primary purposes of responding to
emergency calls and transporting critically ill or injured patients. (Ord. 501,
2019; Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.020: GEOGRAPHIC AREA SERVED:
   A.   The Geographic Area of the Exclusive Franchise for White Pine County
shall be the boundaries of White Pine County exclusive of the area within the
Corporate Boundaries of the City of Ely.
   B.   If the Board of County Commissioners determines that a specific portion
of the County is better served by an exclusive Franchise than by the White Pine
County Ambulance Service, it may define a special Ambulance District that can
be based on the boundaries of a General Improvement District, the established
boundaries of an unincorporated town, or other designation as a Special
Ambulance Service District, and issue an exclusive Franchise to serve that
specific portion of the Count). (Ord. 501, 2019; Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.030: STATE PERMITS AND COUNTY FRANCHISE REQUIRED:
No entity shall furnish, operate, conduct, maintain, advertise, or otherwise be
engaged in or profess to be engaged in the provision of Ambulance Service
within the County outside the corporate boundary of the City of Ely, unless the
entity holds a valid permit for each ambulance used in such business or service
issued by the Nevada Department of Health and Human Services, Division of
Public and Behavioral Health, Emergency Medical Systems, and has been granted a
Franchise for the operation of such business or service by the County, pursuant
to this chapter. (Ord. 501, 2019; Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.040: EXEMPTIONS FROM FRANCHISE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Any entity requested by White Pine County to render assistance in the
case of major catastrophe, mutual aid, mutual aid agreement or interlocal
agreement, or emergency.
   B.   Any entity operated from a location or headquarters outside of the
County in order to transport patients who are picked up beyond the limits of
the County, to facilities located within the County.
   C.   Ambulances owned and operated by an agency of the United States
Government.
   D.   Ambulances owned and operated by White Pine County.
   E.   Ambulances owned by White Pine County and operated by another
government unit charged with providing emergency medical services within the
County pursuant to interlocal or mutual aid agreement.
   F.   Ambulances owned and operated by another government unit charged with
providing emergency medical services within the County pursuant to interlocal
or mutual aid agreement.
   G.   Ambulances owned by White Pine County and operated by another entity
pursuant to mutual aid agreement.
   H.   Any entity operating with the permission of the County from a location
or headquarters within the County which transports patients under circumstances
constituting a Non-Emergency Medical Call. (Ord. 501, 2019; Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.050: EXCLUSIVE NATURE OF FRANCHISE:
   A.   Any entity granted a Franchise for Ambulance Service by White Pine
County shall, for the duration of the Franchise, hold an exclusive right to be
the only entity authorized to provide the Ambulance Service in the County or
specific geographic area with the exception of entities exempted from the
franchise requirements of this Chapter pursuant to Section
2.55.040.
   B.   The franchisee, its successors or assigns shall have the privilege of
providing Ambulance Service within the provisions of this section for the
geographic area defined subject to the limitations now or hereafter provided by
law. (Ord. 501, 2019; Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.060: APPLICATION FOR FRANCHISE:
   A.   Applications for a franchise to provide ambulance service in the county
shall be made by the applicant and shall contain:
      1.   The name and address of the applicant/proposed ambulance service
provider and the owner of the ambulance(s).
      2.   The trade or other fictitious name, if any, under which the
applicant does business, along with a certified copy of an assumed name
certificate stating such name or articles of incorporation stating such name.
      3.   A resume of the training and experience of the applicant in the
transportation and care of patients.
      4.   A full description of the type and level of service to be provided
including the location of the places from which the applicant intends to
operate, the manner in which the public will be able to obtain assistance, and
how the vehicles will be dispatched. An annual audited financial statement of
the applicant as such statement pertains to the operations in the county, shall
be filed with the county within sixty (60) days following its fiscal period;
such financial statement shall be in such form and in such detail as may be
required by the county.
      5.   A description of the applicant's ability to provide service; how
many hours a day the service will be available; how many days a week the
service will be available (the county prefers twenty-four (24) hour, seven (7)
day a week service) for the area covered by the franchise applied for and an
area estimate of the minimum and maximum response time for a call within such
area.
      6.   Any information the county shall deem reasonably necessary for a
fair determination of the capability of the applicant to provide ambulance
service in the county, in accordance with the requirements of state laws and
the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   An application for an exclusive franchise for ambulance service shall
be accompanied by an application fee to be established and amended as needed by
the White Pine County Commission by resolution.
   C.   Any person or entity seeking an exclusive franchise to provide
ambulance service within White Pine County shall submit the application package
and application fee to the White Pine County Clerk. (Ord. 501, 2019; Ord. 486,
2018)
2.55.070: PUBLIC HEARING REQUIRED PRIOR TO GRANT OF EXCLUSIVE FRANCHISE:
   A.   Within thirty (30) days of receipt of an application for a Franchise,
the County shall schedule a time and place for hearing the Applicant. The
Public Hearing shall be noticed in a newspaper of general circulation within
White Pine County, twice, not less than ten (10) business days prior to the
Hearing Date and the Notice shall include the date, time, and place of the
Public Hearing, the name and address of the Applicant, the services to be
provided, and the geographic area to be served.
   B.   Notice of any application for an Ambulance Service Franchise shall be
provided to each Town Council or Area Advisory Board within the proposed
service area via certified mail no less than ten business days prior to the
Public Hearing.
   C.   The County shall cause such investigation as it may deem necessary to
be made of the Applicant and the Applicant's proposed operation.
   D.   A Franchise may be granted by the White Pine County Board of
Commissioners if the Count) finds that:
      1.   The applicant meets state standards outlined in this chapter;
      2.   The proposed service will fit within existing services so as not to
adversely affect the level of service or operations of other services within
the county;
      3.   A need exists for the proposed services in order to improve the
level of ambulance sendees available to residents of the county and that this
is a reasonable cost-effective manner of meeting the need.
   E.   Within 30 days after the public hearing, the county shall issue a
decision either granting, conditionally granting, or denying the franchise to
the applicant.
   F.   The franchise granted under this chapter shall not become effective
until a written agreement is entered into between the applicant and White Pine
County. (Ord. 501, 2019; Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.080: FRANCHISE DURATION:
The franchise shall be granted for a period of five (5) years with an option
for renewal of an additional five (5) years as an exclusive franchised service
to that person or entity offering the best and most advantageous terms to White
Pine County. (Ord. 501, 2019; Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.090: FRANCHISEE RESPONSIBILITIES:
   A.   Scope of Work: The franchise agreement shall specify the duties to be
conducted by the franchisee, its successors and assigns, and the geographic
area to be served.
   B.   Accountability: The franchisee, its successors and assigns, shall be
responsible to the White Pine County Emergency Services Coordinator or other
Count)' Official as defined in the franchise agreement.
   C.   Records: The franchisee, its successors and assigns shall be required
to keep itemized accounts of all collections received under the privileges of
this franchise, including the date the fee was charged, the amount of the fee,
the date the fee was collected, and from whom the fee was collected; and allow
the Board of County Commissioners to inspect, at all reasonable times, the
books and, records pertaining to all business done under the franchise at any
time.
   D.   County Non-liability Guarantee, Insurance: The franchisee, its
successors and assigns, shall be required to guarantee that in the exercise of
dudes under the franchise, every reasonable and proper precaution to avoid
damage or injury' to persons or property shall be used, and that the franchisee
shall, at all times and under all circumstances, hold and save the county
harmless from each and all such damage, injury, loss or expense caused or
occasioned by reason of any act or failure to act of the franchisee, its
officers, agents and employees. The franchisee, its successors and assigns,
further agrees that if the county is sued by any person or entity of any kind
to recover damages for injury to any person or property on account of actions
during performance of duties under the franchise, the franchisee, its
successors and assigns shall defend all such suits and pay all judgment or
judgments any court or courts may enter in such suits. Further, it shall be
required to provide liability insurance in an amount specified in the franchise
agreement and shall provide the county with proof of such insurance.
   E.   Franchisee Bond: The franchisee, its successors and assigns shall be
required to provide a performance bond or time certificate in the amount
specified in the franchise agreement to assure faithful performance of the
requirements of the franchise. Said bond or time certificate shall be subject
to the approval of the White Pine County District Attorney.
   F.   Administrative Fee: The franchisee, its successors and assigns shall
pay to the county an annual administrative fee to be specified in the franchise
agreement to cover the county's costs to administer and monitor the franchise
agreement.
   G.   Any entity exempted from the franchise requirements of this Chapter
pursuant to Section
2.55.040 shall be required to comply with the provisions of this Section prior
to operation as though the entity was granted a franchise. (Ord. 501, 2019;
Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.100: AMBULANCE FEES:
   A.   The franchise agreement shall specify the maximum fees that can be
charged for services.
   B.   Amendments to the fees specified in the franchise agreement must be
approved by the County Commission by resolution and only following a public
hearing.
   C.   Any entity exempted from the franchise requirements of this chapter
pursuant to Section
2.55.040 shall provide a fee schedule to the county prior to operation. The
County Commission shall specify the maximum fees that can be charged for
services. Amendments to the fees specified in the provided schedule must be
approved by a majority vote of the County Commission following a public hearing
at any regular or special meeting lawfully convened. (Ord. 501, 2019; Ord. 486,
2018)
2.55.110: TERMINATION OF FRANCHISE:
The franchisee, its successors and assigns, shall be required to agree that in
the event the franchisee fails to perform any condition of the franchise, or
fails to abide by all laws, rules and regulations pertaining to the franchise,
or becomes bankrupt or insolvent, the county shall have the right to terminate
the franchise and the franchise agreement so awarded if the franchisee fails to
correct the deficiency within thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice
from the county. (Ord. 501, 2019; Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.120: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   This franchise shall be subject to the provisions of the United States
and Nevada Constitutions, the laws of the State and all ordinances enacted by
White Pine County, Nevada.
   B.   Franchisee shall not hire, assign, delegate, subcontract or otherwise
confer upon any other entity, its ability to provide ambulance services or
otherwise operate pursuant to this chapter without the written consent of the
Board of County Commissioners being first had and obtained.
   C.   No entity exempted from the franchise requirements of this chapter
pursuant to Section
2.55.040 may hire, assign, delegate, subcontract or otherwise confer upon any
other entity, its ability to provide ambulance services or otherwise operate
under this chapter without the written consent of the Board of County
Commissioners being first had and obtained.
   D.   The county reserves the right to alter and amend this chapter in any
manner necessary for the safety or welfare of the public, or to protect public
interests, and to cancel the franchise for failure to perform in accordance
with this chapter and the franchise agreement. (Ord. 501, 2019; Ord. 486,
2018)ety or welfare of the public, or to protect public interests, and to
cancel the franchise for failure to perform in accordance with this chapter and
the franchise agreement. (Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.130: LEGAL COMPLIANCE:
Franchisee, its successors and assigns, and/or any entity exempted from the
franchise requirements of this chapter pursuant to Section
2.55.040 shall comply at all times with the requirements of this chapter, the
franchise granted pursuant to this chapter, the franchise agreement, and all
applicable state and local laws relating to health, sanitation, safety,
equipment, ambulance design, and all other laws and ordinances. (Ord. 501,
2019; Ord. 486, 2018)
2.55.140: SPECIAL EVENTS:
   A.   An entity may provide ambulance service for special events within the
County upon majority vote of the County Commission at any regular or special
meeting lawfully convened. The County Commission retains the right to set the
terms and conditions of any such temporary special event franchise, including
the fees to be charged.
   B.   No entity exempted from the franchise requirements of this chapter
pursuant to Section
2.55.040 may provide ambulance services for special events within the County
without complying without first complying with White Pine County Code Section
2.55.140(A). (Ord. 501, 2019)
2.55.150: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this chapter is held to be invalid, such invalidity shall
not affect the remaining provisions of this chapter and each such provision
shall be declared to be severable. (Ord. 501, 2019)
CHAPTER 2.56
WHITE PINE COUNTY GOLF COURSE ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
2.56.010: Establishment
2.56.020: Membership
2.56.030: Terms Of Office, Removal And Vacancies
2.56.040: Compensation And Expenses
2.56.050: Chairman And Officers
2.56.060: Expenditures
2.56.070: Meetings, Rules And Records
2.56.080: Duties
2.56.090: Reports And Recommendations
2.56.010: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby established a White Pine County golf course advisory board
pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 200.1945 as an advisory board to assist the
board of county commissioners of White Pine County regarding the operation,
management, improvement and maintenance of the White Pine County Golf Course
and any other matters relating thereto. (Ord. 378 §1, 2002)
2.56.020: MEMBERSHIP:
The White Pine County golf course advisory board shall consist of five (5)
members who shall be appointed by the board of county commissioners. Membership
of the advisory board shall include one person from each of the following:
White Pine County Men's Golf Association, White Pine County Women's Golf
Association, owner or manager of a business located in White Pine County, the
other one will be at large. One member of the tourism and recreation board not
a commissioner. (Ord. 378 §1, 2002)
2.56.030: TERMS OF OFFICE, REMOVAL AND VACANCIES:
The term of office for the members of the golf course advisory board shall be
four (4) years and shall expire on December 31 of their respective years. The
terms of the members shall be overlapping and the membership of the golf course
advisory board first appointed shall include two (2) members who shall serve
until December 31, 2006, one member who shall serve until December 31, 2005,
one member who shall serve until December 31, 2004, and one member who shall
serve until December 31, 2003.
Members may be removed, after a public hearing if requested, by a majority vote
of the board of county commissioners of White Pine County.
Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of term of office
shall be filled for the unexpired term. (Ord. 378 §1, 2002)
2.56.040: COMPENSATION AND EXPENSES:
Members of the golf course advisory board shall serve without compensation,
except for reasonable travel expenses made necessary in the fulfillment in the
ordinary course of their official duties, with prior approval from the board of
county commissioners. (Ord. 378 §1, 2002)
2.56.050: CHAIRMAN AND OFFICERS:
The golf course advisory board shall elect its chairman from among the
appointed members, and the term of such elected chairman shall be one year,
with eligibility for reelection to successive terms.
The advisory board shall create and fill such other offices as it may deem
necessary. (Ord. 378 §1, 2002)
2.56.060: EXPENDITURES:
The expenditure of the golf course advisory board, exclusive of any gifts
received by it, shall be subject to, and within, the amounts appropriated for
that purpose by the board of county commissioners, which shall provide the
funds, equipment and accommodations necessary for the golf course advisory
board. (Ord. 378 §1, 2002)
2.56.070: MEETINGS, RULES AND RECORDS:
The golf course advisory board shall hold meetings as circumstances may require
or render necessary for the performance of its functions and the proper
discharge of its duties and responsibilities. A majority of the membership
shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of transacting business. Action by
the advisory board shall be by majority vote.
The advisory board shall adopt rules and regulations for the conduct of its
business, subject to the approval of the board of county commissioners.
The advisory board shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions,
findings and determinations which records shall be a public record. The board
will comply with the Nevada open meetings law. (Ord. 378 §1, 2002)
2.56.080: DUTIES:
The golf course advisory board shall serve as an advisory board to assist the
board of county commissioners regarding operation, management, improvement,
maintenance and promotion of the White Pine County Golf Course. (Ord. 378 §1,
2002)
2.56.090: REPORTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS:
The golf course advisory board shall make a report of its findings,
determinations or recommendations to the board of county commissioners on all
matters considered by said advisory board, for final action or disposition by
said board of county commissioners, as may be authorized under applicable law
or ordinance.
No recommendation of the advisory board on the golf course shall be binding on
the county or the board of county commissioners. (Ord. 378 §1, 2002)
CHAPTER 2.60
COUNTY DEPARTMENT OF WELFARE
SECTION:
2.60.010: Established
2.60.020: Definitions
2.60.030: Duties Of The Welfare Director
2.60.040: Eligibility For Medical Care And Financial Assistance
2.60.050: Extent Of County Medical Care
2.60.060: Reimbursement
2.60.070: Fraud
2.60.080: Rules And Regulations
2.60.085: Denial Of Medical Assistance And Right To Appeal
2.60.010: ESTABLISHED:
There is created a county department of welfare which shall consist of a
director of public welfare and such other employees as are hereinafter
authorized. (Ord. 156 §1, 1983)
2.60.020: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
COMMISSIONERS: The White Pine County board of county commissioners.
DIRECTOR: The director of the White Pine County department of welfare.
EMERGENCY MEDICAL CARE: Any care for an urgent medical condition, which is
likely to result in serious and permanent bodily disability or death.
HOSPITAL: Any facility licensed as a medical, surgical or obstetrical hospital,
or as any combination of medical, surgical or obstetrical hospital, by the
health division of the department of human resources.
HOSPITAL CARE: A. Services furnished by a hospital to a patient between the
time of his admission and the time of his discharge, including:
      1.   Bed and board,
      2.   Drugs,
      3.   Anesthesia, nursing services, equipment, supplies and laboratory and
radiological services, whether furnished directly by the hospital or pursuant
to a contractual arrangement made by the hospital, and
      4.   Services of a physician rendered to a patient in a hospital between
the time of his admission and the time of his discharge.
HOUSEHOLD: All persons residing together who are related by birth or marriage.
INCOME TEST: A. Sufficient Funds: A person does not have sufficient funds if
the gross monthly income of the household is less than that set forth under the
definition of "indigent". Income includes, but is not limited to:
      1.   The entire income of a household and a reasonable amount which the
department projects a person or household is able to earn,
      2.   Wages or anticipated earnings for the household unit,
      3.   Trust income, retirement or disability income, or any type of
governmental benefits or subsidies,
      4.   Family contributions or income shared by persons living together out
of wedlock, and
      5.   Loaned income;
   B.   Other Factors: Even if a person does not meet the income test, he may
be eligible if it is determined by the director that he does not have
sufficient funds to pay for all or part of his medical care by reason of the
following:
      1.   Nature of the disability,
      2.   Estimated length of hospitalization,
      3.   Estimated elapsed time before employed person may return to work,
      4.   Effect of the disability, if any, on future income production.
INDIGENT: Those persons:
   A.   Who are not covered by any policy of health insurance;
   B.   Who are ineligible for medicare, medicaid, or any other federal or
state program of public assistance covering the provision of healthcare; and
   C.   Whose gross monthly income as defined in "income test" of this section
is less than:
      1.   For one person living without another member of a household, four
hundred thirty eight dollars ($438.00),
      2.   For two (2) persons, five hundred eighty eight dollars ($588.00),
      3.   For three (3) or more persons, five hundred eighty eight dollars
($588.00), plus one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each person in the
household in excess of two (2).
INJURY IN MOTOR VEHICLE ACCIDENT: Any personal injury accidentally caused in,
by or as the proximate result of the movement of a motor vehicle on a public
street or highway, whether the injured person was the operator of the vehicle
or another vehicle, a passenger in the vehicle, a pedestrian, or had some other
relationship to the movement of a vehicle.
MEDICAID: The program established pursuant to title XIX of the social security
act to provide assistance for part or all of the cost of medical care rendered
on behalf of indigent persons.
MEDICARE: The program of health insurance for aged and disabled persons
established pursuant to title XVIII of the social security act.
PAUPER: One who falls into distress and stands in need of immediate relief.
PERSONAL ASSETS: A. Included Assets: "Personal assets" include, but are not
limited to, the following:
      1.   Fair market value of real property (less encumbrances),
      2.   Cash, stocks, bonds, trust funds, bank accounts, other negotiable
instruments,
      3.   Life insurance policies with cash value. Burial policies and burial
plots are not considered when determining assets,
      4.   Nonessential vehicles, livestock, trailers, boats, etc.,
      5.   Any resources not listed above which are considered assets under
U.S. bankruptcy court provisions.
   B.   Allowable Amounts Of Personal Assets: An applicant is allowed the
amount of personal assets specified in the applicable department rules and
regulations.
   C.   Liquidation Of Assets: Applicants for and recipients of county
assistance programs may not release assets to meet eligibility requirements.
      1.   Sale Of Primary Residence: A family disposing of its primary
residence while receiving aid must reinvest total revenue into a new family
residence within six (6) months. Proof shall be supplied by the recipient at
each certification that the asset remains intact,
      2.   Payments Not Reinvested: Lump sum payments (social security,
insurance settlements, etc.) or proceeds from the sale of the primary residence
within one year prior to application date, or at any time after application
date, that are not reinvested in purchase of a new family dwelling, will be
assumed to be available for meeting family living expenses. A period of
ineligibility will be computed from the date such monies are received, reducing
such proceeds by monthly living expenses, reduced by other family income
allowed in standard of need. The only exception would be proof that legally
enforceable debts were paid with the proceeds,
      3.   Sale Of Other Property: Proceeds from the sale of other real
property is considered an asset,
      4.   Divested Assets: Any asset divested by an applicant or by a
recipient of county assistance within one year prior to application date, or at
any time after application date may be considered as a personal asset in
calculating eligibility.
RESIDENT OR RESIDENCE: Shall not be based upon any specific length of time a
person has lived in the state or county, but shall be determined as follows:
   A.   Residence is established by actual physical presence in the county,
coupled with a bona fide intent to permanently reside in the county.
   B.   Factors bearing on a finding of bona fide intent include, but are not
limited to, the following:
      1.   Registration to vote in the county,
      2.   Purchase of property in the county,
      3.   Local registration of vehicles,
      4.   Length and type of employment in the county,
      5.   Length of physical presence in the county.
   C.   If by the foregoing criteria or statutory or judicial mandate a person
is deemed a resident of another county for eligibility purposes, appropriate
notice shall be given to the client and that county, of their responsibility.
   D.   Questions of residency which cannot be decided by the department on the
foregoing criteria shall be referred to the board of county commissioners whose
decision shall be final.
   E.   When an application is made by any person to the department for medical
assistance, that person is required to submit a written statement that he is or
intends to become a resident of the county.
STATE BOARD OF TRUSTEES: The board of trustees of the state fund for hospital
care to indigents pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 484.125 and 428.195.
WELFARE DEPARTMENT: The White Pine County department of welfare. (Ord. 229 §1
(part), 1989: Ord. 221 §1(part), 1988: Ord. 156 §2, 1983)
2.60.030: DUTIES OF THE WELFARE DIRECTOR:
   A.   A welfare director shall be appointed by the commissioners, who under
the direct supervision of the commissioners, shall discharge all those duties
and administer all such programs as the commissioners may from time to time
delegate to the director. Such duties and administrative responsibilities shall
be restricted to those which under the various state laws of Nevada pertaining
to welfare matters are made the responsibility of the counties and which can be
lawfully delegated by the boards of county commissioners to appointed or
elected officials of such counties. The welfare director shall serve at the
will of the commissioners, and at a salary to be fixed by them. The welfare
director shall have the authority to make decisions regarding disposition of
funds budgeted for the county department of welfare.
   B.   The welfare director shall have the authority to act and make decisions
in emergency situations without the prior approval of the commissioners.
   C.   The welfare department is expressly authorized to exercise those powers
and perform those duties granted to the board of county commissioners under
Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 428. (Ord. 156 §3, 1983)
2.60.040: ELIGIBILITY FOR MEDICAL CARE AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE:
   A.   A person is eligible for medical assistance if the applicant fulfills
all of the following conditions:
      1.   Applicants for the program shall place with the department a
declaration of need and full disclosure of financial and family status,
demonstrating a factual need. The form of this declaration shall be provided by
the department.
      2.   Applicants for county assistance shall, by signed authorization,
permit the department to verify pertinent financial and medical information for
the purpose of determining eligibility. Failure to submit information that will
permit a reasonable investigation and cooperate with the department to verify
need shall result in a denial of aid.
      3.   A declaration of need shall state, and the director shall determine
that:
         a.   Applicant has no funds to pay for all or part of his medical
care, or meets the "income test" as defined herein;
         b.   Applicant is a resident, as defined herein, of the county;
         c.   Applicant is an "indigent", as defined herein;
         d.   Applicant has no relatives of sufficient ability to care for and
maintain him or has relatives but they refuse or neglect to care for and
maintain him;
         e.   That applicant is not receiving adequate aid or assistance from
state or federal medical care programs; and
         f.   That applicant is in need of medically necessary or emergency
medical care. (Ord. 221 §1(part), 1988: Ord. 156 §4, 1983)
2.60.050: EXTENT OF COUNTY MEDICAL CARE:
   A.   General: Medical care shall be rendered to eligible persons to the
extent of available funding and subject to the conditions set forth in this
section, as determined by the director.
   B.   Extent: Medical care as is necessary for the health and safety of an
eligible person shall be provided at facilities within White Pine County first,
if available.
   C.   Prior Approval: Medical care may be rendered at places other than
facilities within the county only upon prior approval of the welfare director.
   D.   Outside State: Medical care may be rendered at places outside the state
only under extraordinary situations and upon prior approval by the welfare
director.
   E.   Deductibles: The county shall not be responsible for insurance
deductibles or copayment amounts required under any type of insurance coverage.
(Ord. 229 §1(part), 1989: Ord. 221 §1(part), 1988: Ord. 156 §5, 1984)
2.60.060: REIMBURSEMENT:
As a condition of such care an eligible person shall reimburse the county of
White Pine in accordance with the following rules:
   A.   Financial Ability: The applicant or other responsible party will be
required to reimburse the welfare department for that portion of the medical
expenses that fall within his financial ability.
   B.   Property: If a person who has received care acquires property or
otherwise ceases to be eligible, the cost of care shall be a charge against him
to the extent such cost exceeds his eligibility.
   C.   Interest: No interest or carrying charge shall be charged in connection
with any debt incurred for county hospital care.
   D.   Liens:
      1.   If it is determined by the welfare department to be in the best
interest of the county, a lien against the property of the patient or
responsible relative may be required.
      2.   Sale or foreclosure of such lien shall not be enforced against the
home of the eligible person or his responsible relative:
         a.   During his lifetime or that of his spouse,
         b.   During the minority of his children if they reside in the home,
         c.   During the lifetime of any dependent adult child who resides in
the home and who is incapable of self-support because of mental or physical
disability.
      3.   Any lien taken by the county for county hospital care shall be
released immediately when the amount owing the county for that care is paid.
      4.   If a person against whose home a lien has been imposed for county
hospital care desires to acquire a different home, the county may release its
lien against the original home and transfer it to the new home if its security
will not thereby be impaired.
      5.   If the person desires to borrow money for the purpose of making
improvements to his home, using his home for security, the county may
subordinate its lien to the mortgage or other security interest given for the
loan if its security will not thereby be impaired.
   E.   Responsible Relatives:
      1.   The cost of care rendered to a person is a charge against the
responsible relative of that person in accordance with the following rules.
      2.   A responsible relative is a spouse, parent, child, or sibling of
that person to whom aid is rendered.
      3.   The cost of such care shall not be a charge against a responsible
relative who is a recipient of public assistance or is eligible for a federal
or state medical care program.
   F.   Installment Payments: If the director deems it appropriate, a person
against whom the cost of care is a charge may pay in installments in such
amounts and at such intervals as approved by the director. (Ord. 156 §6, 1983)
2.60.070: FRAUD:
   A.   In cases where it appears the applicant or responsible relative has
conveyed away property prior to application or anytime thereafter, the welfare
department shall determine as soon as possible whether or not the transfer in
effect makes the person a public charge. In such case, the county may then
proceed against responsible relatives or other parties involved to recover the
expenses incurred by the county.
   B.   If any applicant should attempt to secure aid or assistance under this
chapter by wilfully giving false information about his medical or financial
condition, such action shall constitute a misdemeanor offense. (Ord. 156 §7,
1983)
2.60.080: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The welfare department shall have the duty and the right to establish such
other rules and regulations, or to amend existing rules and regulations, as it
may from time to time find necessary in order to give the provisions of this
chapter full force and effect. Such new rules and regulations shall have the
force and effect of law when their adoption is ordered by the commissioners and
placed on file with the clerk thereof. (Ord. 156 §8, 1983)
2.60.085: DENIAL OF MEDICAL ASSISTANCE AND RIGHT TO APPEAL:
   A.   Any applicant who has been denied assistance by the department has the
right to appeal that decision to the board of county commissioners of the
county within thirty (30) days from the date of issuance of the denial letter.
   B.   An appeal shall be made by delivering a written notice of appeal to the
board of county commissioners which specifies the date the denial was issued,
the name of the person who is appealing, and a copy of the denial letter. If
the person who appeals seeks an evidentiary hearing before the board of county
commissioners, the notice of appeal shall include such a request. Failure to
timely deliver the required notice of appeal waives any right to an appeal or
hearing.
   C.   Upon request of a notice of appeal and request for hearing, the board
of county commissioners shall set a time and date for a hearing on the matter.
Written notice of the time and date of the hearing shall be mailed or delivered
to the appellant at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing date. At the
hearing all relevant and material evidence regarding the appellant's medical
and financial status shall be considered. Copies of all documents, reports and
applicable law to be presented at the hearing shall be delivered to the board
of county commissioners at least five (5) days before the hearing.
   D.   Any employee or other representative of the county who investigated or
made the initial decision to deny assistance shall not participate in any
decision made pursuant to the hearing.
   E.   The board of county commissioners shall render a written decision which
sets forth the factual basis for the decision and the applicable law, ordinance
or regulation. A copy of the decision shall be served personally or by
certified mail upon each party and his representative. A person aggrieved by
the final decision of the board of county commissioners may, within thirty (30)
days after the date on which the written notice of the decision is served or
mailed, petition the district court where he resides to review the decision.
The court shall review the decision on the record of the case before the
county, a copy of which must be certified as correct by the county and filed
with the court as part of its answer to the petition. The costs of transcribing
and preparing the record on appeal to the district court shall be paid by the
appellant prior to said record being filed with the district court.
   F.   Before the date set by the court for a hearing, an application may be
made to the court by motion, with notice to the opposing party and an
opportunity for that party to respond, for leave to present additional
evidence. If it is shown to the satisfaction of the court that the additional
evidence is material and that there were good reasons for failure to present it
in the proceeding before the county, the court may order that the additional
evidence be taken before the county upon conditions determined by the court.
The county may modify its findings and decisions by reason of the additional
evidence and any modifications, new findings or decisions with the reviewing
court.
   G.   The review must be conducted by the court without a jury and must be
confined to the record. The court, at the request of a party, may hear oral
arguments and receive written briefs.
   H.   The court shall not substitute its judgment for that of the county as
to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact. The court may affirm the
decision of the county or remand the case for further proceedings. The court
may reverse the decision and remand the case to the county for further
proceedings if it determines that substantial rights of the appellant have been
prejudiced because the county's findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions
are:
      1.   In violation of constitutional, statutory or regulatory provisions;
      2.   In excess of the statutory authority of the county;
      3.   Made in accordance with an unlawful procedure;
      4.   Affected by other errors of law;
      5.   Clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial
evidence on the whole record; or
      6.   Arbitrary and capricious.
   I.   An aggrieved party may appeal any final judgment of the district court
to the supreme court in the same manner as a civil case. (Ord. 229 §1, 1989:
Ord. 221 §1, 1988)
