month following the period for which the amount is proposed to be determined.
   B.   The limitation specified in this section does not apply in case of a
sales tax proposed to be determined with respect to sales of property for the
storage, use or other consumption of which notice of a deficiency determination
has been or is given pursuant to sections
3.24.445,
 3.24.475 and
3.24.485 of this chapter, and to subsection A of this section. The limitation
specified in this section does not apply in case of an amount of use tax
proposed to be determined with respect to storage, use or other consumption of
property for the sale of which notice of a deficiency determination has been or
is given pursuant to sections
3.24.445,
3.24.475 and
 3.24.485 of this chapter, and to subsection A of this section.
   C.   If, before the expiration of the time prescribed in this section for
the mailing of a notice of deficiency determination, the taxpayer has consented
in writing to the mailing of the notice after that time, the notice may be
mailed at any time before the expiration of the period agreed upon. The period
so agreed upon may be extended by subsequent agreements in writing made before
the expiration of the period previously agreed upon. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.089),
1987)
ARTICLE VIII. DETERMINATIONS WHERE NO RETURN MADE
3.24.455: DETERMINATION IF NO RETURN MADE; ESTIMATE AND COMPUTATION;
DISCONTINUANCE OF BUSINESS:
   A.   If any person fails to make a return, the department shall make an
estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the person, or, as the case may
be, of the amount of the total sales price of tangible personal property sold
or purchased by the person, the storage, use or other consumption of which in
the county is subject to the use tax. The estimate shall be made for the period
or periods in respect to which the person failed to make a return and shall be
based upon any information which is in the department's possession or may come
into its possession. Upon the basis of this estimate, the department shall
compute and determine the amount required to be paid to the county, adding to
the sum thus arrived at a penalty equal to ten percent (10%) thereof. One or
more determinations may be made for one or for more than one period.
   B.   When a business is discontinued, a determination may be made at any
time thereafter within the periods specified in section
3.24.450 of this chapter as to liability arising out of that business,
irrespective of whether the determination is issued prior to the due date of
the liability as otherwise specified in sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.090), 1987)
3.24.460: OFFSETS; COMPUTATION; INTEREST:
   A.   In making a determination, the department may offset overpayments for a
period or periods, together with interest on the overpayments, against
underpayments for another period or periods, against penalties, and against the
interest on the underpayments.
   B.   The interest on underpayments and overpayments shall be computed in the
manner set forth in sections
3.24.525 and
3.24.680 of this chapter. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.091), 1987)
3.24.465: INTEREST ON AMOUNT OF DETERMINATION:
The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, bears interest at the
rate of 1.5 percent per month, or fraction of a month, from the last day of the
month following the period for which the amount, or any portion of it, should
have been returned until the date of payment. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.092), 1987)
3.24.470: PENALTIES FOR FRAUD, INTENT TO EVADE:
If the failure of any person to file a return is due to fraud or intent to
evade sections
 3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, or rules and regulations, a penalty of twenty five
percent (25%) of the amount required to be paid by the person, exclusive of
penalties, shall be added thereto in addition to the ten percent (10%) penalty
provided in section
3.24.455 of this chapter. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.093), 1987)
3.24.475: NOTICE OF ESTIMATE, DETERMINATION AND PENALTY; SERVICE:
Promptly after making its determination, the department shall give to the
person written notice of the estimate, determination and penalty, the notice to
be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice
of a deficiency determination. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.094), 1987)
ARTICLE IX. JEOPARDY DETERMINATIONS
3.24.480: JEOPARDY DETERMINATION; WHEN MADE; DUE DATE:
If the tax commission believes that the collection of any tax or any amount of
tax required to be collected and paid to the county or of any determination
will be jeopardized by delay, it shall thereupon make a determination of the
tax or amount of tax required to be collected, noting the fact upon the
determination. The amount determined is due and payable immediately. (Ord. 196
§1(3.24.095), 1987)
3.24.485: NONPAYMENT; FINALITY OF DETERMINATION:
If the amount specified in the determination is not paid within ten (10) days
after service of notice thereof upon the person against whom the determination
is made, the amount becomes final at the expiration of the ten (10) days,
unless a petition for redetermination is filed within the ten (10) days, and
the delinquency penalty and the interest provided in section
 3.24.525 of this chapter shall attach to the amount of the tax or the amount
of the tax required to be collected. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.096), 1987)
3.24.490: PETITION FOR REDETERMINATION; DEPOSIT OF SECURITY:
The person against whom a jeopardy determination is made may petition for the
redetermination thereof pursuant to this section and sections
3.24.495 through
3.24.520 of this chapter. He shall, however, file the petition for
redetermination with the department within ten (10) days after the service upon
him of notice of determination. The person shall also within the ten (10) day
period deposit with the department such security as it may deem necessary to
ensure compliance with sections
3.24.010 through
3.24.825 of this chapter. The security may be sold by the department in the
manner prescribed by section
3.24.530 of this chapter. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.097), 1987)
ARTICLE X. REDETERMINATIONS
3.24.495: PETITION FOR REDETERMINATION; TIME TO FILE:
   A.   Any person against whom a determination is made under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.470 of this chapter, or any person directly interested, may petition for a
redetermination within thirty (30) days after service upon the person of notice
thereof.
   B.   If a petition for redetermination is not filed within the thirty (30)
day period, the determination becomes final at the expiration of the period.
(Ord. 196 §1(3.24.098), 1987)
3.24.500: ORAL HEARING; NOTICE; CONTINUANCES:
   A.   If a petition for redetermination is filed within the thirty (30) day
period, the department shall reconsider the determination and, if the person
has so requested in his petition, shall grant the person an oral hearing and
shall give him ten (10) days' notice of the time and place of the hearing.
   B.   The department may continue the hearing from time to time as may be
necessary. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.099), 1987)
3.24.505: INCREASE, DECREASE OF AMOUNT OF DETERMINATION:
The department may decrease or increase the amount of the determination before
it becomes final, but the amount may be increased only if a claim for the
increase is asserted by the department at or before the hearing. (Ord. 196 §1
(3.24.100), 1987)
3.24.510: ORDER OF DEPARTMENT ON PETITION FOR REDETERMINATION; FINALITY OF
ORDER:
The order or decision of the department upon a petition for redetermination
becomes final thirty (30) days after service upon the petitioner of notice
thereof. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.101), 1987)
3.24.515: DUE DATE OF DETERMINATIONS; PENALTIES:
All determinations made by the department under sections
3.24.420 through
3.24.475 of this chapter, are due and payable at the time they become final. If
they are not paid when due and payable, a penalty of ten percent (10%) of the
amount of the determination, exclusive of interest and penalties, shall be
added thereto. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.102), 1987)
3.24.520: SERVICE OF NOTICE:
Any notice required by sections
3.24.495 through
3.24.510 of this chapter, shall be served personally or by mail in the manner
prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. (Ord. 196 §1
(3.24.103), 1987)
ARTICLE XI. INTEREST AND PENALTIES
3.24.525: PENALTY, INTEREST FOR FAILURE TO PAY TAX; AMOUNT; RATES:
Any person who fails to pay any tax to the county or any amount of tax required
to be collected and paid to the county, except amount of determinations made by
the department under sections
3.24.420 through
3.24.475 of this chapter, within the time required shall pay a penalty of not
more than ten percent (10%) of the tax or amount of the tax, as determined by
the department, in addition to the tax or amount of tax, plus interest at the
rate of 1.5 percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date on which the
tax or the amount of tax required to be collected became due and payable to the
county until the date of payment. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.104), 1987)
3.24.530: DEPOSIT OF SECURITY; AMOUNT; SALES OF SECURITY; RETURN OF SURPLUS:
   A.   The department, whenever it deems it necessary to ensure compliance
with sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, may require any person subject to those sections to
place with it such security as the department may determine. The amount of the
security must be fixed by the department but, except as noted below, may not be
greater than twice the estimated average liability of persons filing returns
for quarterly periods or three (3) times the estimated average liability of
persons filing returns for monthly periods, determined in such manner as the
department deems proper, or five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), whichever amount
is the lesser.
   B.   In case of persons habitually delinquent in their obligations under
sections
 3.24.015 through
 3.24.825 of this chapter, the amount of the security must not be greater than
three (3) times the average liability of persons filing returns for quarterly
periods or five (5) times the average liability of persons filing returns for
monthly periods, or five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), whichever amount is the
lesser.
   C.   The limitations provided in this section apply regardless of the type
of security placed with the department.
   D.   The amount of the security may be increased or decreased by the
department subject to the limitations in this section.
   E.   The department may sell the security at public auction if it becomes
necessary to recover any tax or any amount required to be collected, interest
or penalty due. Notice of the sale may be served upon the person who placed the
security personally or by mail; if by mail, service must be made in the manner
prescribed for service of a notice of a deficiency determination and must be
addressed to the person at his address as it appears in the records of the
department. Security in the form of a bearer bond issued by the United States
or the state of Nevada which has a prevailing market price may be sold by the
department at a private sale at a price not lower than the prevailing market
price.
   F.   Upon any sale, any surplus above the amount due must be returned to the
person who placed the security. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.105), 1987)
3.24.535: NOTICE OF DELINQUENCY TO PERSONS HOLDING CREDITS OR PROPERTY OF
DELINQUENT; TRANSFER OR DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY OR DEBT AFTER NOTICE; BANK
DEPOSITS:
   A.   If any person is delinquent in the payment of the amount required to be
paid by him or in the event a determination has been made against him which
remains unpaid, the department may, not later than three (3) years after the
payment became delinquent, or within three (3) years after the last recording
of an abstract under section
3.24.575 of this chapter, or of a certificate under section
3.24.590 of this chapter, give notice thereof personally or by registered or
certified mail to all persons, including any officer or department of the state
or any political subdivision or agency of the state, having in their possession
or under their control any credits or other personal property belonging to the
delinquent, or owing any debts to the delinquent or person against whom a
determination has been made which remains unpaid, or owing any debts to the
delinquent or such person. In the case of any state officer, department or
agency, the notice shall be given to such officer, department or agency prior
to the time it presents the claim of the delinquent taxpayer to the state
controller.
   B.   After receiving the notice, the persons so notified shall neither
transfer nor make any other disposition of the credits, other personal
property, or debts in their possession or under their control at the time they
received the notice until the department consents to a transfer or disposition,
or until sixty (60) days elapse after the receipt of the notice, whichever
period expires earlier.
   C.   All persons so notified shall, within ten (10) days after receipt of
the notice, advise the department of all such credits, other personal property,
or debts in their possession, under their control, or owing by them.
   D.   If such notice seeks to prevent the transfer or other disposition of a
deposit in a bank or other credits or personal property in the possession or
under the control of a bank, the notice to be effective shall be delivered or
mailed to the branch or office of such bank at which such deposit is carried or
at which such credits or personal property is held.
   E.   If, during the effective period of the notice to withhold, any person
so notified makes any transfer or disposition of the property or debts required
to be withheld hereunder, to the extent of the value of the property or the
amount of the debts thus transferred or paid, he shall be liable to the county
for any indebtedness due under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, from the person with respect to whose obligation the
notice was given if solely by reason of such transfer or disposition the county
is unable to recover the indebtedness of the person with respect to whose
obligation the notice is given. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.106), 1987)
ARTICLE XII. SUIT FOR THE TAX
3.24.540: ACTION FOR COLLECTION OF TAX, PENALTIES, INTEREST; LIMITATION:
At any time within three (3) years after any tax or any amount of tax required
to be collected becomes due and payable, and at any time within three (3) years
after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected,
or within three (3) years after the last recording of an abstract under section
3.24.575 of this chapter, or of a certificate under section
3.24.590 of this chapter, the department may bring an action in the courts of
this state, or any other state, or of the United States, in the name of the
county to collect the amount delinquent together with penalties and interest.
(Ord. 196 §1(3.24.107), 1987)
3.24.545: ATTORNEY GENERAL TO PROSECUTE ACTION; PROVISIONS OF NEVADA REVISED
STATUTES, NRCP, NRAP, APPLICABLE:
The attorney general, on behalf of the county, shall prosecute the action, and
the provisions of Nevada Revised Statutes and the Nevada rules of civil
procedure and Nevada rules of appellate procedure relating to service of
summons, pleadings, proofs, trials and appeals are applicable to the
proceedings. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.108), 1987)
3.24.550: ISSUANCE OF WRIT OF ATTACHMENT WITHOUT BOND, AFFIDAVIT:
In the action a writ of attachment may issue, and no bond or affidavit previous
to the issuing of the attachment is required. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.109), 1987)
3.24.555: EVIDENTIARY EFFECT OF DELINQUENCY CERTIFICATE:
In the action a certificate by the department showing the delinquency shall be
prima facie evidence of the determination of the tax or the amount of the tax,
of the delinquency of the amounts set forth, and of the compliance by the
department with all provisions of sections
3.24.015 through
 3.24.825 of this chapter, in relation to the computation and determination of
the amount. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.110), 1987)
3.24.560: ACTION FOR USE TAX; MANNER OF SERVICE OF PROCESS:
In any action relating to the use tax brought under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, process may be served according to the Nevada rules
of civil procedure or may be served upon any agent or clerk in this state
employed by any retailer in a place of business maintained by the retailer in
this state. In the latter case a copy of the process shall forthwith be sent by
registered or certified mail to the retailer at his principal or home office.
(Ord. 196 §1(3.24.111), 1987)
ARTICLE XIII. JUDGMENT FOR THE TAX
3.24.565: APPLICATION FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT; FILING OF CERTIFICATE OF
DELINQUENCY:
If any amount required to be paid to the county under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, is not paid when due, the department may, within
three (3) years after the amount is due, file in the office of the county clerk
of the county a certificate specifying the amount required to be paid, interest
and penalty due, the name and address as it appears on the records of the
department of the person liable, the compliance of the department with sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, in relation to the determination of the amount
required to be paid, and a request that judgment be entered against the person
in the amount required to be paid, together with interest and penalty as set
forth in the certificate. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.112), 1987)
3.24.570: ENTRY OF JUDGMENT BY COUNTY CLERK:
The county clerk immediately upon the filing of the certificate shall enter a
judgment for the county against the person in the amount required to be paid,
together with interest and penalty as set forth in the certificate. (Ord. 196
§1(3.24.113), 1987)
3.24.575: FILING OF ABSTRACT, COPY OF JUDGMENT WITH COUNTY CLERK; JUDGMENT
LIEN; DURATION AND EXTENSION:
   A.   An abstract of the judgment or a copy may be filed for record with the
county recorder of any county.
   B.   From the time of the filing, the amount required to be paid, together
with interest and penalty set forth, constitutes a lien upon all the real
property in the county where it is filed which is owned by the person liable or
afterwards and before the lien expires acquired by him. The lien has the force,
effect and priority of a judgment so entered by the county clerk unless sooner
released or otherwise discharged.
   C.   The lien may, within five (5) years from the date of the judgment or
within five (5) years from the date of the last extension of the lien in the
manner herein provided, be extended by filing for record in the office of the
county recorder of any county, an abstract or copy of the judgment, and from
the time of such filing, the lien shall be extended to the real property in
such county for five (5) years, unless sooner released or otherwise discharged.
(Ord. 196 §1(3.24.114), 1987)
3.24.580: EXECUTION; ISSUANCE; SALE:
Execution shall issue upon the judgment upon request of the department in the
same manner as execution may issue upon other judgments, and sales shall be
held under such execution as prescribed in Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 196
§1(3.24.115), 1987)
ARTICLE XIV. PRIORITY AND LIEN OF THE TAX
3.24.585: PRIORITY OF TAX CLAIM OR LIEN; SUBORDINATION TO PRIOR RECORDED LIEN,
OTHER DEBTS:
   A.   The amounts required to be paid by any person under sections
3.24.015 through
 3.24.825 of this chapter, together with interest and penalties shall be
satisfied first in any of the following cases:
      1.   Whenever the person is insolvent;
      2.   Whenever the person makes a voluntary assignment of his assets;
      3.   Whenever the estate of the person in the hands of executors,
administrators or heirs is insufficient to pay all the debts due from the
deceased;
      4.   Whenever the estate and effects of an absconding, concealed or
absent person required to pay any amount under this chapter are levied upon by
process of law.
   B.   This section does not give the county a preference over any recorded
lien which attached prior to the date when the amounts required to be paid
became lien; or preference over costs of administration, funeral expenses,
expenses of last illness, family allowances, debts preferred by the laws of the
United States or wages as provided in Nevada Revised Statutes 150.220. (Ord.
196 §1(3.24.116), 1987)
3.24.590: RECORDATION OF CERTIFICATE OF DELINQUENCY; RESULTING LIEN; DURATION
AND EXTENSION:
   A.   If any amount required to be paid to the county under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, is not paid when due, the department may, within
three (3) years after the amount is due, file for record in the office of the
county recorder of the county or of any other county a certificate specifying
the amount, interest and penalty due, the name and address as it appears on the
records of the department of the person liable for the same, and the fact that
the department has complied with all provisions of sections
3.24.015 through
 3.24.825 of this chapter, in the determination of the amount required to pay.
   B.   From the time of the filing of record, the amount required to be paid,
together with interest and penalty, constitutes a lien upon real property in
the county where it is filed which is owned by the person or afterwards and
before the lien expires acquired by him. The lien has the force, effect and
priority of a judgment lien and shall continue for five (5) years from the time
of the filing of the certificate unless sooner released or otherwise
discharged.
   C.   The lien may, within five (5) years from the date of the filing of the
certificate or within five (5) years from the date of the last extension of the
lien in the manner herein provided, be extended by filing for record a new
certificate in the office of the county recorder of any such county, and from
the time of filing, the lien shall be extended to the real property in such
county for five (5) years, unless sooner released or otherwise discharged.
(Ord. 196 §1(3.24.117), 1987)
3.24.595: DEPARTMENT MAY RELEASE, SUBORDINATE LIEN:
The department may at any time release all or any portion of the property
subject to any lien provided for in sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, from the lien or subordinate the lien to other liens
and encumbrances if it determines that the amount, interest and penalties are
secured sufficiently by a lien on other property or that the release or
subordination of the lien will not jeopardize the collection of the amount,
interest and penalties. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.118), 1987)
3.24.600: EVIDENTIARY EFFECT OF CERTIFICATE OF RELEASE, SUBORDINATION:
A certificate by the department to the effect that any property has been
released from the lien, or that the lien has been subordinated to other liens
and encumbrances, shall be conclusive evidence that the property has been
released, or that the lien has been subordinated as provided in the
certificate. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.119), 1987)
ARTICLE XV. WARRANT FOR COLLECTION OF THE TAX
3.24.605: WARRANT FOR COLLECTION OF TAX; ISSUANCE; EFFECT; LEVY AND SALE:
   A.   At any time within three (3) years after any person is delinquent in
the payment of any amount herein required to be paid, or within three (3) years
after the last recording of an abstract under section
3.24.575 of this chapter, or of a certificate under section
3.24.590 of this chapter, the department or its authorized representative may
issue a warrant for the enforcement of any liens and for the collection of any
amount required to be paid to the county under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter.
   B.   The warrant shall be directed to any sheriff or constable and shall
have the same effect as a writ of execution.
   C.   The warrant shall be levied and sale made pursuant to it in the same
manner and with the same effect as a levy of and a sale pursuant to a writ of
execution. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.120), 1987)
3.24.610: FEES FOR SERVICES OF SHERIFF, CONSTABLE; APPROVAL OF NEWSPAPER
PUBLICATION FEES:
The department may pay or advance to the sheriff or constable the same fees,
commissions and expenses for his services as are provided by law for similar
services pursuant to a writ of execution. The department, and not the court,
shall approve the fees for publication in a newspaper. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.121),
1987)
3.24.615: LIABILITY FOR FEES OF SHERIFF, CONSTABLE:
The fees, commissions and expenses are the obligation of the person required to
pay any amount under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, and may be collected from him by virtue of the
warrant or in any other manner provided in sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, for the collection of the tax. (Ord. 196 §1
(3.24.122), 1987)
3.24.620: POWER OF DEPARTMENT TO SEIZE AND SELL DELINQUENT'S PROPERTY;
EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   At any time within three (3) years after any person is delinquent in
the payment of any amount, the department forthwith may collect the amount in
the following manner: The department shall seize any property, real or
personal, of the person and sell the property, or a sufficient part of it, at
public auction to pay the amount due, together with any interest or penalties
imposed for the delinquency and any costs incurred on account of the seizure
and sale.
   B.   Any seizure made to collect a sales tax due shall be only of the
property of the retailer not exempt from execution under the provisions of
Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.123), 1987)
3.24.625: NOTICE OF SALE; CONTENTS; MAILINGS; PUBLICATION:
   A.   Notice of the sale and the time and place thereof shall be given to the
delinquent person in writing at least ten (10) days before the date set for the
sale in the following manner: The notice shall be enclosed in an envelope
addressed to the person, in case of a sale for use taxes due, at his last known
address or place of business, and, in case of a sale for sales taxes due, at
his last known residence or place of business in this state. It shall be
deposited in the United States mail, postage prepaid. The notice shall also be
published for at least ten (10) days before the date set for the sale in a
newspaper of general circulation published in the county in which the property
seized is to be sold. If there is no newspaper of general circulation in that
county, notice shall be posted in three (3) public places in that county ten
(10) days prior to the date set for the sale.
   B.   The notice shall contain a description of the property to be sold, a
statement of the amount due, including interest, penalties and costs, the name
of the delinquent, and the further statement that unless the amount due,
interest, penalties and costs are paid on or before the time fixed in the
notice for the sale, the property, or so much of it as may be necessary, will
be sold in accordance with law and the notice. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.124), 1987)
3.24.630: SALE; DELIVERY OF BILL OF SALE, DEED; DISPOSITION OF UNSOLD PORTION:
   A.   At the sale the department shall sell the property in accordance with
law and the notice and shall deliver to the purchaser a bill of sale for the
personal property and a deed for any real property sold. The bill of sale or
deed vests the interests or title of the person liable for the amount in the
purchase.
   B.   The unsold portion of any property seized may be left at the place of
sale at the risk of the person liable for the amount. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.125),
1987)
3.24.635: DISPOSITION OF EXCESS PROCEEDS; THIRD PARTY CLAIMS:
   A.   If, upon the sale, the monies received exceed the total of all amounts,
including interest, penalties and costs due the county, the department shall
return the excess to the person liable for the amounts and obtain his receipt.
   B.   If any person having an interest in or lien upon the property filed
with the department, prior to the sale, notice of his interest or lien, the
department shall withhold any excess, pending a determination of the rights of
the respective parties thereto by a court of competent jurisdiction.
   C.   If, for any reason, the receipt of the person liable for the amount is
not available, the department shall deposit the excess monies with the
treasurer of the county, as trustee for the owner, subject to the order of the
person liable for the amount, his heirs, successors or assigns. (Ord. 196 §1
(3.24.126), 1987)
ARTICLE XVI. PAYMENT ON TERMINATION OF BUSINESS AND SUCCESSOR'S LIABILITY
3.24.640: SUCCESSOR, ASSIGNEE TO WITHHOLD TAX FROM PURCHASE PRICE:
If any retailer liable for any amount under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, sells out his business or stock of goods, or quits
the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount of
the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a
receipt from the department showing that it has been paid or a certificate
stating that no amount is due. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.127), 1987)
3.24.645: LIABILITY OF PURCHASER FOR FAILURE TO WITHHOLD PURCHASE PRICE;
RELEASE:
   A.   If the purchaser of a business or stock of goods fails to withhold the
purchase price as required, he becomes personally liable for the payment of the
amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price,
valued in money. Within sixty (60) days after receiving a written request from
the purchaser for a certificate, or within sixty (60) days from the date the
former owner's records are made available for audit, whichever period expires
the later, but in any event not later than ninety (90) days after receiving the
request, the department shall either issue the certificate or mail notice to
the purchaser at his address as it appears on the records of the department, of
the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate.
   B.   Failure of the department to mail the notice will release the purchaser
from any further obligation to withhold the purchase price as provided for in
this section.
   C.   The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced
shall start to run at the time the retailer sells out his business or stock of
goods or at the time that the determination against the retailer becomes final,
whichever event occurs the later. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.128), 1987)
ARTICLE XVII. OVERPAYMENTS AND REFUNDS
3.24.650: CERTIFICATION OF EXCESS AMOUNT COLLECTED; CREDIT AND REFUND;
OVERPAYMENT OF USE TAX BY PURCHASER:
   A.   If the department determines that any amount, penalty or interest has
been paid more than once or has been erroneously or illegally collected or
computed, the department shall set forth that fact in the records of the
department and shall certify to the board of county commissioners of the county
the amount collected in excess of the amount legally due and the person from
whom it was collected or by whom paid. If approved by such board, the excess
amount collected or paid shall be credited on any amounts then due and payable
from the person under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, and the balance shall be refunded to the person, or
his successors, administrators or executors.
   B.   Any overpayment of the use tax by a purchaser to a retailer who is
required to collect the tax and who gives the purchaser a receipt therefor
pursuant to sections
3.24.195 through
3.24.260 of this chapter, shall be credited or refunded by the county. (Ord.
196 §1(3.24.129), 1987)
3.24.655: CLAIMS FOR REFUND, CREDIT; LIMITATION:
   A.   No refund may be allowed unless a claim for it is filed with the
department within three (3) years from the last day of the month following the
close of the period for which the overpayment was made, or, with respect to
determinations made under sections
3.24.420 through
3.24.475 of this chapter, within six (6) months after the determinations become
final, or within six (6) months from the date of overpayment, whichever period
expires later.
   B.   No credit may be allowed after the expiration of the period specified
for filing claims for refund unless a claim for credit is filed with the
department within that period, or unless the credit related to a period for
which a waiver is given pursuant to section
3.24.450 of this chapter. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.130), 1987)
3.24.660: CREDIT OR REFUND FOR USE TAX; REIMBURSEMENT OF VENDOR FOR SALES TAX:
No credit or refund of any amount paid pursuant to sections
3.24.195 through
3.24.260 of this chapter, shall be allowed on the ground that the storage, use
or other consumption of the property is exempted under section
3.24.365 of this chapter, unless the person who paid the amount reimburses his
vendor with respect to the sale of the property and is paid by the vendor to
the county. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.131), 1987)
3.24.665: CLAIM FOR REFUND, CREDIT; FORM; CONTENTS:
Every claim shall be in writing and shall state the specific ground upon which
the claim is founded. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.132), 1987)
3.24.670: EFFECT OF FAILURE TO FILE CLAIM; WAIVER:
Failure to file a claim within the time prescribed in section
3.24.655 of this chapter constitutes a waiver of any demand against the county
on account of overpayment. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.133), 1987)
3.24.675: NOTICE OF DISALLOWANCE OF CLAIM; SERVICE:
Within thirty (30) days after disallowing any claim in whole or part, the
department shall serve notice of its action on the claimant in the manner
prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. (Ord. 196 §1
(3.24.134), 1987)
3.24.680: INTEREST ON OVERPAYMENTS:
   A.   Interest must be paid upon any overpayment of any amount of tax at the
rate of one-half of one percent per month from the last day of the calendar
month following the period for which the overpayment was made; but no refund or
credit may be made of any interest imposed upon the person making the
overpayment with respect to the amount being refunded or credited.
   B.   The interest must be paid as follows:
      1.   In the case of a refund, to the last day of the calendar month
following the date upon which the person making the overpayment, if he has not
already filed a claim, is notified by the department that a claim may be filed
or the date upon which the claim is certified to the board of county
commissioners of the county, whichever date is earlier;
      2.   In the case of a credit, to the same date as that to which interest
is computed on the tax or amount against which the credit is applied. (Ord. 196
§1(3.24.135), 1987)
3.24.685: DISALLOWANCE OF INTEREST; CIRCUMSTANCES:
If the department determines that any overpayment has been made intentionally
or by reason of carelessness, it shall not allow any interest thereon. (Ord.
196 §1(3.24.136), 1987)
3.24.690: INJUNCTION, OTHER PROCESS TO PREVENT TAX COLLECTION PROHIBITED:
No injunction or writ of mandate or other legal or equitable process shall
issue in any suit, action or proceeding in any court against the state, a
county, any officer thereof to prevent or enjoin the collection under sections
 3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, of any tax or any amount of tax required to be
collected. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.137), 1987)
3.24.695: ACTION FOR REFUND; CLAIM AS CONDITION PRECEDENT:
No suit or proceeding shall be maintained in any court for the recovery of any
amount alleged to have been erroneously or illegally determined or collected
unless a claim for refund or credit has been duly filed. (Ord. 196 §1
(3.24.133), 1987)
3.24.700: ACTION FOR REFUND; TIME TO SUE; VENUE OF ACTION; WAIVER:
   A.   Within ninety (90) days after the mailing of the notice of the
department's action upon a claim filed pursuant to sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, the claimant may bring an action against the
department on the grounds set forth in the claim in a court of competent
jurisdiction in Ely for the recovery of the whole or any part of the amount
with respect to which the claim has been disallowed.
   B.   Failure to bring action within the time specified constitutes a waiver
of any demand against the county on account of alleged overpayment. (Ord. 196
§1(3.24.139), 1987)
3.24.705: JUDGMENT FOR PLAINTIFF; CREDITS; REFUND OF BALANCE:
   A.   If judgment is rendered for the plaintiff, the amount of the judgment
shall first be credited as follows:
      1.   If the judgment is for a refund of sales taxes, it shall be created
on any sales or use tax or amount of use tax due from the plaintiff;
      2.   If the judgment is for a refund of use taxes, it shall be credited
on any use tax or amount of use tax due from the plaintiff under sections
3.24.195 through 3.24.260 of this chapter.
   B.   The balance of the judgment shall be refunded to the plaintiff. (Ord.
196 §1(3.24.140), 1987)
3.24.710: ALLOWANCE OF INTEREST:
In any judgment, interest shall be allowed at the rate of six percent (6%) per
annum upon the amount found to have been illegally collected from the date of
payment of the amount to the date of allowance of credit on account of the
judgment, or to a date preceding the date of the refund warrant by not more
than thirty (30) days, the date to be determined by the department. (Ord. 196
§1(3.24.141), 1987)
3.24.715: JUDGMENT NOT TO BE RENDERED FOR ASSIGNEE-PLAINTIFF:
A judgment shall not be rendered in favor of the plaintiff in any action
brought against the department to recover any amount paid when the action is
brought by or in the name of an assignee of the person paying the amount or by
any person other than the person who paid the amount. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.142),
1987)
3.24.720: RECOVERY OF ERRONEOUS REFUNDS; ACTION; JURISDICTION AND VENUE:
The department may recover any refund or part thereof which is erroneously made
and any credit or part thereof which is erroneously allowed in an action
brought in a court of competent jurisdiction in the county, in the name of the
county. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.143), 1987)
3.24.725: DISTRICT ATTORNEY TO PROSECUTE ACTION FOR RECOVERY OF ERRONEOUS
REFUND; APPLICABILITY OF NEVADA REVISED STATUTES, NRCP, AND NRAP:
The district attorney of the county, on behalf of the county, shall prosecute
the action, and the provisions of Nevada Revised Statutes and the Nevada rules
of civil procedure and Nevada rules of appellate procedure relating to service
of summons, pleadings, proofs, trials and appeals are applicable to the
proceedings. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.144), 1987)
3.24.730: CANCELLATION OF ILLEGAL DETERMINATION; PROCEDURE; LIMITATION:
   A.   If any amount in excess of twenty five dollars ($25.00) has been
illegally determined, either by the person filing the return or by the
department, the department shall certify this fact to the board of county
commissioners of the county, and such board shall authorize the cancellation of
the amount upon the records of the department.
   B.   If an amount not exceeding twenty five dollars ($25.00) has been
illegally determined, either by the person filing a return or by the
department, the department, without certifying this fact to such board, shall
authorize the cancellation of the amount upon the records of the department.
(Ord. 196 §1(3.24.145), 1987)
ARTICLE XVIII. ADMINISTRATION
3.24.735: ENFORCEMENT BY DEPARTMENT; REGULATIONS:
   A.   The department shall enforce the provisions of sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, and may prescribe, adopt and enforce regulations
relating to the administration and enforcement of those sections.
   B.   The department may prescribe the extent to which any ruling or
regulation shall be applied without retroactive effect. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.146),
1987)
3.24.740: EMPLOYMENT OF ACCOUNTANTS, INVESTIGATORS AND OTHER PERSONS;
DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY:
The department may employ accountants, auditors, investigators, assistants and
clerks necessary for the efficient administration of sections
 3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, and may delegate authority to its representatives to
conduct hearings, prescribe regulations or perform any other duties imposed by
those sections. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.147), 1987)
3.24.745: RECORDS TO BE KEPT BY SELLERS, RETAILERS AND OTHERS:
   A.   Every seller, every retailer, and every person storing, using or
otherwise consuming in a county tangible personal property purchased from a
retailer shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers
in such form as the department may require.
   B.   Every such seller, retailer or person who files the returns required
under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, shall keep such records for not less than four (4)
years from the making of such records unless the department in writing sooner
authorizes their destruction.
   C.   Every such seller, retailer or person who fails to file the returns
required under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, shall keep such records for not less than eight (8)
years from the making of such records unless the department in writing sooner
authorizes their destruction. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.148), 1987)
3.24.750: EXAMINATION OF RECORDS; INVESTIGATION OF BUSINESS:
The department, or any person authorized in writing by it, may examine the
books, papers, records and equipment of any person selling tangible personal
property and any person liable for the use tax and may investigate the
character of the business of the person in order to verify the accuracy of any
return made, or, if no return is made by the person, to ascertain and determine
the amount required to be paid. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.149), 1987)
3.24.755: REPORTS FOR ADMINISTERING USE TAX; CONTENTS:
   A.   In administration of the use tax, the department may require the filing
of reports by any person or class of persons having in his or their possession
or custody information relating to sale of tangible personal property, the
storage, use or other consumption of which is subject to tax. The report shall:
      1.   Be filed when the department requires;
      2.   Set forth the names and addresses of purchasers of the tangible
personal property, the sales price of the property, the date of sale, and such
other information as the department may require. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.150), 1987)
3.24.760: DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION UNLAWFUL; EXAMINATION OF RECORDS WHEN
ORDERED BY GOVERNOR:
   A.   It is a misdemeanor for any member of the Nevada tax commission or
official or employee of the department to make known in any manner whatever the
business affairs, operations or information obtained by an investigation of
records and equipment of any retailer or any other person visited or examined
in the discharge of official duty, or the amount or source of income, profits,
losses, expenditures or any particular thereof, set forth or disclosed in any
return, or to permit any return or copy thereof, or any book containing any
abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not
connected with the department.
   B.   The governor may, however, by general or special order, authorize
examination of the records maintained by the department under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, by other state officers, by tax officers of another
state, by the federal government, if a reciprocal arrangement exists, or by any
other person. The information so obtained pursuant to the order of the governor
shall not be made public except to the extent and in the manner that the order
may authorize that it be made public.
   C.   Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators, assignees
and grantors, if directly interested, may be given information as to the items
included in the measure and amounts of any unpaid tax or amounts of tax
required to be collected, interest and penalties. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.151), 1987)
ARTICLE XIX. PENALTIES
3.24.765: PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO MAKE RETURN, FURNISH DATA:
Any retailer or other person who fails or refuses to furnish any return
required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return
or other data required by the department, or who renders a false or fraudulent
return, is guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of not more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.152), 1987)
3.24.770: PENALTY FOR FALSE AND FRAUDULENT RETURNS:
Any person required to make, render, sign or verify any report who makes any
false or fraudulent return, with intent to defeat or evade the determination of
an amount due required by law to be made, shall for each offense be fined not
less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than five thousand dollars
($5,000.00), or be imprisoned for not more than one year in the county jail, or
be subject to both fine and imprisonment. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.153), 1987)
3.24.775: PENALTY FOR OTHER VIOLATIONS:
Any violation of sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, except as otherwise provided, is a misdemeanor. (Ord.
196 §1(3.24.154), 1987)
3.24.780: STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS:
Any prosecution for violation of any of the penal provisions of sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, shall be instituted within three (3) years after the
commission of the offense. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.155), 1987)
3.24.785: APPLICATION OF RES JUDICATA DOCTRINE:
In the determination of any case arising under sections
3.24.015 through 3.24.825 of this chapter, the rule of res judicata is
applicable only if the liability involved is for the same period as was
involved in another case previously determined. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.156), 1987)
ARTICLE XX. MISCELLANEOUS
3.24.790: SALES AND USE TAX ACCOUNT; REMITTANCES; DEPOSITS; TRANSFERS:
   A.   All fees, taxes, interest and penalties imposed and all amounts of tax
required to be paid the county under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, must be paid to the department in the form of
remittances payable to the department.
   B.   The department shall deposit the payments in the state treasury to the
credit of the fund for public mass transportation, a special revenue fund
created by subsection 2 of Nevada Revised Statutes 377A.050 in the state
general fund.
   C.   The state controller, acting upon the collection data furnished by the
department, shall, each month, from the fund for public mass transportation in
the state general fund:
      1.   Transfer one percent (1%) of all fees, taxes, interest and penalties
collected in each county during the preceding month to the appropriate account
in the state general fund as compensation to the state for the costs of
collecting the tax for the county;
      2.   Determine for the county the amount of money equal to the fees,
taxes, interest and penalties collected in the state pursuant to sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, during the preceding month less the amount
transferred pursuant to subsection C1 of this section;
      3.   Remit the money to the treasurer of the county for credit to the
public transit fund, which is created by section
3.24.820 of this chapter. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.157), 1987)
3.24.795: REMEDIES OF COUNTY ARE CUMULATIVE:
The remedies of the county provided for in sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter are cumulative, and no action taken by the department,
the attorney general or a district attorney constitutes an election by the
county to pursue any remedy to the exclusion of any other remedy for which
provision is made in sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.158), 1987)
3.24.800: DEPARTMENT'S AUTHORITY TO ACT FOR COUNTIES:
In all proceedings under sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, the department may act for and on behalf of the
county. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.159), 1987)
3.24.805: COUNTY TO CONTRACT WITH DEPARTMENT FOR FUNCTIONS INCIDENT TO SALES
AND USE TAX:
The county shall, before the effective date of sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, enter into an agreement with the department which
provides that the department shall perform all functions incident to the
administration or operation of the tax imposed by those sections. (Ord. 196 §1
(3.24.160), 1987)
3.24.810: AMENDMENTS TO CHAPTER 374 OF NEVADA REVISED STATUTES AUTOMATICALLY
INCORPORATED INTO THIS CODE:
Every amendment to the local school support tax law, chapter 374 of Nevada
Revised Statutes, which becomes effective after the date of enactment of
sections
3.24.015 through 3.24.825 of this chapter, automatically becomes a part of
sections
3.24.015 through
3.24.825 of this chapter, on its effective date unless such amendment is
inconsistent with the provisions of chapter 377A of Nevada Revised Statutes.
(Ord. 196 §1(3.24.161), 1987)
3.24.815: DATE OF IMPOSITION OF SALES AND USE TAX:
The sales tax and the use tax which are provided for in sections
3.24.110 and
3.24.195 of this chapter, respectively, shall each be imposed on the date the
ordinance codified in this chapter is approved by the registered voters of the
county. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.162), 1987)
ARTICLE XXI. CREATION OF PUBLIC TRANSIT FUND
3.24.820: CREATION OF PUBLIC TRANSIT FUND; DEPOSITS; LIMITATIONS ON DIVERSIONS;
AUTHORIZED EXPENDITURES:
   A.   There is created in the county treasury a separate and distinct fund to
be known as the public roads fund.
   B.   The county treasury shall deposit all money received from the state
controller pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 377A.050 and section
3.24.290 of this chapter in the public roads fund.
   C.   Money which is deposited in the public roads fund must not be diverted
to the regional street and highway fund.
   D.   Money in the public roads fund shall be appropriated by the regional
transportation commission pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 377A.080 and may
be used for any lawful purpose set forth in chapter 377A of Nevada Revised
Statutes. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.163), 1987)
3.24.825: PROCEEDS OF TAX MAY NOT BE PLEDGED:
The proceeds from the tax imposed by section
 3.24.015 of this chapter through this section, may not be pledged as security
for revenue bonds or other securities. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.164), 1987)
3.24.830: ALLOCATION OF FUNDS:
Money drawn down from the public transit fund for constructing, repairing and
maintaining public roads must be allocated to the government entities within
the county in the same ratio as each entity's total miles of paved roads bear
to the total miles of paved roads within the county. (Ord. 196 §1(3.24.165),
1987)
CHAPTER 3.25
SWIMMING POOL TAX
SECTION:
3.25.005: Short Title
3.25.010: Authority, Purpose And Scope
3.25.015: Findings And Declaration
3.25.020: Rate Of Tax
3.25.030: Effective Date
3.25.040: Incorporation By Reference
3.25.050: Amendments
3.25.060: Interlocal Contract
3.25.005: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be referred to as the SWIMMING POOL TAX
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 385, 2003)
3.25.010: AUTHORITY, PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
   A.   This chapter is enacted pursuant to the authority granted in chapter
377A of Nevada Revised Statutes, which was enacted by the 61st session of the
Nevada legislature as chapter 683, statutes of Nevada, 1981, as amended by the
63rd session of the Nevada legislature in chapter 234, statutes of Nevada,
1985; as amended by the 72nd session of the Nevada legislature in chapter 377A
by assembly bill 208.
   B.   This chapter establishes a tax upon retail sales of tangible personal
property sold within White Pine County and a tax upon the storage, use or
consumption of tangible personal property within the county. The proceeds of
the tax shall be used for operating and maintaining a public swimming pool.
(Ord. 385, 2003)
3.25.015: FINDINGS AND DECLARATION:
   A.   The board of county commissioners of the county having carefully
considered that there is no other object of taxation, except retail sales,
which is so generally distributed among the residents and visitors to the
county in proportion to their respective population and wealth as to be
suitable for the imposition of a tax for the support of public swimming
facilities:
      1.   It is therefore necessary to impose a separate tax upon tangible
personal property sold at retail in the county to provide for the operation and
maintenance of a public swimming facility within the county;
      2.   In order to avoid imposing unfair competitive hardships upon
merchants within the county, it is necessary that such additional tax be
imposed:
         a.   At the same rate throughout the county; and
         b.   Upon tangible personal property purchased outside the county for
use within the county;
      3.   The convenience of the public and of retail merchants will best be
served by imposing the tax for a swimming pool facility upon exactly the same
transactions, requiring the same reports and making such tax parallel in all
respects to the existing sales and use taxes. (Ord. 385, 2003)
3.25.020: RATE OF TAX:
An additional sales tax in the amount of one-fourth of one percent (0.0025%)
shall be imposed upon all retail sales concurrent with the sales tax now
imposed under chapter 3.24, "Public Roads Tax", of this title. (Ord. 385, 2003)
3.25.030: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This tax shall be reinstated starting March 13, 2012, and shall remain in force
pending further action by the White Pine County commission. (Ord. 443, 2012)
3.25.040: INCORPORATION BY REFERENCE:
Application, collection and enforcement of the swimming pool tax shall be
construed and interpreted in accordance with chapter 3.24 of this title which
is hereby incorporated by this reference as though fully set forth herein.
(Ord. 385, 2003)
3.25.050: AMENDMENTS:
All amendments to Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 374 which are enacted after
the date of enactment of this chapter which are not inconsistent with the terms
of Nevada Revised Statutes 377A shall be automatically incorporated into this
chapter. (Ord. 385, 2003)
3.25.060: INTERLOCAL CONTRACT:
White Pine County will contract with the Nevada department of taxation to
perform all functions incident to the administration of this tax before the
effective date hereof. (Ord. 385, 2003)
CHAPTER 3.27
GENETIC MARKER TESTING FUND
SECTION:
3.27.010: Fund Created
3.27.020: Deposit Of Monies
3.27.030: Actual Charges; Monthly Payments
3.27.040: Surplus Money
3.27.010: FUND CREATED:
There is created in the county treasury a fund for genetic marker testing that
will be named the genetic marker testing fund. (Ord. 386 §1, 2004)
3.27.020: DEPOSIT OF MONIES:
All money collected pursuant to a district court order for genetic marker
testing shall be deposited upon receipt into the genetic marker testing fund.
All funds held in the genetic marker testing fund shall be accounted for
separately from other county funds. (Ord. 386 §2, 2004)
3.27.030: ACTUAL CHARGES; MONTHLY PAYMENTS:
Each month the county treasurer shall use the money in the genetic marker
testing fund for genetic marker testing to pay for the amount actually charged
to the county for obtaining a biological specimen from a defendant pursuant to
Nevada Revised Statutes 176.0913. (Ord. 386 §3, 2004)
3.27.040: SURPLUS MONEY:
Any money remaining in the genetic marker testing fund after the county
treasurer makes the payments required by section
3.27.030 of this chapter shall be paid to the forensic laboratory designed by
the county pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 176.0917 which laboratory shall
use the money only as provided by Nevada Revised Statutes 176.0915. (Ord. 386
§4, 2004)
CHAPTER 3.28
FORENSIC SERVICES FUND
SECTION:
3.28.010: Created
3.28.020: Collection Of Fees For Analysis Of Controlled Substances And
Dangerous Drugs
3.28.030: Disbursement Of Money
3.28.010: CREATED:
Pursuant to authority of chapter 578, 1987 statutes of Nevada, there is created
in the White Pine County treasury a fund for forensic services. (Ord. 224 §2,
1989)
3.28.020: COLLECTION OF FEES FOR ANALYSIS OF CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES AND
DANGEROUS DRUGS:
Fees for analysis of controlled substances and dangerous drugs shall be
collected in accordance with Nevada Revised Statutes 453.575 and 454.358 and
deposited in the fund for forensic services. (Ord. 224 §3, 1989)
3.28.030: DISBURSEMENT OF MONEY:
Disbursement of money from the fund for forensic services shall be in
accordance with Nevada Revised Statutes 453.575 and 454.358. (Ord. 224 §4,
1989)
CHAPTER 3.29
SCHOOL DISTRICT CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT TAX
SECTION:
3.29.010: Code Addition
3.29.020: Title
3.29.030: Rate
3.29.040: Incorporation Of Provisions Of Nevada Revised Statutes 374; Local
School Support Tax
3.29.050: Specific Purpose For Which The Tax Must Be Expended
3.29.060: Effect Of Amendments
3.29.070: Delegation Of Administrative Functions
3.29.080: Exemption
3.29.090: Amending Ordinance
3.29.010: CODE ADDITION:
There is added to this code an addition of this chapter providing for the
imposition of an infrastructure tax for capital improvements to the White Pine
County school district. (Ord. 348 §1.0, 2000)
3.29.020: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as or may be cited as the WHITE PINE COUNTY SCHOOL
DISTRICT CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT TAX. (Ord. 348 §1.1, 2000)
3.29.030: RATE:
A tax of one-eighth of one percent of the gross receipts of all retailers in
White Pine County, Nevada, is here imposed upon the sale of all tangible
personal property sold at retail, or stored, used or otherwise consumed in the
county of White Pine. (Ord. 348 §2.0, 2000)
3.29.040: INCORPORATION OF PROVISIONS OF NEVADA REVISED STATUTES 374; LOCAL
SCHOOL SUPPORT TAX:
The provisions of Nevada Revised Statutes 374, pertaining to local school
support tax, as is, or may be, applicable hereto, are by reference incorporated
herein as governing sales tax, use tax, exemptions, abatements, returns and
repayments, security, overpayments, refunds, administration and penalties.
(Ord. 348 §2.1, 2000)
3.29.050: SPECIFIC PURPOSE FOR WHICH THE TAX MUST BE EXPENDED:
The infrastructure tax imposed hereunder shall be applied to pay capital
improvements within the White Pine County school district. (Ord. 348 §2.2,
2000)
3.29.060: EFFECT OF AMENDMENTS:
Any amendment made to chapter 374 of the Nevada Revised Statutes, after the
date of enactment of the ordinance codified in this chapter, not inconsistent
with the chapter, automatically becomes a part of this chapter. (Ord. 348 §2.3,
2000)
3.29.070: DELEGATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE FUNCTIONS:
The county of White Pine shall contract with the department of administration
for the performance of all functions incident to the administration or
operation of the tax in the county. (Ord. 348 §2.4, 2000)
3.29.080: EXEMPTION:
Exempt from the tax or any increase in the tax are the gross receipts from the
sale of, and the storage, use or other consumption in a county of, tangible
personal property use for the performance of a written contract entered into or
before the effective date of the tax or the increase of the tax; or, for the
construction of an improvement to real property for which a binding bid was
submitted before the effective date of the tax or the increase in the tax if
the bid was afterwards accepted, if, under the terms of the contract or bid,
the contract price or bid amount cannot be adjusted to reflect the imposition
of the tax or the increase in the tax. (Ord. 348 §2.5, 2000)
3.29.090: AMENDING ORDINANCE:
Any ordinance hereafter adopted for purposes of amending this chapter must
include a provision in substance that the county shall amend the contract made
in contemplation of delegation of administrative functions, as set forth by
section
3.29.070 of this chapter, by contract made between the county and the state
acting by and through the department of administration before the effective
date of the amendatory taxing ordinance, unless the county determines with the
written concurrence of the department that no such amendment of the contract is
necessary or desirable. (Ord. 348 §2.6, 2000)
CHAPTER 3.32
JUDICIAL FACILITIES; ADDITIONAL ADMINISTRATIVE ASSESSMENT
SECTION:
3.32.010: Definitions
3.32.020: Additional Administrative Assessment
3.32.030: Purpose Of Additional Assessment
3.32.040: Exceptions To Imposition Of Additional Assessment
3.32.050: Collection Of Additional Assessment
3.32.060: Disposition Of Monies Where Defendant Is Found Not Guilty Or Where
Charges Are Dismissed
3.32.070: Disposition Of Judgment Deemed Uncollectible
3.32.080: Priority Of Payments Made By Installment
3.32.090: Disposition Of Monies Collected For Judicial Facilities
3.32.100: Disposition Of Monies Remaining In Special Revenue Fund After Five
Years
3.32.110: Provision By Treasurer Of Reports
3.32.120: Duration Of Administrative Assessment
3.32.130: Modification By Resolution
3.32.140: Collection Processes And Fees For Unpaid Administrative Assessment
3.32.150: Reduction Of Excessive Fine Or Administrative Assessment
3.32.010: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
CONVICTION: The finding of guilt, by the court, based upon any plea of guilty
or finding of guilt by the justice's court, or upon a finding of guilt based
upon a trial or hearing conducted before the justice. Such term shall also
comprehend any proceeding in which any defendant has waived or otherwise
forfeited the right to appear and contest the allegations of any complaint
lodged against him or her.
JUSTICE'S COURTS: The justice's court of Ely Township 1, the justice's court of
Baker Township, and the justice's court of Lund Township, in and for White Pine
County, Nevada.
NEVADA REVISED STATUTES (NRS): The most recent enactment, revision or update of
any chapter and section of the Nevada Revised Statutes by the Nevada state
legislature. (Ord. 354 §§1.0 - 1.3, 2000)
3.32.020: ADDITIONAL ADMINISTRATIVE ASSESSMENT:
Upon the effective date hereof, an additional administrative assessment of ten
dollars ($10.00) shall be imposed upon any defendant convicted of any
misdemeanor, including the violation of any county ordinance or code, within
the jurisdiction of the justice's court. The justice shall render judgment
against the defendant for the assessment. (Ord. 354 §2.0, 2000)
3.32.030: PURPOSE OF ADDITIONAL ASSESSMENT:
The purpose of the additional administrative assessment imposed hereunder is
solely for the purposes hereinafter enumerated. Any money collected from any
defendant for purposes of an administrative assessment for court facilities
must not be deducted from the fine imposed by the justice but must be taxed
against the defendant in addition to the fine. (Ord. 354 §2.1, 2000)
3.32.040: EXCEPTIONS TO IMPOSITION OF ADDITIONAL ASSESSMENT:
An additional assessment imposed pursuant to section
3.32.020 of this chapter shall not apply to an ordinance regulating metered
parking or an ordinance allowing for the creation of a civil penalty relating
to regulated parking as authorized by Nevada Revised Statutes 244.3575. (Ord.
354 §2.2, 2000)
3.32.050: COLLECTION OF ADDITIONAL ASSESSMENT:
Any money collected by the justice's court under this chapter must be stated
separately on the court's docket and must be included in the amount posted for
bail. (Ord. 354 §2.3, 2000)
3.32.060: DISPOSITION OF MONIES WHERE DEFENDANT IS FOUND NOT GUILTY OR WHERE
CHARGES ARE DISMISSED:
If the defendant is found not guilty, or if the charges relating to the
defendant are dismissed, any money deposited with the court, as an additional
assessment must be returned to the defendant. (Ord. 354 §2.4, 2000)
3.32.070: DISPOSITION OF JUDGMENT DEEMED UNCOLLECTIBLE:
If the justice cancels a fine because the fine has been determined to be
uncollectible, any balance of the fine and the administrative assessment
remaining unpaid shall be deemed to be uncollectible and the defendant is not
required to pay the additional assessment. A defendant shall not be entitled to
any refund of the fine or administrative assessment paid prior to the justice's
determination that the fine or administrative assessment is uncollectible; nor
shall the justice recalculate the administrative assessment imposed hereunder.
(Ord. 354 §2.5, 2000)
3.32.080: PRIORITY OF PAYMENTS MADE BY INSTALLMENT:
   A.   If the justice permits the fine and the administrative assessment,
imposed pursuant to this chapter for the provision of court facilities, to be
made by installments, the payments must by applied in the following order:
      1.   To pay the unpaid balance of an administrative assessment imposed
pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 176.059;
      2.   To pay the unpaid balance of an administrative assessment for the
provision of court facilities pursuant to this chapter; and
      3.   To pay the fine. (Ord. 354 §2.6, 2000)
3.32.090: DISPOSITION OF MONIES COLLECTED FOR JUDICIAL FACILITIES:
   A.   The money collected by the court for the provision of court facilities
must be paid by the clerk of the court to the county treasurer on or before the
fifth day of each month for the preceding month. The county treasurer shall
create and deposit the money received in a special revenue fund. The county may
use the money in the special revenue fund only to:
      1.   Acquire land on which to construct additional facilities for the
justice's court or a regional justice center that includes the justice's court;
      2.   Construct or acquire additional facilities for the justice's courts
or a regional justice center that includes the justice's courts;
      3.   Renovate or remodel existing facilities for the justice's courts;
      4.   Acquire furniture, fixtures and equipment necessitated by the
construction or acquisition of additional facilities or the renovation of an
existing facility for the justice's courts or a regional justice center that
includes the justice's court;
      5.   Acquire advanced technology for use in the additional or renovated
facilities;
      6.   Monies collected pursuant to this chapter may not be used for
purchase of furniture, fixtures or equipment for judicial chambers;
      7.   Monies collected pursuant to this chapter may not be used to pay
debt service on any bonds issued pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 350.020(3)
for the acquisition of land or facilities or the construction or renovation of
facilities for the justice's court or a regional justice center that includes
the justice's court. (Ord. 354 §2.7, 2000)
3.32.100: DISPOSITION OF MONIES REMAINING IN SPECIAL REVENUE FUND AFTER FIVE
YEARS:
Any money remaining in the special revenue fund after five (5) fiscal years
must be deposited in the county general fund, for the continued maintenance of
court facilities, if such money has not been committed for expenditure pursuant
to a plan for the construction or acquisition of court facilities or
improvements to court facilities. (Ord. 354 §2.8, 2000)
3.32.110: PROVISION BY TREASURER OF REPORTS:
The county treasurer shall provide, upon request by the justice's court,
monthly reports of the revenue credited to and expenditures made from the
special revenue fund. (Ord. 354 §2.9, 2000)
3.32.120: DURATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE ASSESSMENT:
The administrative assessment created pursuant to this chapter shall be in
force and effect for a period of twenty five (25) years from effective date
hereof, unless such period has otherwise been terminated by resolution of the
county. (Ord. 354 §2.10, 2000)
3.32.130: MODIFICATION BY RESOLUTION:
Modification hereto, where not otherwise prohibited by or contrary to Nevada
Revised Statutes, may be made by resolution. (Ord. 354 §2.11, 2000)
3.32.140: COLLECTION PROCESSES AND FEES FOR UNPAID ADMINISTRATIVE ASSESSMENT:
   A.   If an administrative assessment imposed upon a defendant pursuant to
this chapter, whether or not such administrative assessment is in addition to
any other punishment, fine, or restitution, remains unpaid after the time
established by the court for its payment, the defendant is liable for a
collection fee, of:
      1.   Not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), if the amount of the
delinquency is less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00);
      2.   Not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), if the amount of the
delinquency is two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or greater, but less than five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00);
      3.   Ten percent (10%) of the amount of the delinquency, if the amount of
the delinquency is more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
   B.   An action to collect under this section shall be the responsibility of
the district attorney. Any action commenced under this section is not intended
to limit the ability of the district attorney, or any other state or local
entity that is responsible for collecting a delinquent fine, administrative
assessment, fee or restitution that remains unpaid by the defendant, to pursue
any other remedy as provided for by Nevada Revised Statutes 176.064. In
addition to, or in lieu of, the commencement of an action to collect the unpaid
administrative assessment fee, the district attorney, or any other authorized
entity may take any or all of the following forms of action:
      1.   Report the delinquency to reporting agencies that assemble or
evaluate information concerning credit;
      2.   Request that the court order the suspension of the defendant's
driver's license; or, where a defendant does not possess a driver's license,
prohibit the defendant from operating a motor vehicle for a specified period of
time and such other remedies and procedures provided for by Nevada Revised
Statutes 176.064(3)(b);
      3.   Contract with a collection agency licensed according to Nevada
Revised Statutes 649.075 to collect the delinquent amount and the collection
fee as provided for by Nevada Revised Statutes 176.064(2)(c);
      4.   Order the defendant confined in the White Pine County Jail as
provided for by Nevada Revised Statutes 176.065 and 176.075. (Ord. 354 §2.12,
2000)
3.32.150: REDUCTION OF EXCESSIVE FINE OR ADMINISTRATIVE ASSESSMENT:
Any reduction made in the amount of an administrative assessment under this
chapter, by the justice, not otherwise inconsistent with section
3.32.020 of this chapter and Nevada Revised Statutes 176.0611(5), must be made
in accordance with the terms of Nevada Revised Statutes 176.085. (Ord. 354
§2.13, 2000)
CHAPTER 3.33
COURT FEES
SECTION:
3.33.010: District Court Filing Fees To Support Programs For The Prevention And
Treatment Of The Abuse Of Alcohol And Drugs
3.33.020: Justice Court Filing Fees To Support Programs For The Prevention And
Treatment Of The Abuse Of Alcohol And Drugs
3.33.030: District Court Filing Fees To Support Programs For Legal Services To
Abused Or Neglected Children And Victims Of Domestic Violence
3.33.040: District Court Filing Fees To Support Programs For Court Security
3.33.010: DISTRICT COURT FILING FEES TO SUPPORT PROGRAMS FOR THE PREVENTION AND
TREATMENT OF THE ABUSE OF ALCOHOL AND DRUGS:
   A.   Additional Filing Fee: There will be an additional ten dollar ($10.00)
filing fee to be paid on the commencement of any civil action or proceeding in
the district court for which a filing fee is required and on the filing of any
answer or appearance in any such action or proceeding for which a filing fee is
required, except as otherwise required pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes
19.034 (addressing reduced filing fees for the adoption of a special needs
child).
   B.   Deposit: On or before the fifth day of each month, the clerk of the
court shall account for and pay over to the county treasurer any such fees
collected by him/her during the preceding month for credit to an account for
programs for the prevention and treatment of the abuse of alcohol and drugs in
the county general fund.
   C.   Approved Use Of Fees: Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 19.03135, the
money in that account may only be used to support programs for the prevention
or treatment of the abuse of alcohol or drugs which may include, without
limitation, any program of treatment for the abuse of alcohol or drugs
established in a judicial district pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 453.580.
(Ord. 424, 2009: Ord. 393 §§1, 2, 3, 2005)
3.33.020: JUSTICE COURT FILING FEES TO SUPPORT PROGRAMS FOR THE PREVENTION AND
TREATMENT OF THE ABUSE OF ALCOHOL AND DRUGS:
   A.   There will be an additional ten dollar ($10.00) filing fee to be paid
on the commencement of any action or proceeding in the justice court for which
a filing fee is required and on the filing of any answer or appearance in any
such action or proceeding for which a filing fee is required.
   B.   On or before the fifth day of each month, the justice of the peace
shall account for and pay over to the county treasurer any such fees collected
by him/her during the preceding month for credit to an account for programs for
the prevention and treatment of the abuse of alcohol and drugs in the county
general fund.
   C.   Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 4.075, the money in that account
may only be used to support programs for the prevention or treatment of the
abuse of alcohol or drugs which may include, without limitation, any program of
treatment for the abuse of alcohol or drugs established in a judicial district
pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 453.580. (Ord. 424, 2009)
3.33.030: DISTRICT COURT FILING FEES TO SUPPORT PROGRAMS FOR LEGAL SERVICES TO
ABUSED OR NEGLECTED CHILDREN AND VICTIMS OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE:
   A.   There will be an additional ten dollar ($10.00) filing fee to be paid
on the commencement of any action or proceeding in the district court for which
a filing fee is required and on the filing of any answer or appearance in any
such action or proceeding for which a filing fee is required and twenty five
dollars ($25.00) to be paid on the filing of any motion or other paper that
seeks to modify or adjust a final order that was issued pursuant to Nevada
Revised Statutes chapter 125, 125B or 125C and on the filing of an answer or
response to such a motion or paper except as exempted by Nevada Revised
Statutes 19.0312(2).
   B.   On or before the first Monday of each month, the clerk of the court
shall account for and pay over to the county treasurer any such fees collected
by him/her during the preceding month for credit to an account for programs for
the provision of legal services to abused or neglected children and victims of
domestic violence.
   C.   Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 19.0312, the money in that account
may only be used to support programs for the provision of legal services to
abused or neglected children and victims of domestic violence. (Ord. 425, 2009)
3.33.040: DISTRICT COURT FILING FEES TO SUPPORT PROGRAMS FOR COURT SECURITY:
   A.   There will be an additional twenty dollar ($20.00) filing fee to be
paid on the commencement of any action or proceeding in the district court for
which a filing fee is required and on the filing of any answer or appearance in
any such action or proceeding for which a filing fee is required.
   B.   On or before the first Monday of each month, the clerk of the court
shall account for and pay over to the county treasurer any such fees collected
by them during the preceding month for credit to an account for provision of
court security programs.
   C.   Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes, the money in that account may only
be used to support programs for court security. (Ord. 431, 2009)
CHAPTER 3.36
REIMBURSEMENT PROCEDURES FOR EMERGENCY SERVICES
SECTION:
3.36.010: Intent
3.36.020: Imposition Of Fee
3.36.030: Rate
3.36.040: Amendments
3.36.050: Responsibility For Collection Of Fees
3.36.010: INTENT:
The intent of this chapter is to provide procedures for reimbursement to the
county of White Pine where emergency services have been provided to
nonresidents of the county. (Ord. 358 §1.1, 2000)
3.36.020: IMPOSITION OF FEE:
The county of White Pine shall impose and collect a fee upon all persons, not
residents of White Pine County, Nevada, who have received emergency services,
including, but not necessarily limited to, fire and ambulance calls. (Ord. 358
§1.2, 2000)
3.36.030: RATE:
Any fee imposed under section
3.36.020 of this chapter must be established by the board of county
commissioners and be reasonable. Any schedule of rates to be imposed under this
chapter may be adopted by resolution. The board may by subsequent resolution
amend, modify, or revoke any schedule of fees previously imposed under this
chapter. (Ord. 358 §1.3, 2000)
3.36.040: AMENDMENTS:
Any amendments or modifications to this chapter may be made upon a resolution
adopted by the board of county commissioners. (Ord. 358 §1.4, 2000)
3.36.050: RESPONSIBILITY FOR COLLECTION OF FEES:
The responsibility for the assessment, billing, and collection of any fees
imposed under this chapter shall be the responsibility of White Pine County
social services (e.g., county social services). White Pine County social
services is authorized to create written collection rules and policies with
which to implement the intent of this chapter. Any such rules and policies must
be presented to the board of county commissioners for final approval. Any rules
and policies created pursuant to this section may be approved by resolution.
(Ord. 358 §1.5, 2000)
CHAPTER 3.40
FLOWAGE FEES FOR ALL FUELS DELIVERED TO AIRCRAFT ON ELY AIRPORT/YELLAND FIELD
SECTION:
3.40.010: Definitions
3.40.020: Flowage Fees
3.40.030: Fixed Base Operators Exempt
3.40.010: DEFINITIONS:
FUEL: Includes both aviation fuel and fuel for jet or turbine powered aircraft.
(Ord. 457, 2014)
3.40.020: FLOWAGE FEES:
   A.   A flowage fee of ten cents ($0.10) per gallon will be assessed against
all transient operators who provide their own fuel to aircraft on Ely Airport/
Yelland Field. (Ord. 457, 2014)
3.40.030: FIXED BASE OPERATORS EXEMPT:
Any fixed base operator who operates under a lease with White Pine County that
addresses flowage fees is exempt from the fee provided for in section
3.40.020 of this chapter. (Ord. 457, 2014)
CHAPTER 3.50
TELEPHONE SURCHARGE
SECTION:
3.50.010: Authority And Purpose
3.50.020: Definitions
3.50.030: Establishment Of Advisory Committee
3.50.040: Chairman, Election, And Duties
3.50.050: Rules And Regulations
3.50.060: Quorum
3.50.070: Meetings
3.50.080: Creation Of Fund
3.50.090: Imposition Of Surcharge
3.50.100: Penalty
3.50.010: AUTHORITY AND PURPOSE:
This chapter is enacted pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 244A.7641 through
244A.7647 for the following purposes:
   A.   To establish an advisory committee to develop a five (5) year master
plan for the enhancement or improvement of the telephone system for reporting
of emergencies in White Pine County and to oversee any money allocated for that
purpose.
   B.   To impose a surcharge for the enhancement or improvement of the
telephone system for reporting an emergency in White Pine County on:
      1.   Each access line or trunk line of each customer to the local
exchange of any telecommunications provider providing those lines in White Pine
County; and
      2.   The mobile telephone service provided to each customer of that
service whose place of primary use is in White Pine County. (Ord. 459, 2016)
3.50.020: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the words and terms defined in this section have the
meanings ascribed to them unless the context requires otherwise:
INCUMBENT LOCAL EXCHANGE CARRIER: Has the meaning ascribed to it in 47 USC
section 251(h)(1), as that section existed on October 1, 1999, and includes a
local exchange carrier that is treated as an incumbent local exchange carrier
pursuant to that section.
MOBILE TELEPHONE SERVICE: Cellular or other service to a telephone installed in
a vehicle or which is otherwise portable.
PLACE OF PRIMARY USE: Has the meaning ascribed to it in 4 USC section 124(8),
as that section existed on August 1, 2002.
SUPPLIER: A person authorized by the federal communications commission to
provide mobile telephone service.
