CHAPTER 6.28
SPECIAL WEED CONTROL DISTRICT
SECTION:
6.28.010: Creation
6.28.020: General Powers
6.28.030: Governing Body
6.28.040: Modification By Resolution
6.28.050: Boundaries Of Weed Control District
6.28.060: Financial Impact Of District Or Regional District
6.28.070: Engineering Services
6.28.080: Legal Services
6.28.090: Performance Of Engineering And Legal Services On A Regional Basis
6.28.100: Services To Be Provided By District
6.28.110: Adoption Of Service Plan
6.28.010: CREATION:
There is created a "special weed control district" in White Pine County,
Nevada, which shall be entitled "White Pine County special weed control
district". (Ord. 343 §1.0, 1999)
6.28.020: GENERAL POWERS:
   A.   The special weed control district created shall have authority to
exercise the following powers:
      1.   Take whatever action necessary for the control, eradication and
removal of noxious weeds;
      2.   Join with other counties in the creation of a joint or regional
special weed control district;
      3.   Enter into such agreements with other counties, municipalities, or
other entities relating to weed control;
      4.   Receive from any other source such technical support, assistance,
supplies, materials and guidance necessary to give effect to this section;
      5.   Apply for and receive grants or other funds from other governmental
or private entities for the purpose of controlling, eradicating and removing
noxious weeds;
      6.   Enter into any agreement with advisors, experts or other specialists
regarding noxious weeds as is or may be necessary to effectuate the purposes of
the district. (Ord. 343 §1.1, 1999)
6.28.030: GOVERNING BODY:
The governing body for the special weed control district shall be the board of
county commissioners for White Pine County, Nevada. (Ord. 343 §1.2, 1999)
6.28.040: MODIFICATION BY RESOLUTION:
Any modification to this chapter may be made by resolution. The governing body,
may by resolution, enter into a regional special weed control district with
adjoining counties. (Ord. 343 §2.0, 1999)
6.28.050: BOUNDARIES OF WEED CONTROL DISTRICT:
The area of the weed control district shall be all lands, other than those
occupied by incorporated cities within the county of White Pine, Nevada. Such
boundary may include such other adjoining counties where the governing body
has, by resolution, determined to create a regional special weed control
district with permission of such other adjoining counties. (Ord. 343 §2.1,
1999)
6.28.060: FINANCIAL IMPACT OF DISTRICT OR REGIONAL DISTRICT:
The creation of any special district hereunder is not intended to impose upon
the county of White Pine, Nevada, any financial obligation. (Ord. 343 §2.2,
1999)
6.28.070: ENGINEERING SERVICES:
Any anticipated engineering services relating to this district shall be
performed by the county engineer as a part of his regular duties. (Ord. 343
§3.0, 1999)
6.28.080: LEGAL SERVICES:
Any legal services conducted hereunder will be performed by the office of the
White Pine County district attorney. (Ord. 343 §3.1, 1999)
6.28.090: PERFORMANCE OF ENGINEERING AND LEGAL SERVICES ON A REGIONAL BASIS:
Any engineering or legal services performed relating to any regional district
created by the governing body, with other adjoining counties, must be approved
by the governing body with the consent of the county engineer and district
attorney. (Ord. 343 §3.2, 1999)
6.28.100: SERVICES TO BE PROVIDED BY DISTRICT:
The district created hereunder shall be responsible for the control,
eradication and elimination of noxious weeds within the area of the district.
Such services are intended to be agricultural, safety related and aesthetic in
nature. (Ord. 343 §4.0, 1999)
6.28.110: ADOPTION OF SERVICE PLAN:
That certain "special weed control district service plan" accepted by the
governing body is made a part of the ordinance codified in this chapter. Any
provision of this chapter inconsistent with such service plan shall be governed
by the service plan. (Ord. 343 §5.1, 1999)
CHAPTER 6.29
NUISANCE CODE
SECTION:
6.29.100: Short Title
6.29.102: Purpose And Scope
6.29.104: Definitions
6.29.106: Unlawful Acts And Enforcement
6.29.108: Public Nuisances
6.29.110: Violation - Criminal Penalty
6.29.100: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be referred to as the NUISANCE CODE. The
White Pine County Code shall be known and may be referred to as the CODE. (Ord.
468, 2017)
6.29.102: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
The Board of County Commissioners determines and declares that an important
public purpose and need exist for its neighborhoods and community, including
property, buildings and environment, to be kept in a safe and clean condition
for the enhancement and maintenance of quality neighborhoods and positive
social and economic conditions in the community. This chapter is intended to
protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of unincorporated White
Pine County, and, except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it shall apply
to all property, buildings, and premises within unincorporated White Pine
County. All property owners and occupants thereof are required to maintain such
property in accordance with State law, this Code and this chapter. (Ord. 468,
2017)
6.29.104: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall be construed to
have the following meanings:
ANIMAL: Every living creature not a member of the human race.
ATTRACTIVE NUISANCE: Any property, structure, premises, instrument, equipment
or vehicle that is in such an unsafe and unprotected state as to constitute an
attraction to children or vagrants, criminals or other unauthorized persons to
their risk of injury or unlawful conduct.
BLIGHT: Conditions that substantially impair the livability of or community
appearance of, or the safe, social or economic conditions of, the surrounding
neighborhood or County community as stated in Nevada Revised Statutes 279.388,
as amended. Such conditions include, without limitation, the accumulation of
debris-refuse-rubbish; broken, rotting, crumbling, cracking or rusting fencing;
broken windows; landscaping that is dead or dying, or exhibits uncontrolled
growth; and any other similar conditions of disrepair and deterioration.
CRIMINAL GANG: As defined at Nevada Revised Statutes 193.168, as amended and
includes any combination of persons, organized formally or informally, so
constructed that the organization will continue its operation even if
individual members enter or leave the organization, which:
   A.   Has a common name or identifying symbol;
   B.   Has particular conduct, status and customs indicative of it; and
   C.   Has as one (1) of its common activities engaging in criminal activity
punishable as a felony, other than the conduct which constitutes the primary
offense.
DANGEROUS CONDITION OR STRUCTURE: A condition or structure that may injure or
endanger the health, life, property or safety of the general public or the
occupants of the property on which the condition or structure is located. This
phrase includes, without limitation, a condition or structure that violates any
rule, regulation, ordinance or code regulating health and safety enacted,
adopted or passed by the Board of County Commissioners, including without
limitation any rule, regulation, ordinance, or code adopted pursuant to Nevada
Revised Statutes 244.3675, as amended concerning minimum levels of health or
safety, the violation of which is designated as a nuisance in the rule,
regulation, ordinance, or code.
DEBRIS-REFUSE-RUBBISH: Material that is discarded, worn out or cast off without
regard to value; and is of a non-decaying nature, or is capable of
decomposition to a putrid state, or is of solid or semi-solid wastes. Examples
are: animal carcasses; accumulation of excrement; leaves; trimmings from brush,
lawns, trees, gardens or shrubbery; weeds; dead trees and branches; piles of
earth mixed with any of the matter set forth in this definition; manure; paper;
trash; cardboard; metal; wood; glass; crockery; bedding; scrap; appliances;
furniture; equipment; parts; junk vehicles; construction waste.
ENFORCEMENT OFFICIAL: The Board of County Commissioners, the Sheriff, County,
City, or Volunteer Fire Chief(s), and County Health Officer or their authorized
designees, as well as the County Building Official, inspectors or other Code
Enforcement Officials in the County Departments of Building and Planning, Parks
and Maintenance, and Public Works, as well as Animal Control Officers and any
other White Pine County employee possessing citation powers pursuant to Nevada
Revised Statutes 171.17751, as amended.
GARBAGE: Putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
storage, preparation, cooking, and sale and serving of food and beverage.
Examples are: offal; swill; kitchen and table waste; organic animal and
vegetable waste; bottles, cans, cups, plates, utensils, or containers that have
been in intimate contact with food, confection, or beverage; and, any component
used in the preparation or manufacture of matter intended for animal or human
consumption.
GRAFFITI: Any markings, as initials, word, figure, design, slogans, or
drawings, written, spray-painted, etched, scratched, or sketched on a sidewalk,
wall of a public or private building, private property, public restroom, public
infrastructure, signage, or the like, which defaces such property.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: As defined at Nevada Revised Statutes 459.430, as amended,
means any waste or combination of wastes, including, without limitation,
solids, semisolids, liquids or contained gases, except household waste, which:
   A.   Because of its quantity or concentration or its physical, chemical or
infectious characteristics may:
      1.   Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or
serious irreversible or incapacitating illness; or
      2.   Pose a substantial hazard or potential hazard to human health,
public safety or the environment when it is given improper treatment, storage,
transportation, disposal or other management.
   B.   Is identified as hazardous by the White Pine County Board of Health, or
as otherwise designated as hazardous material by the White Pine County Fire
Chief, City Fire Chief, or a Volunteer Fire Chief.
The term includes, among other wastes, toxins, corrosives, flammable materials,
irritants, strong sensitizers and materials which generate pressure by
decomposition, heat or otherwise.
JUNK VEHICLE: A street-legal or non-highway vehicle, including component parts,
which is ruined, dismantled or inoperable for any reason, or otherwise unused
for its original purpose; or, a street-legal vehicle that does not possess a
current, valid vehicle registration.
MOTORCYCLE: Every motor vehicle designed to travel on not more than three (3)
wheels in contact with the ground, except any such vehicle as may be included
within the term "tractor" or "moped" as defined in Nevada Revised Statutes
chapter 482, as amended.
OBSTRUCTION: The prevention of travel across or along the pathway of any public
road by, among other things, constructing gates, closing gates, signage or any
other impediment limiting the public use of the public road.
OFF-ROAD VEHICLE: Any motorized vehicle, including a motorcycle, designed for
or capable of cross-country travel on or immediately over land, water, sand,
snow, ice, marsh, swampland, or other natural terrain.
POLLUTANT: As defined at Nevada Revised Statutes 445A.400, as amended and
includes:
   A.   Dredged soil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage
sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive
materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt and
industrial, municipal and agricultural waste discharged into water.
   B.   Pollutant does not mean water, gas or other material which is injected
into a well to facilitate production of oil or gas, or water derived in
association with oil or gas production and disposed of in a well, if the well
is used either for facilitating production or for disposal purposes and if the
White Pine County Board of Health determines that such injection or disposal
will not result in the degradation of ground or surface water resources.
   C.   Further, pollutant does not mean water, gas or other material injected
into a well or used to stimulate a reservoir of geothermal resources if the
White Pine County Board of Health determines that the injection or stimulation
will not result in the degradation of ground or surface water resources.
PUBLIC ROAD: A road adjudicated public by any court of competent jurisdiction
within the State of Nevada, or a road established public pursuant to Nevada
Revised Statutes 405.195, as amended, or a road dedicated to and accepted by a
governmental agency, or a road defined as set forth at Nevada Revised Statutes
405.191, as amended.
PUBLIC VIEW: Plainly visible from the public right-of-way, or from any
regularly used location on public or private property. Items enclosed and
visually obscured within a structure, or within a lawful screen are not
considered to be in public view.
RESIDENTIAL FORECLOSURE: The sale of a single family residence pursuant to
Nevada Revised Statutes 40.430, as amended.
SCREEN: To provide physical separation and visual obscuration of one (1) area
from another on all sides and in all seasons. Such separation must be at least
six feet (6') high and includes, but is not limited to, the combination or
individual use of a fence, decorative wall, structure, earth berm or dense
landscaping.
SOLID WASTE: All putrescible and non-putrescible refuse in solid or semisolid
form. The term does not include hazardous waste.
STRUCTURE: That which is built or constructed, or an edifice or building of any
kind or any piece of work that is man-made or composed of parts joined together
in some definite manner.
VEHICLE: Any self-propelled instrument of conveyance designed primarily for the
transportation of persons or goods.
Non-Highway Vehicle: Any instrument of conveyance or off-road vehicle which
cannot be lawfully licensed or registered for use on public highways, streets,
roads, or other public ways. Examples include, but are not limited to, dune
buggies, all- terrain vehicles, snowmobiles, boats, and personal water craft.
Street-Legal Vehicle: Any instrument of conveyance which can be lawfully
licensed or registered for use on public highways, streets, roads, or other
public ways. Examples include, but are not limited to, automobiles, trucks,
vans, trailers, motor homes or recreational vehicles, campers, motorcycles, and
mopeds.
WELFARE: The public's well-being in any respect including matters of health,
peace, safety, order, and morals. (Ord. 468, 2017)
6.29.106: UNLAWFUL ACTS AND ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be unlawful to maintain, or permit to be maintained, the nuisances
described in this chapter, as well as those matters described in this Code as a
"public nuisance", within the unincorporated area of White Pine County. Any
violation cited by an enforcement official pursuant to this chapter or chapter
6.30 of this title, as amended, shall be subject to the remedies and
enforcement provisions of the codes. The enforcement official must not issue
notices of violation or citations in a field of enforcement in which the
official is not employed, but in the event this occurs it alone shall not serve
to invalidate the notice or citation. (Ord. 468, 2017)
6.29.108: PUBLIC NUISANCES:
In the unincorporated area of the County, a public nuisance is anything
described in this chapter as such, and is further defined as:
   A.   The existence of any dangerous condition or structure, or any property
in a condition adverse or detrimental to public health, safety, or general
welfare.
   B.   Maintenance of property, or any structure, in such a state of disrepair
or deterioration that could:
      1.   Cause harm to persons, or
      2.   Cause damage to property or improvements in the immediate vicinity,
or
      3.   Cause or contribute to blight and cause a substantial reduction of
economic value of neighboring properties.
   C.   Structures that have been partially constructed and have not made
substantial progress towards completion for a period of nine (9) months or
longer, or structures that have been partially destroyed or demolished by fire
or other causes and remain in such a state for a period of nine (9) months or
longer.
   D.   Property having adjacent sidewalks, parkways, and/or alleys that are
not maintained in a safe and sanitary condition, including, but not limited to,
trash, weeds, oil, or similar conditions that interfere with their use.
   E.   Any vegetation, equipment or structure that may endanger in any manner
the security or safe use of, or any access to, any street, utility line, sewer
or public improved place.
   F.   The existence of debris-refuse-rubbish or garbage that could cause harm
to persons, or be materially detrimental to property or improvements in the
immediate vicinity, or could cause appreciable diminution of property values in
the immediate vicinity, or contribute to blight and appreciable diminution of
the use, enjoyment, or aesthetic value of property or improvements in the
immediate vicinity, or could become a harborage for rodents or other vermin, an
attractive nuisance, a fire hazard, or in any other way detrimental to public
health, safety, or welfare. Large, remote lands in their natural state, and
difficult to service with large machinery due to terrain and governmental
regulations, are exempt unless an actual and probable danger exists.
   G.   The existence of any of the following on the exterior of the property
of a residential foreclosure:
      1.   Excessive foliage growth which diminishes the value of the property
or of surrounding properties;
      2.   Trespassers remaining on the property;
      3.   Mosquito larvae growing in standing water; and
      4.   Any other condition that creates a nuisance as provided in this
chapter. Any enforcement of this section must be consistent with the provisions
concerning residential foreclosures within Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 40,
as amended.
   H.   Outdoor storage of any building materials, appliances, debris- refuse-
rubbish, junk vehicles, or garbage in public view except as otherwise permitted
by this chapter or as otherwise authorized. Junk vehicles authorized for
display by County written permission are exempt from this section.
   I.   Structures used for the unlawful manufacture or distribution of
controlled substances as defined in and regulated pursuant to Nevada Revised
Statutes chapter 453, as amended.
   J.   A building or place regularly and continuously used by the members of a
criminal gang to engage in, or facilitate the commission of, crimes by the
criminal gang.
Any enforcement of this section must be consistent with the provisions
concerning criminal gangs within Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 244, as
amended.
   K.   Attractive nuisances, except as otherwise provided in Nevada Revised
Statutes 40.140, as amended, concerning agricultural activity and shooting
ranges.
   L.   Land that has been altered so as to cause or contribute to erosion,
subsidence, or surface water drainage impacting public or private property.
   M.   The grading of land in any manner except as authorized pursuant to
title 17 of this code, as amended. The grading of land incidental to the use of
land for existing farming activities is exempt from this section.
   N.   The discharge of pollutants into receiving waters or into the County's
stormwater management system.
   O.   The existence of hazardous waste in a manner not consistent with
applicable County, State or Federal regulations.
   P.   Obstruction of a public road or recorded public trails.
   Q.   The operation of a motorcycle or an off-road vehicle on public or
private land within three hundred feet (300') of any residence owned or
occupied by another unless for:
      1.   Purposes of ingress onto or egress from the operator's property, or
      2.   Traditional use for property maintenance or on property actively
used primarily for farming, or
      3.   Operation of a lawful vehicle on public streets and highways, or
      4.   The official business of the military, fire, emergency or law
enforcement.
   R.   With the exception of pre-existing agricultural activities pursuant to
Nevada Revised Statutes 40.140, as amended, the keeping, harboring or owning
any animal that by making loud and frequent sounds causes annoyance to, or
disturbance of the peace or comfort of, the neighborhood or a reasonable person
of normal sensitivities in the vicinity.
   S.   Any animal, except domestic cats, found off the real property of or not
under the control of its owner or other person responsible for it within the
congested areas as established in title 8 of this Code, as amended.
   T.   Parking in or obstructing an officially designated fire lane or fire
hydrant.
   U.   Marking, etching, scratching, drawing, or painting graffiti. (Ord. 468,
2017)
6.29.110: VIOLATION - CRIMINAL PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter hereby
adopted or fail to comply with said chapter shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor, and shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) or by imprisonment in the White Pine County Jail for a term
not to exceed six (6) months, or by both fine and imprisonment. (Ord. 468,
2017)
CHAPTER 6.30
CIVIL ACTIONS TO ENJOIN, ABATE OR RESTRAIN NUISANCES
SECTION:
6.30.010: Findings Of County Commissioners
6.30.015: Violations Of Adopted Construction Codes Designated Nuisances
6.30.020: District Attorney Authorized To Bring Civil Actions
6.30.030: Actions Brought In Name Of County; Signature By District Attorney,
Deputy
6.30.040: Control Of Prosecution, Defense By County Commissioners
6.30.050: Recoupment Of Costs Of Abatement
6.30.060: Service And Contents Of Notice
6.30.070: Appeal Of Order
6.30.010: FINDINGS OF COUNTY COMMISSIONERS:
The County Commission hereby reserves all powers and duties to abate those
nuisances identified in this Code pursuant to the authority and mechanisms
outlined in Nevada Revised Statutes 244.360 through Nevada Revised Statutes
244.363. However, in view of the numerous uniform codes and rules and
regulations incorporated therein that have been adopted by the Board of County
Commissioners, the Board of County Commissioners finds that it is desirable to
authorize the District Attorney pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 252.110, in
accordance with the powers conferred on the Board by Nevada Revised Statutes
244.360(5), to bring any necessary civil actions in courts of law to enforce
such uniform codes, rules and regulations, including prosecution pursuant to
section
6.29.110 of this title. (Ord. 468, 2017)
6.30.015: VIOLATIONS OF ADOPTED CONSTRUCTION CODES DESIGNATED NUISANCES:
   A.   The violation of any provision of a code or standard for construction,
including any amendment or modification to a uniform code for construction, is
declared to be, and is designated as, a nuisance and may be enjoined,
collected, abated or restrained in the manner provided in section
6.30.020 of this chapter, and further, may be prosecuted by the District
Attorney for a misdemeanor pursuant to section
6.29.110 of this title.
   B.   For purposes of this section "code or standard for construction" means
and includes, without limitation, the most recent version of the codes or
standards set forth in or as incorporated, amended and modified in title 14 of
this Code such as, but not limited to, the various volumes and editions of the
Building Code, the Uniform Plumbing Code, the National Electrical Code, the
Uniform Fire Code, the Uniform Mechanical Code and the Uniform Sign Code. (Ord.
468, 2017)
6.30.020: DISTRICT ATTORNEY AUTHORIZED TO BRING CIVIL ACTIONS:
Pursuant to the authority granted the Board of County Commissioners in
subsection 6 of Nevada Revised Statutes 244.360, the District Attorney is
authorized, in his discretion, to bring all necessary civil actions in any
court of competent jurisdiction on behalf of the County to enjoin, abate or
restrain the continued violation of any duly enacted or adopted ordinance, rule
or regulation of the County having the force and effect of law, including any
rule or regulation contained within any specialized or uniform code and changes
thereto adopted by ordinance, such as, but not limited to, the various volumes
and editions of the Building Code, the Uniform Plumbing Code, the National
Electrical Code, the Uniform Fire Code, the Uniform Mechanical Code and the
Uniform Sign Code, if the violation is designated as or otherwise constitutes a
nuisance. (Ord. 468, 2017)
6.30.030: ACTIONS BROUGHT IN NAME OF COUNTY; SIGNATURE BY DISTRICT ATTORNEY,
DEPUTY:
All civil actions filed by the District Attorney pursuant to sections
6.30.010 to
6.30.040 of this chapter, inclusive, shall be brought in the name of the
County, and all pleadings and other necessary documents shall be signed by the
District Attorney or his deputy as Attorney for the County. (Ord. 468, 2017)
6.30.040: CONTROL OF PROSECUTION, DEFENSE BY COUNTY COMMISSIONERS:
Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 244.165, the Board of County Commissioners
has the power and jurisdiction to control the prosecution or defense of all
civil actions filed pursuant to sections
6.30.010 to
 6.30.030 of this chapter, inclusive. (Ord. 468, 2017)
6.30.050: RECOUPMENT OF COSTS OF ABATEMENT:
Pursuant to those procedures outlined in Nevada Revised Statutes 244.3605 the
County may impose a special assessment against the offending property to
recover those actual costs incurred to abate the nuisance, as well as to
collect on any civil penalty allowed pursuant to statute or County Code. (Ord.
468, 2017)
6.30.060: SERVICE AND CONTENTS OF NOTICE:
Service of written notice and order under this chapter or chapter 6.03 of this
title, may be affected by personal service by those Enforcement Officials
designated in sections
6.03.090 and
6.29.104 of this title, and Nevada Revised Statutes, or by certified mailing,
return receipt requested. The notice must identify the nuisance, identify which
part of the Code or Nevada Revised Statutes identifies the nuisance as such,
and include the date by which the owner must abate the public nuisance allowing
for a minimum of thirty (30) days for the property owner or occupant to abate
the nuisance if not an immediate danger to the public health. (Ord. 468, 2017)
6.30.070: APPEAL OF ORDER:
Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 244.3605, an individual served with notice
to abate a nuisance, is hereby afforded an opportunity for a hearing with the
enforcement official and may appeal the order to abate unto the County
Commission or unto a court of competent jurisdiction. Any such request for a
hearing, or a notice of appeal, must be filed in writing to the enforcement
official and with the White Pine County Clerk within twenty one (21) calendar
days of receipt of the notice. The date specified in the notice by which the
nuisance is to be abated will be tolled for the period during which the owner
files the request for a hearing or notice of appeal and receives a final
decision. (Ord. 468, 2017)
CHAPTER 6.40
FAMILY CEMETERIES
SECTION:
6.40.010: Designation Of A Family Cemetery
6.40.020: Requirements Prior To Interment
6.40.030: Authority To Prohibit Interment
6.40.040: Severability
6.40.010: DESIGNATION OF A FAMILY CEMETERY:
Any natural person or persons may designate as a family cemetery an area of
land owned by any of those persons, within White Pine County, Nevada, but
outside incorporated Ely City limits, for the interment of the human dead in
that area without charge of any member of the family or any other person. (Ord.
494, 2018)
6.40.020: REQUIREMENTS PRIOR TO INTERMENT:
   A.   Before the first interment in a family cemetery designated in
accordance with this chapter, a member of the family or a representative of the
family shall:
      1.   Notify the Division of Public and Behavioral Health of the
Department of Health and Human Services of the designation of the family
cemetery and its specific location on the land owned by the family and;
      2.   Obtain the permission of the White Pine County Board of County
Commissioners. (Ord. 494, 2018)
6.40.030: AUTHORITY TO PROHIBIT INTERMENT:
   A.   The White Pine County Board of County Commissioners may prohibit
interment of the human dead within a family cemetery designated in accordance
with this chapter if:
      1.   All or any part of the cemetery as a burial place for the human dead
is not in accordance with the health, safety, comfort or welfare of the public
or;
      2.   The parcel of land upon which the family cemetery is designated is
less than forty (40) acres in size. (Ord. 494, 2018)
6.40.040: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this chapter or amendments thereto, or the application of
this chapter to any person, thing, or circumstance is held to be invalid or
unconstitutional, the remaining provisions of this chapter shall continue to be
in full force and effect. (Ord. 494, 2018)

CEMETERY PROVISIONS
SECTION:
7.04.010: Establishment Of Procedures For New Purchases Of Burial Plots At The
Cemetery

1 1. NRS §§403.010 et seq., 403.110 et seq., 244.155, 403.600, 403.610.
7.04.010: ESTABLISHMENT OF PROCEDURES FOR NEW PURCHASES OF BURIAL PLOTS AT THE
CEMETERY:
   A.   It shall be the policy of White Pine County that all fees for new
burial plots, including, but not limited to, purchase of burial plot, payment
of perpetual care charges, and opening and closing costs, if applicable, shall
be collected at the time of purchase, subject to the following payment options:
      1.   Payment in full at the time of purchase.
      2.   Payment in full within ninety (90) days of purchase, interest free.
(Ord. 387 §1, 2004)
7.04.020: ESTABLISHMENT OF POLICY FOR COLLECTION OF ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE:
   A.   Should the purchaser fail to comply with the conditions of the payment
option chosen, one of the following will be administratively applied at the
county's option:
      1.   Ownership of unoccupied burial plot shall revert back to the county
of White Pine and a refund of all amounts paid, less the service charge, if
applicable, shall be made;
      2.   The account may be sent to the county's current collection agency;
or
      3.   The account may be submitted to the district attorney for
collection. (Ord. 387 §1, 2004)

CHAPTER 7.05
COUNTY PROPERTY
SECTION:
7.05.010: Purpose Of Appraiser Provisions
7.05.020: List Of Qualified Appraisers
7.05.030: Appraiser Selection Process
7.05.010: PURPOSE OF APPRAISER PROVISIONS:
Pursuant to the legislative mandate of Nevada Revised Statutes 244.2795(2), the
board of county commissioners of the county of White Pine does hereby adopt
this chapter establishing the procedures for creating and amending a list of
appraisers qualified to conduct appraisals of real property offered for sale or
lease by the board. This chapter applies when the county is offering real
property for sale or lease except as otherwise provided by state law including,
but not limited to, those exceptions contained in Nevada Revised Statutes
244.2795. For the purposes of Nevada Revised Statutes 244.281(3) only, the
board hereby finds and resolves that all county owned parcels are worth more
than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) if offered for sale and authorizes the
county to follow the procedures of section
7.05.030 of this chapter to select appraisers without first having to obtain
another resolution of the board. (Ord. 464, 2016)
7.05.020: LIST OF QUALIFIED APPRAISERS:
   A.   The county shall obtain from the Nevada real estate division a list of
all qualified appraisers in White Pine County. The county shall send a request
for qualification to each appraiser on that list to determine which appraisers
are interested in performing appraisals for sale or lease of county property.
The request for qualifications shall ask the appraiser to designate whether he
or she is willing and qualified to provide an appraisal for the subject
property(ies). The request shall also ask whether the appraiser will and is
qualified to appraise county owned property to be leased. An appraiser who
fails to respond to the request for qualifications for the property(ies) within
the time specified in the request is not eligible to perform appraisals for the
county until requests for qualifications are next released.
   B.   From the responses to the request for qualifications the county shall
prepare a list of appraisers qualified to conduct appraisals of real property
offered for sale or lease by the board. The following standards shall be used
to determine minimum qualifications:
      1.   The appraiser must possess all necessary licenses;
      2.   The appraiser must not have violated professional appraiser
standards or statutory requirements in the performance of appraisals or cannot
have been disciplined or fined by any state or federal agency for conduct that
relates to the ability of the appraiser to perform the work to be required by
the county;
      3.   The appraiser must have the ability to obtain and maintain insurance
coverage as required by the county;
      4.   The appraiser must have the professional qualifications and
experience for the specific appraisal required by the county;
      5.   During the five (5) years immediately preceding the date of the
appointment by the county the appraiser cannot have filed as a debtor in a
business capacity under the provisions of the United States bankruptcy code or
breached any contracts with a public agency or person in this state or any
other state;
      6.   The appraiser's application must be truthful and complete; and
      7.   The appraiser must execute the application form and consent to and
have the ability to satisfy all terms and conditions contained in any proposed
contract for appraisal services presented by the county.
   C.   Appraisers on the list shall keep the county informed of any change in
the status of standards listed in subsections B1 through B6 of this section.
The change in the appraiser's status or failure to maintain the minimum
qualifications is cause for immediate removal from the list by the county. The
county shall provide written notice to any appraiser of his or her removal.
   D.   The names on the list shall be labeled to indicate the appraiser's
willingness and qualification to perform the appraisal(s) on the subject
property(ies). The names on the list must be organized in a random order in a
fashion determined by the county.
   E.   The names of appraisers who are organized in a firm of appraisers may
be placed on the list independently if each is independently qualified. No two
(2) appraisers from the same firm can be selected to appraise the same real
property. An appraiser who cannot be selected because of an appraisal firm
relationship retains his or her place on the list for the next appraisal
required by the county.
   F.   From time to time the county shall obtain a new list from the state
real estate division and follow the procedures in subsections B and C of this
section to assemble a new list. An appraiser whose name is stricken from the
list as required in subsection 7.05.030B of this chapter may be added to the
new list if properly qualified and responsive. (Ord. 464, 2016)
7.05.030: APPRAISER SELECTION PROCESS:
   A.   When an appraisal is required for the sale or lease of county real
property the county shall send a request for proposal to the appraiser whose
name is next on the list for the type of property appraisal required. The
request shall identify the property to be appraised, the desired terms and
conditions of appraisal and the requirements for the response to the request
for proposal. The response from the appraiser must include: a statement of
specific qualifications to do the type of appraisal required; a proposal that
complies with the terms and conditions of the request for proposal; the names
of other appraisers in the appraiser's firm, if any; a disclosure statement
which includes, without limitation, all sources of income of the appraiser that
may constitute a conflict of interest, any prior appraisal by the appraiser of
the subject property and any relationship of the appraiser with the county, the
owner of the subject property or the owners of any adjoining property to the
one being appraised; and a statement that the appraiser is not related within
the first degree of consanguinity or affinity to any person who has an interest
in the real property or an adjoining property.
   B.   If an appraiser responds to the request in terms that are responsive
and satisfactory to the county, the appraiser's proposal shall be presented to
the board of county commissioners which shall verify the qualifications of the
appraiser. The determination of the board as to qualifications is conclusive.
An appraiser's name shall be stricken from the list for the type of appraisal
requested if the appraiser does not satisfactorily respond to the request as
determined by the county or the board declines to verify the appraiser's
qualifications.
   C.   The assessor shall use the list and repeat the selection procedures
until the board approves an appraiser. To expedite the selection process, the
county may send a request for proposal to more than one appraiser on the list.
Those appraisers who respond but are not selected shall retain their places on
the list. The county may also send the name of more than one appraiser to the
board but shall report to the board the order of the appraisers on the list.
(Ord. 464, 2016)
CHAPTER 7.08
COUNTY ROADS
SECTION:
7.08.010: Construction Limitations
7.08.020: Use By Heavy Equipment
7.08.030: Arrangements With County Prior To Heavy Use
7.08.040: Improvement Of Designated Roads Only; Emergency Exceptions
7.08.050: Criminal Penalty
7.08.060: Civil Penalty
7.08.010: CONSTRUCTION LIMITATIONS:
County road construction shall be devoted to the improvement or realignment
only of roads currently in the County Road Inventory system. (Ord. 11/9/74 §1,
1974; amd. Ord. 514, 9-9-2020; Ord. 547, 5-28-2025)
7.08.020: USE BY HEAVY EQUIPMENT:
All maintenance, repairs or improvements necessitated by more than occasional
use of roads by "heavy equipment" shall be provided by the user thereof, and no
heavy usage shall be allowed without prior satisfactory arrangements first
having been made with the board of county commissioners of White Pine County,
Nevada, acting through its authorized agent.
 
HEAVY      Means eight thousand (8,000) pounds per single axle or thirty two thousand
EQUIPMENT: (32,000) pounds for tandem axles, with an overall weight of seventy six thousand
           eight hundred (76,800) pounds.
HEAVY
USAGE OR   Means all use that is not "occasional use.
HEAVY USE:
OCCASIONAL Means personal, pleasure, family, and use for agricultural purposes, occurring
USE:       at infrequent intervals, as incidental, or as casual; that is, as distinguished
           from events of a similar nature recurring with some degree of regularity.
           Means the person or entity who travels over the road, or the person or entity
USER:      who hires another person or entity to travel over the road on its behalf or for
           its benefit. "User" does not mean the United States Postal Service or any like
           package delivery entity. (Ord. 11/19/74 §§2, 3, 1974; amd. Ord. 514, 9-9-2020)
 
7.08.030: ARRANGEMENTS WITH COUNTY PRIOR TO HEAVY USE:
Any user of heavy equipment who intends to engage in the heavy use of heavy
equipment on a County road shall first:
   A.   Submit to the Public Works Director a road maintenance agreement laying
out the following:
      1.   The full name of the user, including the corporate name, if
applicable.
      2.   If the user is a corporation, the state of incorporation, the
corporate address, the names of the officers of the corporation and a local
contact for the corporation.
      3.   If user is a partnership, the full name and contact information for
each member thereof.
      4.   The nature or type of the business or operation;
      5.   The location where the business or operation will be carried out and
the roads sought to be used;
      6.   The start and end dates of the business or operation;
      7.   A guarantee signed by one with authority to act on behalf of the
user guaranteeing that the user maintain the road or roads used to their
current condition.
   B.   Receive the permission of the County prior to operation or use of the
County road. (Ord. 814, 9-9-2020)
7.08.040: IMPROVEMENT OF DESIGNATED ROADS ONLY; EMERGENCY EXCEPTIONS:
No county maintenance, repairs or improvements shall be performed on
nondesignated roads, except during an emergency situation or as a gratuity for
road materials or additional right of way, unless such maintenance or repairs
are approved by the Board of County Commissioners. (Ord. 11/19/74 §4, 1974;
amd. Ord. 514, 9-9-2020)
7.08.050: CRIMINAL PENALTY:
Any person who fails to comply with or violates any provision of this Title
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable up to six (6) months in the
county jail and/or a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) fine for each violation.
(Ord. 814, 9-9-2020)
7.08.060: CIVIL PENALTY:
In addition to any criminal penalty imposed by this Title, any violation of
this Title may result in a civil fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for
each violation. The civil penalties provided for in this Title are intended to
be cumulative and in addition to any criminal fines or punishments imposed. The
County need not seek nor attain criminal penalties prior to pursuing the civil
penalties allowed by this Title. All costs of collecting any such fine imposed
pursuant to this Title shall be borne by the violator of this Title. (Ord. 814,
9-9- 2020)
CHAPTER 7.10
PUBLIC ROADS
SECTION:
Article I. Public Road Defined
7.10.010: Defined
Article II. Private Road Use

7.10.070: Rights-Of-Way

7.10.080: Historic Use Defined
7.10.090: Historic Use Adopted

7.10.100: Immunity From Suit Relating To Public Roads
7.10.110: Immunity From Suit Relating To Minor Roads
Article VIII. Procedure For Abandonment

Article IX. Attachment Of Maps
7.10.130: Attachments
7.10.140: Reservation

7.10.160: Challenge By Governmental Entity
7.10.170: Challenge By Private Person

7.10.190: Protests
7.10.200: Intent
ARTICLE I. PUBLIC ROAD DEFINED
7.10.010: DEFINED:
The term "County road" is and shall be defined as each and every way, pathway,
trail, stock trail and driveway, road, County highway, railbed and other
similar public travel corridors across public lands in, and such other roads as
defined by section
7.10.020 of this chapter, White Pine County, connecting two (2) points of
societal importance (regardless of whether the points so connected are located
inside or outside the boundaries of White Pine County), whether established and
maintained by usage or mechanical means, whether passable by foot, beast of
burden, carts or wagons, or motorized/mechanized vehicles of each and every
sort, whether currently passable or impassable, that was established and
accepted by public use and enjoyment under common law doctrines of property
rights, under R.S. 2477, but only if established and accepted by public use and
enjoyment or under statutory authority, except state and U.S. highways. (Ord.
470, 2017: Ord. 350 art. I §1.0, 2000)
ARTICLE II. PRIVATE ROAD USE
7.10.020: USE:
Roads across private lands within White Pine County (County), not otherwise
established by other law or authority, are or shall be designated as County
roads only if they are offered to, accepted by and dedicated to the County,
according to the County's roads policies and regulations which then are in
effect.
   A.   Any person or entity requesting the County to adopt a private road for
public use must meet all of the requirements enumerated in White Pine County
Code (WPCC) Chapter 17.11 and submit documentation to the County evidencing the
following:
      1.   The recording of a dedicated public road right-of-way and/or
easement, including but not limited to, deeds and recorded surveyor maps;
      2.   The location of existing, and proposed, public and/or private water
supply, sewer system, electrical supply, gas/propane supply, and/or other
facilities, over, under, upon and/or adjacent to the road; and,
      3.   The meeting of the County's road standards, such as, but not limited
to, width of the right-of-way and/or easement, boundaries, lanes, shoulders,
paving or repaving, retrofitting, aprons, curbs and gutters, sidewalks,
lighting, driveways and other approaches, camber, slopes, emergency vehicle
cul-de-sac (turn-a-round) radius, road materials, grading, graveling,
compaction, surfaces, bridges, culvert installations, drainage, signage,
striping, traffic control and pedestrian control signals, and issues of public
safety, all of which are subject to and required to obtain the approval by the
County Road Superintendent, County Engineer, and/or other authorized County
official. (Ord. 470, 2017: Ord. 350 art. II §2.0, 2000; amd. Ord. 547, 5-28-
2025)
ARTICLE III. PUBLIC ROAD OWNERSHIP
7.10.030: OWNERSHIP:
   A.   All County roads are the property of White Pine County, as trustee for
the public users thereof.
   B.   The Board and/or the Board acting as Highway Commissioners, shall have
the authority to locate and determine the alignment and width of such rights-
of-way and open, reopen, establish, construct, rehabilitate, maintain and/or
close thereon County roads or highways, subject to applicable Federal laws and
regulations. (Ord. 470, 2017)
7.10.040: ACTION RELATED TO OWNERSHIP:
The Board shall not, except in the event of an emergency requiring immediate
action, make or implement decisions pursuant to the authority described by
section
7.10.030 of this article without first having advised the appropriate
government agency of its proposed decision or action; and, by and through the
memorandum of understanding processes, attempted to resolve any challenge or
opposition to such decision or action by the appropriate governmental agencies.
(Ord. 470, 2017)
ARTICLE IV. SUBSEQUENT ADOPTION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS
7.10.050: SUBSEQUENT ADOPTION:
The Board and/or the Board acting as Highway Commissioners, hereafter by
ordinance or resolution, will adopt all rules and regulations necessary and
proper to assure that decisions made and actions taken under its authority to
locate, lay out, open, construct, rehabilitate, maintain and/or close public
roads are made upon sufficient findings that such decisions and actions will
result in a benefit to the general public, will, avoid or mitigate to the
fullest extent reasonably possible any significant impairment of the
environment or natural resources; and, unless unavoidable for purposes of the
greater good, will not result in a significant reduction in the value of public
or private property. (Ord. 350 art. IV §4.0, 2000)
7.10.060: EFFECT UPON "TAKING ORDINANCE":
This section is not intended to modify ordinance 339, codified in title 1,
chapter 1.08 of this Code, enacted by the Board of County Commissioners May 12,
1999; that such ordinance shall control relating to any issue relating to the
taking of property by an entity of government, notwithstanding any provision
herein to the contrary. (Ord. 350 art. IV §4.1, 2000)
ARTICLE V. COUNTY RIGHTS-OF-WAY
7.10.070: RIGHTS-OF-WAY:
   A.   A person violates White Pine County's right-of-way concerning any
County road, trail, or gate as defined by section
7.10.010 of this chapter, or any other road across public land, by blocking,
restricting, or otherwise interfering with the public access, use, or enjoyment
of that right-of-way, utilizing a vehicle or otherwise.
      1.   A violation of White Pine County's right-of-way to any County road,
trail, or gate as defined by section
7.10.010 of this chapter shall be considered a violation of Nevada Revised
Statutes 484B.450 and 484B.510.
      2.   Law Enforcement, Emergency Services, Road Departments, or other
designated agents of White Pine County may reasonably control the County's
right-of-way - including blocking, restricting, or limiting access, use, or
enjoyment - when acting pursuant to their official duties, without violating
this section.
      3.   A lawful closure or blockage will necessitate prior approval by the
County Commission after application through the White Pine County Sheriff's
Office and public hearing or as otherwise required by the Nevada Revised
Statutes. (Ord. 470, 2017)
ARTICLE VI. HISTORIC ROAD USE
7.10.080: HISTORIC USE DEFINED:
Historic use or practice means a period of twenty (20) years or more. (Ord. 350
art. VI §6.0, 2000)
7.10.090: HISTORIC USE ADOPTED:
The Board here adopts and ratifies historic uses and practices in White Pine
County allowing for maintenance of County roads by usage or mechanical means;
and, the Board's decision to not mechanically maintain any one (1) or more of
the roads shall not terminate, or affect in any way, the status of such roads
as County roads. (Ord. 470, 2017: Ord. 350 art. VI §6.1, 2000)
ARTICLE VII. IMMUNITY FROM SUIT
7.10.100: IMMUNITY FROM SUIT RELATING TO PUBLIC ROADS:
Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes section 405.193(2), no action may be
brought against White Pine County, its officers, or employees for damage
suffered by a person solely as a result of the unmaintained condition of a road
made public by the Board pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes section 405.195.
(Ord. 350 art. VII §7.0, 2000)
7.10.110: IMMUNITY FROM SUIT RELATING TO MINOR ROADS:
Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes section 403.170, White Pine County is
immune from liability for damages suffered by persons as a result of using any
road designated by the Board as a minor County road. (Ord. 350 art. VII §7.1,
2000)
ARTICLE VIII. PROCEDURE FOR ABANDONMENT
7.10.120: PROCEDURE:
Abandonment or road closure of any White Pine County road must follow the
procedures provided in Nevada Revised Statutes 405.195, including, but not
limited to, public hearings. (Ord. 350 art. VIII §8.0, 2000)
ARTICLE IX. ATTACHMENT OF MAPS
7.10.130: ATTACHMENTS:
Attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter (on file in the County
Clerk's Office) and incorporated herein are maps which specify and designate
those roads located within White Pine County which the Board, and/or the Board
acting as the Highway Commissioners, preliminarily has/have determined are
County roads, pursuant to the definition given hereinabove and all applicable
Federal and State law. (Ord. 470, 2017: Ord. 350 art. IX §9.0, 2000)
7.10.140: RESERVATION:
The Board expressly notes that the process of designation of such roads is not
complete; thus, the maps are not and shall not be deemed a comprehensive or
exhaustive listing or designation of those roads which are or may be County
roads. (Ord. 470, 2017: Ord. 350 art. IX §9.1, 2000)
7.10.150: UPDATE OF MAPS:
It is intended that these maps will be revised and reissued periodically, as
other or additional roads are determined to be County roads or roads
preliminarily so designated are determined, upon further review, not to be
appropriately or lawfully designated as County roads. (Ord. 470, 2017: Ord. 350
art. IX §9.2, 2000)
ARTICLE X. CHALLENGE TO DESIGNATION OF PUBLIC ROADS
7.10.160: CHALLENGE BY GOVERNMENTAL ENTITY:
Other entities of local, State, or Federal government, or any such other entity
of government shall have the standing and right to challenge the designation of
roads as County roads; when and if such entity, through its representatives,
believes that such designation is inappropriate and/or unlawful, based upon
application of Federal and State law and the history of the road(s). (Ord. 470,
2017: Ord. 350 art. X §10.0, 2000)
7.10.170: CHALLENGE BY PRIVATE PERSON:
A private person shall also have the standing and right to challenge the
designation of roads as County roads as provided in section
7.10.160 of this chapter. (Ord. 470, 2017: Ord. 350 art. X §10.1, 2000)
7.10.180: NOTICE:
The White Pine County Clerk, as Clerk of this Board, shall send copies of the
ordinance codified in this chapter and attached maps to other entities of
government, specifically for their review of the designation of County roads.
(Ord. 470, 2017: Ord. 350 art. X §10.2, 2000)
7.10.190: PROTESTS:
Any governmental entity or private person may protest the designation of public
roads by the Board of County Commissioners by the filing of a written protest
prior to final adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter. The Board
shall consider all such protests. (Ord. 350 art. X §10.3, 2000)
7.10.200: INTENT:
The intent of this article is to invite and encourage other governmental
entities to initiate the resolution process set forth in the memorandum of
understanding for any and all roads preliminarily designated as County roads
where any such have reason to believe that any designation made hereunder is
contrary to the best interests of the public, private rights of ownership or
applicable law. (Ord. 470, 2017: Ord. 350 art. X §10.4, 2000)
CHAPTER 7.11
STANDARDS FOR DEVELOPMENT OF DEDICATED ROADS
SECTION:
7.11.010: Generally–Definitions
7.11.020: Intent And Purpose
7.11.030: Scope
7.11.040: Use
7.11.050: Development Standards For Dedicated Roads
7.11.060: Paving, Aprons, Curb And Gutters Required
7.11.070: Road Grading, Graveling, Compaction, Re-paving Or Retrofit Required
7.11.080: Road Connects To Public Right Of Way
7.11.090: Acceptance Of Dedicated Road Into County Maintained Road System
7.11.100: Hardship Variance
7.11.110: Limited Reformation Or Repeal Of Conflicting Ordinances
7.11.120: Severability
7.11.010: GENERALLY–DEFINITIONS:
   A.   The definition and meanings of the following words and phrases, to wit,
"tentative map," "final map subdivisions," "subdivider," "design" and
"improvement" which are defined in the Nevada Revised Statutes (NRS) are used
in this Chapter as so defined, unless from the context it clearly appears that
a different meaning is intended.
   B.   The word "may" indicates an action which is permissive; the word
"shall" indicates an action which is mandatory; and, the word "must" indicates
an action which is mandatory.
   C.   All words in the singular include the plural and the plural the
singular. Each gender includes the other. Each tense includes other tenses.
ABUT: To be contiguous to and in actual contact along a common line.
ALLEY: Any dedicated way intended for vehicular service to the rear or the side
of property served by a public road.
APPROVE: Approved by the White Pine Board of County Commissioners (BOCC),
Regional Planning Commission (RPC), the County's Road Superintendent, County
Engineer, and/or County Department official, having jurisdiction and authority
over/on such matters, unless otherwise specified.
APPROVED PRIVATE ROAD: A strip of land approved by the BOCC for road purposes
which has not been dedicated or accepted as a public road, and which connects a
parcel of land with a public road.
COUNTY ROAD: See "Public road", White Pine County Code (WPCC) Section
7.11.010.
CUL-DE-SAC: A road which terminates in a permanent turnaround and which by
design is not intended to continue beyond its terminal point.
DEAD-END ROAD OR STUB ROAD: A road which is terminated at the boundary line of
the subdivision, but which will be required to be extended at a later date to
provide access to abutting land.
DEDICATED ROAD:
   A.   "Dedicated road" means any public street, avenue, boulevard, road,
lane, parkway, place, viaduct, easement for access or other way which is an
existing federal, state, county or municipal roadway; or, a street or way shown
on a final subdivision map or parcel map duly approved and subsequently filed
and recorded with the recorder's office or a record of Survey of Informational
Map prepared, approved and recorded as required by the Nevada Revised Statutes.
   B.   A dedicated road includes the land between the right-of-way lines,
whether improved or unimproved and may include, but not limited to, pavement,
shoulders, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, parking areas and lawns. A dedicated road
may or may not be part of the County maintained road system. An alley does not
qualify as a dedicated road in the context of this Chapter.
DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS: The director of public works for White Pine County
(County) or, if none, the County's Road Superintendent.
DIVIDER: A person who causes land to be divided for himself or others in a
manner which constitutes a land division.
DIVIDING STRIP: A separation between opposite directional flows of traffic. It
may also serve to separate a road or highway from the parallel frontage road
which provides access to the property.
DIVISION OF LAND: The division of any parcel of land shown on the latest
adopted tax assessment roll as a unit or contiguous units under one ownership
and which is divided for the purpose of sale, leasing or financing either
immediate or future into two, three or four parcels.
DOUBLE FRONTAGE LOT OR THROUGH LOT: A lot having frontage on two (2) roads and
having the right of access to both roads but excluding corner lots.
EASEMENT FOR PUBLIC ROAD: A right-of-way offered to the County for road
purposes by a division of land. Upon acceptance by the County, it is a County
road as defined in WPCC Section
7.11.010.
EXISTING LOT OR BUILDING SITE: A designated lot or contiguous lots on a
lawfully established subdivision map or record of survey existing on the
effective date of the ordinance codified in this Chapter, a whole parcel of
land under separate ownership so existing upon the effective date of this
Chapter, or such a lot or separate parcel of land thereafter lawfully created.
EXPRESSWAY: A highway for through traffic, with full or partial control of
access and generally with intersections at grade.
FREEWAY: A highway for through traffic, with full control of access and
generally with grade separation at intersections.
FRONTAGE: That portion of a parcel of property which abuts on a public or
approved private road.
FRONTAGE ROAD, SERVICE ROAD OR OUTER HIGHWAY: Those roads which parallel
freeways, expressways or highways providing for access to abutting property or
for circulation, and which are separated from the highway by a dividing strip.
MASTER PLAN: The long-range comprehensive master plan for the orderly
development of the County adopted by the BOCC, which may include any of the
elements listed in the Nevada Revised Statutes.
IMPROVEMENTS: Means and refers to only such roadwork and utilities to be
installed or agreed to be installed by the subdivider as are necessary for the
general use of the lot owners in the subdivision and local neighborhood traffic
and drainage needs as a condition precedent to the approval and acceptance of
the final map. The term also applies to similar installations required as
precedent to acceptance of a land division parcel map for a division of land.
IMPROVEMENT PLANS: The plans, profiles, cross-sections and specifications of
all proposed improvements, including but not limited to: Reimbursement for
Oversize Facilities. The BOCC and/or RPC may require a subdivider to install
oversized sewer, drainage or other facilities where the facilities will benefit
property not within the proposed development. If the agency which has
jurisdiction and operational control of such facilities by contract with the
subdivider agrees to reimburse him or his successor in interest.
IMPROVEMENT STANDARDS: The design and improvement requirements established by
the BOCC by ordinance or resolution applicable at the time of approval of the
tentative subdivision map or preliminary parcel map.
LAND DIVISION: See "Division of land", WPCC Section
7.11.010.
LOCAL ROAD: Any public road that is used or is intended to be used for the
principal purpose of serving as access to abutting property.
LOT:
   A.   A parcel of real property with a separate and distinct number or other
designation shown on a subdivision map recorded in the office of the County
recorder;
   B.   A parcel of real property delineated on an approved map of survey or
land division map as filed in the office of the County recorder and abutting at
least one public road or approved private road; or
   C.   A parcel of real property containing not less area than required by the
zone district in which it is located abutting at least one public road or
approved private road and held under separate ownership from adjacent property.
LOT SPLIT: See "Division of land", WPCC Section
7.11.010.
MAJOR ROAD OR HIGHWAY OR ARTERIAL: A highway designated as such in the major
street and highway plan, a part of the general plan of the County, adopted by
the BOCC.
NONACCESS LINE: A boundary line delineated on a subdivision map or described in
a deed which is for the purpose of prohibiting vehicle access.
OUT LOT: A lot designated alphabetically on the subdivision map for specific
use or nonuse.
PARCEL OF LAND: The whole of any numbered lot in an approved division or
subdivision or the whole of any other holding of abutting land under one
ownership.
PARCEL MAP: The map prepared in accordance with the approved preliminary parcel
map as provided for in the WPCC.
PERSON: Means and includes any individual, entity, firm, co-partnership, joint
venture, association, corporation, estate, receiver, syndicate or any group or
combination acting as a unit in the plural as well as the singular number.
PRECISE PLAN LINES: The future right-of-way lines or plan lines of any highway
as shown on the precise plan of street and highways for highway use as adopted
by the BOCC and/or RPC. A yard abutting a highway is to be measured from this
future right-of-way line.
PRELIMINARY PARCEL MAP: The map presented to the BOCC and/or the RPC for
approval for a division of land as provided for in the WPCC.
PRIVATE ROAD: See "Approved private road", WPCC Section
7.11.010.
PUBLIC ROAD: Any state highway, county or city street, avenue, highway or road
which is within the maintained road system of the public agency having
jurisdiction thereof or to be included within the maintained road system by
agreement between the agencies and the subdivider.
RESTRICTED ACCESS STRIP: A strip of land not less than one foot in width for
the purpose of regulating access to part width and dead-end roads until such
time as the roads may be completed or extended. "Restricted access strip" means
a designated strip of land, no less than one foot in width, intended to
regulate, restrict, or prohibit vehicular access to partial-width and dead-end
roads until such roads are completed or extended.
SETBACK LINE, FRONT YARD: The line which defines the depth of the required
front yard measured from the property line.
SETBACK LINE, REAR YARD OR SIDE YARD: The line which defines the width or depth
of the required rear yard or side yard measured from the property line.
SUBDIVIDER: A person who causes land to be divided into a subdivision for
himself or for others.
SUBDIVISION: Any real property, improved or unimproved, or portion thereof
shown on the latest adopted County tax roll as a unit or as contiguous units
which is divided for the purpose of sale, lease or financing whether immediate
or future by any subdivider into five or more parcels; provided, that this
Chapter will not apply to the leasing of apartments, offices, stores or similar
space within an apartment building, industrial building, commercial building or
mobile home park nor will this Chapter apply to mineral, oil or gas leases. The
term "subdivision" does not apply to any division of land which creates lots,
parcels, sites, units or plots of land, each of which comprise forty or more
acres of land including roads and roadway easements or the division of land for
agricultural purposes, in parcels of more than ten acres, not involving any
street, road or highway opening or widening nor will this term apply to other
exclusions contained in NRS Chapter 278.
WATERCOURSE: A strip of land over which water flows having a definite bed, bank
and channel wherein the water need not flow continually but usually flows in a
particular direction.
ZONE DISTRICT: The zone district established by a County zoning ordinance.
(Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.020: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
   A.   The provision of adequate access roads to all property is deemed
necessary in order to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of
White Pine County (County). It is the intent of this Chapter that development
of adequate access roads be the responsibility of the property dividers as
defined by the White Pine County Code (WPCC) and subdividers as defined by WPCC
Section
7.11.010.
   B.   In order to insure that all property being developed in the County is
served by adequate access roads to accommodate public travel in normal weather
conditions, including but not limited to, access for utility vehicles, delivery
service vehicles and emergency vehicles, this Chapter sets forth minimum
standards for development of dedicated roads as defined by WPCC Section
7.11.010. (Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.030: SCOPE:
As provided for in WPCC Section
7.11.020 through
7.11.110, this Chapter applies to all parcel maps, second or subsequent parcel
maps which make up or are part of a contiguous tract of land under the same
ownership and subdivision maps, any of which create a total of five or more
parcels of land. This Chapter does not apply to the division of land exempted
by NRS Chapter 278. (Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.040: USE:
Roads across private lands within White Pine County (County), not otherwise
established by other law or authority, are or shall be designated as County
roads only if they are offered to, accepted by and dedicated to the County,
according to the County's roads policies and regulations which then are in
effect.
   A.   Any person or entity requesting the County to adopt a private road for
public use must comply with all of the requirements of this Chapter and submit
documentation to the County evidencing the following:
      1.   The recording of a dedicated public road right-of-way and/or
easement, including but not limited to, deeds and recorded surveyor maps;
      2.   The location of existing, and proposed, public and/or private water
supply, sewer system, electrical supply, gas/propane supply, and/or other
facilities, over, under, upon and/or adjacent to the road; and,
      3.   The meeting of the County's road standards, such as, but not limited
to, width of the right-of-way and/or easement, boundaries, lanes, shoulders,
paving or repaving, retrofitting, aprons, curbs and gutters, sidewalks,
lighting, driveways and other approaches, camber, slopes, emergency vehicle
cul-de-sac (turn-a-round) radius, road materials, grading, graveling,
compaction, surfaces, bridges, culvert installations, drainage, signage,
striping, traffic control and pedestrian control signals, and issues of public
safety, all of which are subject to and required to obtain the approval by the
County Road Superintendent, County Engineer, and/or other authorized County
official. (Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.050: DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS FOR DEDICATED ROADS:
The following improvements to dedicated roads shall be in place, inspected and
approved by the County Road Superintendent, County Engineer, or other
authorized County official, prior to any final parcel or subdivision map being
approved, in writing, by the County Building and Planning Department for
recording:
   A.   Development Standards For Dedicated Roads:
 
Number of Lots             Five Through Twelve Thirteen and Over
Maximum road grade         8 percent (8%)      8 percent (8%)
Minimum right-of-way width 60 ft.              60 ft.
Minimum right-of-way       28 ft.              30 ft.
improved width
Minimum width of improved  20 ft. shoulder to  28 ft. shoulder to shoulder
driving lanes              shoulder
Minimum depth of ballast   4 inches            8 inches
material (base)
Minimum depth of surface   2 inches            4 inches
material
 
   B.   All dedicated roads constructed as a result of this Chapter shall be
improved to the nearest road which is passable in normal weather conditions as
determined by the County Road Superintendent, County Engineer, or other
authorized County official.
   C.   Where development of a dedicated road breaches an existing fence, a
County approved cattle guard shall be installed by the divider/subdivider and
inspected by the County Road Superintendent, County Engineer, or other
authorized County official.
   D.   Where not otherwise stated, the White Pine County Standard Details for
Public Work Construction ("Orange Book"), dated March 24, 1999 (Ord. 338, WPCC
Chapter 14.24), and subsequent revisions adopted by action of the BOCC, and/or,
when applicable, the most current addition of the American Association of State
Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) Geometric Design of Highways and
Streets ('Green Book"), and/or when applicable, the most current addition of
the AASHTO Guidelines for Geometric Design of Very Low-Volume Local Roads
(Annual Daily Traffic of 400 Vehicles or Less), shall apply to the construction
of all dedicated roads. (Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.060: PAVING, APRONS, CURB AND GUTTERS REQUIRED:
   A.   If, in the judgment of the County's Road Superintendent or County
Engineer, an unpaved road proposed for adoption by the County is subject to or
will foreseeably experience heavy traffic, or frequent needs for grading, re-
graveling, or dust control, or if there are concerns regarding, severe erosion,
drainage, environmental impacts, or other current or anticipated safety issues,
the road must be paved by the road owner(s) with either asphalt or concrete,
along with all of the required concrete curbs and gutters, in compliance with
the County's specifications and to the satisfaction of the County's Road
Superintendent or County Engineer.
   B.   If paving with asphalt or concrete is required for a paved or an
unpaved road to be considered for adoption, any driveway and/or other vehicle
access point connected to the road must include a concrete apron to preserve
the integrity of the paved road surface and prevent edge deterioration. The
concrete apron must meet the following minimum specifications: width of sixteen
feet (16'), length of twelve feet (12'), and depth of six inches (6"), and
completed to the satisfaction of the County's Road Superintendent or County
Engineer.
   C.   If an unpaved road is not required to be paved but connects to a
dedicated, paved County road, the road must include a concrete apron at the
connection point to preserve the integrity of the County's paved road surface
and prevent edge deterioration. The concrete apron must meet the following
minimum dimensions: width of sixteen feet (16'), length of twelve feet (12'),
and depth of six inches (6"), and completed to the satisfaction of the County's
Road Superintendent or County Engineer. (Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.070: ROAD GRADING, GRAVELING, COMPACTION, RE-PAVING OR RETROFIT REQUIRED:
   A.   If, in the judgment of the County's Road Superintendent or County
Engineer, an unpaved road proposed for adoption by the County needs to be
graded, graveled, compacted, and/or retrofitted, in order to meet the County's
specifications and/or to maintain the integrity of the road, the road shall be
graded, graveled, compacted, and/or retrofitted, by the road owner(s), in
compliance with the County's specifications and to the satisfaction of the
County's Road Superintendent or County Engineer.
   B.   If, in the judgment of the County's Road Superintendent or County
Engineer, a paved road proposed for adoption by the County needs to be re-paved
and/or retrofitted, in order to meet the County's specifications and/or to
maintain the integrity of the road, the road shall be re-paved and/or
retrofitted by the road owner(s), in compliance with the County's
specifications and to the satisfaction of the County's Road Superintendent or
County Engineer. (Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.080: ROAD CONNECTS TO PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY:
For a road to be considered for adoption by the County, it must connect
contiguously and uninterrupted to an existing dedicated public right of way.
(Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.090: ACCEPTANCE OF DEDICATED ROAD INTO COUNTY MAINTAINED ROAD SYSTEM:
   A.   Pursuant to the definition for Dedicated Road as found in WPCC Section
7.11.010(B), White Pine County (County) may accept the dedication of a road for
public use without accepting the road into the County maintained road system.
No dedicated road constructed as a result of this Chapter shall become part of
the County maintained road system unless and until it is declared and
designated to be a standard County road and formally accepted into the system
by action of the BOCC pursuant to NRS 403.180.
   B.   The BOCC will entertain a request from the divider/subdivider for
acceptance of dedicated roads into the County maintained road system when the
following conditions are met:
      1.   Sixty percent (60%) of the lots served by the dedicated road are
permanently occupied; and
      2.   The dedicated road has been inspected by the County Road
Superintendent, County Engineer, or other authorized County official, and is
certified, in writing, to be in compliance with the minimum development
standards set forth in this Chapter. (Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.100: HARDSHIP VARIANCE:
Upon written request from a divider/subdivider for a hardship variance, the
BOCC may find the construction of a dedicated road according to the standards
set forth in this Chapter to be a hardship. If such a finding is made, it shall
become a part of the final approval of the parcel map or subdivision. The
finding shall include a detailed description of the road the divider/subdivider
will be required to construct as an alternative to the standards set forth in
this Chapter, any amendment to the time period for completion of construction,
any bonding requirements, and any other conditions placed by the BOCC at the
time of variance approval. (Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.110: LIMITED REFORMATION OR REPEAL OF CONFLICTING ORDINANCES:
   A.   Any and all ordinances or portions of ordinances adopted by the BOCC
which are inconsistent with this Chapter are hereby reformed, but only for the
limited purpose to be read consistently with this Chapter.
   B.   Any and all ordinances or portions of ordinances adopted by the BOCC
which are in conflict with this Chapter and cannot be reformed to be read
consistently with this Chapter are hereby repealed, but only for the limited
purpose of eliminating the conflict with this Chapter. (Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
7.11.120: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this Chapter is held to be invalid, such invalidity shall
not affect the remaining provisions of this Chapter and each such provision
shall be declared to be severable. (Ord.547, 5-28-2025)
CHAPTER 7.12
POLYVINYL CHLORIDE PIPE
SECTION:
7.12.010: Highway Defined
7.12.020: Prohibitions Of Certain Polyvinyl Chloride Pipe Under Highways
7.12.010: HIGHWAY DEFINED:
For the purpose of this chapter, "highway" means the entire width between the
boundary lines of every way dedicated to a public authority when any part of
the way is open to the use of the public for the purpose of vehicular traffic,
whether or not the public authority is maintaining the way. "Highway" includes,
but is not limited to, streets, roads and alleys. (Ord. 195 §1, 1986)
7.12.020: PROHIBITIONS OF CERTAIN POLYVINYL CHLORIDE PIPE UNDER HIGHWAYS:
It shall be a misdemeanor for any person to use polyvinyl chloride pipe in the
construction of any water system under any highway in the county unless such
pipe is rated class 150 or better and meets the specifications set forth by the
American Water Works Association in C900. (Ord. 195 §1, 1986)
CHAPTER 7.20
PUBLIC PARKS
SECTION:
7.20.010: Title
7.20.020: Purpose
7.20.030: Definition Of Public Parks
7.20.040: Adoption And Imposition Of Group Usage Regulations
7.20.050: Application For Park Usage
7.20.060: Imposition And Rates Of Usage Fees
7.20.070: Collection Of Usage Fees
7.20.080: Exemptions
7.20.090: Penalties
7.20.010: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the WHITE PINE COUNTY PARKS
USAGE ORDINANCE. (Ord. 377 §1, 2002)
7.20.020: PURPOSE:
It shall be the purpose of this chapter to establish, for the public good, a
procedure for the application for use, the adoption of usage fees, and
establishment and enforcement of rules and regulations regarding the use of
public parks owned, operated or controlled by White Pine County. (Ord. 377 §1,
2002)
7.20.030: DEFINITION OF PUBLIC PARKS:
"Public parks" are defined as those parcels of real property owned, maintained,
operated or otherwise controlled by White Pine County and designated for public
recreational use. Public parks include, but are not limited to, those areas
within White Pine County known as Steptoe Park, Little League Park, Marich
Field and County Park, and may include other parcels of real property, now or
in the future, owned or controlled by White Pine County that the board of
county commissioners may designate as public parks. (Ord. 377 §1, 2002)
7.20.040: ADOPTION AND IMPOSITION OF GROUP USAGE REGULATIONS:
   A.   The following public park group usage regulations are hereby adopted
and imposed:
      1.   County Park:
         a.   Group users are responsible for removing all trash, food and
other items brought into the public park for the group's purpose.
         b.   For groups of over one hundred (100) people, the public park
usage group must provide a dumpster for refuge and an appropriate number of
portable restroom facilities.
         c.   For groups desiring the usage of the entire public park, the
public park usage group must provide a dumpster for refuge and an appropriate
number of portable restroom facilities.
         d.   For groups of over one hundred (100) people, the public park
usage group must pay a cleaning deposit to the White Pine County treasurer.
Said cleaning deposit to be refunded pursuant to certification of compliance by
the White Pine County parks department following an inspection.
         e.   The group representative obtaining the use permit shall remain
responsible for full compliance with all provisions of this chapter.
      2.   Steptoe Park, Little League Park And Marich Field:
         a.   All regulations applicable to the group usage of the County Park,
supra, shall apply to the group usage of Steptoe Park, Little League Park and
Marich Field, except that group users shall not be responsible to provided
portable restrooms. (Ord. 377 §1, 2002)
7.20.050: APPLICATION FOR PARK USAGE:
For any single function, public park users must reserve the county park, or the
specific area within the park, by applying for a use permit from the office of
the White Pine County public works department. (Ord. 377 §1, 2002)
7.20.060: IMPOSITION AND RATES OF USAGE FEES:
The county commissioners may by majority vote adopt a schedule of fees to be
applicable to county park usage.
