11.04.010: ALLEY:
"Alley" means:
   A.   A highway which has been officially named and signposted with such name
and which name includes "alley";
   B.   A highway which has not been officially named and signposted with such
name and which primarily furnishes access to the rear entrances of abutting
property. (Ord. 43 §1(a), 1966)
11.04.020: BICYCLE:
"Bicycle" means every device propelled by human power upon which any person may
ride, having two (2) tandem wheels either of which is more than twenty inches
(20") in diameter. (Ord. 43 §1(b), 1966)
11.04.030: BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS:
"Board of Commissioners" means the Board of County Commissioners, White Pine
County, Nevada, having authority to enact laws regulating traffic. (Ord. 43 §1
(c), 1966)
11.04.040: BUS:
"Bus" means any motor vehicle designed for carrying more than ten (10)
passengers and used for the transportation of persons, and every motor vehicle,
other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for
compensation. (Ord. 43 §1(d), 1966)
11.04.050: BUSINESS DISTRICT:
"Business district" means the territory contiguous to and including a highway
when within any six hundred feet (600') along such highway there are buildings
in use for business or industrial purposes, including, but not limited to,
hotels, banks or office buildings, railroad stations and public buildings which
occupy at least three hundred feet (300') of frontage on one side or three
hundred feet (300') collectively on both sides of the highway. (Ord. 43 §1(e),
1966)
11.04.060: COMBINATION OF VEHICLES:
"Combination of vehicles" means two (2) or more vehicles coupled together.
(Ord. 43 §1(f), 1966)
11.04.070: CONGESTED AREA:
"Congested area" means any "business district", residential district or "urban
district" as herein defined within the unincorporated area of the county and
any territory within a subdivision platted and approved by the county pursuant
to the provisions of chapter 278 of Nevada Revised Statutes or any other
provisions of law. (Ord. 43 §1(g), 1966)
11.04.080: CONTROLLED ACCESS HIGHWAY:
"Controlled access highway" means every highway, street or roadway in respect
to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal
right of access to or from the same except at such points only and in such
manner as may be determined by the board of commissioners having jurisdiction
over such highway, street or roadway. (Ord. 43 §1(h), 1966)
11.04.090: CROSSWALK:
"Crosswalk" means:
   A.   Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly
indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface;
   B.   In the absence of such lines or markings, or signs indicating no
crossing, that part of a roadway at an intersection included within the
connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of a
highway, other than an alley, measured from the curbs or, in the absence of
curbs from the edges of the traversable roadway. (Ord. 43 §1(i), 1966)
11.04.100: COUNTY:
"County" means White Pine County acting by and through its duly elected board
of county commissioners. (Ord. 43 §1(j), 1966)
11.04.110: DRIVER:
"Driver" means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a
vehicle. (Ord. 43 §1(k), 1966)
11.04.120: EXPLOSIVES:
"Explosives" means any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is commonly
used or intended for the purpose of producing an explosion and which contains
any oxidizing and combustive units or other ingredients in such proportions,
quantities or packing that an ignition by fire, friction, concussion,
percussion or by detonator of any part of the compound or mixture may cause
such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the resultant gaseous
pressures are capable of producing destructive effects on contiguous objects or
of destroying life or limb. (Ord. 43 §1(l), 1966)
11.04.130: FLAMMABLE LIQUID:
"Flammable liquid" means any liquid which has a flash point of seventy degrees
Fahrenheit (70°F), or less, as determined by a tagliabue or equivalent closed
cup test device. (Ord. 43 §1(m), 1966)
11.04.140: HIGHWAY:
"Highway" means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way
publicly maintained by the county when any part thereof is open to the use of
the public for purposes of vehicular travel, located within the unincorporated
area of White Pine County. (Ord. 43 §1(n), 1966)
11.04.150: HOUSE TRAILER:
"House trailer" means:
   A.   A trailer or a semitrailer which is designed, constructed, and equipped
as a dwelling place, living abode or sleeping place, either permanently or
temporarily, and is equipped for use as a conveyance on streets and highways;
or
   B.   A trailer or semitrailer whose chassis and exterior shell is designed
and constructed for use as a "house trailer", as defined in subsection A of
this section, but which is used instead permanently or temporarily for the
advertising, sales, display or promotion of merchandise or services, or for any
other commercial purpose except the transportation of property for hire or the
transportation of property for distribution by a private carrier. (Ord. 43 §1
(o), 1966)
11.04.160: INTERSECTION:
"Intersection" means:
   A.   The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral
curb lines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines, of the roadways of
two (2) highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles,
or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different highways joining at
any other angle may come in conflict;
   B.   Where a highway includes two (2) roadways thirty feet (30') or more
apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an
intersecting highway, or roadway of such intersection highway thirty feet (30')
or more apart from another roadway of such highway, shall be regarded as a
separate intersection. (Ord. 43 §1(p), 1966)
11.04.170: LANED ROADWAY:
"Laned roadway" means a roadway which is divided into two (2) or more clearly
marked lanes for vehicular traffic. (Ord. 43 §1(q), 1966)
11.04.180: LICENSE TO OPERATE MOTOR VEHICLE:
"License to operate a motor vehicle" means any operator's or chauffeur's
license or any other license or permit to operate a motor vehicle issued under
the laws of this State including:
   A.   Any temporary license or instruction permit;
   B.   The privilege of any person to drive a motor vehicle whether or not
such person holds a valid license;
   C.   Any "nonresident's operating privilege" as defined herein. (Ord. 43 §1
(r), 1966)
11.04.190: MOTOR DRIVEN CYCLE:
"Motor driven cycle" means every motorcycle, including every motor scooter,
with a motor which produces not to exceed five (5) horsepower, and every
bicycle with motor attached. (Ord. 43 §1(s), 1966)
11.04.200: MOTOR VEHICLE:
"Motor vehicle" means every vehicle which is self-propelled but not operated
upon rails. (Ord. 43 §1(t), 1966)
11.04.210: MOTORCYCLE:
"Motorcycle" means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of
the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact
with the ground, but excluding a tractor. (Ord. 43 §1(u), 1966)
11.04.220: MOTOR TRUCK:
"Motor truck" means every motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily
for the transportation of property. (Ord. 43 §1(v), 1966)
11.04.230: NONRESIDENT:
"Nonresident" means every person who is not a resident of this State. (Ord. 43
§1(w), 1966)
11.04.240: NONRESIDENT'S OPERATING PRIVILEGE:
"Nonresident's operating privilege" means the privilege conferred upon a
nonresident by the laws of this State pertaining to the operation by such
person of a motor vehicle, or the use of a vehicle owned by such person in this
State. (Ord. 43 §1(x), 1966)
11.04.245: OFF-ROAD VEHICLES:
"Off-road vehicle" means any motorized vehicle capable of, or designed for,
travel on or immediately over land, water, or other natural terrain, excluding:
   A.   Any non-amphibious registered motorboat;
   B.   Any snowmobile or other motorized vehicle for traversing snow;
   C.   Any military, fire, emergency, or law enforcement vehicle while being
used for emergency purposes;
   D.   Any vehicle whose use is expressly authorized by the authorized
officer, or otherwise officially approved;
   E.   Vehicles in official use; and
   F.   Any combat or combat support vehicle when used in times of State or
national defense emergencies. (Ord. 471, 2017)
11.04.250: OFFICIAL TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICE:
"Official traffic control device" means all signs, signals, markings and
devices, placed or erected by authority of a public body or official having
jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning, guiding or directing
traffic. (Ord. 43 §1(y), 1966)
11.04.260: OPERATOR:
"Operator" means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a
motor vehicle upon a highway or who is exercising control over or steering a
vehicle being towed by a motor vehicle. (Ord. 43 §1(z), 1966)
11.04.270: OWNER:
"Owner" means a person who holds the legal title of a vehicle, or in the event
a vehicle is the subject of an agreement for the conditional sale or lease
thereof with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in
the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the
conditional vendee or lessee, or in the event a mortgagor of a vehicle is
entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor
shall be deemed the owner for the purpose of this title. (Ord. 43 §1(aa), 1966)
11.04.280: PARK, PARKING:
"Park" or "parking" means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not,
otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in
loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. (Ord. 43 §1(bb), 1966)
11.04.290: PEDESTRIAN:
"Pedestrian" means any person afoot. (Ord. 43 §1(cc), 1966)
11.04.300: PERSON:
"Person" means every natural person, firm, trust, copartnership, association,
or corporation. (Ord. 43 §1(dd), 1966)
11.04.310: POLICE OFFICER:
"Police officer" means every officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic
or to make arrests for violations of traffic laws or regulations in the
unincorporated area of White Pine County, Nevada. (Ord. 43 §1(ee), 1966)
11.04.320: PRIVATE ROAD, DRIVEWAY:
"Private road" or "driveway" means every way or place in private ownership and
used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied
permission from the owner, but not by other persons. (Ord. 43 §1(ff), 1966)
11.04.330: RAILROAD:
"Railroad" means a carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than
streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. (Ord. 43 §1(gg), 1966)
11.04.340: RAILROAD SIGN, SIGNAL:
"Railroad sign" or "railroad signal" means any sign, signal or device erected
by authority of a public body or official or by a railroad and intended to give
notice of the presence of railroad tracks or the approach of a railroad train.
(Ord. 43 §1(hh), 1966)
11.04.350: RAILROAD TRAIN:
"Railroad train" means a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without
cars coupled thereto, operated upon rails. (Ord. 43 §1(ii), 1966)
11.04.360: RESIDENCE DISTRICT:
"Residence district" means the territory contiguous to and including a highway
not comprising a business district when the property on such highway for a
distance of three hundred feet (300') or more is in the main improved with
residences or residences and buildings in use for business. (Ord. 43 §1(jj),
1966)
11.04.370: REVOCATION OF DRIVER'S LICENSE:
"Revocation of driver's license" means the termination by formal action of the
Department of Motor Vehicles of a person's driver's license or privilege to
operate a motor vehicle on the public highways. (Ord. 43 §1(kk), 1966)
11.04.380: RIGHT-OF-WAY:
"Right-of-way" means the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. (Ord.
43 §1(ll), 1966)
11.04.390: ROADWAY:
"Roadway" means that portion of a highway improved, designed or ordinarily used
for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder, and if a highway
includes two (2) or more separate roadways, then "roadway" means any such
roadway separately but not all such roadways collectively. (Ord. 43 §1(mm),
1966)
11.04.400: SAFETY ZONE:
"Safety zone" means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for
the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or
indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set
apart as a safety zone. (Ord. 43 §1(nn), 1966)
11.04.410: SCHOOL BUS:
"School bus" means every motor vehicle owned by a public or governmental agency
or a private school and operated for the transportation of children to or from
school or privately owned and operated for compensation for the transportation
of children to or from school. "School bus" does not include a motor vehicle
owned and operated by a common or contract carrier under the jurisdiction of
the Interstate Commerce Commission or the Public Service Commission of Nevada
when such vehicle is operated in the regular conduct of his business as a
common or contract carrier in interstate or intrastate commerce within the
State of Nevada. (Ord. 43 §1(oo), 1966)
11.04.420: SIDEWALK:
"Sidewalk" means that portion of a highway between the curb lines, or the
lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for use
of pedestrians. (Ord. 43 §1(pp), 1966)
11.04.425: SNOWMOBILE:
"Snowmobile" means a motor vehicle with an engine powering a belt or tracks in
the rear with directional runners for steering in the front, for traveling over
snow. (Ord. 471, 2017)
11.04.430: STAND, STANDING:
"Stand" or "standing" means the halting of a vehicle, whether occupied or not,
otherwise than for the purpose of and while actually engaged in receiving or
discharging passengers. (Ord. 43 §1(qq), 1966)
11.04.440: STOP:
"Stop", when required, means complete cessation from movement. (Ord. 43 §1(rr),
1966)
11.04.450: STOP, STOPPING:
"Stop" or "stopping", when prohibited, means any halting even momentarily of a
vehicle whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with
other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or
traffic control device. (Ord. 43 §1(ss), 1966)
11.04.460: TOW CAR:
"Tow car" means a motor vehicle which has been altered or designed and equipped
for and exclusively used in the business of towing vehicles by means of a
crane, hoist, tow bar, towline or dolly, or is otherwise exclusively used to
render assistance to other vehicles. (Ord. 43 §1(tt), 1966)
11.04.470: TRAFFIC:
"Traffic" means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, streetcars,
and other conveyances, either singly or together, while using any highway for
purposes of travel. (Ord. 43 §1(uu), 1966)
11.04.480: TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNAL:
"Traffic control signal" means any device, whether manually, electrically or
mechanically operated, placed or erected by authority of a public body or
official having jurisdiction, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop
and to proceed. (Ord. 43 §1(vv), 1966)
11.04.490: TWO DIRECTIONAL ROADWAY:
"Two directional roadway" means a highway consisting of a single roadway upon
which vehicles are allowed to proceed in opposite directions. (Ord. 43 §1(ww),
1966)
11.04.500: URBAN DISTRICT:
"Urban district" means the territory contiguous to and including any highway
which is built up with structures devoted to business, industry or dwelling
houses situated at average intervals of less than one hundred feet (100') for a
distance of a quarter of a mile or more. (Ord. 43 §1(xx), 1966)
11.04.510: VEHICLE:
"Vehicle" means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or
may be transported or drawn upon a highway, excepting devices moved by human
power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. (Ord. 43 §1(yy),
1966)
CHAPTER 11.08
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
11.08.010: Application Of Title
11.08.020: Obedience To Traffic Police Required
11.08.030: Nevada Revised Statutes 484 Adopted By Reference; Application
11.08.040: Highway Use Restriction
11.08.010: APPLICATION OF TITLE:
The provisions of this title relating to the operation of vehicles refer
exclusively to the operation of vehicles upon highways in the unincorporated
area in White Pine County, Nevada, except where a different place is
specifically referred to in a given section. (Ord. 43 §2(a), 1966)
11.08.020: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC POLICE REQUIRED:
No person shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or
direction of any police officer invested by law with authority to direct,
control or regulate traffic. (Ord. 43 §2(b), 1966)
11.08.030: NEVADA REVISED STATUTES 484 ADOPTED BY REFERENCE; APPLICATION:
This title is enacted to supplement state traffic laws. The provisions of
Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 484, as amended and as may be amended from time
to time by the Nevada state legislature are adopted by reference. It is the
intent of the board of county commissioners that the state traffic laws shall
apply to all highways in the unincorporated area of White Pine County. (Ord. 43
§2(c), 1966)
11.08.040: HIGHWAY USE RESTRICTION:
The board of commissioners may, by resolution, restrict the use of any county
roadway or highway by motor vehicles and request the county sheriff to clearly
post the roadway or highway accordingly. (Ord. 43 §7(b)(5), 1966)
CHAPTER 11.12
CONTROL DEVICES
SECTION:
11.12.010: Location Authority
11.12.020: Precedence Of Direction Of Traffic Police Or Flagman
11.12.030: Signal; Legend Designation
11.12.040: Signal; Flashing
11.12.050: Unauthorized Display Prohibited
11.12.060: Interference, Injury, Removal Prohibited
11.12.070: Conformance To State Standards Required
11.12.010: LOCATION AUTHORITY:
The board of commissioners is authorized with respect to highways under its
jurisdiction to determine locations for the placement of official traffic
control devices in order to provide for the safe and expeditious movement of
traffic. (Ord. 43 §3(a), 1966)
11.12.020: PRECEDENCE OF DIRECTION OF TRAFFIC POLICE OR FLAGMAN:
Notwithstanding any contrary law, all traffic shall obey such official traffic
control devices when they have been erected, except when otherwise directed by
a police officer or flagman authorized by law, and shall always obey the
directions of a police officer. (Ord. 43 §3(b), 1966)
11.12.030: SIGNAL; LEGEND DESIGNATION:
   A.   Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic control signals exhibiting
the words "go", "caution" or "stop", or exhibiting different colored lights
successively one at a time, or with arrows, the following colors only shall be
used and such terms and lights shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles
and pedestrians as follows:
      1.   Green alone or "go":
         a.   Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through
or turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn.
But vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or left, shall yield
the right of way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the
intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time such signal is exhibited,
         b.   Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway
within any marked or unmarked crosswalk;
      2.   Steady yellow alone:
         a.   Vehicular traffic facing the signal is thereby warned that the
red or "stop" signal will be exhibited immediately thereafter and such
vehicular traffic shall not enter or be crossing the intersection when the red
or "stop" signal is exhibited,
         b.   Pedestrians facing such signal are thereby advised that there is
insufficient time to cross the roadway, and any pedestrian, then starting to
cross shall yield the right of way to all vehicles;
      3.   Steady red alone or "stop":
         a.   Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering
the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then before
entering the intersection and shall remain standing until green or "go" is
shown alone, except that the driver of a vehicle which is stopped as close as
practicable at the entrance to the crosswalk on the near side of the
intersection, or if none, then at the entrance to the intersection, in
obedience to a steady red alone or "stop" signal, may make a right turn, but
shall yield the right of way to pedestrians and other traffic proceeding as
directed by the signal at such intersection, unless the board of commissioners
has by ordinance prohibited any such right turn at any intersection and erected
a sign at such intersection giving notice of such prohibition,
         b.   No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway unless
he can do so safely and without interfering with any vehicular traffic;
      4.   In the event an official traffic control signal is erected and
maintained at a place other than an intersection, the provisions of this
section shall be applicable except as to those provisions which by their nature
can have no application. Any stop required shall be made at a sign or marking
on the pavement indicating where the stop shall be made, but in the absence of
any such sign or marking the stop shall be made at the signal. (Ord. 43 §3(c),
1966)
11.12.040: SIGNAL; FLASHING:
   A.   Whenever an illuminated flashing red or yellow signal is used in a
traffic sign or signal it shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as
follows:
      1.   Flashing Red (Stop Signal): When a red lens is illuminated with
rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the
nearest crosswalk at an intersection or at a limit line when marked, or, if
none, then before entering the intersection, and the right to proceed shall be
subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign;
      2.   Flashing Yellow (Caution Signal): When a yellow lens is illuminated
with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the
intersection or past such signal only with caution.
   B.   This section shall not apply at railroad grade crossings. Conduct of
drivers of vehicles approaching railroad grade crossings shall be governed by
the provisions of state law. (Ord. 43 §3(d), 1966)
11.12.050: UNAUTHORIZED DISPLAY PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any
highway any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be
or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device or
railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic,
or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official
traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal.
   B.   No person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit
upon any highway any traffic sign or signal bearing thereon any commercial
advertising.
   C.   This section shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private
property adjacent to highways of signs giving useful directional information
and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs.
   D.   Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is declared to be a
public nuisance and the board of commissioners having jurisdiction over the
highway is empowered to remove it or cause it to be removed without notice.
(Ord. 43 §3(e), 1966)
11.12.060: INTERFERENCE, INJURY, REMOVAL PROHIBITED:
No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact alter, deface,
injure, knock down or remove any official traffic control device or any
railroad sign or signal or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon, or any
other part thereof. (Ord. 43 §3(f), 1966)
11.12.070: CONFORMANCE TO STATE STANDARDS REQUIRED:
   A.   Traffic control devices, signals and signs hereafter erected under
authority of the board of commissioners at new locations, or replacements of
such devices, signals and signs at existing locations on any county road shall
conform to the uniform state standard prescribed by the state highway engineer
for the manufacture, display, erection and location of such devices, signals
and signs.
   B.   The board of commissioners shall not erect and maintain any stop sign
or traffic control signal at any location so as to require the traffic on any
state highway, to stop before entering or crossing any intersecting county road
or street within unincorporated areas unless approval in writing has first been
obtained from the state highway engineer.
   C.   Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as changing the
existing statutory power of board of commissioners to control the use of roads
and streets under their jurisdiction. (Ord. 43 §3(g), 1966)
CHAPTER 11.15
OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES
SECTION:
11.15.010: Public Right-Of-Way
11.15.020: Permission To Use Land
11.15.030: Prohibition On Use Of Land
11.15.040: Exempt Locations
11.15.050: Exempt Vehicles
11.15.060: Government Property
11.15.010: PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY:
   A.   A person possessing a valid driver's license may operate a motor
vehicle, properly registered and insured with the State of Nevada, along or
across any designated Forest Service, BLM, State, or County road. (Ord. 471,
2017)
11.15.020: PERMISSION TO USE LAND:
   A.   No person shall drive a motor vehicle on land belonging to or occupied
by another without having the express permission from the owner of such land,
but this section shall not apply to a person having lawful business with the
owner.
      1.   It shall be a defense against this provision if the person has in
immediate possession and presents, upon request of a peace officer, written
permission from the owner of such lands, his agent, or the person in lawful
possession thereof. (Ord. 471, 2017)
11.15.030: PROHIBITION ON USE OF LAND:
   A.   No person shall operate any motor vehicle, snowmobile, off- road
vehicle, or any motorized equipment off any Forest Service, BLM, State, or
County road in a manner which damages or unreasonably disrupts public
resources, including land, wildlife, or vegetation.
      1.   It shall be a defense against this provision if the person has in
immediate possession and, upon request of a peace officer, written permission
from the owner of such lands, his agent, or the person in lawful possession
thereof.
   B.   No person shall operate any motor vehicle, snowmobile, off- road
vehicle, or any motorized equipment in a wilderness area. (Ord. 471, 2017)
11.15.040: EXEMPT LOCATIONS:
   A.   This chapter shall not apply on public or private lands expressly set
apart for the use of motor vehicles by or with permission of the owner of such
lands pursuant to any zoning permit or other permit or licensing procedure
authorized by law. (Ord. 471, 2017)
11.15.050: EXEMPT VEHICLES:
   A.   This chapter shall not apply to:
      1.   Vehicles operated by law enforcement responding to violations of the
law;
      2.   Farm vehicles being used for agricultural purposes;
      3.   Maintenance vehicles being used for grading or construction
purposes;
      4.   Government vehicles or vehicles being used for governmental
purposes; or
      5.   Golf carts being used on golf courses. (Ord. 471, 2017)
11.15.060: GOVERNMENT PROPERTY:
   A.   Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to interfere with the right of
any government agency to regulate, prohibit or permit the use of motor vehicles
on property owned by it or under its control and under its jurisdiction, nor to
permit or authorize any trespass or nuisance. (Ord. 471, 2017)
CHAPTER 11.16
PARKING
SECTION:
11.16.010: Parallel To Right Hand Curb Required
11.16.020: Adjacent To Left Hand Curb
11.16.030: Angle
11.16.040: Signs
11.16.050: Truck And Bus Restrictions
11.16.060: No Parking Area

11.16.010: PARALLEL TO RIGHT HAND CURB REQUIRED:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, every vehicle stopped or parked
upon a roadway where there are adjacent curbs shall be so stopped or parked
with the right hand wheels of such vehicle parallel to and within eighteen
inches (18") of the right hand curb. (Ord. 43 §7(b)(1), 1966)
11.16.020: ADJACENT TO LEFT HAND CURB:
The board of commissioners may, by resolution, permit parking of vehicles with
the left hand wheels adjacent to and within eighteen inches (18") of the left
hand curb of the roadway. (Ord. 43 §7(b)(2), 1966)
11.16.030: ANGLE:
The board of commissioners may, by resolution, permit angle parking on any
county roadway. (Ord. 43 §7(b)(3), 1966)
11.16.040: SIGNS:
The board of commissioners with respect to highways under its jurisdiction may,
by resolution, place signs prohibiting or restricting the stopping, standing or
parking of vehicles on any highway where, in its opinion, such stopping,
standing or parking is dangerous to those using the highway or where the
stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would unduly interfere with the free
movement of traffic thereon. These signs shall be official signs and no person
shall stop, stand or park any vehicle in violation of the restrictions stated
on such signs. (Ord. 43 §7(b)(4), 1966)
11.16.050: TRUCK AND BUS RESTRICTIONS:
It is unlawful for any person to park a service truck, bus, commercial motor
vehicle, or any vehicle larger than a pickup anywhere on Fourth Street, McGill,
White Pine County, Nevada, between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) A.M., except for a restricted parking area on Fourth Street,
McGill, White Pine County, Nevada, between Avenue I and the north end of Circle
Drive, wherein it is unlawful for the above referenced vehicles to park between
the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. for more than
thirty (30) minutes. (Ord. 301 §1, 1995: Ord. 287 §1(part), 1993: Ord. 12 §1,
1958)
11.16.060: NO PARKING AREA:
   A.   That certain portion of Avenue F in East Ely (Ely City), White Pine
County, Nevada, beginning at the southwest corner of the junction of Avenue F
and U.S. Highway 6 and 93 and extending approximately one hundred feet (100')
in length along the south side of Avenue F in a westerly direction is
designated a "no parking area".
   B.   The board is authorized to place such signs and marks designating this
area as a "no parking area" as they deem expedient. (Ord. I §§1, 2, 1946)
11.16.070: FOURTH STREET, MCGILL:
   A.   Automobiles shall be parked parallel only, on the west side of Fourth
Street in McGill, White Pine County, between the post office building and the
standard market located in the McGill garage building.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person or persons traveling or operating a motor
vehicle to park the vehicle within the parallel parking zone without complying
with the terms hereof. (Ord. J §§1, 2(part), 1954)
11.16.075: CAMPTON STREET, ADJACENT TO THE WHITE PINE COUNTY COURTHOUSE:
   A.   For the purposes of this section, "disabled vehicle designation" means
a notification issued and attached to a vehicle in some manner indicating the
vehicle is legally allowed to be parked in a space reserved for disabled
persons. This includes: a state issued placard designed to be hung onto the
rearview mirror; a disabled insignia on a license plate; and any other state
approved form of indicating a vehicle may be legally parked in a space reserved
for disabled persons.
   B.   Sixty feet (60') of length along the north sidewalk of Campton Street,
starting on the curb at a point ten feet (10') west of the southwest corner of
the courthouse and running westerly, constitute two (2) 30-foot parking spaces,
which are hereby reserved for the parking of patrons with valid disabled
vehicle designations issued by the state of Nevada or another state.
      1.   These parking spaces addressed in this subsection B have no time
limitation.
      2.   The owner of a vehicle parked in any of these spaces described in
this subsection B without a valid disabled vehicle designation is subject to a
monetary fine of up to one hundred fifty five dollars ($155.00) pursuant to
Nevada Revised Statutes 244.3575, as amended, and/or towing at the owner's
expense.
   C.   Fifty feet (50') of length along the north sidewalk of Campton Street,
immediately abutting the spaces described in subsection B of this section to
the west constitute two (2) 25-foot time restricted parking spaces.
      1.   Parking in these spaces is limited to one hour during the hours of
eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M., Monday through Friday,
excluding government holidays.
      2.   The owner of a vehicle parked in any of these spaces described in
this subsection C in excess of one consecutive hour during hours when parking
time is restricted is subject to a monetary fine of up to one hundred fifty
five dollars ($155.00), pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 244.3575, as
amended, and/or towing at the owner's expense. (Ord. 467, 2016)
11.16.080: NEVADA ROUTE 38, LUND:
It is unlawful for any person to stand or park a vehicle upon that certain
street designated Nevada Route 38, Lund, White Pine County, Nevada, other than
parallel with the edges of this street, headed in the direction of lawful
traffic movement, and with the right hand wheels of the vehicle within eighteen
inches (18") of the curb or edge of this street. (Ord. 28 §1, 1962)
11.16.090: ADJACENT TO HYDRANT:
It is unlawful for any person to stop or cause to be stopped or to leave
standing, for any period of time whatever, any vehicle within ten feet (10') of
any fire hydrant in Ely City. (Ord. D §3, 1943)

11.20.010: RECKLESS DRIVING PROHIBITED:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate a vehicle of any kind
or character:
      1.   In a reckless manner on any street or highway in this county;
      2.   In any other than a careful or prudent manner;
      3.   At a rate of speed greater than is reasonable and proper, having due
regard for the traffic, surface and width of the highway;
      4.   At such a rate of speed as to endanger the life, limb or property of
any person.
   B.   Any person who violates the provisions of this section is guilty of a
misdemeanor. (Ord. 43 §4(a), 1966)
11.20.020: SCHOOL BUS RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   No school bus shall exceed a speed of fifty (50) miles per hour when
transporting pupils to and from school.
   B.   Any person who violates the provisions of this section is guilty of a
misdemeanor. (Ord. 43 §4(b), 1966)
11.20.030: PRIMA FACIE SPEED LIMITS:
   A.   A fifteen (15) mile per hour speed limit shall be required:
      1.   When passing a school building or the grounds thereof during school
recess or while children are going to or leaving or playing about the school;
      2.   When turning a corner from one street or highway into another in any
"congested area" as defined in this title;
      3.   In public parks within the unincorporated area of the county.
   B.   Twenty five (25) miles per hour speed limit shall be required upon any
street, highway or alley in any "congested area" as defined in this title in
the unincorporated area of the county unless a speed limit is otherwise
established as provided in subsection A3 of this section.
   C.   Restricted speed zone regulations shall be as follows:
      1.   In order to protect life, limb, and property, and to facilitate the
orderly movements of vehicular traffic upon the streets and highways in the
unincorporated area of the county, the board of county commissioners may, by
resolution, establish restricted speed zones. After the establishment of any
restricted speed zone, the sheriff of White Pine County shall cause to be
placed upon the street or highway where such restricted speed zone has been
established appropriate signs or signals giving notice thereof.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to disobey the
instructions of any sign or signal placed in accordance with the provisions of
subsection C1 of this section, unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
(Ord. 43 §4(c), 1966)
11.20.040: RACING PROHIBITED ON PUBLIC STREETS:
   A.   No person shall engage in any motor vehicle speed contest or exhibition
of speed on a highway or street and no person shall aid or abet in any such
motor vehicle speed contest or exhibition upon any highway or street.
   B.   No person shall for the purpose of facilitating or aiding or as an
incident to any vehicle speed contest upon a highway or street in any manner
obstruct or place any barricade or obstruction or assist or participate in
placing any such barricade or obstruction upon any highway or street.
   C.   Any person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord.
43 §4(d), 1966)
11.20.050: SLOWNESS IMPEDING TRAFFIC PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS:
It is unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle upon a street or highway in
the county at such a slow speed as to impede or block the normal and reasonable
movement of traffic, except when reduced speed is necessary for safe operation
or because upon a grade. (Ord. 43 §4(e), 1966)
11.20.053: BAKER SPEED LIMIT:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to ride, travel, or propel any vehicle of
any kind or character whatsoever at a speed greater than twenty-five (25) miles
per hour (MPH) upon, or along any County road or alley located within the
unincorporated Township of Baker, Nevada, unless another speed limit is
lawfully posted.
   B.   The County's unincorporated Township of Baker, Nevada, commonly known
as "Baker Townsite" or "Baker", is situated as follows:
      Township 13 North, Range 70 East, Mount Diablo Base and Meridian
(M.D.B.M.)
      Section 9
      East Half of the Southwest Quarter (E ½ SW ¼)
      West Half of the West Half of the Northwest Quarter of the Southeast
Quarter (W½ W ½ NW ¼ SE ¼)
   C.   The Sheriff of White Pine County, or their designee, is authorized to
regulate the speed of such vehicular travel within the areas described above by
clear and conspicuous posting of signage indicating the twenty-five (25) miles
per hour speed limit.
   D.   A violation of the speed limit set out in subsection A shall
constitute, and subject the violator to the penalties fixed for, a misdemeanor
offense or a civil infraction under this Code and/or the Nevada Revised
Statutes. (Ord, 548, 5-28-2025)
11.20.055: CROSS TIMBERS SPEED LIMIT:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to ride, travel, or propel any vehicle of
any kind or character whatsoever at a speed greater than twenty-five (25) miles
per hour upon, or along any road or alley within the County’s unincorporated
subdivision of Cross Timbers, expect for County Road 212 North and/or unless
another speed limit is so posted.
   B.   The County unincorporated subdivision commonly known as “Cross Timbers”
is situated as follows:
      Sections 14, 15, 16, 21, and 22 of Township 17 North, Range 63 East,
M.D.B.M.
   C.   The Sheriff of White Pine County is authorized to otherwise regulate
the speed of such vehicular travel within these areas by clear and conspicuous
posting.
   D.   A violation of the speed limit set out in subsection A shall subject
the violator to the penalties fixed for misdemeanor violations and/or civil
infractions of this Code or the Nevada Revised Statutes.
(545, 2025)
11.20.060: MCGILL SPEED LIMIT:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to ride, travel, or propel any vehicle of
any kind or character whatsoever at a speed greater than twenty (20) miles per
hour upon, or along any street or alley within the unincorporated town of
McGill, unless another speed limit is so posted.
   B.   The sheriff of White Pine County is authorized to otherwise regulate
the speed of such vehicular travel within these areas by clear and conspicuous
posting. (Ord. 507, 2020; Ord. 30 §§1, 2, 1963: Ord. 24 §1, 1962)

   B.   The unincorporated town of Lund is also known as “Lund Township” and is

11.20.070: EAST ELY SPEED LIMIT:

East Ely and along any street or alley within the Ely City townsite and the

   B.   The sheriff of White Pine County is authorized to otherwise regulate

feet more or less to the US Highway 93 intersection.

11.20.074: SPEED LIMIT; GEORGETOWN ROAD:
The speed limit for the Georgetown Road from the following points shall be

   B.   The road described in subsection A of this section shall be posted, and

civil infractions of this code or the Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 538, 2024)
11.20.076: SPEED LIMIT; BLUE DIAMOND ESTATES EAST SUBDIVISION ROADS:
The speed limit in the entire Blue Diamond Estates East Subdivision described
below shall be as follows:
   A.   The speed limit shall be twenty-five (25) miles per hour in both
directions on all paved and unpaved roads within the Blue Diamond Estates East
Subdivision including, but not limited to, 185th South Street, 191st South
Street, South 3rd East Street, East 198th South Street, 205th South Street,
212th South Street, and all other County roads that are in Township 16 North,
Range 63 East, South ½ Section 35.
   B.   The roads described in subsection A of this section shall be posted,
and a violation of the speed limit set out in subsection A of this section
shall subject the violator to the penalties fixed for misdemeanor violations
and/or civil infractions of this code or the Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord.
538, 2024)
11.20.078: SPEED LIMIT; PRESTON LOOP:
The speed limit for the Preston Loop from the following points shall be thirty-
five (35) miles per hour in both directions:
   A.   Commencing at the intersection of Nevada State Highway 318 and County
Road 895, bear 228.61 degrees in a southwesterly direction 393 feet, thence
bearing 246.3 degrees southwesterly 97 feet, thence bearing 262.33 degrees
southwesterly 946 feet, thence 303.66 degrees northwesterly 4,347 feet, thence
289.07 degrees northwesterly 272 feet, thence bearing 273.6 degrees
northwesterly 289 feet.
   B.   The road described in subsection A of this section shall be posted, and
a violation of the speed limit set out in subsection A of this section shall
subject the violator to the penalties fixed for misdemeanor violations and/or
civil infractions of this code or the Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 539, 2024)
11.20.080: SPEED LIMIT; AVENUE F EXTENDED:
The speed limit shall be twenty five (25) miles per hour for a street extending
Avenue F east of the East Ely town boundary and further described as follows:
Beginning at a point whence the sandstone monument marking the 1/4 corner
between Sections 11 and 14, T. 16 N., R. 63 E., M.D.B. & M. bears S. 82°25'37"
E., 782.36 feet distant.

paramedics, firemen, and all emergency response personnel and their official

for relief or treatment, or otherwise exempt by Nevada Revised Statute.
(Ord. 103 §1, 1980; amd. Ord. 543, 2025)
