11.20.130: RESTRICTIONS OF SPEED:
   A.   Basic Rule: It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate a vehicle
of any kind or character, on a public highway:
      1.   At a rate of speed greater than is reasonable or proper, having due
regard for the traffic, surface width of the highway, the weather and other
highway conditions;
      2.   At such rate of speed as to endanger the life, limit, or property of
any person;
      3.   A rate of speed that is greater than that posted by a public
authority for the particular portion of the highway being traversed;
      4.   At a rate of speed greater than that established by any other
section of this chapter for a particular vehicle use or highway being
traversed;
      5.   In any event, at a rate of speed greater than seventy five (75)
miles per hour.
   B.   Definitions: As used in this chapter:
   HIGHWAY: The entire width between the boundary lines of every way dedicated
to the county of White Pine, when any part of the way is open to the use of the
public for purposes of vehicular traffic, whether or not the public authority
is maintaining the way.
   PUBLIC AUTHORITY: The White Pine County road department or any other entity
of state or federal government, or any political subdivision thereof,
authorized by Nevada law or the law of the United States Of America to impose
any control or regulations on the use of any highway in White Pine County,
Nevada.
   VEHICLE: Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may
be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power or
used exclusively upon stationary rails. Vehicle shall also mean animal drawn
vehicles.
   C.   Special Uses: Any speed limits established in subsection A of this
section do not apply to special uses such as, but not necessarily limited to,
road races or other events, where permission for any such race or event has
been granted by a public authority.
   D.   Posting Of Speed Limits:
      1.   Posting Of Speed Limits Not Previously Established: The White Pine
County road department is authorized to establish speed limits on all roadways,
not otherwise posted, by erecting speed limit signs clearly and conspicuously
providing notice of a maximum rate of speed for a particular portion of the
highway being traversed. Any such speed limits established must be made and
based upon consideration given the traffic volume, surface, width, and location
of the highway to be posted and public safety. The posting of any highway
bearing curves shall be made upon consultation with the county engineer.
      2.   Changes To Previously Established Speed Limits: The White Pine
County road department is authorized to make a change to any speed limit
previously established under this chapter. Any such change shall be made and
based upon consideration given the traffic volume, surface, width, physical
characteristics, public safety and location of the highway to be posted.
      3.   Adoption Of Previously Established Speed Limits: All speed limits
previously established under this chapter are hereby adopted subject to any
change thereto made by the White Pine County road department as provided for by
subsection D2 of this section; that such adoption shall be effective as of the
date of the passage hereof.
      4.   Posting Of New Speed Limits Or Change To Established Speed Limit By
Resolution Or Ordinance: In addition to any authority granted the White Pine
County road department to establish any new speed zone, or to change an
established speed zone, the board of county commissioners may also establish
any new speed zone or change an established speed limit previously adopted
under this chapter or previously set by the White Pine County road department.
Any such speed limit may be established by resolution of the board. The board
of county commissioners may also establish any speed limit or make any change
to an existing speed limit by ordinance, when the board determines it advisable
to receive public comment at a hearing on the matter. Any such speed limit
established or changed by resolution or ordinance of the board of county
commissioners must be established or changed upon consideration given to
traffic volume, surface, width, and location of the highway to be posted and
public safety. (Ord. 365 §§1.0 - 2.3, 2000)
 
CHAPTER 11.22
PROHIBITION ON LOUD BRAKING
SECTION:
11.22.010: Purpose
11.22.020: Definitions
11.22.030: Loud Braking Prohibited
11.22.040: Time And Areas Of Prohibition
11.22.050: Signage
11.22.060: Exceptions/Affirmative Defense
11.22.070: Enforcement And Penalties
11.22.080: Severability
11.22.010: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this Chapter is to prohibit the excessive, loud, unusual or
explosive use of engine retarding brake(s), mechanical exhaust device(s),
braking system(s), or any other device(s) that uses the compression of the
engine of a vehicle, near and within town limits, designated areas, and Urban
Districts in White Pine County. (Ord. 531, 2023)
11.22.020: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this Chapter the following words and phrases are defined as
follows:
 
                        A "Dynamic Brake," "Jake Brake," "Jacobs Brake," "C-
                        Brake," "Paccar Brake," transmission brake, mechanical
                        exhaust device, or any other engine brake system or
                        device that alters, or is designed to alter, the normal
ENGINE RETARDING BRAKE: compression of the engine and subsequently releases
                        that compression for the purpose of braking,
                        deceleration, or maintaining a steady speed of a
                        vehicle, with or without the use of friction-based
                        wheel brakes, and is collectively referred to as the
                        "prohibited braking system" in this Chapter.
                        Every person who drives or is in actual physical
                        control of a vehicle upon a public highway, including,
                        without limitation, any road, boulevard, parkway,
OPERATOR:               avenue, street, alleyway or other public right-of-way,
                        and includes, without limitation, every person, firm,
                        corporation, company, or other entity, who is steering,
                        maneuvering, braking, decelerating, maintaining speed,
                        and/or exercising control over a vehicle.
                        The territory contiguous to and including, without
                        limitation, any highway which is built up with
URBAN DISTRICT:         structures devoted to business, industry or dwelling
                        houses situated at average intervals of less than one
                        hundred feet (100') for a distance of a quarter of a
                        mile or more.
                        Every device in, upon or by which any person or
                        property is or may be transported or drawn upon a
VEHICLE:                highway, excepting devices moved by human power,
                        animals, or used exclusively upon stationary rails or
                        tracks. (Ord. 531, 2023)
 
11.22.030: LOUD BRAKING PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to use or operate, or
cause to be used or operated, any engine retarding brake(s), transmission brake
(s), mechanical exhaust device(s), braking system(s), any other device(s) or
other prohibited braking system(s), that uses the compression of the engine of
the vehicle to aid in the braking, deceleration, and/or maintaining speed, of
any vehicle, that results in excessive, loud, unusual or explosive noise from
such vehicle. Such prohibition shall be applicable only to those public
highways, or portions thereof, identified in the areas of prohibition below (in
Section
11.22.040). (Ord. 531, 2023)
11.22.040: TIME AND AREAS OF PROHIBITION:
Unless another time period is clearly specified on signage posted by the State
Highway Engineer or the Nevada Department of Transportation, the prohibition
set forth herein shall apply at all times, day or night, twenty four (24) hours
a day, to all public highways, including, without limitation, any roadways,
boulevards, parkways, avenues, streets, alleyways, or other public right-of-
ways, within White Pine County or portions thereof located within, and
including up to a quarter mile from, the following towns, townships, townsites,
or unincorporated areas of the County:
   A.   Baker, as heretofore platted and of record in the county recorder's
office.
   B.   East Ely, including therein all of Ely City townsite and the Park
Addition to Ely City townsite, as heretofore platted and of record in the
county recorder's office.
   C.   Lund, Blocks One through Fourteen, inclusive, of the Lund Townsite Plat
Survey.
   D.   McGill, as heretofore platted and of record in the county recorder's
office.
   E.   Preston, Blocks One, Two, Three, Four, Five, Six, Seven and Eight, of
Preston Town Survey, and Lots Two, Three, Six and Seven of Block 14A of the
Preston Ten-Acre Plat Survey.
   F.   Ruth, as heretofore platted and of record in the county recorder's
office.
   G.   Cherry Creek, as heretofore platted and of record in the county
recorder's office.
   H.   Urban District(s). (Ord. 531, 2023)
11.22.050: SIGNAGE:
Signs stating "NO ENGINE BRAKES" or the like, may be installed at locations
deemed appropriate, but no further than a quarter mile from the towns,
townships, townsites, or unincorporated areas listed above (in Section
11.22.040), by the White Pine County Board of County Commissioners (BOCC), the
White Pine County Sheriff's Office (WPCSO), or the White Pine County Road
Department, except that no such sign shall be installed/posted on a State
Highway by White Pine County without written permission from the State Highway
Engineer or the Nevada Department of Transportation. The provisions of this
Chapter shall be in full force and effect even if no such signs are installed/
posted, and does not preclude the installation or posting of signs by
electronic means. Nothing in this Chapter shall preclude the State Highway
Engineer or the Nevada Department of Transportation from installing/posting of
any sign(s). (Ord. 531, 2023)
11.22.060: EXCEPTIONS/AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE:
Emergency vehicles shall be exempt from the application of this Chapter. Under
this Chapter, use of a prohibited braking system, if necessary to avoid
imminent danger, is an affirmative defense to a violation of Section
11.22.030, and if proved by a preponderance of the evidence, is not subject to
the penalties described in Section
11.22.070, if: the driver reasonably believes that an emergency requires the
use of the prohibited braking system to protect the physical safety of a person
or others from an immediate threat of physical injury or to protect against an
immediate threat of damage to property. (Ord. 531, 2023)
11.22.070: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
Until April 30, 2023, only verbal warnings of a violation of this Chapter shall
be issued by any law enforcement officer. Beginning May 1, 2023, a person,
firm, corporation or entity who violates any provisions of this Chapter is
guilty of a civil infraction punishable to the equivalent penalties of a
violation of NRS 484D.285 (Conditions for use of compression brakes) and
pursuant to NRS 484A.703 to 484A.705, inclusive. (Ord. 531, 2023)
11.22.080: SEVERABILITY:
If any provisions of this Chapter or amendments thereto, or the application of
this Chapter to any person, firm, corporation, company, entity, thing or
circumstance, is held to be invalid or unconstitutional, the remaining
provisions of this Chapter shall continue to be in full force and effect. (Ord.
531, 2023)
CHAPTER 11.24
SCHOOL ZONE
SECTION:
11.24.010: Designated
11.24.020: Speed Limit
11.24.010: DESIGNATED:
There is created a school zone on the Kimberly Highway (Nevada State Highway
44) from the Riepetown turnoff to the town limits of Kimberly, White Pine
County, Nevada. (Ord. K §1, 1954)
11.24.020: SPEED LIMIT:
All vehicular traffic passing through the zone designated in section
11.24.010 of this chapter shall not exceed the speed of twenty (20) miles per
hour and shall be prepared to stop immediately at all times. (Ord. K §2, 1954)
CHAPTER 11.28
RADAR DEVICE
SECTION:
11.28.010: Adoption For Use By Sheriff's Department
11.28.020: Signposting Required When Speed Is Radar Timed
11.28.030: Exact Rate Of Speed; Basis For Fines
11.28.010: ADOPTION FOR USE BY SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT:
A device for the checking of the speed of moving vehicles by radar is adopted
and the use thereof by the sheriff's department of White Pine County
authorized. (Ord. 21 §1, 1960)
11.28.020: SIGNPOSTING REQUIRED WHEN SPEED IS RADAR TIMED:
An adequate number of signs indicating the use of this method of checking speed
shall be posted upon principal streets and thoroughfares of White Pine County
stating in substance "SPEED RADAR TIMED". (Ord. 21 §2, 1960)
11.28.030: EXACT RATE OF SPEED; BASIS FOR FINES:
   A.   The use of such device making possible the determination of the exact
rate of speed of any moving vehicle, the following is adopted as a minimum
basis for fines to be assessed for violation of established speed limits:
      1.   One dollar ($1.00) for each mile per hour of speed in excess of the
posted speed limit thereof, with a minimum of five dollars ($5.00);
      2.   Aggravated circumstances, such as attempts to evade arresting
officer by speeding or otherwise, shall be considered specially and fine
assessed accordingly. (Ord. 21 §3, 1960)
CHAPTER 11.30
VEHICLE SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD RESTRICTIONS
SECTION:
11.30.010: Statutes Adopted
11.30.020: Applicability
11.30.030: Violation; Penalty
11.30.010: STATUTES ADOPTED:
The provisions of law set forth in Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 484.737 et
seq., regarding the size, weight and load of vehicles traveling upon public
roads are adopted by reference and are made fully applicable as the governing
law regarding such matters on designated county roads. (Ord. 219 §1, 1988)
11.30.020: APPLICABILITY:
The provisions of this chapter shall be applicable and uniform throughout the
county on all designated county roads to which the public has access or to
which persons have access as invitees or licensees. (Ord. 219 §2, 1988)
11.30.030: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this chapter shall
be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished
as set forth in Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 484. (Ord. 219 §3, 1988)
CHAPTER 11.32
VEHICLE EQUIPMENT
SECTION:
11.32.010: Inspection By Peace Officers; Arrest Notice
11.32.020: Operation Of Vehicles Without Required Equipment Or In Unsafe
Condition Prohibited
11.32.030: Failure, Refusal To Stop And Submit To Inspection And Test
11.32.040: Removal Of Unauthorized Lights, Sirens
11.32.010: INSPECTION BY PEACE OFFICERS; ARREST NOTICE:
   A.   The sheriff of White Pine County and his deputies in pursuance of
assigned duty, having reasonable cause to believe that any vehicle or
combination of vehicles not equipped as required by the laws of the state of
Nevada or in such unsafe condition as to endanger the driver or other occupant
or any person upon a public highway, may require the driver thereof, to stop
and submit such vehicle or combination of vehicles to an inspection of the
mechanical condition or equipment thereof and such test with reference thereto
as may be appropriate.
   B.   If such vehicle or combination of vehicles is found to be in an unsafe
mechanical condition or is not equipped as required by this section, the
officer making the inspection may give such driver a notice of arrest and
further require the driver or the owner of the vehicle to produce in court
satisfactory evidence that such vehicle or its equipment has been made to
conform with the requirements of this section.
   C.   Every officer giving such directions or a notice of arrest as provided
in this section shall mail a copy or otherwise give notice thereof to the owner
and any legal owner of such vehicle if other than the driver. (Ord. 43 §6(a),
1966)
11.32.020: OPERATION OF VEHICLES WITHOUT REQUIRED EQUIPMENT OR IN UNSAFE
CONDITION PROHIBITED:
No person shall operate any vehicle or combination of vehicles after notice of
such unsafe condition or that the vehicle is not equipped as required by the
laws of the state of Nevada, except as may be necessary to return such vehicle
or combination of vehicles to the residence or place of business of the owner
or driver or to a garage, until the vehicle and its equipment has been made to
conform with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 43 §6(b), 1966)
11.32.030: FAILURE, REFUSAL TO STOP AND SUBMIT TO INSPECTION AND TEST:
Whenever the driver of a vehicle is directed by the sheriff of White Pine
County or his deputies, in pursuance of assigned duty, to stop and submit the
mechanical condition of the vehicle or its equipment to an inspection or test
under conditions stated in section
11.32.010 of this chapter, such driver shall stop and submit to such inspection
or test. A failure or refusal to do so is a misdemeanor. (Ord. 43 §6(c), 1966)
11.32.040: REMOVAL OF UNAUTHORIZED LIGHTS, SIRENS:
The sheriff of White Pine County, or his deputies shall remove and destroy or
cause to be removed and destroyed, all red or amber lights and all sirens
unlawfully installed or operated. (Ord. 43 §7(a), 1966)
CHAPTER 11.36
EMERGENCY VEHICLES
SECTION:
11.36.010: Defined; Permit Required
11.36.020: Permit Issuance
11.36.030: Traffic Law Exemptions
11.36.040: Speed Limit Not Applicable
11.36.050: Fire Vehicle Right Of Way
11.36.060: Other Vehicles To Stop For Fire Vehicles
11.36.010: DEFINED; PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   "Authorized emergency vehicle" means a vehicle permitted to depart from
certain traffic laws as provided herein when equipped with an approved red
light and an approved siren, and includes:
      1.   A vehicle publicly owned and operated in the performance of its duty
as a member of any of the following organizations:
         a.   Police, fire and sheriff department vehicles,
         b.   Ambulances of public agencies,
         c.   Lifeguard or lifesaving vehicles,
         d.   State, county and city traffic law enforcement departments;
      2.   Vehicles publicly maintained in whole or in part by the state or
city, or county and privately owned and operated by a member of and who
receives salary from and is regularly employed by a police department, or by a
sheriff's office, or traffic law enforcement department, and such vehicles
shall be authorized emergency vehicles but only under each and all of the
following conditions:
         a.   When such vehicle has such a permit from the department of motor
vehicles,
         b.   Where such person operates such vehicles so owned by him in
responding to emergency calls or fire alarms or highway patrol duty or operates
such vehicles in the pursuit of actual or suspected violators of the law,
         c.   When the state, county or city does not furnish to such officer a
publicly owned vehicle for the purposes stated in subsection A2b of this
section. (Ord. 43 §5(a), 1966)
11.36.020: PERMIT ISSUANCE:
   A.   The department of motor vehicles may issue authorized emergency vehicle
permits to other vehicles required to be operated primarily for the immediate
preservation of life or property or for the apprehension of law violators. Such
permits shall not be issued to vehicles when there are available comparable
emergency type services provided by agencies referred to in section
11.36.010 of this chapter.
   B.   The issuance of authorized emergency vehicle permits to vehicles under
this section shall be limited to:
      1.   Law enforcement agencies;
      2.   Firefighting equipment designed and operated exclusively as such;
      3.   Vehicles owned or operated by an agency of the United States engaged
primarily in law enforcement work; and
      4.   Ambulances designed and operated exclusively as such.
   C.   Notwithstanding any provision contained in this section or in section
11.36.010 of this chapter, the following shall not be considered emergency
vehicles or be permitted to operate as such:
      1.   Tow trucks;
      2.   Public utility vehicles;
      3.   Vehicles used in merchant patrols;
      4.   Vehicles used in private escort service. (Ord. 43 §5(b), 1966)
11.36.030: TRAFFIC LAW EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an
emergency call or when in pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law
or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may exercise
the privileges set forth in this section, but subject to the conditions herein
stated.
   B.   The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may:
      1.   Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this chapter;
      2.   Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after
slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation;
      3.   Exceed any speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or
property;
      4.   Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in
specified directions.
   C.   The exemptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle shall
apply only when such vehicle is making use of audible and visual signals as
required by law.
   D.   The foregoing provisions shall not relieve the driver of an authorized
emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all
persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of
his reckless disregard for the safety of others. (Ord. 43 §5(c), 1966)
11.36.040: SPEED LIMIT NOT APPLICABLE:
The speed limits set forth in this chapter shall not apply to authorized
emergency vehicles when driven in response to an emergency call or in pursuit
of an actual or suspected violator of the law, and the drivers thereof sound
audible signal by bell, siren or exhaust whistle. This provision shall not
relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive
with due regard for the safety of all persons using the street, nor shall it
protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequence of a reckless
disregard of the safety of others. (Ord. 43 §4(f), 1966)
11.36.050: FIRE VEHICLE RIGHT OF WAY:
All apparatus of the Ely fire department when going to, on duty at, or
returning from a fire in Ely City (East Ely) shall have the right of way over
all other vehicles or persons on any street, crossing or other public place of
the town. (Ord. D §1, 1943)
11.36.060: OTHER VEHICLES TO STOP FOR FIRE VEHICLES:
When the Ely fire department is responding to an alarm, all other vehicles
(except peace officers or ambulances) shall come to a standstill along the
nearest right hand curb until the fire department vehicles shall have passed.
(Ord. D §2, 1943)
CHAPTER 11.40
TRUCKS
SECTION:
11.40.010: Definitions
11.40.020: License And Certificate Of Public Convenience Required
11.40.030: Certificate Of Public Convenience; Condition Required
11.40.040: Certificate Of Public Convenience; Hearing
11.40.050: Certificate Of Public Convenience; Notice
11.40.010: DEFINITIONS:
"Motor trucks" and "motor vehicles" as used herein are defined as wheeled
vehicles, propelled by steam, electricity or gasoline and used upon public
highways (not rails or tracks), of this county for the transportation of
persons or things for hire or used in the business of a common carrier of
freight, merchandise or passengers. (Unnumbered, undated ordinance §1)
11.40.020: LICENSE AND CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE REQUIRED:
No person, firm, company, partnership, association or corporation shall run or
operate a motor truck or motor vehicle upon any public highway within this
county without first securing from the board of county commissioners and having
in full force and effect a certificate of public convenience, and also a
license therefor. (Unnumbered, undated ordinance §2)
11.40.030: CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE; CONDITION REQUIRED:
Upon application by a person, firm, company, partnership, corporation to the
board of county commissioners, and it being made to appear to the satisfaction
of the board that public necessity or public convenience requires the operation
of a motor truck or motor vehicle upon any designated public highway within
this county, the board in its discretion, may grant to such applicant a
certificate that the public necessity or public convenience requires the
operation of a motor truck or motor vehicle upon such public highway, which
highway shall be designated in general terms in such certificate. (Unnumbered,
undated ordinance §3)
11.40.040: CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE; HEARING:
Upon the filing of such application it shall be the duty of the clerk of the
board of county commissioners to set the application down for hearing at a
regular or adjourned session of the board not less than ten (10) days nor more
than thirty (30) days after the date of such application, and give notice
thereof as herein provided. (Unnumbered, undated ordinance §4)
11.40.050: CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE; NOTICE:
Notice of the filing of an application for a certificate of public convenience,
and the time assigned for hearing there on, shall be published in some
newspaper of general circulation published in White Pine County and a copy of
such notice mailed by the clerk of the board to each person or company known to
the clerk to be directly interested, not less than six (6) days before the day
of hearing thereon. Such notice shall be substantially in the following form:
NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN THAT                      of       has made application
for a Public Convenience Certificate to operate as an automobile common carrier
of             between             and               in the County of White
Pine; and public hearing of said application will be held at the White Pine
County Court House, in the city of Ely, on the       day of                
19      at           o'clock in the       noon of said day, when and where
evidence will be heard in support of and in opposition to said application.
                  By                
(Unnumbered, undated ordinance §5)
CHAPTER 11.44
ARRESTS
SECTION:
11.44.010: Forms And Records
11.44.020: Hearing Before Magistrate
11.44.030: Notice To Appear In Court
11.44.040: Failure To Appear In Court
11.44.050: Citation Deemed Lawful Complaint
11.44.060: Citation On Illegally Parked Vehicle
11.44.070: Warrant Issuance; Conditions
11.44.010: FORMS AND RECORDS:
   A.   The sheriff of White Pine County shall provide books to include traffic
citation forms for moving and nonmoving violations, for notifying alleged
violators to appear and answer to charges of violations of traffic laws and
regulations in the traffic court of White Pine County. These books shall
include serially numbered sets of citations in triplicate in the form
prescribed and approved by the district attorney of White Pine County.
   B.   The sheriff of White Pine County shall be responsible for the issuance
of books of citation forms to the employees of his department charged with the
duty of enforcing the traffic laws and regulations, and shall maintain a record
of every book so issued and shall require a receipt for each book. (Ord. 43 §8
(a), 1966)
11.44.020: HEARING BEFORE MAGISTRATE:
   A.   Whenever any person is arrested for violation of this title proof state
law punishable as a misdemeanor, the arrested person shall be immediately, or
as soon as court time permits, given a hearing, in any of the following cases:
      1.   When a person arrested demands an immediate hearing;
      2.   When the person is arrested upon a charge of negligent homicide;
      3.   When the person is arrested upon a charge of driving while under the
influence of intoxicating liquor or of stimulating drugs;
      4.   When the person is arrested upon a charge of intoxication in or
about a vehicle;
      5.   When the person is arrested upon a charge of failure to stop in the
event of an accident causing death, personal injury or damage to property;
      6.   In any other event when the person arrested refuses to give his
written promise to appear in court as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 43 §8(b),
1966)
11.44.030: NOTICE TO APPEAR IN COURT:
   A.   Whenever a person is cited for a violation of any provisions of this
title or of state law punishable as a misdemeanor, and such person is not
immediately taken before a court as hereinbefore required, the officer shall
prepare in triplicate written notice to appear in court containing the name and
address of such person, the license number of his vehicle, if any, the offense
charged and the time and place when and where such person shall appear in
court.
   B.   The time specified in this notice must be at least five (5) days after
such citation unless the person cited shall demand an earlier hearing.
   C.   In order to secure release as provided in this section, the person must
give his written promise to appear in court by signing at least one copy of the
written notice prepared by the officer. The officer shall deliver a copy of the
notice to the person promising to appear. Thereupon, the officer shall
forthwith release the person. (Ord. 43 §8(c), 1966)
11.44.040: FAILURE TO APPEAR IN COURT:
It is unlawful for any person to violate his written promise to appear given to
an officer upon the issuance of a traffic citation regardless of the
disposition of the charge for which such citation was originally issued. (Ord.
43 §8(d), 1966)
11.44.050: CITATION DEEMED LAWFUL COMPLAINT:
In the event the form of citation provided under section
11.44.010 of this chapter includes information and is sworn to as required
under the general laws of this state in respect to a complaint charging
commission of the offense alleged in the citation to have been committed, then
such citation when filed with a court having jurisdiction shall be deemed to be
a lawful complaint with the purpose of prosecution under this title. (Ord. 43
§8(e), 1966)
11.44.060: CITATION ON ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLE:
Whenever any motor vehicle without driver, is found parked or stopped in
violation of any of the restrictions imposed by the provisions of this title or
of state law, the officer finding such vehicle, shall take its registration
number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may
identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a traffic
citation, on a form provided by the sheriff of White Pine County, for the
driver to answer to the charge against him within five (5) days during the
hours and at a place specified on this citation. (Ord. 43 §8(f), 1966)
11.44.070: WARRANT ISSUANCE; CONDITIONS:
In the event any person fails to comply with a traffic citation given to such
person or attached to a vehicle, or fails to make appearance pursuant to a
summons directing an appearance in traffic court, the sheriff of White Pine
County or his deputies shall secure and issue a warrant for his arrest. (Ord.
43 §8(g), 1966)
CHAPTER 11.48
ABANDONED, WRECKED, DISMANTLED OR INOPERATIVE MOTOR VEHICLES
SECTION:
11.48.010: Definitions
11.48.020: Storing, Parking Or Leaving Vehicles On Public Or Private Property
11.48.030: Motor Vehicle Nuisance; Exceptions
11.48.040: Notice To Remove
11.48.050: Responsibility For Removal
11.48.060: Hearing
11.48.070: Removal Of Motor Vehicle
11.48.080: Removal; Notice
11.48.090: Disposition Of Vehicles Abandoned To Public Domain
11.48.100: Private Claim To Title Of An Abandoned Or Junk Vehicle
11.48.110: Disputing Claimed Title
11.48.120: Liability Of Owner Or Occupant
11.48.130: Notice Of Public Sale
11.48.140: Public Sale
11.48.150: Redemption Of Impounded Vehicles
11.48.160: Violation; Penalty
11.48.010: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in
the plural number include the singular number and words in the singular number
include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely
directory.
COUNTY: The County of White Pine.
JUNK VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle, as defined by the definition of "motor
vehicle" of this section, which lacks an unexpired license plate or plates,
and/or the condition of which is wrecked, dismantled, partially dismantled,
inoperative, abandoned or discarded.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Any vehicle which is self-propelled and designed to travel along
the ground and shall include, but not be limited to, automobiles, buses,
motorbikes, motorcycles, motorscooters, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golf carts,
campers and trailers.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or
organization of any kind.
PRIVATE PROPERTY: Any real property within the County which is privately owned
and which is not "public property" as defined below.
PUBLIC PROPERTY: Any road, street, highway, public easement or thoroughfare -
which shall include the entire width between the boundary lines of every way
publicly maintained for the purposes of vehicular travel - or County-owned
parking lot, parking garage, or impound, including any other publicly owned
property or facility. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.020: STORING, PARKING OR LEAVING VEHICLES ON PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   No person shall:
      1.   Abandon a vehicle.
         a.   A vehicle shall be considered abandoned which has been left
unattended and:
            (1)   Is positioned on property not intended to support motor
vehicles; or
            (2)   Has been inoperable for forty eight (48) hours on public
property not immediately adjacent to private property owned, rented, or leased
by the vehicle's owner; or
            (3)   Has remained on private property not owned by the vehicle's
owner without the consent of the property owner or person in control of the
property for more than forty eight (48) hours; or
            (4)   Is more than five (5) years old and has remained on a
designated County, State, or Federal right-of-way for more than forty eight
(48) hours; or
            (5)   Is five (5) or less years old and has remained on a
designated County, State, or Federal right-of-way for more than ninety six (96)
hours.
      2.   Park a vehicle on public property, which:
         a.   Does not have a valid and current registration issued from the
Nevada Department of Motor Vehicles or another state or nation; or
         b.   Does not appropriately display a valid and current license plate,
temporary placard, or moving permit issued for that vehicle by the Nevada
Department of Motor Vehicles or by another state or nation; or
         c.   Is suspended on jacks or any other lifting device, except as and
to the extent reasonably necessary to change a tire or effect an immediate
repair; or
         d.   Is disassembled or engaged in mechanical repairs, except as to
the extent reasonably necessary to effect an immediate emergency repair.
      3.   Allow a junk vehicle to remain:
         a.   Unmoved on public property for more than seventy two (72)
consecutive hours without:
            (1)   Notifying the Sheriff of the County; and
            (2)   Obtaining written approval for the vehicle to remain;
         b.   On any adjoining public property adjacent to the same parcel or
property line for more than seventy two (72) hours of any consecutive ninety
six (96) hour period without:
            (1)   Notifying the Sheriff of the County; and
            (2)   Obtaining written approval for the vehicle to remain;
         c.   In a parking space in the parking lot of a multifamily
residential development for more than seven (7) consecutive days if the
vehicle:
            (1)   Is in an obviously mechanically inoperable condition or a
state of disassemble; and
            (2)   Is visible from public property.
      4.   Park any vehicle in the White Pine County Courthouse, Sheriff, and/
or Detention Facility parking lot(s) located at 1785 and 1786 Great Basin,
Blvd., Ely, Nevada, between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and five
o'clock (5:00) A.M. (of the succeeding day), except for County owned vehicles,
vehicles owned or operated by County Employees, Law Enforcement Officers, and/
or persons conducting official, after-hours business at the Courthouse,
Sheriff, and/or Detention Facilities.
         a.   The daily hours designated for closure to public use of the White
Pine County Courthouse, Sheriff, and/or Detention Facility parking lot(s)
located at 1785 and 1786 Great Basin, Blvd., Ely, Nevada, that is, between the
hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. (of the
succeeding day), shall be posted (by signs) in conspicuous places at each of
the facilities, including, but not limited to, areas commonly used for public
ingress and egress of vehicles, intervals of such a distance as is necessary to
ensure that at least one such sign would be within the direct line of sight of
a person standing next to another such sign, but at intervals of not more than
five hundred (500) feet.
         b.   This provision shall apply, without limitation, to any and all
current and future public Courthouse, Sheriff, and/or Detention Facility
parking lot(s), owned or controlled by White Pine County, including, but not
limited to those located within the city limits of the City of Ely, Nevada.
         c.   Any person who violates this provision shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and may be punished according to White Pine County Code Section
10.28.030 and the vehicle is subject to towing and storage at the vehicle
owner's expense.
   B.   For purposes of the forty eight (48), seventy two (72), and ninety six
(96) hour limitations contained in this chapter, vehicles which are moved short
distances with the intent of avoiding the time limitations will be considered
in violation. (Ord. 528 § 1, 2022: Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.030: MOTOR VEHICLE NUISANCE; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   An abandoned or junk vehicle or parts thereof, whether on private or
public property, is a public nuisance, which may be abated as such in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
      1.   This section shall not apply to any motor vehicle:
         a.   Enclosed within a building on private property; or
         b.   Held in connection with a business enterprise, lawfully licensed
by the County and properly operated in the appropriate business zone, pursuant
to the zoning laws of the County; or
         c.   That is in operable condition and specifically adopted or
designed for operation on drag strips or raceways; or
         d.   That is in operable condition and retained by the owner for
antique collection purposes. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.040: NOTICE TO REMOVE:
   A.   Procedure:
      1.   Any law enforcement or Code Enforcement Officer of the County who
has reasonable grounds to believe that a vehicle has been abandoned, parked, or
remains on public property in violation of this chapter may affix a warning to
a conspicuous location on the vehicle, which will be considered proper notice
to the owner that the vehicle may be in violation of the provisions of this
chapter and is subject to removal.
         a.   The officer may also mark one (1) or more tires of the vehicle to
indicate the tire's position on the road, and the current date.
      2.   Any law enforcement or Code Enforcement Officer of the County who
has reasonable grounds to believe that a vehicle has been abandoned, parked, or
remains on private property shall allow at least ten (10) days before the time
of compliance.
         a.   It shall constitute sufficient notice, when a copy of the notice
is posted in a conspicuous place upon the private property on which the vehicle
is located and duplicate copies are sent by registered mail to the owner or
occupant of the private property at his last known address.
   B.   Contents:
      1.   Notice shall:
         a.   Be titled "Notice of Infraction"; and,
         b.   Request removal within the time specified in this chapter; and,
         c.   Advise that upon failure to comply with the notice to remove, the
County shall undertake such removal with the cost levied against the owner of
the vehicle or the owner or occupant of the property; and,
         d.   Include the date and time the vehicle will be removed as provided
by the time restrictions provided in section
11.48.020 of this chapter. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.050: RESPONSIBILITY FOR REMOVAL:
   A.   Upon proper notice and opportunity to be heard, the owner of the
abandoned or junk vehicle shall be responsible for its removal.
      1.   If the abandoned or junk vehicle is on private property not owned or
occupied by the owner of the vehicle, the owner or occupant of the private
property on which the vehicle is located shall be responsible for removal.
      2.   In the event of removal and disposition by the County:
         a.   The owner, or occupant of the private property where the vehicle
is located, shall be liable for the expenses incurred.
         b.   The owner or occupant of the private property where the vehicle
is located is entitled to compensation for those expenses by the owner of the
vehicle. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.060: HEARING:
   A.   Request:
      1.   The persons to whom notice is directed pursuant to subsection
11.48.040A2 of this chapter, or their duly authorized agents, may file a
written request for hearing before the Board of County Commissioners of White
Pine County or its designee within the ten (10) day period of compliance
prescribed in section
11.48.040 of this chapter for the purpose of defending the charges by the
County.
   B.   Procedure:
      1.   The hearing shall be held as soon as practicable after the filing of
the request and the persons to whom the notices are directed shall be advised
of the time and place of said hearing at least three (3) days in advance
thereof. At any such hearing the County and the persons to whom the notices
have been directed may introduce such witnesses and evidence as either party
deems necessary. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.070: REMOVAL OF MOTOR VEHICLE:
   A.   If the violation described in the notice represents a substantial risk
to the public, has not been remedied within the noticed period of compliance,
or the violation is affirmed in a hearing pursuant to section
11.48.060 of this chapter, the White Pine County Sheriff or a designee shall
have the right to take possession of the abandoned or junk vehicle.
      1.   It is unlawful for any person to interfere with, hinder, or refuse
to allow such person or persons to enter upon private property for the purpose
of removing a vehicle under the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   Subject to the provisions of Nevada Revised Statutes chapters 484B and
487, the Sheriff or designee with the right of possession to a vehicle pursuant
to this section is authorized to immediately remove the vehicle, or have the
vehicle removed, from any public or private property, for the purpose of
storage or disposition, whether to the Sheriff's impound or to a designated
garage, yard, or storage within the County. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.080: REMOVAL; NOTICE:
   A.   Within forty eight (48) hours of the removal of a vehicle, the White
Pine County Sheriff shall give notice that the vehicle has been impounded and
stored for violation of this chapter to:
      1.   The registered owner of the vehicle, or if the vehicle is
unregistered, to the last known owner; and,
      2.   The owner or occupant of the private property from which the vehicle
was removed, if removed from private property.
   B.   Notice of removal shall give an accurate description of:
      1.   The location from where the vehicle was removed; and,
      2.   The facility where the vehicle is stored; and,
      3.   The costs incurred by the County for removal. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.090: DISPOSITION OF VEHICLES ABANDONED TO PUBLIC DOMAIN:
   A.   Upon removing a vehicle pursuant to section
11.48.070 of this chapter, the County shall submit a written request for
appraisal to the Nevada Department of Motor Vehicles after no more than ten
(10) days, to which the Nevada Department of Motor Vehicles has ten (10) days
to respond 1 .
   B.   The Sheriff shall, within forty eight (48) hours after the appraisal,
notify the head of the Nevada Department of Motor Vehicles of the removal and
disposition of the vehicle 2 .
      1.   If the vehicle is appraised at two hundred dollars ($200.00) or
less, the White Pine County Sheriff shall execute an affidavit attesting to the
vehicle as junk pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 487.260(2) and describing
the vehicle, including the license plates, if any, the appraised value of the
vehicle, and a statement as to how the Sheriff intends to dispose of the
vehicle.
         a.   The White Pine County Sheriff, after complying with the above,
may claim title to the junk vehicle with an affidavit which attests to its
value as junk.
         b.   The Sheriff may then summarily dispose of the vehicle.
      2.   If the vehicle is appraised at more than two hundred dollars
($200.00) but for five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less, the White Pine County
Sheriff shall execute an affidavit so attesting and describing the vehicle,
including the license plates, if any, the appraised value of the vehicle, and a
statement as to how the Sheriff intends to dispose of the vehicle.
         a.   Failure to reclaim a vehicle appraised at five hundred dollars
($500.00) or less within fifteen (15) days after notification constitutes a
waiver of interest in the vehicle by any person having an interest in the
vehicle 3 .
            (1)   If no interested parties present themselves to the White Pine
County Sheriff with the intent of reclaiming the vehicle, the Sheriff may claim
title to the vehicle pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 487.250(4) with an
affidavit which attests to the failure in subsection B2a of this section.
            (2)   After receiving the salvage title from the Nevada Department
of Motor Vehicles, the Sheriff may summarily dispose of the vehicle.
      3.   If the vehicle is appraised at more than five hundred dollars
($500.00), the White Pine County Sheriff shall execute an affidavit so
attesting and describing the vehicle, including the license plates, if any, the
appraised value of the vehicle, and a statement as to how the Sheriff intends
to dispose of the vehicle.
         a.   Failure to reclaim a vehicle appraised at more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) within forty five (45) days after notification constitutes a
waiver of interest in the vehicle by any person having an interest in the
vehicle.
            (1)   If no interested parties present themselves to the White Pine
County Sheriff with the intent of reclaiming the vehicle, the Sheriff may claim
title to the vehicle pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 487.810(1)(d) with an
affidavit which attests to the failure in subsection B3a of this section.
            (2)   After receiving the salvage title from the Nevada Department
of Motor Vehicles, the Sheriff may summarily dispose of the vehicle.
               (A)   If the White Pine County Sheriff chooses to conduct a sale
of any vehicle in their possession worth more than five hundred dollars
($500.00), the Sheriff shall give notice of public sale not less than ten (10)
days before the date of the proposed sale. (Ord. 473, 2017)
 
Notes
1 1. NRS 487.240.
2 2. NRS 487.250 - 270.
3 3. NRS 487.250.
11.48.100: PRIVATE CLAIM TO TITLE OF AN ABANDONED OR JUNK VEHICLE:
   A.   A person on whose property a vehicle has been adversely abandoned
becomes a de facto lienholder after seven (7) days.
      1.   A lien established under this section is called an "abandoned
vehicle lien".
   B.   The holder of an abandoned vehicle lien is entitled to claim a salvage
title pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 487.810(1)(d) when the number of days
as determined by value in subsection
11.48.090B of this chapter have passed since the lienholder has:
      1.   Become a lienholder pursuant to subsection A of this section; and,
      2.   Engaged local law enforcement to conduct a check of the vehicle's
VIN to verify it has not been stolen; and,
      3.   Completed an attempt to notice the last registered owner of the
vehicle by direct service, mail, or publication (see Nevada DMV Form VP212);
and,
      4.   Made reasonable efforts to discover other interested parties beside
the registered owner (insurer, loan provider, and loan servicer). (Ord. 473,
2017)
11.48.110: DISPUTING CLAIMED TITLE:
   A.   A person with document interest in an abandoned vehicle may dispute a
title claimed pursuant to an abandoned vehicle lien if:
      1.   No more than one (1) year has passed since the vehicle was
abandoned; or,
      2.   No more than six (6) months has passed since the abandoned vehicle
lienholder perfected title.
   B.   The local court, whether a Justice Court or Municipal Court, shall have
jurisdiction over disputed claims.
      1.   The court, or the Judge thereof, shall require the substance of all
possible issues of a complaint in relation to the interest of the parties to be
contained in the pleading challenging title.
         a.   If any issue is not included in the pleading challenging title it
is forever waived.
   C.   Any judgment or decree rendered in an action challenging a title
claimed pursuant to the abandoned vehicle lien shall apply to and conclude any
interest in the vehicle with respect to such persons. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.120: LIABILITY OF OWNER OR OCCUPANT:
Upon the failure of the owner or occupant of property on which abandoned
vehicles have been removed by the County to pay the unrecovered expenses
incurred by the County in such removal, a lien shall be placed upon the
property for the amount of such expenses. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.130: NOTICE OF PUBLIC SALE:
The notice of sale shall state:
   A.   The sale is of abandoned property in the possession of the County;
   B.   A description of the vehicle, including make, model, license number and
any other information which will accurately identify the vehicle;
   C.   The terms of the sale;
   D.   The date, time and place of the sale. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.140: PUBLIC SALE:
The vehicle shall be sold to the highest and best bidder. At the time of
payment of the purchase price, the White Pine County Sheriff shall execute a
certificate of sale in duplicate, the original of which to be given to the
purchaser, and the copy thereof to be filed with the Clerk of the County.
Should the sale for any reason be invalid, the County's liability shall be
limited to the return of the purchase price. (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.150: REDEMPTION OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLES:
The owner of any vehicle seized under the provisions of this chapter, impounded
in the course of the Sheriff's duties as Coroner, or secured for purposes of
probate, may redeem such vehicle at any time after its removal but prior to the
sale or destruction thereof upon proof of ownership and payment to the White
Pine County Sheriff of such sum as he may determine and fix for the actual and
reasonable expense of removal, and any preliminary sale advertising expenses,
not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus ten dollars ($10.00) per day
for storage for each vehicle redeemed, to a maximum fee of five hundred dollars
($500.00). (Ord. 473, 2017)
11.48.160: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Whenever it comes to the attention of the White Pine County Sheriff
that any nuisance as defined in section
11.48.030 of this chapter exists in White Pine County a notice in writing shall
be served upon the occupant of the land where the nuisance exists, or in case
there is no such occupant, then upon the owner of the property or his agent,
notifying them of the existence of the nuisance and requesting its removal in
the time specified in this chapter.
      1.   The first notice shall be provided without penalty.
      2.   Subsequent notices may be issued no earlier than ten (10) days,
exclusive, from day the prior notice was issued.
      3.   Subsequent notices shall each be deemed a separate offense.
   B.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine of not
more than two hundred dollars ($200.00).
      1.   Each act in violation of any of the provisions hereof shall be
deemed a separate offense.
   C.   If the title to a vehicle is claimed by the Sheriff or by a wrecker,
garage, yard, or other storage within the County and disposed of pursuant to
section
11.48.090 of this chapter, the total fines shall be reduced to no more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 473, 2017)
CHAPTER 11.52
VEHICLE OPERATION ON LANDSCAPED OR IMPROVED COUNTY PROPERTY
SECTION:
11.52.010: Operation Of Motor Vehicle On Improved Or Landscaped County
Property; Unlawful
11.52.020: Exceptions
11.52.010: OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLE ON IMPROVED OR LANDSCAPED COUNTY
PROPERTY; UNLAWFUL:
Except as otherwise provided herein, it is unlawful for any person to operate a
motor vehicle on any lawn, flowerbed, garden, park or other landscaped or
improved property owned or operated by White Pine County other than highways
and parking areas. (Ord. 180 §1, 1984)
11.52.020: EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Section
11.52.010 of this chapter does not apply to the following:
      1.   Employees of White Pine County in the course of the duties of such
employment;
      2.   Authorized emergency vehicles;
      3.   Any person who has obtained written permission for operation of a
motor vehicle signed by the sheriff of White Pine County or his deputy. Such
permission shall state the date of such permitted operation. (Ord. 180 §1,
1984)
CHAPTER 11.56
NEIGHBORHOOD VEHICLE CLASSIFICATION, AUTHORIZATION, USE AND LICENSING
SECTION:
11.56.010: Neighborhood Vehicle Defined
11.56.020: Operational Area
11.56.030: Operational Limitations
11.56.040: Equipment Requirements
11.56.050: Permit Requirements
11.56.060: Driving Age
11.56.070: Penalties
11.56.010: NEIGHBORHOOD VEHICLE DEFINED:
A motorized vehicle, propelled by electric motor or gasoline engine, consisting
of three (3) or four (4) wheels with a top speed of less than twenty (20) miles
per hour, of a type generally operated on golf courses. (Ord. 433, 2009)
11.56.020: OPERATIONAL AREA:
Neighborhood vehicles may be operated on White Pine County general, standard
and minor roads, within the unincorporated areas of the county and within the
townships of Baker, Lund, McGill and Ruth and on all county paved roadways
where the speed limit is posted twenty five (25) miles per hour or less. (Ord.
433, 2009)
11.56.030: OPERATIONAL LIMITATIONS:
Neighborhood vehicles may be driven only during daylight hours. Neighborhood
vehicles may not be operated on state highways such as State Highways 44, 487,
489, etc., nor on Federal Highways 6, 50, 93, etc., except neighborhood
vehicles may be driven across state or federal highways so long as crossings
are performed at intersections and are perpendicular to the highway being
crossed. Neighborhood vehicles must drive as far to the right hand side of the
roadway as possible. (Ord. 433, 2009)
11.56.040: EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
Neighborhood vehicles must be equipped with a rearview mirror, a slow vehicle
triangle, red reflectors and a neighborhood vehicle permit displayed on the
back of the unit, which permit shall be issued by the sheriff's office. (Ord.
433, 2009)
11.56.050: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
The White Pine County sheriff shall issue a permit for the use of neighborhood
vehicles on county roadways. The permit shall be affixed permanently to the
rear area of the vehicles so that the permit is readily visible to other
vehicles. The permit shall identify the driver authorized to operate the
neighborhood vehicle. The sheriff is authorized, in his sole discretion, to
deny a permit or revoke a permit at any time to any citizen or any neighborhood
vehicle for any reason the sheriff deems constitutes a risk to the motoring
public. Permits will be issued after payment of a fee of ten dollars ($10.00)
valid for one year, from January 1 to December 31. (Ord. 433, 2009)
11.56.060: DRIVING AGE:
The same as state law requirements for driver's license. (Ord. 433, 2009)
11.56.070: PENALTIES:
Any violation of any section of this chapter is punishable as a misdemeanor
violation and for any violation a court of competent jurisdiction may impose a
civil penalty in any amount up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) but may not
impose jail time for a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 433, 2009)
