16.04.010: SHORT TITLE:
This title shall be known and referred to as the COUNTY SUBDIVISION ORDINANCE.
(Ord. 39 §1, 1965)
CHAPTER 16.08
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
16.08.010: Owner
16.08.020: Subdivider
16.08.030: Subdivision
16.08.010: OWNER:
"Owner" is the individual, firm, association, syndicate, copartnership or
corporation, having sufficient proprietary interest in the land sought to be
subdivided, to commence and maintain proceedings to subdivide the land under
this title, and while used herein in the masculine gender and singular number,
it means the feminine and neuter gender and plural number whenever required.
(Ord. 39 §3.1, 1965)
16.08.020: SUBDIVIDER:
"Subdivider" means any individual, firm, association, syndicate, copartnership,
corporation, trust, or other legal entity commencing proceedings under this
title, to effect a subdivision of land hereunder for himself or for another
and, while used herein in the masculine gender and singular number, it means
and includes the feminine or neuter gender and the plural number whenever
required. (Ord. 39 §3.2, 1965)
16.08.030: SUBDIVISION:
   A.   "Subdivision" means any land, vacant or improved, which is divided or
proposed to be divided into five (5) or more lots, parcels, sites, units or
plots, for the purpose of any transfer, development on any proposed transfer or
development, unless exempted by one of the following provisions:
      1.   The term "subdivision" does not apply to any division of land which
creates lots, parcels, sites, units or plots of land each of which comprises at
least:
         a.   One sixty-fourth (1/64) of a section as described by a government
land office survey; or
         b.   Ten (10) acres in area, including roads and easements.
      2.   The term "subdivision" does not apply to any division of land which
creates lots, parcels, sites, units or plots of land for agricultural purposes
into parcels of more than ten (10) acres, if a street, road or highway opening
or widening or easement of any kind is not involved.
      3.   Any joint tenancy or tenancy in common shall be deemed a single
interest in land.
      4.   Unless a method of disposition is adopted for the purpose of evading
this chapter and applicable sections of the Nevada Revised Statutes, or would
have the effect of evading such laws, the term "subdivision" does not apply to:
         a.   Any division of land which is ordered by any court in this state
or created by operation of law;
         b.   A lien, mortgage, deed or trust or any other security instrument;
         c.   A security or unit of interest in any investment trust regulated
under the laws of this state or any other interest in an investment entity;
         d.   Cemetery lots; or
         e.   An interest in oil, gas, minerals or building materials, which
are now or hereafter severed from the surface ownership of real property. (Ord.
147 §1, 1982: Ord. 39 §3.3, 1965)
CHAPTER 16.12
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
16.12.010: Purpose
16.12.020: Effect Of Repeal
16.12.030: Sale Restrictions
16.12.040: Commencement Of Construction
16.12.050: Area Excluded
16.12.010: PURPOSE:
This title is enacted for the purpose of adopting subdivision regulations in
accordance with the applicable statutes of the state of Nevada. (Ord. 39 §2.1,
1965)
16.12.020: EFFECT OF REPEAL:
The repeal of ordinances codified herein shall not affect any agreement,
contract, or bond executed pursuant to such ordinances, or any rights of action
accrued thereunder. (Ord. 39 §2.2, 1965)
16.12.030: SALE RESTRICTIONS:
It is unlawful for any individual, firm, association, syndicate, copartnership,
trust, or any other legal entity, as a principal, agent, or otherwise, to offer
to sell, to contract to sell, or to sell, or lease, or transfer, any
subdivision of land or any part thereof in White Pine County, unless and until
all the requirements hereinafter provided have been complied with. This shall
not be construed to prohibit the sale of any lot or parcel of land which is of
record as a lot or parcel of land on January 30, 1965. (Ord. 39 §2.3, 1965)
16.12.040: COMMENCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION:
It is unlawful for any individual, firm, association, syndicate, copartnership,
trust, or any other legal entity, as a principal, agent, or otherwise, to
commence construction of any permanent structure on any lands upon which a
tentative map has been filed, unless or until the final map or record of survey
map has been approved as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 39 §2.4, 1965)
16.12.050: AREA EXCLUDED:
There is excluded from the operation of this title that area comprising the
city of Ely, Nevada. (Ord. 39 §12.1, 1965)
CHAPTER 16.16
TENTATIVE MAPS 1
SECTION:
16.16.010: Size, Scale
16.16.020: Contents
16.16.030: Statements Of Subdivider Required
16.16.040: Filing Of Copies; Profiles Required
16.16.050: Preparation To Conform To State Law
16.16.060: Time Of Filing
16.16.070: Referral To Utility Agencies, Surveyor And Recorder
16.16.080: County Planning Commission Action
16.16.090: Appeal Procedure
 
Notes
1 1. NRS 278.330 - 278.360.
16.16.010: SIZE, SCALE:
Tentative maps shall be twenty four by thirty two inches (24 x 32") in size and
to a scale of not less than one inch equals one hundred feet (1" = 100'),
unless otherwise approved by the county planning commission. (Ord. 435, 2009:
Ord. 39 §4.1, 1965)
16.16.020: CONTENTS:
   A.   The tentative map shall show:
      1.   The name of the subdivision;
      2.   The names and addresses of record owners, subdividers, and engineer
or licensed surveyor;
      3.   Essential facts as to adjoining properties, such as street locations
and widths;
      4.   A small diagram with scale indicated, showing the general location
of the subdivision with respect to nearby communities and principal highways;
      5.   All boundary dimensions showing property lines and essential
topographic information regarding land to be subdivided, especially areas
subject to inundation, and the location, width, and direction of flow of all
watercourses. A contour map shall be required when, in the judgment of the
county planning commission, such a map is needed;
      6.   All proposed streets, with widths, approximate radii of curves, and
grades;
      7.   All lots, with approximate dimensions and numbers thereof;
      8.   Proposed easements and building or setback lines with dimensions;
      9.   Proposed parks and areas offered for dedication;
      10.   Date, north point, and scale. (Ord. 435, 2009: Ord. 39 §4.2, 1965)
16.16.030: STATEMENTS OF SUBDIVIDER REQUIRED:
   A.   The tentative map shall be accompanied by written statements of the
subdivider or his agent indicating the following:
      1.   Evidence of ownership of property to be subdivided;
      2.   Type of street improvements which the subdivider proposes to
install;
      3.   The restrictions which the subdivider proposes to apply, if any;
      4.   Evidence of feasibility of a proper and adequate sewage disposal
system, and domestic water supply system;
      5.   Evidence of proper and adequate utility service. (Ord. 39 §4.3,
1965)
16.16.040: FILING OF COPIES; PROFILES REQUIRED:
In connection with the making of any subdivisions the subdivider or his agent,
shall prepare and file with the county planning commission four (4) copies of
the tentative map or maps of such subdivision. Profiles shall accompany the
maps, showing all streets and road grades and vertical curves. (Ord. 435, 2009:
Ord. 55 §1, 1971: Ord. 52 §1, 1970: Ord. 39 §5.1, 1965)
16.16.050: PREPARATION TO CONFORM TO STATE LAW:
The tentative map or maps shall also be prepared and submitted in accordance
with the provisions of Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 39 §5.2, 1965)
16.16.060: TIME OF FILING:
The tentative map or maps shall be filed prior to the final survey of any
streets or lots, before any grading or construction work is started upon any
proposed street or road, and before the sale of any lot or parcel of land
within the proposed subdivision. (Ord. 39 §5.3, 1965)
16.16.070: REFERRAL TO UTILITY AGENCIES, SURVEYOR AND RECORDER:
A copy of the tentative subdivision map shall be referred to each utility
agency providing gas, telephone, power, culinary water and sanitary sewer and
to the county surveyor and recorder for checking and recommendation concerning
the availability of service, easements, required problems to be solved, etc.
(Ord. 52 §2, 1970: Ord. 39 §5.3(a), 1965)
16.16.080: COUNTY PLANNING COMMISSION ACTION:
The county planning commission shall report to the subdivider and the board of
county commissioners on the map or maps of any subdivision submitted to it
within thirty (30) days after the tentative map has been filed; and the report
shall approve, conditionally approve, or disapprove the map or maps of the
subdivision. If conditionally approved or disapproved, the report shall state
the conditions under which the map would have been approved. (Ord. 435, 2009:
Ord. 39 §5.4, 1965)
16.16.090: APPEAL PROCEDURE:
If the subdivider is dissatisfied with any action of the county planning
commission, he may, within fifteen (15) days after such action, appeal from the
action of the county planning commission to the board of county commissioners
which must hear the same, unless the subdivider consents to a continuance,
within ten (10) days or at its next succeeding regular meeting. The board of
county commissioners may by a majority vote of its members overrule any ruling
of the county planning commission in regard to the tentative map, and make such
findings as are not inconsistent with the provisions of the Nevada Revised
Statutes and this title. (Ord. 435, 2009: Ord. 39 §5.5, 1965)
CHAPTER 16.20
FINAL MAPS 1
SECTION:
16.20.010: Size; Scale; Materials
16.20.020: Title
16.20.030: Certificates
16.20.040: Surveying Data; Lots
16.20.050: Surveying Data; Streets
16.20.060: Easement Designation
16.20.070: Existing Monument Designation
16.20.080: Established Line Designation
16.20.090: Preparation To Conform To State Law
16.20.100: Submission To County Planning Commission
16.20.110: Filing Of Improvement Plans
16.20.120: Approval By Board Of County Commissioners
16.20.130: Clerk To Notify Subdivider Of Board's Action
16.20.140: Filing For Recordation
16.20.150: Compliance Required For Recordation
 
Notes
1 1. NRS 278.380 - 278.460.
16.20.010: SIZE; SCALE; MATERIALS:
The final subdivision map shall be clearly and legibly drawn upon tracing cloth
of good quality. All lines, letters and figures shall be made in black india
ink. Certificates may be stamped or printed with opaque ink. The size of each
sheet of the map shall be twenty four by thirty two inches (24 x 32"). A
marginal line shall be drawn completely around each sheet, leaving an entirely
blank margin of one inch (1") at the top, bottom, and right edges, and of two
inches (2") at the left edge along the twenty four inch (24") dimension. The
name, title, or other designation, and all drawings, affidavits, certificates,
acknowledgments, endorsements, acceptance of dedication, and notarial seals
shall be within the marginal line.
The scale to which the drawing is made shall be large enough to show the
details clearly, and enough sheets shall be used to accomplish this end. Each
sheet shall be numbered. The relation of one sheet to another shall be clearly
shown, and the number of sheets used shall be set forth in the title of the
map. (Ord. 39 §6.1, 1965)
16.20.020: TITLE:
The first sheet shall contain the title conspicuously placed in the lower right
hand corner of the map. Below the title shall be a subtitle consisting of a
general description of all of the property being subdivided, by reference to
deeds or to maps which have been recorded, or to official United States
surveys.
Maps filed for the purpose of reverting subdivided land to acreage shall be so
designated on the title sheet by an appropriate note containing the words "map
of vacation" followed by "reversion to acreage".
Every sheet comprising the map proper shall bear the title (but not subtitle),
scale, north point, and sheet number. The title sheet shall show, in addition,
the basis of bearings, the names of the engineer and subdivider, and a location
diagram. (Ord. 39 §6.2, 1965)
16.20.030: CERTIFICATES:
   A.   A certificate of the licensed land surveyor or civil engineer,
accompanied by his seal, shall appear certifying to the accuracy of the final
map, and of all data shown thereon. In addition, there shall be such other
certificates as may be required by law, including the following:
      1.   Certificate of owner, consenting to subdivision;
      2.   Certificate of owner, offering to dedicate streets and other lands;
      3.   Clerk's certificate indicating official approval of map and
acceptance of dedications;
      4.   Certificate of county surveyor indicating that map complies with
law;
      5.   Certificate of county tax receiver showing that no liens or
assessments stand against the property;
      6.   Certificate of county tax receiver giving an estimate of taxes which
are a lien but not yet payable and a certificate of the board of county
commissioners acknowledging bond for same;
      7.   Certificate of the state health officer indicating feasibility of a
proper and adequate sewage disposal system, and domestic water supply system.
(Ord. 39 §6.3, 1965)
16.20.040: SURVEYING DATA; LOTS:
Sufficient data must be shown to determine readily the bearing and length of
every lot line, block line, and boundary line. Linear dimension shall be
expressed in feet and decimals of a foot. No ditto marks shall be used. Lots
containing one acre or more must show acreage to the nearest hundredth. Length,
radius and total delta and length of arc of all centerline curves on streets
and lengths of arc and delta of each curved lot boundary must be shown. (Ord.
39 §6.4, 1965)
16.20.050: SURVEYING DATA; STREETS:
The map shall show the centerlines of all streets, the total width of each
street, the width of the portion being dedicated; and the width of existing
dedication; also the width of railroad right of way, flood control or drainage
channels, and of any other easement appearing on the map. (Ord. 39 §6.5, 1965)
16.20.060: EASEMENT DESIGNATION:
The map shall show the lines of all easements to which the lots are subject.
Easements for storm drains, sewers, and other purposes shall be denoted by fine
dotted lines. The width of the easement, and the lengths and bearings of the
lines thereof, and sufficient dimensions and ties to locate the easement
definitely with respect to the subdivision, shall be shown.
The easement shall be clearly labeled and identified, and if already of record,
proper reference to the records given. If the easement is being dedicated by
the map, it shall be properly set out in the owner's certificate of dedication.
(Ord. 39 §6.6, 1965)
16.20.070: EXISTING MONUMENT DESIGNATION:
The map shall show clearly what stakes, monuments, or other evidence was found
on the ground to determine the boundaries of the tract. The corners of all
adjoining subdivisions or portions thereof shall be identified by lot number,
tract name, and place of record, or by section, township, and range, or by
other proper designation. (Ord. 39 §6.7, 1965)
16.20.080: ESTABLISHED LINE DESIGNATION:
Wherever the county surveyor has established the centerline of a street or
alley, that data shall be shown on the final map, indicating all monuments
found and making proper references to maps bearing records of surveys of the
monuments. The map shall show all city boundaries crossing or adjoining the
subdivision clearly designated and tied in. (Ord. 39 §6.8, 1965)
16.20.090: PREPARATION TO CONFORM TO STATE LAW:
The final map or record of survey map shall be prepared and submitted in
accordance with all the provisions of Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 39 §7.1,
1965)
16.20.100: SUBMISSION TO COUNTY PLANNING COMMISSION:
The final map or record of survey map, together with all certificates as
required by law, shall be prepared and submitted in five (5) copies to the
county planning commission for its approval, conditional approval, or
disapproval at its next regularly scheduled meeting. The county planning
commission shall then submit the final map or record of survey map, together
with its report, to the clerk of the board of county commissioners in four (4)
copies (1 each for the board of county commissioners, road commissioner,
assessor and recorder). (Ord. 435, 2009: Ord. 39 §7.2, 1965)
16.20.110: FILING OF IMPROVEMENT PLANS:
The subdivider shall file with the county surveyor or road commissioner,
complete plans covering the improvements of streets, alleys, curb and gutters,
sidewalks, proposals for surface drainage, culinary water supply and sewage
disposal including water and sewer mains, hydrants, etc., and such other plans
as may be required together with a detailed estimate of the cost of such
improvements. (Ord. 52 §3, 1970: Ord. 39 §7.2(a), 1965)
16.20.120: APPROVAL BY BOARD OF COUNTY COMMISSIONERS:
The board of county commissioners shall at its next meeting, or within a period
of not more than thirty (30) days after the filing, approve the map if it
conforms to all legal requirements; and the board of county commissioners
shall, at that time also, accept or reject any or all offers of dedication, and
may, as a condition to acceptance of any streets or easements, require that the
subdivider, at his option, either improve or agree to improve the streets or
easements. The board of county commissioners may also require as a condition
precedent to the approval of any final map, that any or all of the parcels of
land shown thereon and intended for any public use shall be offered for
dedication for public use, except those parcels, other than streets, intended
for the exclusive use of the lot owners in the subdivision, their licensees,
visitors, tenants and servants. (Ord. 39 §7.3, 1965)
16.20.130: CLERK TO NOTIFY SUBDIVIDER OF BOARD'S ACTION:
The clerk of the board of county commissioners shall notify the subdivider, or
his authorized agent, of the action of the board of county commissioners. (Ord.
39 §7.4, 1965)
16.20.140: FILING FOR RECORDATION:
In the event the final map or record of survey map is approved by the board of
county commissioners, the subdivider, or his authorized agent, may, within a
period of one year, file one copy of the final map or record of survey map with
the recorder for recordation. (Ord. 39 §7.5, 1965)
16.20.150: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED FOR RECORDATION:
No final map of a subdivision as defined in Nevada Revised Statutes shall be
accepted by the county recorder for record unless all provisions of the Nevada
Revised Statutes or this title have been complied with. The county recorder may
have not more than ten (10) days to examine the final map before accepting or
refusing it for recordation. (Ord. 39 §7.6, 1965)
CHAPTER 16.24
DESIGN STANDARDS
SECTION:
16.24.010: Compliance With Chapter Required
16.24.020: Relation Of Blocks And Streets To Topography
16.24.030: Continuation Of Street Centerlines
16.24.040: Street Names
16.24.050: Primary And Secondary Highway Widths
16.24.060: Street And Local Road Widths
16.24.070: Street Grades
16.24.080: Intersections
16.24.090: Dead-End Streets
16.24.100: Reserve Strips
16.24.110: Alleys
16.24.120: Easements
16.24.130: Lots
16.24.010: COMPLIANCE WITH CHAPTER REQUIRED:
No tentative or final subdivision map shall be approved by the board of county
commissioners until and unless the map or maps indicate full compliance with
the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 39 §8.1(part), 1965)
16.24.020: RELATION OF BLOCKS AND STREETS TO TOPOGRAPHY:
Topographic conditions shall determine the general pattern of blocks, and
natural contour shall control the placement and alignment of streets, highways,
and ways. (Ord. 39 §8.1(a), 1965)
16.24.030: CONTINUATION OF STREET CENTERLINES:
The arrangement of streets shall provide for the direct continuation of the
centerline of the principal existing streets or highways adjacent or adjoining
subdivided areas. In general, such streets shall have a width at least as great
as existing streets. (Ord. 39 §8.1(b), 1965)
16.24.040: STREET NAMES:
Streets that are extensions of or obviously in alignment with existing named
streets shall bear the names of the existing streets. The names of new streets
shall be subject to the approval of the board of county commissioners and shall
not duplicate existing street names, except as provided above. (Ord. 39 §8.1
(c), 1965)
16.24.050: PRIMARY AND SECONDARY HIGHWAY WIDTHS:
The width of a primary highway shall not be less than eighty feet (80'), and
width of a secondary highway shall not be less than sixty feet (60'). (Ord. 39
§8.1(d), 1965)
16.24.060: STREET AND LOCAL ROAD WIDTHS:
The standard width of all streets and local roads, which are not main County
roads, shall be sixty feet (60'), wherever reasonably possible, but the
requirements that a sixty foot (60') right of way be dedicated may be modified
and a lesser or greater width approved under such conditions as the Board of
County Commissioners (BOCC) may prescribe. However, no road shall be accepted
having a width less than forty feet (40') unless otherwise necessitated by road
classification or having given consideration to other factors impacting the
width, Including but not limited to, existing topography, terrain, landscape,
and the primary purpose and use of the road and/or right of way easement. (Ord.
39 §8.1(e), 1965; amd. Ord. 547, 5-28-2025)
16.24.070: STREET GRADES:
Street grades shall not exceed seven percent (7%) unless topographical
conditions make grades in excess of seven percent (7%) necessary. On primary
and secondary highways the maximum grade shall be six percent (6%). (Ord. 39
§8.1(f), 1965)
16.24.080: INTERSECTIONS:
The intersections of streets shall be at an angle of ninety degrees (90°), or
as close to such an angle as is practicable, but in no case shall an
intersection be at an angle less than thirty degrees (30°). (Ord. 39 §8.1(g),
1965)
16.24.090: DEAD-END STREETS:
Where necessary to give access to or permit a satisfactory subdivision of
adjoining land, streets shall run through to the boundary of the property and
the resulting dead-end streets may be approved without a turnaround, provided
they are a minimum of sixty feet (60') in width, but may require, under some
circumstances, a temporary turnaround having a radius of fifty feet (50') or
more; but in all other cases a permanent, dedicated turnaround having a radius
of fifty feet (50') or more shall be provided. (Ord. 39 §8.1(h), 1965; amd.
Ord. 547, 5-28-2025)
16.24.100: RESERVE STRIPS:
Narrow parcels or reserve strips controlling access to streets or highways from
adjoining property will not be approved, unless the control or disposal of such
land is placed under the jurisdiction of the board of county commissioners,
under conditions satisfactory to the board. (Ord. 39 §8.2, 1965)
16.24.110: ALLEYS:
An alley having a minimum width of twenty feet (20') shall be laid out in the
rear of proposed commercial lots. In residential blocks the provision of alleys
is optional with the subdivider, but where they are provided, the minimum width
shall be twenty feet (20'). (Ord. 39 §8.3, 1965)
16.24.120: EASEMENTS:
Where alleys are not provided, public utilities easements not less than five
feet (5') in width, and direct and continuous from block to block, shall be
provided on each side of rear lot lines, and of side lines where necessary.
When an easement on only one side of a lot line is required, it shall have a
width of ten feet (10'). Easements of greater width will be required along
natural watercourses, conforming substantially to the lines of such channel.
(Ord. 39 §8.4, 1965)
16.24.130: LOTS:
The size and shape of lots shall be in conformance to any zoning regulations
effective in the area of the proposed subdivision provided that in areas in
which no zoning regulations are in effect, lots shall not be less than sixty
feet (60') in width nor less than six thousand (6,000) square feet in area, nor
less than eighty feet (80') in depth, provided that for corner lots the width
shall not be less than seventy feet (70').
In no case shall the depth be greater than three (3) times the width of a lot.
Where individual sewage disposal systems are installed, the minimum size shall
be ten thousand (10,000) square feet; where individual sewage disposal and
individual water systems are installed, the minimum size shall be fifteen
thousand (15,000) square feet. The board of county commissioners may recommend
the granting of exceptions to this subsection where lots are to be used for
commercial or industrial purposes or where there are unusual topographic
conditions, curved, or cul-de-sac streets or other special conditions.
   A.   Sidelines: The sidelines of all lots, so far as possible, shall be at
right angles to the street which the lot faces, on radial or approximately
radial if the street is curved.
   B.   Setback Lines: Building setback lines shall be indicated by dotted
lines on the subdivision map, as required by the board of county commissioners.
   C.   Divided Lots: No lot shall be divided by a city boundary line.
   D.   Lot Numbers: Lot numbers shall begin with the number "1" and shall
continue consecutively throughout the block with no omissions or duplications.
   E.   Frontage: Lots without frontage on a public street will not be
permitted.
   F.   More Than One Street: Lots, other than corner lots, may front on more
than one street where in the opinion of the board of county commissioners, such
is necessitated by topographic or other unusual conditions. Where lots front on
more than one street, adequate guarantees shall be made to assure that all
structures constructed on a series of such lots face the same street or road.
   G.   Purpose: All lots shall be suitable for the purpose for which they are
intended to be sold. (Ord. 52 §4, 1970: Ord. 39 §8.5, 1965)
CHAPTER 16.28
SURVEYS AND MONUMENTS
SECTION:
16.28.010: Survey Requirements
16.28.020: Monuments And Bench Marks
16.28.010: SURVEY REQUIREMENTS:
The survey to be used in preparation of the final map shall be made in
accordance with the laws of the state of Nevada regarding surveys and shall be
in accordance with the best professional standards. (Ord. 39 §9.1, 1965)
16.28.020: MONUMENTS AND BENCH MARKS:
   A.   Before a final map shall be accepted, there shall be installed a
monument designating the corner of each lot and block within the subdivision,
with lot and block numbers indicated thereon.
   B.   Permanent monuments shall be set at all angle and curve points on the
exterior boundaries of the subdivision and in any case at intervals of not over
five hundred feet (500'). Such monuments shall also be set at the points of
intersection of street right of way lines or at the beginning or end of curves
on such intersecting right of way lines.
   C.   Permanent elevation bench marks referring to an approved datum may be
required to be set at each street intersection in the curb return or other
location approved by the board of county commissioners; these bench marks shall
be noted on the final map.
   D.   Any monument or bench mark, as required by this title, that is
disturbed or destroyed before acceptance of all improvements shall be replaced
by the subdivider.
   E.   Monuments and bench marks shall be set before acceptance of
improvements by the board of county commissioners, unless exception is
recommended by the county surveyor and approved by the board of county
commissioners. (Ord. 39 §9.2, 1965)
CHAPTER 16.32
IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
16.32.010: Installation; Compliance With Specifications Required
16.32.020: Streets
16.32.030: Curbs And Gutters
16.32.040: Sidewalks
16.32.050: Surface Drainage
16.32.060: Water Supply And Fire Hydrants
16.32.070: Sewage Disposal
16.32.080: Improvement Of Public Ways Required
16.32.090: Agreements To Improve Public Ways; Improvements Specified
16.32.100: Bond Required
16.32.010: INSTALLATION; COMPLIANCE WITH SPECIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
The board of county commissioners shall require the following improvements to
be installed by the subdivider at his cost in accordance with the
specifications approved by the board of county commissioners and prepared by
the county surveyor and road commissioner, the original of which shall be filed
with the county clerk and copies thereof shall be made available to subdividers
at the offices of the county surveyor or road commissioner. (Ord. 52 §5(part),
1970: Ord. 39 §9.3(part), 1965)
16.32.020: STREETS:
All public streets, rights of way and alleys shall be graded and surfaced.
(Ord. 52 §5(part), 1970: Ord. 39 §9.3(a), 1965)
16.32.030: CURBS AND GUTTERS:
Curbs and gutters shall be installed in all public streets where in the opinion
of the board of county commissioners they are necessary to remove surface water
or for safety or other reasons. (Ord. 52 §5(part), 1970: Ord. 39 §9.3(b), 1965)
16.32.040: SIDEWALKS:
Sidewalks shall be installed wherein the opinion of the board of county
commissioners they are necessary for reasons of traffic safety or public
protection and welfare. (Ord. 52 §5(part), 1970: Ord. 39 §9.3(c), 1965)
16.32.050: SURFACE DRAINAGE:
Surface drainage and drainage structures shall be installed when in the opinion
of the board of county commissioners they are necessary to adequately cope with
water runoff needs. (Ord. 52 §5(part), 1970: Ord. 39 §9.3(d), 1965)
16.32.060: WATER SUPPLY AND FIRE HYDRANTS:
   A.   Where a public water supply is reasonably accessible, water mains,
laterals and fire hydrants, etc., shall be installed and connected to the
public water system or a contract made with a local water distributing agency
to make the water supply available to each lot in the subdivision, to install
water lines, fire hydrants and any other required water supply facilities,
sewer lines and facilities and any other subdivision improvements required in
sections
16.32.010 through
16.32.070 of this chapter.
   B.   Where a public water supply is not reasonably accessible or procurable
the subdivider shall either obtain approval for the drilling of individual
wells from the state engineer or install water lines and provide a water supply
from wells or other approved sources in accordance with the requirements of the
state board of health. (Ord. 52 §§5(part), 6, 1970: Ord. 39 §9.3(e), 1965)
16.32.070: SEWAGE DISPOSAL:
Where a public sanitary sewer is reasonably accessible, the subdivider shall
obtain approval for the installation of individual sewage disposal systems on
each of the lots from the state board of health. (Ord. 52 §5(part), 1970: Ord.
39 §9.3(f), 1965)
16.32.080: IMPROVEMENT OF PUBLIC WAYS REQUIRED:
Prior to the approval of any final subdivision map, the subdivider shall
improve or agree to improve the streets, highways, and ways offered for public
use; and no final subdivision map shall be approved and no streets, highways,
or ways shall be accepted for vehicle use until and unless such streets,
highways, and ways have been improved in a manner satisfactory to the board of
county commissioners, or a valid warranty, agreement, or contract guaranteeing
such improvements has been filed with and accepted by the board of county
commissioners. (Ord. 39 §10.1, 1965)
16.32.090: AGREEMENTS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC WAYS; IMPROVEMENTS SPECIFIED:
The subdivider or owner of the land embraced by every subdivision map, and
every map of dedication, shall before presenting any final map to the board of
county commissioners, make, execute, acknowledge, and deliver to the board of
county commissioners, in consideration of the acceptance of dedication, a valid
warranty, agreement, and contract to improve all streets, highways, and ways
offered for public use, designating the same by the name and appropriate
description thereon.
The improvements shall consist of such structures, improvements, and equipment
as may be deemed necessary by the board of county commissioners for the use of
such streets, highways, and ways of the proper drainage thereof, and may
include street grading and drainage, street surfacing, culverts, and bridges.
Actual work thereon shall be commenced not later than ninety (90) days after
the date the subdivision map is recorded, unless such time is extended for good
and sufficient reasons by the board of county commissioners, and all work shall
be fully completed on or before three (3) years after the date of such
recordation. (Ord. 39 §10.2, 1965)
16.32.100: BOND REQUIRED:
There shall be attached to the warranty, agreement, and contract, and
accompanying the same as an integral part thereof, a security for the
performance thereof, which shall be submitted to the board of county
commissioners. Such security or bond shall not be released until the county
surveyor and the road commissioner shall have inspected the work and
improvements required by the warranty and agreement, and shall have filed their
certificate certifying to the satisfactory completion thereof. (Ord. 39 §10.3,
1965)
CHAPTER 16.36
EASEMENTS
SECTION:
16.36.010: Required Prior To Road Construction; Widths
16.36.010: REQUIRED PRIOR TO ROAD CONSTRUCTION; WIDTHS:
No maintenance or construction work shall be performed by the White Pine
County's (County's) road department until such time that the owners of land
adjacent to the street, road or highway on which the work is to be performed,
shall have delivered to the Board of County Commissioners (BOCC) a right of way
easement for the construction of power, water, utility, drainage, sidewalk and
highway purposes, such easement to be in the minimum width of eighty feet (80')
along section lines for a road classified as a main County road, and sixty feet
(60') for quarter section lines, and other locations, or other width unless
otherwise necessitated by road classification or having given consideration to
other factors impacting the width, including but not limited to, existing
topography, terrain, landscape, and the primary purpose and use of the road
and/or right of way easement. (Ord. 39 §11.1, 1965; amd. Ord. 547, 5-28-2025)
CHAPTER 16.60
DIVISION OF LAND INTO LARGE PARCELS
SECTION:
16.60.010: Application Of Chapter
16.60.020: Division Of Land Into Large Parcels; Application Procedure
16.60.030: Public Notice
16.60.040: Planning Commission Action
16.60.050: Waiver Of Requirement To File Tentative Map
16.60.060: Final Land Division Map Procedure
16.60.070: Effect Of Recordation
16.60.010: APPLICATION OF CHAPTER:
   A.   A proposed division of land is subject to the provisions of this
chapter if each proposed lot is at least:
      1.   One sixty-fourth (1/64) of a section, as described by a government
land office survey; or
      2.   Ten (10) acres in area, including roads and easements.
   B.   A proposed division of land into lots or parcels, each of which
contains not less than one section or six hundred forty (640) acres, is not
subject to this chapter. (Ord. 148 §1(part), 1982)
16.60.020: DIVISION OF LAND INTO LARGE PARCELS; APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
   A.   Prior to a proposed division of land as described in section
16.60.010 of this chapter, the owner shall file an application with the
regional planning commission. The application shall:
      1.   Be made on forms available at the office of the regional planning
commission and contain the information required in chapter 16.64 of this title;
      2.   Be submitted to the regional planning commission a minimum of twenty
(20) days prior to the planning commission meeting at which the owner wishes to
be heard;
      3.   Include all contiguous holdings of the owner including land in the
"same ownership", with an indication of the portion which is proposed to be
subdivided;
      4.   Be accompanied by the number of copies of the tentative map as set
by resolution of the board of county commissioners, unless the filing of a
tentative map is waived;
      5.   Be accompanied by a fee as set by resolution of the board of county
commissioners;
      6.   Be accompanied by a certificate from the county treasurer stating
that no taxes and/or assessments are delinquent;
      7.   Such other information necessary for review of the tentative map
that the regional planning commission may regularly require.
   B.   Applications will not be considered complete and will not be set for
hearing until all the information required herein is submitted. (Ord. 148 §1
(part), 1982)
16.60.030: PUBLIC NOTICE:
   A.   The notice of hearing before the regional planning commission, or board
of county commissioners, if deemed necessary by the county commissioners, shall
be advertised at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in White Pine
County, at least one week prior to the date of the hearing.
   B.   Notice of any hearing required in this chapter, shall be mailed to each
property owner owning property abutting the area proposed to be subdivided.
(Ord. 148 §1(part), 1982)
16.60.040: PLANNING COMMISSION ACTION:
   A.   All tentative land division maps must be heard by the regional planning
commission. The planning commission shall, within sixty (60) days after
receiving a tentative map, if required, recommend approval, conditional
approval or disapproval of the map in a written report filed with the board of
county commissioners, unless said time period is extended by mutual consent of
the owner and the regional planning commission.
   B.   The regional planning commission, in reviewing any division application
and map, if required, shall consider the factors enumerated in chapter 16.64 of
this title.
   C.   The regional planning commission may within the sixty (60) day period,
designate the location and width of any easements for roads and public
utilities as shown on the master plan, if there is one applicable to the area
to be divided, or designate the location and width of any easements for roads
and public utilities which may be reasonably necessary to serve the area to be
divided. (Ord. 148 §1(part), 1982)
16.60.050: WAIVER OF REQUIREMENT TO FILE TENTATIVE MAP:
The regional planning commission may waive the requirement of filing the
tentative map in appropriate circumstances. (Ord. 148 §1(part), 1982)
16.60.060: FINAL LAND DIVISION MAP PROCEDURE:
   A.   Filing: After the regional planning commission has approved the
tentative map or waived the requirement of its filing, or after the expiration
of sixty (60) days from the date of its filing, whichever is sooner, the owner
who proposes to divide the land may file a final map of the division with the
board of county commissioners.
   B.   Approval: The board of county commissioners must approve, conditionally
approve or disapprove the map filed, basing its action on the requirements of
Nevada Revised Statutes 278.472 and chapter 16.64 of this title, within forty
five (45) days after its filing.
   C.   Decision Of Board: If the map is disapproved, the board of county
commissioners shall return the map to the owner who proposes to divide the
land, with the reason for its action and a statement of what changes would be
necessary to render the map acceptable. If the board of county commissioners
neither approves nor disapproves the map within forty five (45) days, the map
shall be deemed approved unconditionally.
   D.   Recording The Map: It shall be the responsibility of the owner to file
the original map with the county recorder within thirty (30) days after
approval. Simultaneously with the filing of the map, the owner shall record
such other legal documents as shall be required to be recorded by the county.
   E.   Recording Fee: The county recorder shall charge and collect, for
recording the final map, a fee as set by resolution by the board of county
commissioners. (Ord. 148 §1(part), 1982)
16.60.070: EFFECT OF RECORDATION:
   A.   Recordation of the final map with the county recorder shall operate as
a continuing:
      1.   Offer to dedicate for public roads the areas shown as proposed roads
or easements of access, which the board of county commissioners may accept in
whole or in part at any time or from time to time;
      2.   Offer to grant the easements shown for public utilities, which any
public utility may similarly accept, with the approval of the board of county
commissioners, without excluding any other public utility whose presence is
physically compatible.
   B.   After a map has been filed with the county recorder, any lot shown
thereon may be conveyed by reference to the map, without further description.
(Ord. 148 §1(part), 1982)
CHAPTER 16.64
TENTATIVE MAP OF DIVISION INTO LARGE PARCELS
SECTION:
16.64.010: Tentative Land Division Map; Requirements
16.64.020: Final Land Division Map; Requirements
16.64.010: TENTATIVE LAND DIVISION MAP; REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   This map must be:
      1.   Entitled "tentative map of division into large parcels"; and
      2.   Prepared and certified by a registered land surveyor.
   B.   This map must show:
      1.   The approximate, calculated or actual acreage of each lot and the
total acreage of the land to be divided;
      2.   All roads or easements of access which exist, are proposed in the
applicable master plan, or are proposed by the person who intends to divide the
land;
      3.   Any easements for public utilities which exist or which are
proposed;
      4.   Any existing easements for irrigation or drainage, and any normally
continuously flowing watercourses;
      5.   An indication of any existing road or easement which the owner does
not intend to dedicate;
      6.   The name and address of the owner of the land;
      7.   That each lot is accessible by road or easement traversable by
vehicles suited to the area, unless this requirement is waived by the board of
county commissioners. (Ord. 148 §1(part), 1982)
16.64.020: FINAL LAND DIVISION MAP; REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   This map must be:
      1.   Entitled "map of division into large parcels";
      2.   Filed with the board of county commissioners within one year from
the date that the tentative map was first filed with the regional planning
commission or the date that the requirement of its filing was waived;
      3.   Prepared by a registered land surveyor;
      4.   Based upon an actual survey by the preparer and show the date of
such survey, or based upon the most recent government survey and show the date
of approval of such government survey and contain a certificate by the preparer
that the parcels contain the number of acres shown for each parcel;
      5.   Clearly and legibly drawn in black waterproof india ink upon good
tracing cloth or produced by the use of other materials of a permanent nature
generally used for such purpose in the engineering profession, but affidavits,
certificates and acknowledgments must be legibly stamped or printed upon the
map with opaque ink;
      6.   Twenty four by thirty two inches (24 x 32") in size with the
marginal line drawn completely around each sheet, leaving an entirely blank
margin of one inch (1") at the top, bottom, and right edges, and of two inches
(2") at the left edge along the twenty four inch (24") dimension;
      7.   Of scale large enough to show clearly all details;
      8.   The particular number of the sheet and the total of sheets
comprising the map must be stated on each of the sheets, and its relation to
each adjoining sheet must be clearly shown.
   B.   This map must show and define:
      1.   All subdivision lots by number and actual acreage of each lot;
      2.   All roads or easements of access which exist and which the owner
intends to offer for dedication, all roads or easements of access which are
shown on the applicable master plan, and all roads or easements of access which
are specially required by the regional planning commission or board of county
commissioners;
      3.   Any easements for public utilities which exist or are proposed;
      4.   Any existing easements for irrigation or drainage, and any normally
continuously flowing watercourses.
   C.   The map filed with the county recorder must include:
      1.   A certificate signed and acknowledged by the owner of the land
consenting to the dedication of the roads and granting of the easements;
      2.   A certificate signed by the clerk of the board of county
commissioners that the map was approved, or the affidavit of the owner
presenting the map for filing that the time limited by chapter 16.60 of this
title for action by the board of county commissioners has expired;
      3.   Proof of security for the completion of any road or other
improvement required by the regional planning commission or the board of county
commissioners. (Ord. 148 §1, 1982)
CHAPTER 16.68
PROCEDURE FOR SECOND OR SUBSEQUENT PARCEL MAPS
SECTION:
Article I. Scope
16.68.010: Applicability
16.68.020: Compliance Required
16.68.030: Division Of Land For Which Parcel Map Previously Approved
Article II. Application, Tentative Parcel Map
16.68.040: Tentative Parcel Map Application
16.68.050: Tentative Map, Form And Content
Article III. Tentative Parcel Map; Area, Dimensions, Frontage, Improvements
16.68.060: Area, Dimensions, And Frontage
16.68.070: Easements And Roads
16.68.080: Petition For Exceptions
Article IV. Criteria For Approval
16.68.090: Principles Of Approval
16.68.100: Tentative Map, Criteria For Approval
Article V. Procedure For Approval
16.68.110: Regional Planning Commission Review
16.68.120: Technical Corrections
Article VI. Subsequent Parcel Maps
16.68.130: Regional Planning Commission Certification
Article VII. Appeal
16.68.140: Procedure
ARTICLE I. SCOPE
16.68.010: APPLICABILITY:
This chapter applies to any second or subsequent division of a parcel of land
that may be used for residential, commercial, or industrial purposes into four
(4) or fewer parcels of land. This chapter does not apply to the division of
land which is a subsequent parcel exempted by title 22, chapter 278, Nevada
Revised Statutes. (Ord. 410 §2, 2008)
16.68.020: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
No division of land into four (4) or fewer parcels will be made except in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter and per Nevada Revised Statutes
278.461 through 278.469 inclusive. (Ord. 410 §2, 2008)
16.68.030: DIVISION OF LAND FOR WHICH PARCEL MAP PREVIOUSLY APPROVED:
Any person desiring to divide land for which a parcel map has been previously
approved within five (5) years of the application shall: a) submit to the
regional planning commission an application for approval of the land division
as provided in section
16.68.040 of this chapter, b) submit to the regional planning commission a
tentative parcel map of the proposed division as provided in Nevada Revised
Statutes 278.461 through 278.469 inclusive, together with as many copies and in
the format as may be required by the governing body. (Ord. 410 §2, 2008)
ARTICLE II. APPLICATION, TENTATIVE PARCEL MAP
16.68.040: TENTATIVE PARCEL MAP APPLICATION:
   A.   Application Form: Application for approval of a tentative parcel map
will be made upon the form provided by the regional planning commission. The
application shall:
      1.   Be made on forms available at the office of the regional planning
commission and contain the information required in section
16.68.050 of this chapter;
      2.   Be submitted to the regional planning commission a minimum of ten
(10) days prior to the planning commission meeting at which the owner wishes to
be heard;
      3.   Include all contiguous holdings of the owner including land in the
"same ownership", with an indication of the portion which is proposed to be
divided;
      4.   Be accompanied by the number of copies of the tentative parcel map
as set by the board of county commissioners, unless the filing of a tentative
parcel map is waived;
      5.   Be accompanied by a fee as set by the board of county commissioners;
      6.   Be accompanied by a certificate from the county treasurer stating
that no taxes and/or assessments are delinquent;
      7.   Include such other information necessary for review of the tentative
parcel map that the regional planning commission may regularly require.
   B.   Complete Applications Required: Applications will not be considered
complete and will not be scheduled for review until all the information
required herein is submitted.
   C.   Tentative Parcel Map: The applicant shall submit the original of the
tentative parcel map prepared in accordance with section
16.68.050 of this chapter and as many copies and in the formats required by the
regional planning commission. (Ord. 410 §3, 2008)
16.68.050: TENTATIVE MAP, FORM AND CONTENT:
The tentative parcel map submitted for a second or subsequent parcel map shall
be legibly drawn on tracing paper suitable for reproduction to a scale and in a
manner to best illustrate the proposed division and shall include the
information required for a tentative map in section
16.16.020 of this title. (Ord. 410 §3, 2008)
ARTICLE III. TENTATIVE PARCEL MAP; AREA, DIMENSIONS, FRONTAGE, IMPROVEMENTS
16.68.060: AREA, DIMENSIONS, AND FRONTAGE:
   A.   All lots on the tentative parcel map shall conform to the following:
      1.   The area and dimensions of parcels resulting from or created by a
division of land will conform to the property development standards of the
zoning district in which the division of land is located. A larger minimum lot
area may be required where necessitated by topographical and geological
considerations.
      2.   All parcels will have frontage on at least public or approved
private road.
      3.   The area, dimensions or frontage of each parcel will be such as to
allow for the future widening, extension, or opening of any street or alley
which may be established by a transportation plan or where the projected
ultimate right of way lines are determinable from existing development.
      4.   The configuration of each lot will be such as to provide for
statutory location criteria. Lots shall conform to the minimum area or
dimensions as determined by Nevada administrative code 444, or 445A where
applicable. (Ord. 410 §4, 2008)
16.68.070: EASEMENTS AND ROADS:
   A.   All ingress, egress, and utility easements to be opened or extended to
serve the parcels that may be necessary for local traffic, drainage, and
sanitary needs shall be shown on the tentative parcel map.
   B.   Ingress and egress easements will comply with the adopted county road
standards. The manner in which the improvements are to be designed and
constructed shall conform to the applicable standards. (Ord. 410 §4, 2008)
16.68.080: PETITION FOR EXCEPTIONS:
A land divider may petition to the regional planning commission and county
commission for modification of requirements and improvement standards set forth
in sections
16.68.060 and
16.68.070 of this chapter. The petition will be filed with the regional
planning commission at the time the subsequent parcel map is filed. (Ord. 410
§4, 2008)
ARTICLE IV. CRITERIA FOR APPROVAL
16.68.090: PRINCIPLES OF APPROVAL:
   A.   The land division is subject to approval based on the following
principles:
      1.   The size and configuration of parcels is such as to encourage the
efficient utilization of land and not to deter or hinder the development of
adjacent parcels present and future.
      2.   Use of existing streets and roads and development of streets and
roads for traffic circulation in the interests of convenience, safety, and
welfare as per Nevada Revised Statutes 278.349. (Ord. 410 §5, 2008)
16.68.100: TENTATIVE MAP, CRITERIA FOR APPROVAL:
   A.   A tentative parcel map will be approved when it is found that all of
the following conditions exist:
      1.   All parcels to be created by the proposed division meet the design
and size requirements of the zoning district.
      2.   All easements required have been or will be offered to the county.
      3.   The proposed division will not be in violation of any other law or
ordinance.
      4.   In cases where exceptions or modifications of certain requirements
have been granted by the board of county commissioners or where a variance from
criteria requirements of this code has been granted, the map shall be in
accordance with such exceptions, modifications, and/or variance and the
conditions attached thereto.
   B.   A tentative parcel map will be conditionally approved when it is found
that all of the previous conditions will be satisfied prior to the recording of
the final parcel map. (Ord. 410 §5, 2008)
ARTICLE V. PROCEDURE FOR APPROVAL
16.68.110: REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION REVIEW:
Within sixty (60) days of delivery of payment of appropriate fees, the regional
planning commission will review the tentative parcel map and supporting
materials in an open public meeting and will forward its decision to the owner
and board of county commissioners to approve, conditionally approve, or
disapprove the map unless the time is extended by agreement with the applicant
per Nevada Revised Statutes 278.330. If conditionally approved or disapproved,
the report shall state the conditions under which the map would have been
approved. (Ord. 410 §6, 2008)
16.68.120: TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS:
Technical corrections to the tentative parcel map may be accepted when the
subsequent parcel map is filed. Technical corrections will not be accepted on
the map if they increase the number of parcels or increase the total acreage of
the parcels. (Ord. 410 §6, 2008)
ARTICLE VI. SUBSEQUENT PARCEL MAPS
16.68.130: REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION CERTIFICATION:
No subsequent parcel map may be considered for final approval unless the
regional planning commission has certified that it is substantially the same as
the approved tentative parcel map and has been signed by the chairman of the
regional planning commission. Upon final approval of the map, it will be
recorded with the county recorder. (Ord. 410 §7, 2008)
ARTICLE VII. APPEAL
16.68.140: PROCEDURE:
If an applicant disagrees with any decision of the regional planning
commission, the applicant has thirty (30) days in which to file an appeal and
any additional information the applicant determines to be relevant to approval
of the tentative parcel map. The county commission will review the request
within forty five (45) days of the appeal and render a decision whether to
uphold or deny the appeal. (Ord. 410 §8, 2008)
TITLE 17
ZONING 1
CHAPTER 17.04
TITLE AND PURPOSE
SECTION:
17.04.010: Short Title
17.04.020: Intent And Purpose
 
Notes
1 1. NRS 278.250, 278.030 - 278.310, 278.090 - 278.130.
17.04.010: SHORT TITLE:
This title shall be known and referred to as the ZONING ORDINANCE OF WHITE PINE
COUNTY, NEVADA. (Ord. 203 §1, 1987)
17.04.020: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
In order to conserve and promote the public health, safety, morals and general
welfare of the inhabitants of the county by lessening congestion in the public
streets and highways; to secure safety from fire, panic and other danger; to
avoid undue concentration of population; to facilitate the adequate provisions
of transportation, water, sewage, schools, parks and other public requirements;
secure the character of districts; conserve the value of buildings and
property; to encourage the most appropriate use of land; and by other means in
accordance with the master plan for land use, there is adopted, established and
revised a zoning ordinance for White Pine County, Nevada. (Ord. 203 §2, 1987)

17.08.010: GENERALLY:
   A.   When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense
include the future; words in the singular number include the plural; and those
in the plural number include the singular. As used in this title, the masculine
includes the feminine. "Maps" means the zoning maps of White Pine County.
"Governing body" means the board of county commissioners. "Regional planning
commission", "planning commission", or "commission" means the planning
commission of White Pine County, state of Nevada. "County" means the county of
White Pine, state of Nevada. The county of White Pine is declared to be the
county planning district, the boundaries of which district shall be the
boundaries of White Pine County, state of Nevada, excluding the area within the
corporate boundaries of the city of Ely.
   B.   Unless the context of the title otherwise requires, the definitions of
words and phrases set out in this chapter shall be used in the interpretation
and construction of this title. (Ord. 435, 2009: Ord. 203 §§6, 32, 1987)
17.08.015: ABUTTING:
"Abutting" means lots having a common boundary line, or existing as contiguous
units, except that where two (2) or more lots adjoin only at a corner or
corners, they shall not be considered as abutting or contiguous unless the
common property line between the two (2) parcels measures not less than eight
feet (8') in a single direction. (Ord. 203 §32(1), 1987)
17.08.020: ACCESS OR ACCESSWAY:
"Access" or "accessway" means the place, means or way by which pedestrians and
vehicles shall have a safe, adequate and usable ingress and egress to a
property or use as required by this chapter. (Ord. 203 §32(2), 1987)
17.08.025: ACCESSORY STRUCTURE OR USE:
"Accessory structure or use" means a structure or use incidental, appropriate,
and subordinate to the main structure or use on the same lot. (Ord. 203 §32(3),
1987)
17.08.030: ADJACENT:
"Adjacent" means near, close; for example, an industrial district across the
street or highway from a residential district shall be considered as
"adjacent". (Ord. 203 §32(4), 1987)
17.08.035: ADJOIN:
"Adjoin" means the same as "abutting". (Ord. 203 §32(5), 1987)
17.08.040: ADOPT:
"Adopt" means the legislative action of governing bodies when passing a law,
ordinance, regulation or policy. (Ord. 203 §32(6), 1987)
17.08.045: ADULT BOOKSTORE:
"Adult bookstore" means an establishment having as a substantial or significant
portion of its stock in trade books, magazines, films for sale or viewing on
premises, by use of motion picture devices or any other coin operated means and
other periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on
matters depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or
specified anatomical areas or an establishment with a segment or section
devoted to the sale or display of such material. (Ord. 203 §32(7), 1987)
17.08.050: ADULT ENTERTAINMENT CABARET:
"Adult entertainment cabaret" means a public or private establishment which is
licensed to serve food and/or alcoholic beverages, which features topless
dancers, strippers, male or female impersonators, or similar entertainers.
(Ord. 203 §32(8), 1987)
17.08.055: ADULT MINI-MOTION PICTURE THEATER:
"Adult mini-motion picture theater" means an enclosed building with a capacity
of less than fifty (50) persons used for presenting material distinguished or
characterized by an emphasis on matters depicting, describing, or relating to
specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by
patrons therein. (Ord. 203 §32(9), 1987)
17.08.060: ADVERTISING:
"Advertising" means any writing, printing, dissemination, painting, display,
emblem, drawing, sign or other device, designed, used or intended to be used to
advertise products, goods, service, or promote the sale of objects, or attract
attention to a place, or lettering for the purpose of making anything known.
   A.   "On premises advertising" means any advertising display strictly
incidental to a lawful use of the premises on which it is located, indicating
the business transacted at, services rendered, goods sold or produced on the
premises, name of the business, name of the person, firm or corporation
occupying the premises.
   B.   "Off premises advertising" means any advertising display indicating the
business transacted, services rendered, goods sold or produced, name of
business, person, firm or corporation which is not available or located on the
same premises as the display. (Ord. 203 §32(10), 1987)
17.08.065: ADVERTISING STRUCTURE:
"Advertising structure" means any notice of advertisement, pictorial or
otherwise, and any structure used as or for the support of any such notice or
advertisement, for the purpose of making anything known about goods, services
or activities not on the same lot as the advertising structure. (Ord. 203 §32
(11), 1987)
17.08.070: AESTHETICS:
"Aesthetics" means any object of zoning, concerned with the beautiful, the
moral, and especially the useful; usually limited to matters affecting the
sense of sight. (Ord. 203 §32(12), 1987)
17.08.073: AGRICULTURAL ACTIVITY:
The term "agricultural activity, operation, or facility, or appurtenances
thereof" shall include, but not be limited to, the cultivation and tillage of
the soil, dairying, the production, cultivation, growing, and harvesting of any
agricultural commodity including timber, viticulture, apiculture, or
horticulture, the raising of livestock, furbearing animals, fish, or poultry,
and any practices performed by a farmer or on a farm as incidental to or in
conjunction with those farming operations, including preparation for market,
delivery to storage or to market, or delivery to carriers for transportation to
market. (Ord. 454, 2014)
17.08.074: AGRICULTURAL PROCESSING ACTIVITY:
"Agricultural processing activity" shall include, but not be limited to, the
operation, facility, or appurtenances thereof for licensed rendering plants and
collection centers, cubing hay and alfalfa, the canning or freezing of
agricultural products, the processing of dairy products, the production and
bottling of beer and wine, the processing of meat and egg products, the drying
of fruits and grains, the packing and cooling of fruits and vegetables, and the
storage or warehousing of any agricultural products and includes processing for
wholesale or retail markets of agricultural products. (Ord. 454, 2014)
17.08.080: AIRPORT/HELIPORT:
"Airport/heliport" means any area of land which is used, or intended for use,
for the landing and takeoff of an aircraft, and any appurtenant areas which are
used, or intended for use, for airport building or other airport facilities or
rights of way, together with all airport buildings and facilities located
thereon (see also definition of "landing strip").
   A.   "Airport approach" means that area of approach and transition surface
areas around airports, where special land use and height regulations are
established.
   B.   "Airport approach zone" means an imaginary surface, beginning at the
end of, and at the same elevation as, the primary surface and extending a
specified horizontal distance along with the extended runway centerline which
is necessary for the safe takeoff and landing of aircraft. Precision approaches
are preserved with a fifty foot (50') horizontal to one foot (1') vertical
approach surface, ten thousand feet (10,000') long, followed by a forty
thousand foot (40,000') long to one (40:1) approach surface. Visual runways
have a five thousand foot (5,000') long (20:1) approach surface.
   C.   "Airport hazard" means any structure, tree, or use of land which
hinders or obstructs the airspace required for the safe operation of aircraft
in or around an airport or land field.
   D.   "Airport reference point" means the highest point of an airport's
usable landing area, measured in feet above mean sea level.
   E.   "Airspace obstructions" means any structure, tree, land mass, smoke or
steam, or use of land which penetrates a primary, transitional, horizontal, or
conical surface of an airport as defined by federal aviation regulations (FAR
part 77).
   F.   "Conical surface zone" means an area extending outward from the
horizontal surface at a ratio of twenty to one (20:1), to a height of three
hundred fifty feet (350') above the airport reference point elevation.
   G.   "Horizontal surface zone" means that flat, disc shaped, imaginary
surface, one hundred fifty feet (150') above the airport reference point
elevation, through which no structures or uses should penetrate and which is
necessary to protect the airspace.
   H.   "Primary surface" means a surface longitudinally centered on a runway.
When the runway has a specially prepared hard surface, the primary surface
extends to two hundred feet (200') beyond each end of that runway, but when the
runway has no specially prepared hard surface or planned hard surface the
primary surface ends at each end of that runway. The width of the primary
surface of a runway will be that width prescribed in part 77 of the federal
aviation administration regulations (FAR), for the most precise approach
existing or planned for either end of that runway. The elevation of any point
of the primary surface is the same as the elevation of the nearest point on the
runway centerline.
   I.   "Runway" means a defined area on an aircraft prepared for landing and/
or takeoff of aircraft along its path.
   J.   "Transitional surface zones" means that area necessary to protect the
airport approach surfaces which extends at a ratio of seven feet (7')
horizontal to one foot (1') vertical, beginning at the sides of and at the same
elevation as the primary and the approach surfaces, and extending to a height
of one hundred fifty feet (150') above the airport reference point elevation,
except where approach surface extended upward and beyond the horizontal
surface. A transitional zone is also established at the same seven to one (7:1)
ratio.
   K.   "Turning zone" means the circular area centered upon an airport
reference point. (Ord. 203 §32(14), 1987)
17.08.085: ALLEY:
See definition of "roads". (Ord. 203 §32(15), 1987)
17.08.090: AMEND:
"Amend" means to change or revise. (Ord. 203 §32(16), 1987)
17.08.095: AMUSEMENT, COMMERCIAL:
"Commercial amusement" means any amusement enterprise in an indoor or outdoor
setting offering entertainment or games of skill to the general public for a
fee or charge; this terms includes, but is not limited to, a golf driving
range, archery range, and miniature golf course, bowling alley, movie theater,
or pool hall. (Ord. 203 §32(17), 1987)
17.08.100: ANCILLARY USES:
"Ancillary uses" means those uses which are secondary and complementary to the
primary uses in an area or district. (Ord. 203 §32(18), 1987)
17.08.105: ANIMAL HOSPITAL:
"Animal hospital" means a place where animals or pets are given medical or
surgical treatment and are cared for during the time of such treatment. Use as
a kennel shall be limited to short time boarding and shall be only incidental
to such hospital use. (Ord. 203 §32(19), 1987)
17.08.110: ANIMAL HUSBANDRY:
"Animal husbandry" means management, breeding, and raising of animals. (Ord.
203 §32(20), 1987)
17.08.115: ANNEXATION CONTRACT:
"Annexation contract" means a binding agreement between a city and county which
requires the parties to accomplish specified tasks prior to and/or after
property identified in the contract is annexed by city action into city
jurisdiction. (Ord. 203 §32(21), 1987)
17.08.120: APARTMENT:
See definition of "residence". (Ord. 203 §32(22), 1987)
17.08.125: APPEAL:
The process for appeal of a planning action depends upon the source of the
action and varies in cost. (Ord. 203 §32(23), 1987)
17.08.130: APPLICANT:
"Applicant" means a person who sponsors, and is responsible for an application.
The applicant is responsible for meeting all conditions on the issuance of the
permit, and otherwise ensuring that all policies and regulations are
implemented in the development. (Ord. 203 §32(24), 1987)
17.08.135: APPLICATION:
"Application" means a statement containing information, maps and reports, for
the purpose of notifying the governing body, referral agencies, and the public
of the applicant's intention to conduct, undertake or use a development. (Ord.
203 §32(25), 1987)
17.08.140: APPROVAL:
In reference to an application, "approval" means a decision indicating that the
development meets all requirements and has received a majority of votes in
support of the development at a public hearing. (Ord. 203 §32(26), 1987)
17.08.145: AREAS OF NATURAL DISASTER AND HAZARDS:
"Areas of natural disaster and hazards" means areas that are subject to natural
events that are known to result in death or endanger the works of man, such as
stream flooding, ocean flooding, groundwater, erosion and disposition,
landslides, earthquakes, weak foundation soils and other hazards unique to
local or regional areas. (Ord. 203 §32(27), 1987)
17.08.150: ASSESSOR:
"Assessor" means the county assessor of White Pine County. (Ord. 203 §32(28),
1987)
17.08.155: AUTOMOBILE REPAIR, MAJOR:
"Major automobile repair" means the general repair, rebuilding or
reconditioning of engines, motor vehicles or trailers; collision service,
including body, frame or fender straightening or repair; overall painting or
paint shop. (Ord. 203 §32(29), 1987)
17.08.160: AUTOMOBILE REPAIR, MINOR:
"Minor automobile repair" means upholstering of, replacement of parts
(including glass) for, and motor service to passenger cars and trucks not
exceeding one and one-half (11/2) tons' capacity, but not including any
operation named under "automobile repair, major", or any other operation
similar thereto. (Ord. 203 §32(30), 1987)
17.08.165: AUTOMOBILE SERVICE STATION:
"Automobile service station" means a building or lot having pumps and storage
tanks where fuels, oils and accessories for motor vehicles are dispensed, sold
or offered for sale at retail only, and where repair service is secondary.
(Ord. 203 §32 (31), 1987)
17.08.170: AUTOMOBILE WRECKING YARD:
"Automobile wrecking yard" means any property where:
   A.   The business of wrecking of motor vehicles or trailers is conducted;
   B.   The storage, sale or disposal of dismantled, partially dismantled, or
wrecked vehicles or their parts is conducted; or
   C.   The open storage of five (5) or more unlicensed motor vehicles not in
running condition from which parts have been removed. (Ord. 203 §32(32), 1987)
17.08.175: BAR, LOUNGE, DRINKING ESTABLISHMENT OR TAVERN:
"Bar", "lounge", "drinking establishment", or "tavern" means an establishment,
the primary activity of which is the sale and consumption on the premises of
beer, wine, or other liquors, and where food service, if any, is secondary to
the sale of beer, wine or other liquors. (Ord. 203 §32(33), 1987)
17.08.180: BASE MAP:
"Base map" means a map showing certain information to which other information
may be added. (Ord. 203 §32(34), 1987)
17.08.185: BASEMENT:
"Basement" means a part of a building below ground level. (Ord. 203 §32(35),
1987)
17.08.190: BATCH PLANT:
"Batch plant" means a plant which measures out the material for batches of
concrete. (Ord. 203 §32(36), 1987)
17.08.195: BILLBOARD:
"Billboard" means the same as "advertising structure". (Ord. 203 §32(37), 1987)
17.08.200: BOARD:
"Board" means the board of county commissioners for White Pine County. (Ord.
203 §32(38), 1987)
17.08.205: BOARDING OR LODGING HOUSE:
"Boarding house" or "lodging house" means a dwelling or part thereof, other
than a hotel or motel or multiple-family dwelling, where lodging with or
without meals is provided for compensation for three (3) or more persons. (Ord.
203 §32(39), 1987)
17.08.210: BONUS:
"Bonus" means a credit given to a development, usually by allowing more
intensive use of the land in return for certain public benefits, such as open
space, special housing, etc. (See also definition of "bonus density".) (Ord.
203 §32(40), 1987)
17.08.215: BONUS DENSITY:
"Bonus density" means an increase in density permitted by the planning
commission or governing body pursuant to the zoning and subdivision
regulations, which is granted in order to promote developments which
incorporate innovative means of providing open space, preserving or enhancing
natural features, providing recreational facilities, enhancing energy
conservation, and providing innovative designs. (See also definition of
"bonus".) (Ord. 203 §32(41), 1987)
17.08.220: BUFFER:
"Buffer" means an area created to separate or protect one type of land use from
another. This could be in the form of a planting screen or another land use.
(Ord. 203 §32(42), 1987)
17.08.225: BUILDABLE LANDS:
"Buildable lands" means lands in urban and urbanizable areas that are suitable,
available and necessary for residential use. (Ord. 203 §32(43), 1937)
17.08.230: BUILDING:
"Building" means any structure built and maintained for the support, shelter or
enclosure of persons, animals, chattels, or property of any kind, fully
enclosed with walls (including windows and doors, but excluding canvas or
fabric) and having a roof (canvas or fabric excluded) and conforming to
applicable legal requirements affecting design and construction. Travel
trailers, with or without wheels, shall not be considered as buildings. (Ord.
203 §32(44), 1987)
17.08.235: BUILDING, AGRICULTURAL:
"Agricultural building" means a structure the use of which shall be primarily
for storage of farm implements, crops, feed, or similar farm products, to
provide shelter for livestock, poultry or fowl. (Ord. 203 §32(45), 1987)
17.08.240: BUILDING HEIGHT:
See definition of "structure height". (Ord. 454, 2014)
17.08.245: BUILDING INSPECTOR:
"Building inspector" means the building inspector of the city of Ely and county
of White Pine, as appropriate. (Ord. 203 §32(47), 1987)
17.08.250: BUILDING LINE:
"Building line" means the building setback line; a line on a plan or map
indicating the limit behind which buildings or structures may be erected. (Ord.
203 §32(48), 1987)
17.08.255: BUILDING LOT:
"Building lot" means a lot occupied or intended to be occupied by a principal
building or a group of such buildings and accessory buildings, together with
such open spaces as are required by this title, and having the required
frontage on a street. (Ord. 203 §32(49), 1987)
17.08.260: BUILDING, MAIN:
"Main building" means a building within which is conducted the principal use
permitted on the lot, as provided by this title. (Ord. 203 §32(50), 1987)
17.08.265: CAFETERIA:
"Cafeteria" means a self-service restaurant. (Ord. 203 §32(51), 1987)
17.08.270: CAMPGROUND, DRY:
"Dry campground" means a camping facility which does not provide water or
septic hookups to each space. (Ord. 203 §32(52), 1987)
17.08.275: CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM:
"Capital improvement program" means a program which provides for coordinated
financing and development of community facilities such as sewer, water, roads,
fire protection, libraries, and other governmental facilities related to the
physical development of the community. The program details planned capital
expenditures over a five (5) or six (6) year period and is one principal means
of implementing the comprehensive plan. (Ord. 203 §32(53), 1987)
17.08.280: CARPORT:
"Carport" means a permanently constructed building with a covered roof and open
sides available for the parking of a motor vehicle. (Ord. 203 §32(54), 1987)
17.08.285: CARETAKER'S QUARTERS:
"Caretaker's quarters" means a dwelling unit for the housing of personnel
required for maintenance or protection of the main use or structure on the
property. (Ord. 203 §32(55), 1987)
17.08.290: CASINO:
"Casino" means any place where gaming is operated or maintained, except that
"casino" shall not be construed to include any place devoted to slot machines.
(Ord. 203 §32(56), 1987)
17.08.295: CEMETERY:
"Cemetery" means any land used or intended to be used for the burial of the
dead and may include columbariums, crematoriums, mausoleums, and mortuaries
when operated in conjunction with and within the boundary of such cemetery.
(Ord. 203 §32(57), 1987)
17.08.300: CHURCH:
"Church" means a structure the primary use of which is for worship by religious
organizations. (Ord. 203 §32(58), 1987)
17.08.305: CITY:
"City" means the city of Ely, Nevada. (Ord. 203 §32(59), 1987)
17.08.310: CITY COUNCIL OR COUNCIL:
"City council" or "council" means the city council of the city of Ely, Nevada.
(Ord. 203 §32(60), 1987)
17.08.315: CLINIC, MEDICAL, DENTAL OR OPTICAL:
"Medical, dental or optical clinic" means a facility for examining, consulting
with and treating patients, including offices, laboratories and outpatient
facilities, but does not include hospital beds for overnight care or treatment
except for emergency or temporary care. (Ord. 203 §32(61), 1987)
17.08.320: CLUB:
"Club" means an association of persons (whether or not incorporated), religious
or otherwise, for a common purpose, but not including groups which are
organized primarily to render a service carried on as a business for profit.
(Ord. 203 §32(62), 1987)
17.08.325: CLUSTER DEVELOPMENT:
See definition of "residential". (Ord. 203 §32(63), 1987)
17.08.330: COMMERCIAL FEEDLOT:
"Commercial feedlot" means a lot or portion of a property where ten (10) or
more livestock are penned and fed for the purpose of preparing them for resale
or slaughter, and in which the land area is incapable of producing sufficient
forage to support the number of animals confined. This definition is intended
to apply only to activities carried on as commercial enterprises, and,
therefore, does not apply to the feeding of animals accessory to a dairy use or
other permitted use, or to the fattening of animals solely for the domestic use
of the property owner, or to the penning and feeding of animals for display or
show. (Ord. 203 §32(64), 1987)
17.08.335: COMMERCIAL POWER GENERATION FACILITY:
"Commercial power generation facility" means an electrical power generation
plant with a nominal electrical generating capacity of more than twenty five
thousand (25,000) kilowatts including, but not limited to, a thermal power
plant, hydro power plant, combustion turbine power plant, geothermal power
plant, or a nuclear installation disposal facility, and any facility handling a
quantity of fissionable materials sufficient to form a critical mass. A
commercial power generation facility includes related or supporting facilities,
including any structure adjacent to and associated with an energy facility,
including associated transmission lines, reservoirs, intake structures, road
and rail access, pipelines, office or industrial structures built in
conjunction with and used as part of the energy facility. A commercial power
generation facility does not include a portable power plant, the principal use
of which is to supply power in emergency or for individual domestic use. (Ord.
203 §32(65), 1987)
17.08.340: COMMON OPEN SPACE:
"Common open space" means an open area within a development, designed and
intended for the use or enjoyment of all residents of the development, or for
the use and enjoyment of the public in general, and can include use of land,
water and complementary structures and improvements. (Ord. 203 §32(66), 1987)
17.08.345: COMMUNITY BUILDING:
"Community building" means a facility owned and operated by a governmental
agency or a nonprofit community organization, provided that the primary purpose
of the facility is for recreation, social welfare, community improvements or
public assembly, and further provided that no permanent commercial eating or
drinking facilities shall be operated on these premises. (Ord. 203 §32(67),
1987)
17.08.350: COMMUNITY SEWAGE SYSTEM:
"Community sewage system" means a subsurface sewage disposal system or sewer
system which will serve more than one lot, parcel, or dwelling unit. (Ord. 203
§32(68), 1987)
17.08.355: COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEM:
"Community water system" means domestic water supply source or distribution
system which serves more than three (3) single residences or other users for
the purpose of supplying water for household uses, but is neither a municipal
water supply system nor a public utility water supply system, as defined by
state law. (Ord. 203 §32(69), 1987)
17.08.360: COMPATIBLE:
"Compatible" means uses which coexist in harmony and do not conflict in regard
to type of use, height of building, or bulk. (Ord. 203 §32(70), 1987)
