CHAPTER 17.65
INDUSTRIAL PARK DISTRICT, I-P-1
SECTION:
17.65.010: Purpose
17.65.020: White Pine County Industrial Park Review Board
17.65.030: Protective Covenants
17.65.040: Application For Use Permit
17.65.050: Marijuana Establishments
17.65.010: PURPOSE:
It shall be the purpose of the Industrial Park District to create areas where
industrial uses can be located together harmoniously in a planned development
setting. These areas shall be characterized by deep setbacks, landscaping, off
street parking and attractive architectural design and development standards
that will enhance and protect the value of the industrial development, create
desirable working conditions, and protect the value of surrounding land use
patterns. (Ord. 251 §1, 1990)
17.65.020: WHITE PINE COUNTY INDUSTRIAL PARK REVIEW BOARD:
Permitted uses, development and construction within the Industrial Park
District are subject to the Industrial Park Review Board and the protective
covenants as recorded in the Office of the County Recorder. (Ord. 251 §1, 1990)
17.65.030: PROTECTIVE COVENANTS:
The protective covenants for permitted uses, development and construction
within the Industrial Park District set forth development standards consistent
with the purpose of this chapter. (Ord. 251 §1, 1990)
17.65.040: APPLICATION FOR USE PERMIT:
No application for a use permit within the Industrial Park District shall be
made to the commission prior to review by the Industrial Park Review Board.
(Ord. 251 §1, 1990)
17.65.050: MARIJUANA ESTABLISHMENTS:
A "marijuana establishment" as defined in WPCC
10.62.010  may operate within the Industrial Park District (L-P-1) but only
according to a special use permit. (Ord. 537, 2024; Ord. 523, 2021; Ord. 487,
2018)
CHAPTER 17.68
AIRPORT ZONES
SECTION:
17.68.010: Height Limits
17.68.020: Use Restrictions
17.68.030: Most Restrictive Limitation Prevails
17.68.040: Airport Master Plan Provisions
17.68.010: HEIGHT LIMITS:
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this title, no structures or natural
growth shall be erected, altered, allowed to grow or maintained in the height
limiting zones hereinafter described to a height in excess of the height
specified therefor or established for such zone or any point therein by an
approved and adopted airport master plan: horizontal surface zone; approach
surface zone; transitional surface zone; conical surface zone; turning zone.
(Ord. 203 §26(part), 1987)
17.68.020: USE RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this title, no use shall be
made of land within any of the districts listed in such a manner as to: create
electrical interference with radio or other electronic communications between
the airport and aircraft; make it difficult for flyers to distinguish between
airport lights and others; result in glare in the eyes of flyers using the
airport; impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport; or otherwise
endanger the landing, taking off or maneuvering of aircraft.
   B.   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this title, no places of public
assembly, including, but without limitation, schools, churches, hospitals,
barracks, multiple dwellings, apartment housing, trailer camps, and theaters,
shall be erected or otherwise located within any of the areas established as an
approach zone by this title for a distance of eleven thousand feet (11,000')
from the end of the runway. (Ord. 203 §26(part), 1987)
17.68.030: MOST RESTRICTIVE LIMITATION PREVAILS:
Where an area is covered by more than one height limitation, the more
restrictive limitation shall prevail. (Ord. 203 §26(part), 1987)
17.68.040: AIRPORT MASTER PLAN PROVISIONS:
Airport height provisions for any airport shall be determined by and based on
an airport master plan for such airport, approved by the proper airport
officials and/or by the civil aeronautics administration. Any such map so
approved at the time of passage hereof shall be deemed to be as much a part of
this title by this reference as if fully described and detailed herein. (Ord.
203 §26, 1987)
CHAPTER 17.72
HOME OCCUPATIONS
SECTION:
17.72.010: Statement Of Intent And Purpose
17.72.020: Activity That Does Not Require A Home Occupation Permit
17.72.030: Activity Deemed A Minor Deviation And Allowed With A Home Occupation
Permit
17.72.040: Business Activity Requiring A Special Use Permit In A Residential
Zone
17.72.050: O-5 Zoning
17.72.060: R-A And R-E Zoning
17.72.070: General Requirements For Home Occupation Permits
17.72.080: Applications
17.72.090: Fees
17.72.100: Correspondence
17.72.110: Letter Of Opinion
17.72.120: Submission Requirements
17.72.130: Review And Approval Or Denial
17.72.140: Findings
17.72.150: Written Notice Of Approval Or Denial
17.72.160: Publication
17.72.170: Appeals
17.72.180: Commencement Of Permit Activity
17.72.190: Permit Expiration; Renewal
17.72.200: Renewal Fee
17.72.210: Renewal Notice
17.72.220: Publication Of Permit Action
17.72.230: Revocation Of A Home Occupation Permit
17.72.240: Complaint
17.72.010: STATEMENT OF INTENT AND PURPOSE:
White Pine County recognizes home occupations can be useful to both the general
community as well as the business owner. It is the intent and purpose of the
minor deviation/home occupation provisions to provide for certain types of
occupational uses within residential districts. Home occupations must have the
following characteristics: a) they are not disruptive to the residential use of
adjacent properties; b) they generate less traffic and noise than typical
commercial or industrial activities; and c) they are compatible in appearance,
operating hours, and other factors with the surrounding neighborhood. Home
occupations may involve service as well as manufacturing, but must be accessory
and subordinate to the residential use of the property. Home occupations are
not intended to create new commercial or industrial areas, but rather to
provide an opportunity to supplement an income, start up a business, or
establish a workplace at home. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.020: ACTIVITY THAT DOES NOT REQUIRE A HOME OCCUPATION PERMIT:
   A.   Activity that would ordinarily be allowed in a residential zone for
personal use and enjoyment and may generate revenue for the resident, that is
occasional, that is not advertised as a business activity, that does not have
the characteristics of a business (contracts for products and services,
business liability insurance, or special permits and licenses), and that has no
impact on the residential neighborhood in excess of normal residential activity
does not require a home occupation permit.
      1.   Examples include: a) periodic baby sitting; b) occasional sale of
animals (based on number and type of animals allowed in residential areas under
provisions of this code); c) periodic sales of products manufactured as a
result of a hobby that is allowed in a residential area (woodworking, sewing,
photography, etc.); d) foster care; e) occasional yard and garage sales; f)
periodic consulting services; g) occasional internet sales and trading
activity; h) in home or off site sales providing delivery and storage of
products does not impair the residential character of the neighborhood; and i)
other activity deemed similar by the commission. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.030: ACTIVITY DEEMED A MINOR DEVIATION AND ALLOWED WITH A HOME OCCUPATION
PERMIT:
   A.   Activity which is carried out on a regular, full time, and year round
basis and has the characteristics of a business (is advertised, involves
contracts for products and services, and may require business liability
insurance or licensing and permits) but falls within the ten percent (10%)
limits of a minor deviation may be conducted with a home occupation permit
authorized without a public hearing. Characteristics of a minor deviation home
occupation include: 1) ongoing business activity that is conducted by the home
owner/renter (with the owner's written permission) and members of the family
residing in the dwelling; 2) activity that does not generate traffic, parking,
or deliveries in excess of normal residential use; 3) activity that is
secondary to the residential use of dwellings, garages, other accessory
buildings, and yard areas; 4) activity that does not require modification of
the property that is inconsistent with the residential character of the
neighborhood; 5) activity that does not generate noise, fumes, vibration,
storage of hazardous or flammable materials, or electrical interference that is
in excess of normal residential use.
      1.   Examples include: sewing and tailoring for clients; photography and
artwork on a contract basis; instrument instruction; tutoring; personal
trainers; housekeeping and janitorial work; landscaping and lawn care services;
childcare which falls under state guidelines for licensed childcare; medical
transcription and billing; secretarial and/or bookkeeping service; home office
facilities for off site business activity including sales, building contractor,
surveying, and over the road trucking; offices for professional services
including attorneys, architects, engineers, accountants, or real estate
brokers, or other home occupation activity deemed similar in nature by the
commission.
      2.   Business activities that are not considered eligible for home
occupation permits include: a) activities that by their nature include
hazardous materials, activity, and outside storage activity that is
incompatible with residential zoning requirements including on site automobile
repair, auto bodywork, auto upholstering, or similar automobile related
activity, munitions manufacturing, and food processing or packaging; b) any
activity that is not allowed within the same structure as a dwelling by state
or federal regulation; and c) any activity that would be in violation of any
portion of this code. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.040: BUSINESS ACTIVITY REQUIRING A SPECIAL USE PERMIT IN A RESIDENTIAL
ZONE:
Any business activity conducted in a residential zone that exceeds the
definition of a minor deviation requires a special use permit. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.050: O-5 ZONING:
Zoning requirements governing production and sale of agricultural, mineral and
nonmineral rock products, forest products, and other natural resource related
products in open range, O-5 zones are included in the zoning use section for O-
5, open range. All other types of home occupation activities conducted in O-5,
open range zones require a home occupation permit. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.060: R-A AND R-E ZONING:
Zoning requirements governing production and sales of agricultural produce in
ranch agricultural (R-A) zones and residential, R-E zones are included in the
zoning use section for ranch agricultural (R-A) and R-E zones. All other types
of home occupation activities conducted in ranch agricultural (R-A) and
residential, R-E zones require a home occupation permit. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.070: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR HOME OCCUPATION PERMITS:
   A.   Nontransferable: Every home occupation permit issued shall be personal
to the permittee and applicable only to the specific use and to the specific
property for which it is issued. Permits for home occupations are not
transferable and do not run with the land.
   B.   Number Of Home Occupation Permits Per Premises: The total number of
home occupation permits per premises is limited to one which shall encompass
all business activities conducted within the property boundary and the
cumulative impact of all business activity conducted on the premises must meet
the criteria of a ten percent (10%) deviation.
   C.   Garages: When located in a garage, the home occupation shall not
permanently eliminate the use of the garage as a parking space for personal
vehicles.
   D.   Outside Storage: There shall be no outside storage of materials, waste,
or merchandise visible from any public right of way.
   E.   Utilities: The use of utilities and community facilities shall be
limited to that normally associated with the use of the property for
residential purposes.
   F.   Residential Character: No dwelling or accessory building shall be built
or altered in such a manner as to change the residential character and
appearance of the premises, or in such a manner as to cause the structure to be
recognized as a place where a nonresidential use is conducted. There shall be
no entrance or exit specifically provided or marked on the dwelling for the
conduct of the home occupation.
   G.   Impact On Surrounding Property: There shall be no home occupation
activities that are objectionable due to glare, dust, fumes, odor, vibration,
smoke, or noise noticeable beyond the property line. No equipment or process
shall be used which creates visual or audible electrical or mechanical
interference in any radio or television receiver or other device outside the
dwelling unit structure or cause fluctuations in the line voltage outside the
dwelling unit structure. Activities conducted or equipment or material used or
stored shall not adversely change the fire safety of the premises.
   H.   Signage: There may be a nonflashing sign not exceeding two (2) square
feet in area indicating name and/or occupation of a person or persons residing
in or legally occupying the premises or indicating a home occupation legally
existing on the premises.
   I.   Advertisement: There must be no public advertising which calls
attention to the fact that the dwelling is being used for business purposes.
Telephone listings, business cards, or any other advertising of the business
shall not include the dwelling address. The name, telephone, and purpose of the
home occupation may be advertised on not more than one vehicle which is
operated by the resident or residents of the dwelling in conjunction with the
business. The home address may appear on letterhead and invoices when the home
address is also the business address.
   J.   Traffic And Parking: The home occupation shall not generate vehicular
traffic measurable in excess of that normally associated with single-family
residential use (average of 10 trips per day per household in medium density
residential neighborhoods). There shall be no more than one vehicle, which
cannot exceed two (2) tons in capacity at the residence specifically associated
with the home occupation. The building and planning department may make
additional requirements for on site parking for clients, customers, or
students.
   K.   Deliveries: Deliveries shall not restrict traffic circulation. Delivery
and pick up of materials to and from the premises by a commercial panel
delivery vehicle is permitted but delivery and pick up of materials by a
semitruck (18 wheels, tandem axles, averaging 20,000 to 24,000 pounds empty,
80,000 pounds loaded) shall be limited to no more than one trip per week and
shall not restrict traffic on residential streets.
   L.   Employees: No on site office staff or business personnel shall be
permitted in any home occupation unless the employees are members of the family
and reside on the premises. Persons engaged in building trades or similar
fields using residential premises as an office for business activities
conducted off the premises, may have employees if they are not employed on the
premises. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.080: APPLICATIONS:
Applications for a home occupation permit are filed with the building and
planning department. Responsibility for review, approval, and enforcement of
home occupation permits is assigned to the building and planning department.
(Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.090: FEES:
Fees for home occupation permit applications, renewals, and appeals are
established by resolution by the county commission and shall cover the costs of
advertisement and, as needed, mailing certified, return receipt notices to the
adjacent property owners. The home occupation permit fee is nonrefundable if
the application is denied or the applicant decides not to proceed with the
activity. The fee is not transferable to the special use permit application fee
if the final determination of the review of a home occupation permit
application is that a special use permit is required. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.100: CORRESPONDENCE:
All correspondence from the building and planning department to an applicant or
potential applicant for a home occupation permit shall be in writing and shall
be sent via certified mail. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.110: LETTER OF OPINION:
In response to an inquiry for a home occupation permit, an information package
explaining the requirements and process for a home occupation permit will be
provided to the potential applicant to assist in determining if they should
proceed with the application for a home occupation permit or if their proposed
activity will require a special use permit. The building and planning
department will conduct an initial review of an inquiry or application for a
home occupation permit, and issue a letter of opinion that a home occupation
permit is not required, a home occupation permit is required, or that a special
use permit will be needed within ten (10) business days of the inquiry. (Ord.
448, 2013)
17.72.120: SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   The applicant for a home occupation permit must submit:
      1.   Application And Checklist: A completed application form and home
occupation compliance checklist.
      2.   Parcel Map: A copy of the assessor's parcel map of the property
showing the size, configuration of the plot, the affected properties, and the
property ownership of the affected properties.
      3.   Support From Affected Properties: Per Nevada Revised Statutes
278.319, a signed statement in support of the proposed use from each of the
owners of the affected properties must accompany the application.
      4.   Statement Indicating Use Is Compliant: A statement signed by the
applicant that the proposed use shall comply with all local, state, and federal
regulations pertinent to the activity pursued and that the applicant
understands that he/she is responsible to contact the building and planning
department, other agencies which may have additional requirements or
limitations regarding the proposed use.
      5.   Rental Property: If the home occupation is to be conducted in a
rental unit, a written statement from the property owner giving permission for
the home occupation shall be provided by the applicant.
      6.   Notarization And Fee: The signed application package must be
notarized and be accompanied with the fee for a home occupation permit
application. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.130: REVIEW AND APPROVAL OR DENIAL:
All home occupation applications are reviewed by the building and planning
department which will make a determination on the application and issue a
written notice of approval or denial no later than thirty (30) days after
receipt of a complete application. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.140: FINDINGS:
Approval is based on the facts found in the application. The building and
planning department will determine if the proposed use meets the criteria of a
minor deviation from the required use of the zone district and that the site is
adequate in size and shape to accommodate the proposed activity, which will be
secondary to the residential use and will not change the residential character
of the premises; that the site for the proposed use is accessible by streets
adequate in width and pavement type to carry the quantity and kind of traffic
generated by the proposed use; and that the proposed use will have no adverse
effect upon affected properties or the permitted use thereof. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.150: WRITTEN NOTICE OF APPROVAL OR DENIAL:
   A.   The building and planning department shall issue a written notice of
approval or denial.
      1.   The notice of approval shall list the findings and any special
conditions placed upon the permit and shall include a statement that the
conditions are deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety, and
general welfare.
      2.   The notice of approval will include a home occupation agreement
listing the requirements and specific terms of the permit. The agreement must
be signed by the permittee and be attested to by the county clerk. A copy of
the permit will be provided to the permittee and the original will be retained
on file at the building and planning department.
      3.   The notice of denial shall list the specific reasons for denial of
the application and if a special use permit is recommended. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.160: PUBLICATION:
All decisions of approval or denial of a home occupation permit application
shall be reported in a legal advertisement in a newspaper of general
circulation in the county twice in two (2) consecutive weeks commencing within
ten (10) days of the date of the written notice of approval or denial. (Ord.
448, 2013)
17.72.170: APPEALS:
   A.   Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 278.3195, the decision to grant or
deny a home occupation permit may be appealed by the applicant or aggrieved
party to the county commission.
      1.   A written appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days after the
final public notification in the "Ely Times".
      2.   The county commission shall schedule a public hearing to consider
the appeal in accordance with section
17.100.010 of this title, procedures for public hearing. The county commission
may decide to affirm, modify, or reverse a decision to approve or deny a home
occupation permit. The decision must be guided by the statement of purpose
underlying the regulation of the improvement of land and must be made within
sixty (60) days of the appeal.
      3.   The fee for an appeal includes the cost of advertising and
notification of affected property owners by certified mail and is the
responsibility of the appellant.
      4.   The decision of the county commission is final for the purpose of
judicial review. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.180: COMMENCEMENT OF PERMIT ACTIVITY:
The activity for which the home occupation permit is granted shall commence
operations within twelve (12) months of the date of final approval unless an
extension request has been granted, or the home occupation permit shall become
null and void. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.190: PERMIT EXPIRATION; RENEWAL:
All home occupation permits expire on the first calendar day of the year and
shall be renewed annually. Notice of renewal will be provided to all home
occupation permit holders no later than November 1 of each calendar year and
all home occupation permits must be renewed by December 1 of the calendar year.
(Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.200: RENEWAL FEE:
All home occupation renewal requests shall be accompanied by a renewal fee and
a signed, notarized statement by the owner that the home occupation activity is
conducted in accordance with the provisions of this code and the conditions of
the home occupation permit. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.210: RENEWAL NOTICE:
The building and planning department will review the applications for renewal.
A notice of approval of the renewal will be provided to the applicant no later
than January 1 of each calendar year. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.220: PUBLICATION OF PERMIT ACTION:
A notice of the home occupation permits that have expired, been renewed, or
been revoked accompanied by a statement that the renewal is based on the
owner's certification that the activity is in conformance with this code and
special conditions of the permit, shall be published in a daily newspaper of
general circulation in the county twice in two (2) consecutive weeks commencing
no later than January 31 of each year. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.230: REVOCATION OF A HOME OCCUPATION PERMIT:
   A.   In the event any or all of the home occupation criteria, terms, or
conditions associated with a specific permit are not adhered to, the home
occupation permit may be subject to possible revocation by the county
commission. If the building and planning department determines that the
activity no longer fits the provisions for a home occupation permit and exceeds
the threshold for a ten percent (10%) deviation from the land use requirements
in the residential zone, the permittee will be informed in writing and will
have sixty (60) days to work with the building and planning department to
correct the deficiencies. If the deficiencies are satisfactorily addressed, the
building and planning department will provide written certification that the
activity has been revised to meet the home occupation permit criteria.
      1.   If the owner does not respond to the notice of noncompliance, or if
the issues cannot be addressed successfully within the sixty (60) day period,
the building and planning department will provide the permittee with a written
notice that a request to consider revocation of the permit will be forwarded to
the county commission to be placed on the next county commission agenda for a
decision.
      2.   The home occupation activity may continue until a final decision is
rendered or the special use permit process is completed. (Ord. 448, 2013)
17.72.240: COMPLAINT:
   A.   A complaint that the home occupation permit activity is not being
operated in compliance with this chapter or the special terms and conditions of
the permit may be filed by an aggrieved party at any time.
      1.   The complaint must be in written form and include a notarized
signature by the complainant.
      2.   Within ten (10) business days of the receipt of a complaint, the
building and planning department will notify the owner in writing and
investigate the complaint.
      3.   Within thirty (30) days of the written notification to the owner,
the building and planning department will issue a written opinion to the owner
and the complainant and will report the action taken in an open public meeting
of the White Pine County board of county commissioners.
         a.   If the building and planning department reports to the county
commission that the activity is appropriate for the home occupation permit, the
complainant may file a written appeal with the board of county commissioners.
            (1)   The county commission will review the appeal and issue a
decision in an open public meeting no later than thirty (30) days from the
receipt of the appeal.
            (2)   If the county commission upholds the building and planning
department's decision, the complainant's final recourse is through court
action.
         b.   If the building and planning department determines that the
activity is not appropriate for the home occupation permit, the process for
revocation of the home occupation permit (section
17.72.230 of this chapter) will be invoked. (Ord. 448, 2013)
CHAPTER 17.76
PARKING AND STORAGE OF AUTOMOBILES
SECTION:
17.76.010: Residential Parking Space Requirements
17.76.020: Nonresidential Parking Space Requirements
17.76.030: Industrial District Parking Requirements
17.76.010: RESIDENTIAL PARKING SPACE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   In any R district there shall be at least one parking space for every
dwelling unit; such space or spaces shall be on the same lot with the structure
which they are intended to serve.
   B.   In any C or M district, when used for dwelling purposes there shall be
one parking space available for each dwelling unit on the same or contiguous
lots. (Ord. 536, 2023: Ord. 203 §20, 1987)
17.76.020: NONRESIDENTIAL PARKING SPACE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   On the same or adjoining premises with any building or structure, there
shall be provided off street parking in accordance with the following
schedules:
      1.   For Churches, Theaters, Auditoriums, And Similar Places Of Assembly:
At least one parking space for every five (5) permanent seats. In cases where
temporary or movable seats are provided for, there shall be one parking space
for every forty (40) square feet of area within the auditorium or meeting hall.
      2.   For Hospitals And Institutions: There shall be at least one parking
space for every two (2) beds provided in the building, or one parking space for
every one thousand (1,000) square feet of total floor space included within the
building, whichever provides the greater number of spaces.
      3.   For Hotels And Clubs: There shall be at least one parking space for
every two (2) guestrooms for the first forty (40) guestrooms, and one space for
every four (4) guestrooms over the initial forty (40).
      4.   Auto Courts And Motels: There shall be one parking space for every
individual sleeping room or living unit.
      5.   For Commercial Districts, Except As Otherwise Provided In This
Section:
         a.   Office Buildings: One space for each five hundred (500) square
feet of gross floor area;
         b.   Medical/Dental Clinics: Three (3) spaces for each doctor's
office, plus one space for each two (2) employees;
         c.   Retail Or Service Establishments, But Not Including Food Markets:
Two (2) spaces for each five hundred (500) square feet of floor area;
         d.   Food Stores Or Markets: One parking space for each two hundred
(200) square feet of floor area. (Ord. 536, 2023: Ord. 203 §20(part), 1987)
17.76.030: INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT PARKING REQUIREMENTS:
There shall be one off street parking space, located within three hundred feet
(300') of the property served for each two (2) permanent employees. In
addition, there shall be at least one parking space for each truck operated by
the concern and one parking space for each salesperson permanently employed.
(Ord. 536, 2023: Ord. 203 §20(part), 1987)
CHAPTER 17.80
LOADING AND UNLOADING SPACES
SECTION:
17.80.010: Loading And Unloading Spaces
17.80.010: LOADING AND UNLOADING SPACES:
   A.   On the premises with every building devoted to retail trade, retail and
wholesale food markets, warehouses, supply houses, wholesale and manufacturing
trade, hospitals, hotels, laundry and dry cleaning establishments, or other
buildings where goods are received or shipped, there shall be provided loading
and unloading space with adequate ingress and egress as follows:
      1.   One loading space of not less than ten feet (10') in width, twenty
five feet (25') in length, and fourteen feet (14') in height;
      2.   The location and width of such points of ingress and egress shall be
submitted to the commission for approval. (Ord. 203 §21, 1987)
CHAPTER 17.84
NONCONFORMING USES
SECTION:
17.84.010: Buildings
17.84.020: Land
17.84.010: BUILDINGS:
   A.   Any uses on the land existing at the time this title is adopted,
whether housed in structures or outside the structures, not agreeing with the
uses permitted therein, are declared to be nonconforming uses. Such uses shall
be permitted to continue except as hereinafter provided:
      1.   Nonconforming buildings may be continued if the building is not
added to or structurally altered.
      2.   Whenever a nonconforming building (including a trailer or mobile
home) is removed from the land for a period of three hundred sixty five (365)
days, any further buildings and uses shall be in conformity with the provisions
of this title.
      3.   Any building occupied by a nonconforming use which is discontinued
for a period of three hundred sixty five (365) days or more shall thereafter be
used in conformity with the provisions of the district in which it is located.
      4.   The provisions of this title shall not prevent the reconstruction,
repairing or rebuilding, and the continuing use of any nonconforming building
or buildings damaged by fire, explosion or act of God or the enemy subsequent
to the effective date hereof, wherein the cost of such reconstruction,
repairing or rebuilding does not exceed fifty percent (50%) of the reasonable
replacement value to the building immediately prior to its damage.
      5.   Any portion of a nonconforming building or use which is altered or
changed to a conforming use may not thereafter be used for a nonconforming use.
      6.   The extension of a nonconforming use to any portion of such
building, which portion was arranged or designed for such nonconforming use at
a time of the passage of this title, shall not be deemed the extension of a
nonconforming use. (Ord. 203 §22, 1987)
17.84.020: LAND:
   A.   The nonconforming use of land where no structures are involved may
continue for a period not to exceed five (5) years after the effective date
hereof, subject to the following conditions:
      1.   No such nonconforming use of land shall be expended or extended in
any way, either on the same or adjoining property.
      2.   Where such nonconforming use or any portion thereof is discontinued
for one hundred eighty (180) days or changed, any future use of the land shall
be conformity with the provisions of this title.
      3.   Any sign, billboard or commercial advertising structure which
lawfully existed and was maintained at the time this title became effective may
be continued, providing no structural alterations are made thereto and that all
such nonconforming signs, billboards or commercial advertising structures shall
have been removed from the district not later than five (5) years from the
effective date hereof. (Ord. 203 §23, 1987)
CHAPTER 17.88
SPECIAL USE PERMITS
SECTION:
17.88.005: urpose/When Required
17.88.010: Criteria For Approval Of A Special Use Permit
17.88.020: Criteria For Denial Of A Special Use Permit Application
17.88.030: Application Procedure
17.88.040: Application Review
17.88.050: Public Hearing
17.88.060: Approval/Approval With Conditions/Denial Of The Application
17.88.070: Appeal
17.88.080: Enforcement
17.88.090: Severability
17.88.005: PURPOSE/WHEN REQUIRED:
   A.   Purpose:
      1.   The purpose of this chapter,
Chapter 17.88 : Special Use Permits, is to provide a method of reviewing
proposed land uses which possess characteristics that require special appraisal
in order to determine if the uses have the potential to adversely affect other
land uses, transportation systems, public facilities in the vicinity, and other
social, economic and public interest considerations, including, but not limited
to increased fire risk, impacts on wildlife and livestock, impacts on property
values, impacts on community character, noise impacts, visual impacts, risk of
loss of wetland:? and/or other wildlife habitat, changes to community
character, public health issues, air quality issues, and the impacts on
existing land uses.
      2.   The Building Official, the Regional Planning Commission, or the
Board of County Commissioners may require conditions of approval necessary to
eliminate or minimize to an acceptable level any potentially adverse effects of
the use.
   B.   When Required: A special use permit is required whenever a proposed
land use possesses the characteristics addressed in White Pine County Code
Section
17.88.005 (A), In the event of a conflict between
Chapter 17.88  of the White Pine County Code and any other provision of the
White Pine County Code addressing permissible land use.
Chapter 17.88  shall prevail as the relevant and binding authority. (Ord. 506,
2020)
17.88.010: CRITERIA FOR APPROVAL OF A SPECIAL USE PERMIT:
   A.   The White Pine County commission may approve an application for a
special use permit under the following conditions:
      1.   The proposed use exceeds a ten percent (10%) deviation from the
requirements of the zoning designation.
      2.   The county commission has determined that the proposed use with the
appropriate restrictions or conditions will not be significantly detrimental to
the public health, safety, or general welfare; will not be injurious to the
property or improvements of adjacent properties; will not be detrimental to the
character of the surrounding area;, or will not be inconsistent with the
general purposes and intent of this title or land use plan. When making its
determination, the county commission may consider whether the proposed land use
possesses any of the characteristics addressed in White Pine County Code
Section 17.88.005(A).
      3.   The White Pine County commission has reviewed the application, the
supplemental information and findings of fact, comments from the public
hearing, the zoning map, and the county's land use plan and has determined that
the proposed use is sufficiently similar in nature to the use in the zoning
designation or surrounding designations or that it is in compliance with the
goals and recommendations for the vicinity identified in the county's land use
plan to allow it to occur within its existing zone if it operates in accordance
with specific conditions identified through the application and review process.
      4.   Issuance of a zone change for the proposed use would constitute
"spot zoning" or the county commission determines that it would be unwise to
allow future development that could involve any or all of the permitted uses of
the new zoning designation. (Ord. 506, 2020; Ord. 447, 2013)
17.88.020: CRITERIA FOR DENIAL OF A SPECIAL USE PERMIT APPLICATION:
   A.   The White Pine County commission may deny an application for a special
use permit under the following conditions:
      1.   The county commission determines that the proposed use, even with
restrictions or conditions, would be significantly detrimental to the public
health, safety, or general welfare injurious to the property or improvements of
adjacent properties; be detrimental to the character of the surrounding area:
or be inconsistent with the_ general purposes and intent of this title or land
use plan.    When making its determination, the county commission may consider
whether the proposed land use possesses any of the characteristics addressed in
White Pine County Code Section 17.88.005(A).
   2.   The county commission determines that the proposed use would create
negative and costly impacts on county services and surrounding property owners.
   3.   The county commission determines that it is consistent with the
county's zoning map and land use plan to consider a zone change application for
this and other similar uses in the vicinity.
   4.   If the project is located on federal or state land, and the
environmental review by state or federal or state land management agencies
concludes that the project may result in significant irretrievable loss of
resources or irreversible negative impacts to the environment, the county
commission may deny the permit. (Ord. 506, 2020; Ord. 452, 2014: Ord. 447,
2013)
17.88.030: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
   A.   Information Package: In response to an inquiry for a special use
permit, the building and planning department will provide an information
package explaining the criteria, general policies, and procedures to the
potential applicant to assist in determining if they should proceed with the
application.
   B.   Letter Of Opinion: If the initial review of an inquiry or application
for a special use permit indicates that no action is needed, a letter of
opinion will be issued by the building and planning department to the potential
applicant within ten (10) business days of the inquiry.
   C.   Application Package: The applicant for a special use permit must
submit:
      1.   A completed application form including a detailed description of the
proposed use.
      2.   A copy of the assessor's parcel map of the property showing the
size, configuration of the plot, the affected properties, and the property
ownership of the affected properties.
      3.   A statement signed by the applicant that the proposed use shall
comply with all local, state, and federal regulations pertinent to the activity
pursued and that the applicant understands that he/she is responsible to
contact the building and planning department, other agencies which may have
additional requirements or limitations regarding the proposed use.
      4.   The application must be accompanied with the assessor's
certification that the applicant is current property owner or a copy of an
accepted offer to purchase contingent on approval of the special use permit.
      5.   The signed application package must be accompanied with the fee for
a special use permit.
      6.   If the project is located on federal or state land, and if any
appropriate documents related to the environmental review by state or federal
land management agencies satisfy the requirements outlined for all or any part
of a special use permit application, those documents may be submitted in lieu
of any of the required documentation.
   D.   Renewable Energy Generation Project: All applications for renewable
energy generation project special use permits shall include the following:
      1.   Project Description: A detailed project description of the proposed
renewable energy generation project including a legal description of the
property on which the project would be located and any existing easements,
including conservation or restrictive use easements, or a preliminary title
report;
      2.   Maps: Maps showing the physical features and land uses of the
project area, both before and after construction of the proposed energy
project. The applicant must include at least one map of the proposed project
site printed on a standard eight and one-half inch by eleven inch (81/2" x 11")
page. The applicant must also include maps, diagrams, or color photographs that
show:
         a.   The project area boundaries;
         b.   The location, height and dimensions of all existing and proposed
structures and fencing including building elevations (in color);
         c.   Existing topography of the site;
         d.   Water bodies, waterways, wetlands and drainage channels;
      3.   Distance Requirements: Applicant must show the location of and
distance to surrounding uses that may be affected by the proposed renewable
energy generation project. Applicant must also show the location and distance
to public or private airports or airstrips. In order to protect existing uses
that are adjacent to the project, the proposed facility must be located a
specified distance from any adjacent properties that may be impacted by noise
or other externalities created by the project. This specified distance will
meet any existing setback requirements or, if there are none, will be
determined by staff, in conjunction with the applicant, and shall be based on
an analysis of the project's externalities together with the nature of the
surrounding uses;
      4.   Requirements From Other Agencies: Applicant must provide a list of
permits, approvals or other actions that the applicant has requested or will
request from other government agencies;
      5.   Transmission: A description of any new transmission or distribution
facilities and/or gen-tie lines that will be built in association with the
project;
      6.   Meteorological Or Wind Testing Towers: Provide locations, site map,
and height of tower;
      7.   Travel Routes And Roads For Existing And Proposed Roads:
         a.   A detailed map showing travel routes and roads to and within the
proposed site(s) and estimates of traffic loads and quantities both during
construction and at build out/operations phase;
         b.   County road department or staff will determine, in consultation
with the applicant, the potential impact and mitigation measures, if any, that
will be required of the applicant. Any mitigation requirements shall be
proportionate to the impact from the proposed project;
         c.   All nonpaved temporary or permanent on site roads and staging
areas shall be constructed to fire apparatus access road and turnaround
specifications and improved pursuant to county standards or specifications of
the Orange Book;
         d.   During site development and construction, the applicant must
regularly water or otherwise mitigate roads and staging areas as necessary to
minimize dust and wind erosion;
      8.   Grading: A technical report showing that construction and operation
of the project including, but not limited to, the development, operation, and
reclamation of all roads, access corridors, foundation pads, equipment storage
and staging areas, and all related facilities, will conform to accepted slope
stability requirements and all Nevada division of environmental protection
(NDEP) best management practices (BMPs);
      9.   Weed Control: A plan for weed control, specifically to hinder the
spread of invasive and nonnative species onto adjacent property. The plan
should account for activities during both construction and operation and may
include mitigation activities such as wash stations for construction vehicles;
      10.   Lighting: A plan showing lighting on and around the project and all
related facilities including, but not limited to:
         a.   Lighting mitigation measures that follow "dark sky" lighting
practices including, but not limited to: all proposed lighting shall be located
to avoid light pollution onto any adjacent lands as viewed from a distance; all
lighting fixtures shall be hooded and shielded, face downward, located within
soffits and directed onto the pertinent site only, and away from adjacent
parcels or areas;
         b.   The lighting plan should indicate the types of lighting and
fixtures, the locations of fixtures, lumens of lighting, and the areas
illuminated by the lighting plan;
         c.   Any required FAA lighting should be consolidated and minimized
wherever possible, so long as it still meets FAA requirements and intent;
      11.   Noise: If applicable, a plan for noise mitigation including
buffering if needed to reduce noise impacts. Generation equipment shall not
emit normal or consistent noise levels in excess of sixty five (65) dBA time
weighted average, as measured at the property line at which the facility is
located or one-half (1/2) mile from the plant, whichever is closer. Adjustments
for ambient noise will be made and irregular, short periods of exceedance will
be tolerated in association with anomalies or maintenance;
      12.   Water: The plan shall indicate the amount, place of origin, and
place of disposal, if any, of all water and effluent that will be used or
reused in connection with construction, management, operation and maintenance
of the renewable energy generation project, including water used for drilling,
including washing facility components, machine components (i.e., blades), and
making concrete for foundation pads and other structures within the facility.
Any plan created or measures put in place to meet regulations pursuant to state
oversight from the Nevada division of environmental protection and/or the state
division of water resources may be submitted to meet the requirements of this
section;
      13.   Drainage And Erosion Control: A drainage and erosion control plan
for construction and operation developed in consultation with White Pine
County. Any plan created or measures put in place to meet regulations pursuant
to state oversight from the Nevada department of environmental protection may
be submitted to meet the requirements of this section;
      14.   Environmental Impacts: Assurance that the proposed project can be
designed, constructed and operated without significant adverse impact to fish,
wildlife and native plant resources, including fish and wildlife habitat,
migratory routes and state or federally listed threatened or endangered fish,
wildlife or plant species;
      15.   Fire And Emergency Protection: A plan developed in consultation
with White Pine County emergency management and fire department, and the Nevada
state fire marshal prior to construction shall address all activities at the
proposed project site from the start of construction through operation, and
shall result in a response plan to address all identified potential fire,
rescue, evacuation and hazardous materials scenarios. Any plan created or
measures put in place to meet regulations pursuant to state oversight from the
Nevada department of environmental protection and/or the state fire marshal may
be submitted to meet the requirements of this section;
      16.   Revegetation Plan: Applicant must provide a revegetation plan for
restoring areas temporarily disturbed during construction;
      17.   Closure, Removal, And Postclosure: If a postclosure plan has been
required by any state or federal entity a copy of said plan shall be provided
to the county. If no state or federal entity has required a postclosure plan,
the applicant will enter into an agreement with White Pine County to develop
and submit said plan for fundamental commitments to site restoration. The
applicant is required to return the subject property to the condition existing
prior to construction and establishment of the renewable energy generation
project. In order to meet this goal the postclosure plan shall include:
         a.   Removal of aboveground and underground equipment structures and
foundations to a depth of at least three feet (3') below grade;
         b.   Restoration of the surface grade and soil and revegetation of
restored soil areas with native seed mixes;
         c.   A schedule for completion of restoration work;
         d.   A detailed cost estimate for site restoration in current year
dollars, including an explanation of the basis for cost estimates and
assumptions;
      18.   Bond For Assurance Of Postclosure Remediation: Unless required by a
state or federal entity, the county may require the applicant to submit a bond
or letter of credit in a form and amount satisfactory to White Pine County,
assuring the availability of adequate funds to restore the site to a useful,
nonhazardous condition, if the operator fails or is otherwise unable to restore
the site as required by the permit.
         a.   The amount of the bond or letter of credit shall be adjusted for
inflation using the U.S. gross domestic product implicit price deflator;
         b.   The applicant shall increase the amount of the bond or letter of
credit annually by the percentage increase in the index and shall prorate the
amount within the year to the date of retirement. If at any time the index is
no longer published, White Pine County shall select a comparable index for
adjusting the amount;
         c.   The certificate holder shall describe the status of the bond or
letter of credit in an annual report submitted to White Pine County;
         d.   The bond or letter of credit shall not be subject to revocation
or reduction before retirement of the energy project site;
      19.   Bond For Assurance Of Remediation Of Impacts To County Roads: The
county may require a separate bond to support necessary maintenance and repair
on county roads if not completed by the applicant.
      20.   Application And Requirements: All of the requirements for review,
evaluation, and decision to approve, deny, or approve a special use permit with
special conditions pursuant to this chapter shall be met. (Ord. 452, 2014: Ord.
447, 2013)
17.88.040: APPLICATION REVIEW:
   A.   The building and planning department will review the application
package and provide the applicant with a dated and written determination that
the application is complete or a list of the required information and/or
documentation needed within ten (10) business days of receipt of the package.
Once the additional information and/or documentation is provided, the building
and planning department will provide the applicant with a dated and written
notice that the package is complete.
   B.   The building and planning department will determine the property owners
within three hundred feet (300') of the applicant property boundaries and will
notify the applicant of the number of notifications to be sent and the cost.
The applicant must provide the advertising and notification fee before the
application process can proceed.
   C.   Upon receipt of the advertising and notification fees, the building and
planning department will schedule a public hearing on the county commission
agenda not more than sixty five (65) days from the date the fees have been
received and will generate both the legal advertisement and the notification of
property owners in compliance with Nevada Revised Statutes 278.260.
   D.   The building and planning department staff will provide copies of the
application to any governmental or other agency when the safeguarding of the
public health, safety, or welfare requires a study of the use requested by the
agency affected. Comments on potential impacts of the proposed use will be
collected to support the findings of fact. This will include, but not be
limited to, the county sheriff's office; county fire department; county
emergency medical services; county road department; county planning commission;
district attorney; utility providers including water, sewer, telephone, cable
TV, and electrical services; and the White Pine County school district. As
needed, the application will be provided to the Nevada department of
transportation, Nevada consumer health protection services, state and federal
land management agencies, and appropriate town councils or town advisory
boards. If the building and planning department determines that the proposed
application is within a wellhead protection district as defined in chapter
17.22 of this title, the application will be provided to the appropriate public
water system operator. One copy of the full application will be provided to the
White Pine County clerk's office for public review.
   E.   The building and planning department will compile the comments received
from governmental agencies, utilities, and if appropriate the town board or
council and public water system operators to develop the findings of fact. The
findings of fact and accompanying documentation will be provided to the White
Pine County commission to be included in the commission meeting packet for
distribution and public review and a copy will be provided to the applicant no
less than five (5) business days before the public hearing. (Ord. 447, 2013)
17.88.050: PUBLIC HEARING:
The county commission will conduct a public hearing in compliance with Nevada
Revised Statutes 278.260 and the Nevada state open meeting law on the
application on the date and at the time listed in the public hearing notice.
(Ord. 447, 2013)
17.88.060: APPROVAL/APPROVAL WITH CONDITIONS/DENIAL OF THE APPLICATION:
   A.   Following the public hearing and review of the findings of fact, the
county commission may vote to approve the special use permit without
conditions, approve it with special conditions, or deny the application.
   B.   Special conditions shall be identified as part of the motion to approve
the application.
   C.   The decision to deny an application will include a list of the specific
reasons for the denial.
   D.   The county commission may ask to postpone a decision on the application
with the concurrence of the applicant to allow time to collect additional
information or negotiate special conditions. If the applicant refuses to accept
a postponement, the commission will vote on whether to approve or deny the
application.
   E.   The decision of the county commission will be made as a resolution
which will include either the conditions for approval or the reasons for
denial.
   F.   The resolution will be recorded with the White Pine County recorder's
office. The original will be kept on file and the applicant will be provided
with a confirmed copy.
   G.   The conditions for approval of a special use permit may include a
development agreement to ensure, protect, and promote the health, safety,
morals, and general welfare of the community. (Ord. 452, 2014: Ord. 447, 2013)
17.88.070: APPEAL:
The decision of the White Pine County commission is a final decision for the
purpose of judicial review. An applicant or other person aggrieved by a
decision of White Pine County commission may appeal that decision to the
district court of White Pine County by filing a petition for judicial review
within twenty five (25) days after the date of filing of notice of the decision
with the clerk or secretary of the governing body, as set forth in Nevada
Revised Statutes 278.0235.
If the applicant appeals the decision of the White Pine County commission
regarding a renewable energy generation project special use permit and desires
further review, the appeal may be submitted to the Nevada state public
utilities commission pursuant to the provisions of Nevada Revised Statutes
278.26506. (Ord. 452, 2014)
17.88.080: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Revocation Of A Special Use Permit:
      1.   In the event any or all of the terms, or conditions associated with
a special use permit are not adhered to, the permit may be subject to
revocation by the county commission. If the building and planning department
determines that the activity no longer fits the provisions outlined in the
resolution approving a special use permit, the permittee will be informed in
writing and will have sixty (60) days to work with the building and planning
department to correct the deficiencies. If the deficiencies are satisfactorily
addressed, the building and planning department will provide written
certification that the activity has been revised to meet the special use permit
criteria.
      2.   If the owner does not respond to the notice of noncompliance, or if
the issues cannot be addressed successfully within the sixty (60) day period,
the building and planning department will provide the permittee with a written
notice that a request to consider revocation of the permit will be forwarded to
the county commission to be placed on the next county commission agenda for a
decision.
      3.   The special use activity may continue until a final decision is
rendered.
   B.   Complaint:
      1.   A complaint that the special use permit is not being conducted in
compliance with the special terms and conditions of the permit may be filed by
an aggrieved party at any time. Upon receipt of a complaint, the building and
planning department will notify the owner and investigate the complaint. If the
activity is deemed appropriate for the terms and conditions of the special use
permit a written response will be provided to the owner and the complainant(s)
and the complainant(s) will be referred to the district attorney's office if
they wish further action. If the building and planning department determines
that the activity is not appropriate, the complaint and results of the
investigation will be forwarded to the district attorney's office for action.
(Ord. 447, 2013)
17.88.090: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this Title or amendments thereto, or the application of
this Title to any person, thing, or circumstance is held to be invalid or
unconstitutional, the remaining provisions of this Title shall continue to be
in full force and effect. (Ord. 506, 2020)
CHAPTER 17.92
BUILDING PERMITS
SECTION:
17.92.010: Building Permits Required
17.92.010: BUILDING PERMITS REQUIRED:
   A.   A building permit shall be required for the erection, construction,
establishment, moving, alteration, enlargement, repair or conversion of any
building or structure and the use of land subject to the following provisions:
      1.   Application for a building permit shall be the responsibility of the
owner of the subject property or his designated contractor or builder and shall
be made on a form furnished by the building inspector and shall, in addition to
any plans for the buildings and structures, be accompanied by a plot plan,
drawn on a scale, which shall show the size and location of the lot and
existing and proposed buildings or structures on the lot, the dimensions of all
yards and open spaces, and such other information as may be necessary.
      2.   The board of county commissioners may designate the local building
official and/or building inspector as its agent to receive and inspect,
consider and approve or disapprove the plans on behalf of such governing body.
      3.   In all cases where a variance or use permit has been authorized, the
building inspector may issue a building permit to allow such building or work
to be done in accordance with the provisions of the variance or use permit,
provided that no permit shall be issued pursuant to any decision until the time
for rehearing or appeal therefrom shall have expired, and then only in the
event that no appeal or application for rehearing shall have been filed within
such time.
      4.   No building permit shall be issued by the building inspector unless
the application for such permit shall conform to all of the applicable
regulations of this title and is to be occupied for a use in conformity with
the provisions of this title. Any permit issued in conflict with the provisions
of this title shall be null and void. (Ord. 435, 2009: Ord. 203 §25, 1987)
CHAPTER 17.96
VARIANCES
SECTION:
17.96.010: Criteria For Approval Of An Application For A Variance
17.96.020: Criteria For Denial Of An Application For A Variance
17.96.030: Application Procedure
17.96.040: Application Review
17.96.050: Public Hearing
17.96.060: Approval/Approval With Conditions/Denial Of The Application
17.96.070: Appeal
17.96.080: Enforcement
17.96.010: CRITERIA FOR APPROVAL OF AN APPLICATION FOR A VARIANCE:
   A.   The White Pine County commission may approve an application for a
variance if the following conditions are met:
      1.   Pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 278.300 a variance may be
issued:
Where by reason of exceptional narrowness, shallowness, or shape of a specific
piece of property at the time of the enactment of the regulation, or by reason
of exceptional topographic conditions or other extraordinary and exceptional
situation or condition of the piece of property, the strict application of any
regulation enacted under NRS 278.010 to 278.630, inclusive, would result in
peculiar and exceptional practical difficulties to, or exceptional and undue
hardships upon, the owner of the property.
   (Ord. 447, 2013)
17.96.020: CRITERIA FOR DENIAL OF AN APPLICATION FOR A VARIANCE:
   A.   An application for a variance may be denied if:
      1.   It does not meet the criteria listed above.
      2.   A review of the application, supporting information, findings of
fact, and public hearing shows that granting the variance would significantly
impair public health, safety, or general welfare, would create hardship for
neighboring property owners, or would result in substantial and costly impacts
to county infrastructure and services. (Ord. 447, 2013)
17.96.030: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
   A.   Information Package: In response to an inquiry for a variance, the
building and planning department will provide an information package explaining
the criteria, general policies, and procedures to the potential applicant to
assist in determining if they should proceed with the application.
   B.   Letter Of Opinion: If the initial review of an inquiry or application
for a variance indicates that no action is needed, a letter of opinion will be
issued by the building and planning department to the potential applicant
within ten (10) business days of the inquiry.
   C.   Application Package: The applicant for a variance must submit:
      1.   A completed application form including a detailed description of the
proposed use or construction activity.
      2.   A copy of the assessor's parcel map of the property showing the
size, configuration of the plot, the affected properties, and the property
ownership of the affected properties.
      3.   A statement signed by the applicant that the proposed use or
construction activity shall comply with all local, state, and federal
regulations pertinent to the activity pursued and that the applicant
understands that he/she is responsible to contact the building and planning
department, other agencies which may have additional requirements or
limitations regarding the proposed use or construction activity.
      4.   The application must be accompanied with the assessor's
certification that the applicant is current property owner or a copy of an
accepted offer to purchase contingent on approval of the variance.
      5.   The signed application package must be accompanied with the fee for
a variance. (Ord. 447, 2013)
17.96.040: APPLICATION REVIEW:
   A.   The building and planning department will review the application
package and provide the applicant with a dated and written determination that
the application is complete or a list of the required information and/or
documentation needed within ten (10) business days of receipt of the package.
Once the additional information and/or documentation is provided, the building
and planning department will provide the applicant with a dated and written
notice that the package is complete.
   B.   The building and planning department will determine the property owners
within three hundred feet (300') of the applicant property boundaries and will
notify the applicant of the number of notifications to be sent and the cost.
The applicant must provide the advertising and notification fee before the
application process can proceed.
   C.   Upon receipt of the advertising and notification fees, the building and
planning department will schedule a public hearing on the county commission
agenda not more than sixty five (65) days from the date the fees have been
received and will generate both the legal advertisement and the notification of
property owners in compliance with Nevada Revised Statutes 278.260.
   D.   The building and planning department staff will provide copies of the
application to any governmental or other agency when the safeguarding of the
public health, safety, or welfare requires a study of the use requested by the
agency affected. Comments on potential impacts of the proposed variance will be
collected to support the findings of fact. This will include, but not be
limited to, the county sheriff's office; county fire department; county
emergency medical services; county road department; county planning commission;
district attorney; utility providers including water, sewer, telephone, cable
TV, and electrical services; and the White Pine County school district. As
needed, the application will be provided to the Nevada department of
transportation, Nevada consumer health protection services, state and federal
land management agencies, and appropriate town councils or town advisory
boards. If the building and planning department determines that the proposed
application is within a wellhead protection district as defined in chapter
17.22 of this title, the application will be provided to the appropriate public
water system operator. One copy of the full application will be provided to the
White Pine County clerk's office for public review.
   E.   The building and planning department will compile the comments received
from governmental agencies, utilities, and if appropriate the town board or
council and public water system operators to develop the findings of fact. The
findings of fact and accompanying documentation will be provided to the White
Pine County commission to be included in the commission meeting packet for
distribution and public review and a copy will be provided to the applicant no
less than five (5) business days before the public hearing. (Ord. 447, 2013)
17.96.050: PUBLIC HEARING:
The county commission will conduct a public hearing in compliance with Nevada
Revised Statutes 278.260 and the Nevada state open meeting law on the
application on the date and at the time listed in the public hearing notice.
(Ord. 447, 2013)
17.96.060: APPROVAL/APPROVAL WITH CONDITIONS/DENIAL OF THE APPLICATION:
   A.   Following the public hearing and review of the findings of fact, the
county commission may vote to approve the variance without conditions, approve
it with special conditions, or deny the application. Special conditions shall
be identified as part of the motion to approve the application.
   B.   The decision to deny an application will include a list of the specific
reasons for the denial.
   C.   The county commission may ask to postpone a decision on the application
with the concurrence of the applicant to allow time to collect additional
information or negotiate special conditions. If the applicant refuses to accept
a postponement, the commission will vote on whether to approve or deny the
application.
   D.   The decision of the county commission will be made as a resolution
which will include either the conditions for approval or the reasons for
denial.
   E.   The resolution will be recorded with the White Pine County recorder's
office. The original will be kept on file and the applicant will be provided
with a confirmed copy. (Ord. 447, 2013)
17.96.070: APPEAL:
The decision of the county commission is final for the purpose of judicial
review. (Ord. 447, 2013)
17.96.080: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Revocation Of A Variance:
      1.   In the event any or all of the terms, or conditions associated with
a variance are not adhered to, the variance may be subject to possible
revocation by the county commission. If the building and planning department
determines that the activity no longer fits the provisions outlined in the
resolution approving a variance, the applicant will be informed in writing and
will have sixty (60) days to work with the building and planning department to
correct the deficiencies. If the deficiencies are satisfactorily addressed, the
building and planning department will provide written certification that the
activity has been revised to meet the variance criteria.
      2.   If the owner does not respond to the notice of noncompliance, or if
the issues cannot be addressed successfully within the sixty (60) day period,
the building and planning department will provide the applicant with a written
notice that a request to consider revocation of the variance will be forwarded
to the county commission to be placed on the next county commission agenda for
a decision.
   B.   Complaint:
      1.   A complaint that the variance is not being conducted in compliance
with the special terms and conditions of the variance may be filed by an
aggrieved party at any time.
      2.   Upon receipt of a complaint, the building and planning department
will notify the owner and investigate the complaint.
      3.   If the activity is deemed appropriate for the terms and conditions
of the variance a written response will be provided to the owner and the
complainant(s) and the complainant(s) will be referred to the district
attorney's office if they wish further action.
      4.   If the building and planning department determines that the activity
is not appropriate, the complaint and results of the investigation will be
forwarded to the district attorney's office for action. (Ord. 447, 2013)
CHAPTER 17.100
PUBLIC HEARING
SECTION:
17.100.010: Public Hearing Notification
17.100.010: PUBLIC HEARING NOTIFICATION:
   A.   Upon receipt by the commission of an application for which a public
hearing is required, a time and place shall be set therefor and at least
fifteen (15) days' notice given. Such hearing shall be held no later than sixty
(60) days following the date of filing of such application or following the
referral thereof to the hearing authority. The applicant and each owner of
property not signing the application but within the boundaries of the land
proposed for reclassification or within three hundred feet (300'), or more as
deemed necessary, of the boundaries of the land described in such application
shall be notified of the time and place of the hearing, the description of the
property involved, and the nature of the hearing.
   B.   Notification of a public hearing may be given by any of the following
methods:
      1.   By mailing a notice to each property owner involved, as shown on the
latest assessment rolls of the county or other public records;
      2.   By the posting of a written notice, posted conspicuously at a
minimum of two (2) places within the affected area;
      3.   By publishing a legal notice in a daily paper of general circulation
in the county. (Ord. 203 §28, 1987)
CHAPTER 17.104
ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
17.104.010: Legal Procedure, Enforcement And Penalties
17.104.010: LEGAL PROCEDURE, ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
   A.   It is the duty of the building inspector to enforce the provisions of
this title. It is the duty of county officials charged with the issuance of
licenses to enforce the provisions of this title pertaining to the use of land
or buildings for which such license is required by any other ordinance of the
county.
   B.   It is the duty of all county officers charged with the enforcement of
law to enforce this title and all of its provisions.
   C.   Any person, whether acting as principal, agent, employee or otherwise,
violating any provision of this title or of any variance or special permit
granted hereunder, or the owner, general agent, lessee or tenant of a building
or premises where a violation of any provision of this title exists in any
violation, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof
shall be punished by a fine or not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or
by imprisonment in jail for a term not to exceed six (6) months, or by both
such fine and imprisonment. Such person, firm or corporation shall be deemed
guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which
any violation of this title is committed or continued by such person, firm or
corporation and shall be punishable as provided in this chapter.
   D.   Any building or structure hereafter set up, erected, built, moved or
maintained, or by use of property hereafter, contrary to the provisions of this
title, is unlawful and a public nuisance, and the county attorney shall, upon
order of the governing body, immediately commence action for abatement, removal
and enjoinment thereof, in the matter provided by law, and shall take such
other steps and shall apply to such court or course as may have jurisdiction to
grant such relief as will abate or remove such building, structure or use, and
restrain and enjoin any persons from setting up, erecting, building, moving or
maintaining any such building or structure, or using any property contrary to
the provisions of this title.
The issuance or granting of a building permit or approval of plans or
specifications under the authority of the building code shall not be deemed or
construed to be a permit for or an approval of any violation of any of the
provisions of this title or any amendment thereto. (Ord. 203 §30, 1987)
CHAPTER 17.108
ABANDONMENT OF STREETS, ALLEYS OR EASEMENTS
SECTION:
17.108.010: Purpose
17.108.020: Petition For Abandonment
17.108.010: PURPOSE:
It shall be the purpose of this chapter to establish, for the public good, a
procedure for the vacation or abandonment of streets, alleys or easements,
owned or controlled by White Pine County. (Ord. 375 §1, 2002)
17.108.020: PETITION FOR ABANDONMENT:
   A.   Any abutting property owner, or White Pine County, desiring the
vacation or abandonment of any street, alley or easement owned, or controlled
by White Pine County, shall file a petition, in writing, with the planning
commission. Said petition shall be filed no less than twenty one (21) days
prior to the day of the planning commission meeting and shall be accompanied
by: a legal description, prepared and certified by a licensed land surveyor, of
the street, alley or easement, and that portion thereof for which vacation or
abandonment is sought; a map prepared after an accurate survey of the street,
alley or easement, sought to be vacated or abandoned, specifically illustrating
all property boundaries, easements and any other property interest that may be
affected by the proposed vacation or abandonment; the reason(s) why the street,
alley or easement is no longer required for beneficial public use; and, a
filing fee in the amount to be set by the board of county commissioners of
White Pine County, to cover all costs, including, but not limited to,
advertising, postage, and copy costs, and that may be adjusted from time to
time by resolution of the board of county commissioners of White Pine County.
   B.   Upon the filing of a petition, the planning commission shall set the
matter for public hearing.
   C.   Notice of the public hearing shall be published once in a newspaper of
general circulation within the county at least ten (10) days prior to the
hearing. Each owner of property abutting the proposed vacated or abandoned real
property, shall be notified by certified mail at least ten (10) days prior to
the hearing of the scheduled date and time of the hearing.
   D.   Subsequent to the public hearing of the planning commission, the
planning commission shall make a recommendation to the board of county
commissioners of White Pine County, by submitting to the board of county
commissioners the map of the proposed abandonment, certified by the regional
planning commission, and indicating their recommendation to either approve or
deny the abandonment.
   E.   Upon receipt of the resolution from the planning commission, the board
of county commissioners shall set the matter for public hearing. Notice of said
hearing shall be published once in a newspaper of general circulation in White
Pine County, at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing. Each owner of
property abutting the proposed vacated or abandoned real property shall be
notified by certified mail, of the public hearing, at least ten (10) days prior
to the hearing.
   F.   Upon public hearing, if the board of county commissioners is satisfied
that the public will not be materially injured by the proposed vacation or
abandonment, it shall order the street, alley or easement vacated or abandoned.
The order may be made conditional and the order becomes effective only upon the
fulfillment of the conditions prescribed.
   G.   The order, petition, description and map must be recorded in the office
of the White Pine County recorder, as soon as all of the conditions of the
order have been fulfilled.
   H.   Upon recordation, title to the described property or easement reverts
to the abutting property owners in approximate proportion that the property was
dedicated by the abutting property owners or their predecessors in interest.
(Ord. 375 §1, 2002)
CHAPTER 17.112
FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT
